title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Missourians for a Balanced Energy Future (MBEF) (Part 2 of 2) (web)
commentText:
Though I support clean air for Missouri, I cannot support the EPAs proposed Clean Power Plan because it unnecessarily forces Missouri utility customers to pay more for electricity, threatens jobs and creates numerous system reliability risks. It is very important that Missouri address its environmental needs without shifting the financial burden to consumers.
 
A more reasonable approach for Missouri is Ameren Missouri's Transition Plan, which will ultimately meet the EPAs CO2 reduction targets while saving money and protecting jobs. The proposed modifications are Missouris best hope for transitioning to clean, affordable energy systems.
 
I urge you to adopt the Ameren Missouri plan, a sensible approach to protecting jobs and our environment.  

302 people have signed this message (see attached list for names).
docketTitle: Standards of Performance for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Existing Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units

title: Mass Comment Campaign submitted by Santee Cooper customers (web)
commentText:
Santee Cooper submits the attached comments on behalf of 36,133 of its customers.  These comments were sent to Santee Cooper by our customers for inclusion in the above-referenced docket.  The comments state:

Dear EPA: 

In your final CO2 emissions control plan, South Carolina needs equitable treatment for its nuclear units under construction. Our utilities proactively committed to building more clean nuclear power years ago and are now constructing two new nuclear units in our state. As a South Carolinian, I am already paying for the construction of these units. Your goal is a national average 30 percent emissions reduction in CO2 emissions, and so South Carolinians should not have to pay for a 51 percent reduction in our state. Give us credit for early action on nuclear and bring our cost share closer to the national average.

Sincerely,

[Name and Address of Commenter]

We request that these comments be filed and considered individually in the above-referenced docket.
docketTitle: Standards of Performance for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Existing Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Environment America (web)
commentText:
Heat waves, extreme weather, and dangerous sea level rise are bad enough today, but unchecked global warming would make all these things much worse for the world our children will inherit. Thats why its so important that we reduce the pollution thats fueling global warming.

Power plants are the largest single source of carbon pollution in the U.S. By shifting to renewable energy, expanding energy efficiency, and reducing our use of the dirtiest fuels, we can ensure a safer climate for our children.

I support strong limits on carbon pollution from power plants and a transition to a cleaner, greener future.
docketTitle: Standards of Performance for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Existing Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Business for Innovative Climate & Energy Policy (BICEP) et al. (email)
docketTitle: Standards of Performance for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Existing Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Environment America (Web)
commentText:
I urge you to move forward with limits on carbon pollution from existing coal-fired power plants. This pollution is the largest source of global warming pollution in America, and if we don't take action now, it will mean more heat waves, extreme weather, and dangerous sea level rise for future generations.

-Signatories attached
docketTitle: Standards of Performance for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Existing Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC) (web)
commentText:
Attached are five .xlsx files containing the names of 254,009 commenters who signed an identical online petition sponsored by the Natural Resources Defense Council in support of the clean power plan proposed rule (docket number: EPA-HQ-OAR-2013-0602)

The petition language read as follows:

Thank you for proposing this standard to limit carbon pollution from existing power plants. Without these standards in place, polluters will continue to dump an unlimited amount of carbon pollution into our air.

This is a critical part of President Obamas plan to cut carbon pollution coming from power plants each year. With these limits we can avoid some of the worst consequences of climate change.

Carbon pollution fuels climate change, drives extreme weather, threatens communities and cuts too many lives short. I urge you to adopt this critical new standard (Docket EPA-HQ-OAR-2013-0602).

The attached files are:

* NRDC-LCX-EPA-HQ-OAR-2013-0602.xlsx (108,984 records)
* NRDC-DailyKos-EPA-HQ-OAR-2013-0602.xlsx (53,867 records)
* NRDC-Care2-EPA-HQ-OAR-2013-0602.xlsx (10,476 records.  Some people added additional comments when signing our petition.  These additional comments are included in column H)
* NRDC-PermissionData-EPA-HQ-OAR-2013-0602.xlsx (30,063 records)
*  NRDC-Pandora-EPA-HQ-OAR-2013-0602.xlsx (50,619 recordsmost of these records do not include names, but do include zip codes, so please consider them anonymous)

Please contact me if you have any questions about this bulk comment submission.

Liz Langton
Director of Engagement
Natural Resources Defense Council
1152 15th Street NW, Suite 300, Washington, DC 20005
Office: 202-289-2437, Cell: 202-763-1389
llangton@nrdc.org
docketTitle: Standards of Performance for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Existing Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by West Virginia Coal Association (WVCA) (web)
commentText:
December 1, 2014

Ms. Regina A. McCarthy
Administrator 
U.S. Environmental Protection Agency
1200 Pennsylvania Ave. NW
Washington, D.C. 20460
Attn: Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OAR-2013-0602 (70 FR 34829)

Re:	Proposed Standards of Performance for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Existing Stationary Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units

Dear Administrator McCarthy:

	The West Virginia Coal Association submits the attached comments on the federal Environmental Protection Agencys proposed standards for greenhouse gas emissions from existing power plants. 
The West Virginia Coal Association (WVCA) is a non-profit state coal trade association representing the interests of the West Virginia coal industry on policy and regulation issues before various state and federal agencies that regulate coal extraction, processing, transportation and consumption.  WVCAs general members account for 95 percent of the Mountain States underground and surface coal production.  WVCA also represents associate members that supply an array of services to the mining industry in West Virginia.  WVCAs primary goal is to enhance the viability of the West Virginia coal industry by supporting efficient and environmentally responsible coal removal and processing through reasonable, equitable and achievable state and federal policy and regulation.  WVCA is the largest state coal trade association in the nation.

In addition to these comments, the WVCA also adopts the comments filed by the National Mining Association and incorporates them herein by reference.  WVCA has also attached a petition containing signatures of West Virginia residents and those of other states opposing the proposed 111(d) standards 

Respectfully Submitted, 
					


Jason D. Bostic  
Vice-President
docketTitle: Standards of Performance for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Existing Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by NextGen Climate (NGC) (web)
commentText:
NextGen Climate has gathered 42,666 total public comments in support of the EPA's Clean Power Plan proposal for carbon pollution limits from existing power plants (Docket ID EPA-HQ-OAR-2013-0602). These comments are attached in three documents separated based on the text of the letter to which individuals signed. Thank you for considering the overwhelming public input in favor of strong protections from carbon pollution.

********************

NGC Attachment 1 -- The following letter was signed by 28,699 individuals:

"I fully support setting carbon pollution standards for existing power plants. As climate change and the emissions that cause it significantly endanger the country, the EPA is fully justified in creating the first federal limits on this pollution. I recommend that the agency set earlier enforcement dates, create a Federal Implementation Plan for non-complying states, and finalize the strongest possible emission reductions."

********************

NGC Attachment 2 -- The following letter was signed by 13,955 individuals:

"I strongly support your efforts to limit carbon pollution from all power plants."

********************

NGC Attachment 3 -- The following letter was signed by 12 individuals:

"I fully support your decision to limit carbon pollution from existing power plants.   Thanks to these vital safeguards, we can finally end the era of unmitigated carbon dumping that harms the health of our communities and our environment.  These regulations are a critical part of President Obamas plan for the United States to lead the world in the fight to arrest climate change.  I urge you to stand strong in the face of Big Coals disinformation campaign.  The plan you proposed is thorough, flexible and wise, and will help this country transition to an advanced energy economy."
docketTitle: Standards of Performance for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Existing Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsoring organization unknown (web)
commentText:
Environmental Protection Agency
EPA Docket Center (EPA/DC)
Mail code 28221T
Attn: Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OAR-2013-0602
1200 Pennsylvania Ave. NW.
Washington, DC 20460
			
				
ATTN: Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OAR-2013-0602, Carbon Pollution Emission Guidelines for Existing Stationary Sources

Enclosed are 93,104 individual public comments collected by CREDO Action for submission to the Carbon Pollution Emission Guidelines for Existing Stationary Sources docket. Individual comments may differ throughout, although the majority read as follows: 

Thank you for taking the long overdue step of proposing limits on carbon pollution from power-plants. Limiting carbon pollution from power plants is a crucial step to protect our health and safety. Unfortunately, these rules fall far short of what is needed. Much of the 2020 goal of 25% emissions reduction has already been achieved, leaving only an additional 5% to be achieved over 10 long years. EPA should call for more ambitious reductions of at least 40% by 2030, and insure states stick to the schedule by allowing for no extensions on plans for 2020. Global warming represents the largest single threat to our long term health and security, and demands much more aggressive action to protect our nation.

The comments have been split into 31 documents in order to facilitate uploading to the Regulations.gov website.
 
Please contact me if you have any questions about the attached comment submissions.

Sincerely, 

Elijah Zarlin
Campaign Manager, CREDO Action 
ezarlin@credoaction.com 
415-369-2000

title: Mass Comment campaing sponsored by Missourians for a Balanced Energy Future (MBEF) (web)
commentText:
Though I support clean air for Missouri, I cannot support the EPAs proposed Clean Power Plan because it unnecessarily forces Missouri utility customers to pay more for electricity, threatens jobs and creates numerous system reliability risks. It is very important that Missouri address its environmental needs without shifting the financial burden to consumers.
 
A more reasonable approach for Missouri is Ameren Missouri's Transition Plan, which will ultimately meet the EPAs CO2 reduction targets while saving money and protecting jobs. The proposed modifications are Missouris best hope for transitioning to clean, affordable energy systems.
 
I urge you to adopt the Ameren Missouri plan, a sensible approach to protecting jobs and our environment.  

446 people have signed this message (see attached list for names).

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by National Caucus of Environmental Legislators (NCEL) (web)
commentText:
Please see the attached comment letter from 259 state lawmakers. 

V/r

Alex Cornell du Houx
State Rep. Maine (2008-12) 
National Caucus of Environmental Legislators
207 319 4511  
www.ncel.net
@ncelenviro



December 1, 2014

Administrator Gina McCarthy
Environmental Protection Agency
1200 Pennsylvania Avenue, N.W.
Washington, DC  20460

Dear Administrator McCarthy: 

We the undersigned state legislators would like to applaud the Environmental Protection Agency for taking action to reduce the greenhouse gas emissions causing climate change from existing power plants by at least 30 percent nationally from 2005 levels by 2030.

Clean energy is an American success story. Industry data shows it is one of the fastest growing economic sectors in the United States and already employs far more people than the coal industry. In this context, it would be very helpful for EPA to develop and distribute comparative data on the job impact of new technology development and installation versus the potential job impact of reduced use of coal.   

We believe the Clean Power Plan could achieve even more pollution reductions with higher renewable energy and energy efficiency goals for states, and we support EPA moving in that direction.

The four pillar strategy of 1) increasing generation efficiency at existing power plants by 6 percent, 2) dispatching natural gas combined cycle power plants in place of coal, 3) increasing zero-emissions power sources, and 4) relying on end-use, demand response energy efficiency programs, is a solid start to moving our nation away from being dependent on dirty energy sources. 

We appreciate the flexibility the EPA has given the states to adopt emission reduction measures other than those used to set the state targets. In addition, our ability to collaborate and develop plans on a multi-state basis, ability to choose how to meet the goal through whatever collection of measures that reflects our particular circumstances and policy objectives, and support for building on existing reduction programs, provides states the flexibility to effectively meet and hopefully exceed our carbon reduction goals.  

Democrats and Republicans are in rare agreement on the issue. A June 2014 Washington Post-ABC News Poll found 57 percent of Republicans, 76 percent of independents and 79 percent of Democrats support state-level limits on greenhouse gas emissions.

We stand ready to assist your efforts to reduce carbon dioxide pollution to protect our families, communities and nation. 

Sincerely,

(Please see attached signatures)

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Environmental Action (web)
commentText:
Attached you will find the comments of over 29,000 individual members of Environmental Action. Like many of these individuals, Environmental Action was excited to see President Obama call for action to limit - for the first time in US history - global warming pollution form our power sector.

This rule, and the spirit of action it embodies, are a bold and empowering sign of the President's climate leadership.

However, as you will see in many of the comments attached, many of us also feel that the EPA's interpretation of President Obama's call to action does not go far enough. In particular, the draft rules must be amended to set a higher bar for pollution reduction from the states. As drafted, many states would already exceed their targets. And we simply cannot solve climate change without more aggressive action.

Even more concerning, the draft rules use out-dated research and inaccurate assumptions to conclude that natural gas - especially gas derived from hydraulic fracturing, or fracking - is cleaner for our climate than coal. new studies clearly indicate that when the carbon impacts of methane leakage are considered, fracked gas is just as bad for the climate as coal, and can actually be WORSE in the short run. Not to mention that the EPA's own research has show that fracking contaminates groundwater, and contributes to myriad public health concerns from water pollution to increased earthquakes. It is essential, in the words of many of these individual comments - to Un-frack the clean power plan. Substituting one extreme fossil fuel for another is not the plan or action the president called for.

While many of the attached comments repeat ideas, concerns and phrases common to our members, we encourage you to treat each comment in the spirit it was submitted: as an individual perspective on the clean power rule, each action contains it's own subject referencing the correct Docket number. Our choice to compile comments into a series of consolidated documents does not mean you should count all 29,000+ messages attached as one 'comment'. While rule making need not be based on a public vote, each of these citizens wants and deserves to be heard. Please treat their concerns as such.

Again, thank you for this strong step in the right direction to stop global warming. Don't stop here, consider these comments and as you write the final rules, please take the advice of these many thousands of Americans and strengthen them.

Environmental Action
294 Washington St, Ste 500
Boston, MA 02108
P: (617) 747-4404

commentText:
Please support this new rule from the EPA. It's incredibly important to
limit our carbon pollution for the sake of our health, the next
generation's health, and our long-term life on this planet earth.  The
earth and the fragile atmosphere that surrounds it are God's good
creation for the sustenance and enjoyment of all things. Our policies
must protect creation from interests and activities that damage it.
Power plants should not be allowed to release unlimited amounts of
carbon pollution into the air.
We can't sacrifice public health for the sake of cheap energy. It's
time we start seriously investing in renewable, clean energy sources
that will benefit current and future generations.

Thank you!

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by CREDO Action (web)
commentText:
Dear Commissioners,
I am writing to deliver the public comments of 4,010 Americans regarding Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OAR-2011-0660. Collected by Change.org on behalf of CREDO Action, all listed signatories have signed onto the following comment: 

Regulating greenhouse gas pollution from power plants to mitigate the disastrous impacts of climate change is one of the most urgent matters before the EPA.

But the proposed new source rule for greenhouse gas pollution, while symbolically important, falls far short of what is needed. It is clearly weak in many respects including the following:

1) It doesn't change the facts on the ground but merely codifies them -- construction of new coal plants has already been halted by the hard work of community and environmental activists along with the rising cost of coal and low natural gas prices.

2) It contains massive loopholes including the exemption for biomass, the one year grace period for new plants that will be exempt from the rules, and allowing new coal plants to pollute for ten years if they plan to install CCS.

3) The carbon pollution limit for new power plants - 1,000 pounds of CO2 per megawatt hour of energy produced -- is low enough to limit new coal fired power plants, but high enough not to affect natural gas plants.

Don't bow to pressure from climate denying extremists or fossil fuel propagandists who are a literal threat to our future survival. I urge you to strengthen the new source carbon pollution standard and immediately implement a strong rule to limit carbon pollution from existing sources.

No matter how extreme and anti-science the political climate, nothing less than bold action is required to fight climate change, one of the most urgent challenges facing us as a nation and a planet.

If you have any questions, please dont hesitate to contact me.

Sincerely,
Elijah Zarlin
Campaign Manager, CREDO Action
415-369-2000

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by American Lung Association (ALA) (web)
commentText:
For your convenience, I am submitting an electronic version of postcards collected by American Lung Association networks and previously delivered in person to the EPA docket office on June 25, 2012.  I have also included the letter from Paul G. Billings that accompanied the postcards delivered to the EPA Docket Office for more information.

For reference, the 2,589 postcards read as follows:

----------------------

Dear Administrator Jackson: 
RE: Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OAR-2011-0660

I support the Environmental Protection Agencys efforts to clean up power plant carbon pollution because it will protect public health and set the stage for the next generation of Americas power plants to be the cleanest and most modern in the world. 

Scientists warn that the buildup of carbon pollution will create warmer temperatures which could lead to higher smog levels. More smog means more childhood asthma attacks and complications for others with lung disease. Healthy air is important to me. 

Please issue final rules before the end of 2012. 

Thank you.

commentText:
I oppose the EPAs proposed greenhouse gas regulations for new power plants because we need to balance our countrys energy needs with environmental concerns. Its very important that we all have the electricity needed to run our lives and the economy.
 
The potential for these new regulations to dramatically raise energy prices and cost thousands of hard-working American jobs is too great.
 
These new plans to regulate power plants dont work for my family, my community or our nations economy.

6,786 people have signed this message (see attached list for names).

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Earthjustice (web)
commentText:
Earthjustice, a public interest law organization, has been collecting public comments on the proposed Standards of Performance for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from New Stationary Sources (EPA-HQ-OAR-2013-0495-0001). Of the comments we have gathered, 30,373 have not yet been submitted through any of the established methods. These letters are compiled in the attached file. Individuals were able to write their own letters; the default text also is included below for your reference.

Thank you for considering this public input as you determine how best to clean the air and combat climate change.

----------

I strongly support the EPA's effort to limit industrial carbon pollution from new power plants.

These new clean air standards will protect public health, fight climate change and create jobs and innovation in industries crucial to our competitiveness globally. I urge you to strengthen the standard for large natural gas plants and resist pressure from the polluters to weaken your proposed standard for coal plants. It's our obligation to protect our communities, as well as our children and future generations, from the effects of climate change.
docketTitle: Standards of Performance for Greenhouse Gas Emissions for New Stationary Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsoring organization unknown (web)
commentText:
EPA Docket Center
U.S. EPA, Mail Code 2822T 
1200 Pennsylvania Ave. NW. 
Washington, DC 20460 


RE: Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OAR-2013-0495, Performance Standards for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from New Stationary Sources

President Obama and the EPA,

Enclosed are 54.954 individual public comments collected by CREDO Action on the proposed carbon pollution limits for power plants. Individual comments may differ throughout, although the majority read as follows: 

A strong rule to limit carbon pollution from power plants is one of the most important things that the Obama administration can do to fight climate change. With atmospheric CO2 concentration breaching 400 ppm for the first time in recorded human history, we can't afford to wait any longer. We need strong rules to limit carbon pollution -- not only from new, unbuilt power plants but especially from the existing power plants whose pollution is heating up our atmosphere right now. The administration needs to stop dragging its feet and immediately implement the strong rules that we desperately need.

The document has been split into 16 PDFs in order to facilitate uploading onto the Regulations.gov website. 
 
Please contact me if you have any questions about the attached comment submissions.

Sincerely,

Elijah Zarlin
Campaign Manager, CREDO Action 
ezarlin@credoaction.com 
415-369-2000

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by National Wildlife Federation (NWF) Action Fund (web)
commentText:
Dear Environmental Protection Agency,

The National Wildlife Federation Action Fund is submitting the comments below on behalf of the 35,409 people listed in the attached spreadsheet who submitted the following comments in support of limits on carbon pollution from new sources. 

Thank you for proposing limits to industrial carbon pollution from future power plants. I strongly support the Environmental Protection Agency's action on climate change. 

We have an obligation to protect our future generations from climate change by addressing its causes and impacts including carbon pollution from power plants. 

Power plants account for 40% of the carbon pollution in the United States, and while we currently protect public health with limits on arsenic, lead, soot and other pollution from power plants, there are no existing federal limits on carbon pollution.

Please move quickly on finalizing the new carbon pollution standards to ensure no future power plants can dump unlimited amounts of carbon pollution into the air and stick to your commitment to cut the pollution from existing plants that drives climate change.

On behalf of the undersigned 35,409 Americans concerned with the impacts of climate change to the future of our nations wildlife, thank you for your consideration of these comments.

Sincerely,

Jennifer Janssen
Online Campaign Manager
NWF Action Fund
docketTitle: Standards of Performance for Greenhouse Gas Emissions for New Stationary Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by National Wildlife Federation (NWF) (web)
commentText:
Dear Environmental Protection Agency,

We would like to submit comments on behalf of the attached 926 signers who expressed their support of protecting local wildlife in their state from the impacts of climate change. 

The 926 people in the attached list signed a postcard to the EPA expressing:

Climate change is already having terrible consequences for wildlife. We must take immediate and major steps to reduce carbon pollution  the underlying cause of climate change. 

Please use your authority under the Clean Air Act to set strong standards to limit carbon pollution from new and existing power plants in line with your commitment to address climate change.

Thank you for your consideration.

Jennifer Janssen
Online Campaign Manager
National Wildlife Federation
docketTitle: Standards of Performance for Greenhouse Gas Emissions for New Stationary Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by America's Electric Cooperatives (web)
commentText:
From: America's Electric Cooperatives nreca@action.coop
Sent: 5/9/2014
Subject: Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OAR-2013-0495


5/9/2014

The Honorable Gina McCarthy, Administrator
Environmental Protection Agency
1200 Pennsylvania Ave, NW
Washington DC 20460


Dear Administrator McCarthy,

The Administration has repeatedly said that it supports an "all-of-the-above" energy strategy. Electric co-ops have pursued "all-of-the-above" by spending billions on innovative, clean and efficient technologies.

But the EPA's proposal to regulate greenhouse gas emissions at new power plants seems to be an "all-but-one" approach.

I'm a member of my local not-for-profit electric cooperative/PPD and this rule has me really concerned. In uncertain economic times, I urge the Administration to stick by its "all-of-the-above" promise.

Administrator McCarthy, please withdraw this proposal and work with electric cooperatives on a common sense solution that balances energy needs and environmental concerns.

Sincerely,

America's Electric Cooperatives
docketTitle: Standards of Performance for Greenhouse Gas Emissions for New Stationary Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Environment North Carolina (web)
commentText:
The attached 1,707 members and supporters of Environment North Carolina, the statewide, citizen-based environmental advocacy group, have signed on to the following statement in support of rules to limit carbon pollution from new and existing power plants:

"I urge the EPA to move forward with tough limits on carbon pollution from power plants, both new and existing. Doing so will protect our health, our environment, our children and generations to come." 

Thanks to the EPA for its leadership on this critical issue.

Sincerely,

Elizabeth Ouzts
Environment North Carolina State Director

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Sierra Club (web)
commentText:
Re: Docket No. EPA-HQ-OAR2017-0355 regarding Replacement of the Clean Power Plan

I am deeply concerned about the effects of climate change, especially in the wake of extreme weather events that are fueled by a warming world -- stronger hurricanes, unprecedented flooding, and raging wildfires. 

The Clean Power Plan is the most significant federal action to mitigate climate change. We must not change it. If anything, it should be made stronger to even better protect the health of our families and communities. Actions that limit carbon pollution from coal power plants don't just help us fight climate change; they also reduce other harmful emissions that jeopardize human health. The Clean Power Plan would have reduced carbon emissions from the electricity sector by 32 percent, avoided 90,000 asthma attacks per year, and prevented 3,200 premature deaths per year by 2030. 

Dismantling the Clean Power Plan, as you are proposing to do, puts the health and well-being of our communities -- especially communities of color and low-income families that bear the brunt of climate impacts -- further at risk. Millions of Americans count on the government to help protect them from climate change and public health disasters. This is one of those moments: Please do not replace the Clean Power Plan with this unlawful and unacceptable proposal.

Please see the attached 56,749 comments, of which 12,495 people left personal messages.
docketTitle: Repeal of Carbon Dioxide Emission Guidelines for Existing Stationary Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units; Emission Guidelines for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Existing Electric Utility Generating Units; Revisions to Emission Guideline Implementing Regulations; Revisions to New Source Review Program

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC) Action Fund (Web)
commentText: Please accept these 14,236 public comments from online members and activists of the NRDC Action Fund regarding EPA-HQ-OAR-2017-0355-21117, in addition to the previously submitted 16,018 comments EPA-HQ-OAR-2017-0545-0001, in opposition to these efforts to weaken or replace the Clean Power Plan. Keeping the Clean Power Plan in place would provide health protections and economic opportunities in clean energy across the country while the proposed replacement could encourage even more pollution from power plants, and create loopholes for fossil fuel companies and utilities to pollute more. Considering this, the proposed replacement for the Clean Power plan should be rejected. Thank you for your consideration.

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by The Climate Reality Project (web)
commentText:
Dear Acting EPA Administrator Wheeler,

As devastating heat waves, hurricanes, wildfires, and droughts have made the reality of the climate crisis so painfully clear, The Climate Reality Project and our supporters know that its time to promote common sense solutions over the interests of big polluters. The Clean Power Plan was a landmark rule to keep our air clean and fight climate change, but your proposed replacement is bad for our health, our jobs, and the climate. We oppose this attempt to replace the Clean Power Plan with the Affordable Clean Energy Rule,  more accurately called the Dirty Power Scam.  

The Dirty Power Scam puts Big Polluters over people. It allows the fossil fuel industry to keep pumping more and more pollution into our atmosphere, exacerbating the climate crisis and leaving American families to pay the price in premature deaths, asthma, and so much more.  Instead of trying to prop up the struggling coal industry, America should be supporting the clean energy jobs of the future. In fact, there are already 3.2 million clean energy jobs and growing in the US today. The EPA must act to protect the health and economic vitality of America. 

The 13,123 comments attached reflect signatures gathered online from our supporters across the country demanding that the EPA not replace the Clean Power Plan with the Affordable Clean Energy Rule, as stated by this language presented to signees:

"We strongly oppose replacing the Clean Power Plan with the weaker Affordable Clean Energy Rule.

Poll after poll shows that the overwhelming majority of Americans want the government to confront the climate crisis head-on by shifting from dirty fossil fuels to clean, renewable energy. When EPA proposed the Clean Power Plan, over 4.3 million Americans spoke up to support it. 

The message couldnt be any clearer: We want a clean energy economy. 

The Clean Power Plan is an example of the federal government listening to the American people and taking action. By replacing it with this new, weaker rule, we allow carbon pollution and toxic emissions from the power sector to continue driving climate change and causing health issues for the most vulnerable among us. And we compromise the continued growth of the booming clean energy and efficiency industry that already employs 3.2 million Americans  more than oil, coal, and gas combined.

The EPAs mission is to protect human health and the environment  and we need acting Administrator Andrew Wheeler to live up to that solemn responsibility.

A clean energy economy is good for our planet, our families, and our health. We strongly oppose replacing the Clean Power Plan with this weaker rule and call on EPA to act on climate for the sake of all Americans."

The Climate Reality Project and its many supporters demand that the Environmental Protection Agency live up to its mission of protecting our health and our planet by protecting and strengthening the Clean Power Plan, not replacing it with the Dirty Power Scam.  

Sincerely,

Ken Berlin
President and CEO, The Climate Reality Project

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Defend Our Future (web)
commentText:
To Whom It May Concern:

Attached, please find the signatures of 2,315 Defend Our Future supporters from across the country who have submitted comments regarding the Environmental Protection Agency and Department of Transportation's proposed rule, Emission Guidelines for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Existing Electric Utility Generating Units: Emission Guideline Implementing Regulations; New Source Review Program. Please consider each a formal comment in the federal docket regarding Docket Number EPA-HQ-OAR-2017-0355-21117.

The comment they each submitted reads:

As a young American, I am writing today deeply concerned by the EPA's proposal to "replace" the Clean Power Plan. This proposal does not protect American communities from dangerous pollution and greenhouse gas emissions that exacerbate climate change.

Our communities are already facing the impacts of climate change, from near-unstoppable wildfires to extreme flooding to dangerous super-storms. These impacts are only getting worse. And my generation will bear the brunt of the damage.

We deserve a Clean Power Plan that will significantly reduce carbon pollution and pollution that has negative health impacts for American communities. This is no time to move backwards on climate protections. 

This proposal does not go far enough to protect our communities, our health, and our planet.

Please contact me if you have any questions or concerns about this submission.

Thank you for your consideration,

Kyli Wagner
docketTitle: Repeal of Carbon Dioxide Emission Guidelines for Existing Stationary Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units; Emission Guidelines for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Existing Electric Utility Generating Units; Revisions to Emission Guideline Implementing Regulations; Revisions to New Source Review Program

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Environment America (Web)
commentText:
Dear Administrator Wheeler,
 
I write today on behalf of Environment Americas members and supporters across the country who want clean air and a healthy climate. We strongly oppose the administrations attempts to repeal and replace the Clean Power Plan. 
 
The original Clean Power Plan was designed to cut air pollution and help prevent the worsening impacts of climate change. However, the suggested replacement would do just the opposite.
 
If fully implemented, the Clean Power Plan would have eliminated 32 percent of the carbon pollution from the electric power sector by 2030 with huge corresponding health and environmental benefits. Instead, the administration aims to keep dirty coal plants online longer and increase carbon emissions, at a time when scientists are telling us we must reduce this pollution quickly to stave off catastrophic impacts of global warming.
 
Instead of working as hard as we can to reduce carbon pollution from our power plants to prevent even worse impacts, the administrations plan promises to set us back. We expect this plan to flatline or even allow an increase in the burning of dirty, dangerous fossil fuels and stymie the transition of the power sector to clean, renewable energy.
 
Increasing greenhouse gas emissions from the burning of fossil fuels like coal and natural gas will further exacerbate global warming and destabilize the climate. Given the urgency of the climate challenge we need national programs that will accelerate the reduction of carbon emissions. The Clean Power Plan didnt come out of thin air  EPA conducted extensive public outreach and solicited stakeholder feedback from every corner of the country. It is based on a strong legal foundation  consistent with the law, earlier court precedents, and other EPA standards that protect Americans from dangerous pollution. Americans have sent more than 8 million comments to EPA in support of standards limiting carbon pollution from new and existing power plants, the most ever received by the agency. 

By 2030, the Clean Power Plan would prevent as many as 4,500 premature deaths each year, along with 90,000 asthma attacks and 300,000 missed work and school days. Replacing the Clean Power Plan with this weaker version will mean more sick kids, more expensive hospital visits, and thousands of premature deaths that could have been prevented  and could lead to more intense and destructive severe weather events.


Dismantling the Clean Power Plan poses grave risks to citizens and communities across the United States. Ignoring air pollution wont make our country great for kids with asthma or older Americans who struggle to breathe. Ignoring climate change wont make American families safe from storms powered by oceans that are rising and growing warmer or wildfires fueled by hotter temperatures. When it comes to global warming, the EPA needs to accept the science, recognize the reality, and put the health and well being of Americans first. 

Environment Americas recent study, Trouble in the Air, shows that as of 2016, 73 million Americans experienced more than 100 days of degraded air quality in 2016, and the impacts of unhealthy air are being worsened by climate change. To safeguard public health, the nation needs to preserve and strengthen existing air quality protections at the federal and state level and move to reduce the future air pollution threats posed by global warming.

The nations power sector is on track to meet the goals of the Clean Power Plan. In fact, by the end of 2018, emissions are projected to be down by 28%, closing in on the the overall goal of 32% by 2030 earlier than expected. Several states are already cutting power plant pollution by capping emissions through innovative programs like the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative in the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic. But this move will reverse progress on carbon reductions. We need to have the Clean Power Plan as a backstop that guarantees continued progress toward cleaner power plants - progress that is by no means certain without it. A strong Clean Power Plan can also lay the groundwork for the even more dramatic emission reductions that will be needed from the power sector in the years and decades to come.

Environment America is submitting 11,940 comments today in support of a strong Clean Power Plan. We ask that these names be entered into the official record and considered as separate public comments.

No one wants more pollution, more illness, and more deaths from burning dirty fossil fuels, yet that is exactly what well get from this new proposed rule. The EPAs mission is to protect our environment and our health. The administration needs to stop this rollback and get back to work doing just that.

Sincerely,
Andrea McGimsey
Senior Director of Global Warming Solutions
Environment America

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by National Wildlife Federation Action Fund (web)
commentText:
Attached are 29,937 unique, individually submitted comments from National Wildlife Federation Action Fund supporters reflecting the following:

We need swift, responsible action to ensure a safe and stable climate, not the pro-coal plan that you are proposing. The Environmental Protection Agency is charged with protecting human health and the environment, and by law you are obligated to take real steps to cut climate pollution. It is your job to ensure Americans and all wildlife have clean air, land and water. Climate change poses an unprecedented threat to all and requires action to cut the pollution causing it.

The Clean Power Plan was the greatest step the U.S. has ever taken to reduce carbon pollution. The plan would have furthered the already booming clean energy economy, created more jobs, driven American ingenuity and helped to secure a bright future for wildlife and our communities. Your decision to repeal this rule and replace it with the "Affordable Clean Energy" rule is a serious mistake. The agency's own analysis shows the rule could result in thousands of additional premature deaths each year from increased coal use and pollution, not to mention untold climate effects. 

Reconsider your actions and implement the original Clean Power Plan, which would actually reduce harmful carbon pollution from power plants. Drop your plan to repeal the Clean Power Plan, and do not magnify the harm by implementing a pro-coal rule that puts people and wildlife at risk. Toss the pro-coal plan and do your job.

Thank you.
docketTitle: Repeal of Carbon Dioxide Emission Guidelines for Existing Stationary Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units; Emission Guidelines for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Existing Electric Utility Generating Units; Revisions to Emission Guideline Implementing Regulations; Revisions to New Source Review Program

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Environmental Defense Fund (EDF) (web)
commentText:
Attached, please find the signatures of 49,165 Environmental Defense Fund supporters from across the country who have submitted comments regarding Docket ID EPA-HQ-OAR-2017-0355. The text of each comment submitted reads: 

"I am extremely disappointed in EPA's proposed plan to "replace" the Clean Power Plan. This watered-down version would not meet the agency's legal obligation to protect Americans from the devastating effects of climate change that we are already experiencing today, from super-charged hurricanes to seemingly unstoppable wildfires. We deserve better. 

"The Clean Power Plan would achieve a 32 percent reduction in carbon pollution from existing power plants once fully implemented, compared to 2005 levels. It would also cut pollution that harms human health, preventing up to 90,000 childhood asthma attacks, 1,700 heart attacks, and 4,500 premature deaths every year.

"But according to the RIA of this new plan, it would lead to over 1,000 additional deaths from air pollution in 2030 alone, relative to the Clean Power Plan. This is not acceptable. Any revision to the Clean Power Plan must provide Americans with greater protections from harmful climate pollution, not less."

Please feel free to contact me if you have any questions or concerns about this submission. 

Thank you for your consideration,

Heather Shelby
Manager, Grassroots Organizing & Activism
Environmental Defense Fund
hshelby@edf.org
(202) 572 3242
docketTitle: Repeal of Carbon Dioxide Emission Guidelines for Existing Stationary Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units; Emission Guidelines for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Existing Electric Utility Generating Units; Revisions to Emission Guideline Implementing Regulations; Revisions to New Source Review Program

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by The Environmental Law and Policy Center (web)
commentText:
The Environmental Law and Policy Center submits the attached petition signed by386 individual signatories in regards to EPA's Proposed Rule: Emission Guidelines for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Existing Electric Utility Generating Units: Emission Guideline Implementing Regulations; New Source Review Program.

"We, the undersigned, believe the EPA proposed Affordable Clean Energy (ACE) rule moves our country backward by reversing efforts to cut carbon pollution and allowing more old coal plants to keep polluting our air and water. 

Carbon dioxide is making climate change worse. Climate impacts are already being felt from stronger storms, more intense heat waves, and harmful algal blooms in our lakes. Many Midwest cities also have unhealthy levels of soot and smog. This proposal encourages more dirty electricity from coal plants. 

EPAs own analysis shows that this proposal puts the health and safety of families and communities at risk from increased pollution. ACE could lead to as many as 1,630 early deaths per year in 2030 compared to leaving the CPP in place. 

Its time for America to move forward with clean energy solutions to our climate change problems. Withdraw the dangerous Affordable Clean Energy rule and leave the Clean Power Plan in place!
docketTitle: Repeal of Carbon Dioxide Emission Guidelines for Existing Stationary Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units; Emission Guidelines for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Existing Electric Utility Generating Units; Revisions to Emission Guideline Implementing Regulations; Revisions to New Source Review Program

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Environmental Action (web)
commentText:
I am writing today on behalf of the national conservation organization Environmental Action and 16,071 people concerned about the administrations proposed plan for the nations power plants. (Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OAR-2017-0355).

In 2018, Americans experienced massive wildfires, droughts, flooding, scorching temperatures, frequent extreme weather events, and even toxic algae that's littered Florida beaches with the rotting corpses of manatees, sea turtles and other imperiled wildlife -- all related to rising global temperatures.

The United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate change now says that we may have as little as 12 years to avoid even more intense climate-related impacts.  Unfortunately, this proposal would  delay one of the most meaningful actions the federal government has yet taken to address climate change and reduce carbon, soot, and other harmful pollutants in our air. 

In fact, the new rule is so bad that it could result in as many as 1,400 more early deaths in the US each year -- and that's according to the Environmental Protection Agencys own numbers.

Attached, please find the signatures of 16,071 people who have signed a petition opposing the administrations proposed Affordable Clean Energy rule.

Individuals were given the option to customize their comments, but most have signed some version of this text:

"We, the undersigned, strongly object to the regulatory revisions proposed in the Affordable Clean Energy rule (Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OAR-2017-0355). The proposed rule would delay meaningful action to address climate change or reduce carbon, soot, and other harmful pollutants in our air and could result in as many as 1,400 more early deaths in the US each year."

To ensure an accurate public commenting process, we ask that these comments be placed in the public record and considered in your planning. Should you wish to review the petition online, it is available at https://environmental-action.webaction.org/p/dia/action4/common/public/?action_KEY=28875

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Moms Clean Air Force (web)
commentText:
Attached, please find the signatures of 31,172 Moms Clean Air Force supporters from across the country who have submitted comments regarding the Environmental Protection Agency's proposed rule, Emission Guidelines for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Existing Electric Utility Generating Units: Emission Guideline Implementing Regulations; New Source Review Program. Please consider each a formal comment in the federal docket regarding Docket Number EPA-HQ-OAR-2017-0355-21117.

The comment they each submitted reads:

As a parent, I am deeply concerned by the EPA's proposal to replace the Clean Power Plan. Instead of addressing and curbing greenhouse gas emissions and pollution from power plants, this proposal gives polluters a free pass to keep endangering our children's health and future.

Millions of children in the United States are already suffering from asthma at record rates and climate change will make asthma worse. It will increase risk of heart and lung complications for children, the elderly, and all Americans.

The EPA has a responsibility to protect our families and communities from the grave threat of climate change. This proposal to replace America's Clean Power Plan is a dangerous reversal that threatens the health and future of America's children.

Please contact me if you have any questions or concerns about this submission.

Thank you for your consideration,
docketTitle: Repeal of Carbon Dioxide Emission Guidelines for Existing Stationary Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units; Emission Guidelines for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Existing Electric Utility Generating Units; Revisions to Emission Guideline Implementing Regulations; Revisions to New Source Review Program

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Environmental Action (web)
commentText:
I am submitting this comment today on behalf of the national conservation organization Environmental Action and 12,974 people who are opposed to the administrations proposed changes to mercury emissions standards for U.S. power plants (EPA-HQ-OAR-2017-0355-21117).

This proposal would weaken federal rules the Obama administration put in place to reduce mercury emissions from power plants and help address climate change.

Mercury is toxic to people and wildlife. It can cause cancer and harms the brains of children and fetuses. Mercury persists in the environment, contaminating water and accumulating in fish. It can travel up the food chain and harm people and animals alike.

But the effects of the proposed rollback on mercury rules are even more far-reaching.    

The United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has warned that we have roughly 12 years left to avoid the worst impacts of climate change. Instead, this proposal would boost coal-fired power plants, fueling climate change. 

Attached, please find the signatures of 12,974 people who have signed this petition in opposition to the administrations mercury emissions proposal:

"We, the undersigned, oppose the administrations proposed changes to mercury emissions standards for power plants (EPA-HQ-OAR-2017-0355-21117). Mercury is a neurotoxin, and we believe that these changes will dramatically increase its impact on human health, wildlife, and the environment. Worse, the proposal would also mean that the US burns even more fossil fuels that contribute to the climate change crisis".

Like you, Environmental Action wants the public record of the decision making process on changes to mercury emissions guidelines to be as complete and accurate as possible. To that end, we ask that these comments be placed in the public record and considered in your planning.

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Maine Conservation Voters (web)
commentText:
Dear EPA Administrator Pruitt, 

In Maine, climate change is not just a looming threat - we can see its impacts already. That is why Maine people, and people across the country, are supporting the Clean Power Plan (CPP) to take action and mitigate the devastating consequences of climate change. 

The CPP would drastically reduce carbon pollution from coal-fired power plants and push for renewable energy sources that support a clean energy future and economy. Americans overwhelmingly support the CPP - and Mainers are no different -  because we know that it's time for our country to take serious steps to protect our public health, natural resources, and future from the growing threats of climate change.
 
Maine depends on its abundant natural resources to fuel our state's economy, and climate change is already taking a toll on the industries that Maine's economy depends on, from lobster fisheries to moose populations. Furthermore, Maine sits at the tailpipe of the nation: even though Maine is not home to any coal-fired power plants, Maine has one of the highest rates of asthma in the country because we breathe in the pollution from power plants in western states. We need federal policy like the CPP to make sure that the air we breathe and the water we drink in Maine remains clean and healthy for future generations. 

We expect you to defend our environmental and public health by protecting the Clean Power Plan and moving our nation forward instead of backwards. 

Signed,

The 663 Maine people listed in the attached file.
docketTitle: Repeal of Carbon Dioxide Emission Guidelines for Existing Stationary Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units; Emission Guidelines for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Existing Electric Utility Generating Units; Revisions to Emission Guideline Implementing Regulations; Revisions to New Source Review Program

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Clean Water Action (web)
commentText:
Docket ID: EPA-HQ-OAR-2017-0355

Dear Administrator Pruitt, 

On behalf of Clean Water Action, I am submitting 4,455 letters from our members urging you to drop your plan to repeal the Clean Power Plan. The CPP is our most serious attempt to fight climate change and protect public health. By repealing the Plan you are putting profits for fossil fuel companies before the needs of our families and public health.

The Clean Power Plan is projected to prevent 90,000 asthma attacks, 300,000 missed work and school days, and 3,600 premature deaths annually by 2030. Repealing these standards means more sick kids, more expensive hospital visits, and thousands of premature deaths that could have been prevented. There is no way to justify this decision.

While you have been working to dismantle action on climate, supercharged hurricanes and climate fueled wildfires are ravaging our communities and killing Americans. Climate change is real. Its happening now. And EPA is required by law to address it.

States, cities, and businesses across the country are moving forward with clean energy solutions that reduce air and carbon pollution and grow the clean energy economy, creating good-paying American jobs. Repealing the Clean Power Plan will create uncertainty and put these solutions at risk.

Please drop this reckless proposal to repeal the Clean Power Plan.

Sincerely, 
Andrew Grinberg, National Campaigns Special Projects Manager

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Environment America (web)
commentText:
Administrator Scott Pruitt
Office of the Administrator 1101A
U.S. Environmental Protection Agency
1200 Pennsylvania Avenue, N.W.
Washington, D.C. 20460

Re: Docket No. EPA-HQ-OAR-2017-0355

April, 26, 2018 

Dear EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt, 

Environment America is submitting the attached 21,922 names of individuals urging the Environment Protection Agency to withdraw its proposal to repeal the Clean Power Plan. We ask that these names be entered into the official record and considered as separate public comments. 

Each of the 21,922 people signed the following public comment language: 

Dear Administrator Pruitt,

The Clean Power Plan is our nation's best tool to reduce carbon pollution from power plants, combat climate change and protect our health. Analysis by the Environmental Protection Agency finds that the Clean Power Plan could prevent the premature deaths of as many as 4,500 Americans per year by 2030. Americans deserve clean air to breathe and a safe future for our children. I urge you to protect our climate and our health by keeping the Clean Power Plan intact.We urge you to move forward with federal standards to limit dangerous global warming pollution and protect our health. 

Sincerely,

Andrea McGimsey 
Environment America

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Green For All (web)
commentText:
From:  	Michelle Romero, Deputy Director, Green For All
To:  	Administrator Scott Pruitt, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency
Date:  	April 26, 2018
Re: 	Comments on Proposed Repeal of the Clean Power Plan 
Docket ID Number:  EPA-HQ-OAR-2017-0355

 
Dear Administrator Pruitt,

This cover letter accompanies the 4,408 comments we received from people across the country who wanted to speak out in support of the Clean Power Plan. 

Green For All works to build an inclusive green economy strong enough to lift people out of poverty. Our goals are to make sure that:
People of color have a place and voice in the climate movement
Our neighborhoods are strong, resilient and healthy, and
The growing clean energy economy brings jobs and opportunity to our communities. 

The Trump Administrations proposal to repeal the Clean Power Plan is a direct assault on our lives and childrens futures. Dismantling the first and only federal limits on carbon pollution from existing power plants wont help vulnerable families breathe. Power plant pollution is sending people who live near them to the hospital, with breathing problems.

Power plants should not be allowed to pollute our communities as much as they want. Polluters routinely target communities of color and low-income communities for their dirtiest projects. Families living and working at the frontlines of pollution have been paying the health, economic, and climate costs for generations while fossil fuel companies have enjoyed record profits. Its time to reverse the trend.  

In addition to curbing air pollution, the Clean Power Plan is essential to meeting our climate goals. The vast majority of the comments we received agree that setting strict carbon pollution regulations for power plants through the Clean Power Plan is good for the environment and the economy.  

On behalf of Green For All, and on behalf of our more than 4,408 members who submitted enclosed public comments, please do NOT eliminate or weaken the Clean Power Plan in any way.

Thank you.

Sincerely,

Michelle Romero
Deputy Director
docketTitle: Repeal of Carbon Dioxide Emission Guidelines for Existing Stationary Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units; Emission Guidelines for Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Existing Electric Utility Generating Units; Revisions to Emission Guideline Implementing Regulations; Revisions to New Source Review Program

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Sierra Club (web)
commentText:
Over 122,000 Sierra Club members and supporters sent in public comments on this docket via sc.org/CPP. Their names are attached as a spreadsheet, along with a pdf of over 3,500 people who made a personalized comment beyond the statement they signed on to below:

"Over a million Americans submitted public comments in favor of the Clean Power Plan and other EPA protections for the climate. The American people demand our power plants, cars, and other pollution sources reduce the amount of climate disrupting pollution they spew into our atmosphere.

We will not stand by and allow you to dismantle the progress we've made to act on climate change. If the EPA wishes to roll back the Clean Power Plan, we demand you replace it with something that will result in even greater reduction in carbon and other forms of climate pollution.

EPA's own Endangerment Finding (as well as Supreme Court cases like Massachusetts v. EPA) empower and obligate the EPA to protect the climate and reduce carbon emissions. We demand you act on climate change and reduce the carbon emissions that fuel it."

We urge you to not repeal the Clean Power Plan, keep it in place, and strengthen our commitment to solving the issue of climate change.

These comments were also sent to a-and-r-Docket@epa.gov

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Moms Clean Air Force (web)
commentText:
To Whom It May Concern: 

Attached, please find the signatures of 6,874 Moms Clean Air Force supporters from across the country who have submitted comments regarding the Environmental Protection Agency's proposal to repeal the Clean Power Plan. Please consider each a formal comment in the federal docket regarding Docket Number EPA-HQ-OAR-2017-0355. 

The comment they each submitted reads: 

The EPA's dangerous decision to repeal America's Clean Power Plan is an insult to current and future Americans. Our children, grandchildren, and those to follow are counting on us to lead in the fight against climate change, which threatens the health and future of my children.

As a parent, I am concerned about the health impacts of climate change and air pollution. America's Clean Power Plan would offer significant health benefits to Americans. It would avoid thousands of premature deaths each year as a result of reductions in particle pollution, and prevent 90,000 asthma attacks each year, yielding tens of billions of dollars in annual health benefits. Hundreds of thousands of Americans have expressed support for the plan, along with Democrats and Republicans alike, cities and communities, religious leaders and businesses. 

I implore the EPA--as America's first defender against toxic pollution and climate-changing pollutants--to institute a plan that will take seriously these threats and do all it can to keep American families safe and healthy.

Please contact me if you have any questions or concerns about this submission. 

Thank you for your consideration,

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Environmental Action (web)
commentText:
April 25, 2018

Administrator Scott Pruitt:

On behalf of Environmental Action, an education and advocacy organization dedicated, I formally submit 29,320 signatures in strong opposition to repeal the clean power plan. 

The Clean Power Plan aims to cut carbon emissions from the nation's electricity sector 32 percent by 2030, compared to 2005 levels -- one of the strongest actions ever taken by the United States to combat climate change. We need stronger climate action, not cuts to existing protections.

I ask that these signatures be entered into the official record and considered as individual comments. Each of the people listed in the attached spreadsheet signed this comment:

Administrator Pruitt,

I am writing to urge you to protect the Clean Power Plan. This plan is a key part of our country's efforts to curb the disastrous effects of climate change, and will help protect our country's air, water and health. I oppose all efforts to weaken, roll back or dismantle the Clean Power Plan. I urge you to protect and strengthen the Clean Power Plan for the future of our families, our health.

For your convenience, the petition remains available online at: https://bit.ly/2KfProO. 

Should you have any questions about the petition or signature file, please contact me at 202-461-2449 x349 or by email at Sally@environmental-action.org.

Sincerely,

Sally King
Environmental Action

title: Mass Comment Campaign submitted by parishioners at Saint James Parish, Arlington Heights, IL (web)
commentText:
Dear Administrator Pruitt and the EPA,

We, the undersigned, strongly oppose a repeal of the Clean Power Plan.

Air pollution is a threat to our health and welfare.  We want clean air to breathe and better than an "F" grade for air quality. This is affecting our daily lives by worsening breathing problems and heart disease.

The Clean Power Plan is essential in reducing pollutants from power plants. We want to see the Clean Power Plan fully implemented by 2030. We need to lower carbon pollution from the power sector to 32 percent below 2005 levels. This will secure the progress we need toward a healthy and sustainable future. We support policies that will drastically reduce carbon and other polluting gases. 

We view this as a moral responsibility. We speak for those most vulnerable as they are disproportionally affected by public health disasters.

We oppose the dismantling of the Clean Power Plan.

Sincerely yours,
Jeanne Coughlin and
189 concerned parishioners of Saint James Parish in Arlington Hts, IL signed below in the attachments-this is only a portion of the signatures gathered.

Re: 	Comments on Proposed Repeal of the Clean Power Plan 
Docket ID Number:  EPA-HQ-OAR-2017-0355
 
Dear Administrator Pruitt,
This cover letter accompanies the 3,254 comments we received from people across the country who wanted to speak out in support of the Clean Power Plan. 

Green For All works to build an inclusive green economy strong enough to lift people out of poverty. Our goals are to make sure that:

-People of color have a place and voice in the climate movement
-Our neighborhoods are strong, resilient and healthy, and
-The growing clean energy economy brings jobs and opportunity to our communities. 

The Trump Administration's proposal to repeal the Clean Power Plan is a direct assault on our lives and children's futures. Dismantling the first and only federal limits on carbon pollution from existing power plants won't help vulnerable families breathe. Power plant pollution is sending people who live near them to the hospital, with breathing problems.

Power plants should not be allowed to pollute our communities as much as they want. Polluters routinely target communities of color and low-income communities for their dirtiest projects. Families living and working at the frontlines of pollution have been paying the health, economic, and climate costs for generations while fossil fuel companies have enjoyed record profits. It's time to reverse the trend.  

In addition to curbing air pollution, the Clean Power Plan is essential to meeting our climate goals. The vast majority of the comments we received agree that setting strict carbon pollution regulations for power plants through the Clean Power Plan is good for the environment and the economy.  

On behalf of Green For All, and on behalf of our more than 3,254 members who submitted enclosed public comments, please do NOT eliminate or weaken the Clean Power Plan in any way.

Thank you.

Sincerely,

Michelle Romero
Deputy Director

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Environmental Defense Fund (EDF) (web)
commentText:
To Whom It May Concern: 

Attached are two documents containing the signatures of 75,366 Environmental Defense Fund supporters from across the country who have submitted electronic comments regarding EPA's Proposed Rule: Oil and Natural Gas Sector; Emission Standards for New, Reconstructed, and Modified Sources: Stay of Certain Requirements. The comment they each submitted reads: 

"I'm writing today in strong opposition to your proposal to suspend vital air pollution safeguards that will reduce harmful methane, smog-forming volatile organic compounds, and toxic air pollutants like benzene from new and modified sources in the oil and natural gas sector. 

This decision threatens the health and welfare of countless Americans who live in close proximity to oil and gas development by allowing thousands of tons of these harmful air pollutants to be emitted into the atmosphere. Each day this suspension is in place, the harm will be compounded: more new wells are drilled and other wells subject to the standards are allowed to continue emitting harmful pollution, which cannot later be removed from the air.

These common-sense safeguards are also highly cost-effective, leveraging widely used technologies and best practices that are already required in several energy-producing states.  They were also developed through extensive public input and years of agency deliberation. There is no basis for EPA to suspend these safeguards. 

Please reverse this unlawful, dangerous decision, and ensure these crucial pollution safeguards are put into action."

Please let me know if you have any additional questions or concerns about this submission. 

Thank you for your consideration, 

Heather Shelby
Manager, Grassroots Organizing & Activism
Environmental Defense Fund
hshelby@edf.org

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by National Wildlife Federation Action Fund (web)
commentText:
Attached are individual comments from 17,735 National Wildlife Federation Action Fund supporters from across the country, urging the Environmental Protection Agency to withdraw the methane rule suspension and immediately begin putting it into effect. Specifically:

I am deeply concerned that the Environmental Protection Agency is proposing to delay implementation of key parts of the methane new and modified source rule for two years, and may be seeking to permanently undo the rule entirely.  I urge you to withdraw this proposed suspension and immediately begin putting the methane rule into effect.

Methane is a super-pollutant that speeds climate change in the short-term, imperiling pronghorn and other wildlife and special places that are important to me and to our nation as a whole.  The oil and gas industry is the single largest source of this pollution in the U.S., and companies are not doing enough to keep excessive methane pollution from flaring and leaking into the atmosphere.  Also, toxic and smog-forming pollution is released along with the methane pollution, making local pollution problems worse and threatening my family's health.

As Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, your duty is to protect public health and welfare and the environment from undue harm. My family, wildlife, and natural treasures should not have to pay the price for pollution that could be reduced by a more responsible industry. EPA sometimes has to press industry to clean up, and this is one of those times.

I urge you to withdraw the methane rule suspension and immediately begin putting it into effect.
docketTitle: Oil and Natural Gas Sector -- New Source Performance Standards, National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants, and Control Techniques Guidelines

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Sierra Club (web)
commentText:
August 9, 2017 

Mass Comment Campaign of the Sierra Club
RE: Docket EPA-HQ-OAR-2010-0505-7736

To Whom It May Concern:

The attached document contains comments collected from 55,162 activists from across the country. Each has submitted electronic comments on the EPA's proposed stay of certain requirements of methane rules for the oil and natural gas sector. More than 47,710 have submitted the quoted text below. Please note that 7,452 people have taken the time to write a personalized comment in addition to the quoted text below; these individual additions are noted in the attached document. 

"I oppose any delay in the implementation of methane pollution standards. Staying these protections will put our environment and public health at risk. If anything, the EPA should strengthen methane pollution safeguards. We depend on the EPA to protect us from harmful pollution that makes it harder to breathe, aggravates asthma, and fills our air with toxic compounds. The EPA must fulfill its mission to "protect human health and the environment" by maintaining and enforcing these standards and protecting our children's health. EPA has an obligation to protect all Americans from harmful methane pollution. Any attempt to slow or dismantle standards that cut pollution from the oil and gas industry is a direct assault on our health."

Sincerely,

Matthew Gravatt
Associate Director, Federal and Administrative Advocacy
Sierra Club
docketTitle: Oil and Natural Gas Sector -- New Source Performance Standards, National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants, and Control Techniques Guidelines

title: Mass comment campaign sponsoring organization unknown (web)
commentText:
I am submitting the attached 1,418 comments on Docket EPA-HQ-OAR-2010-0505 collected by the Power Shift Network, a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization. The commenters represented in the attachment all wish to submit the text of the comment included below (also in the attachment), in addition to further personal comments many added to their submission. 

Please don't hesitate to contact Devyn Powell at devyn@powershift.org if any questions or issues arise.

-------

Comment text:

Docket ID: EPA-HQ-OAR-2010-0505 

I strongly oppose the EPA's proposal to delay the implementation of critical methane pollution standards. The EPA should be leading efforts to protect our planet and our health, not rolling back important regulations on oil and gas industry pollution.

The EPA's mission is to protect human health and the environment -- not corporate polluters' profits. It is especially indefensible that the EPA would propose this order when the agency has even admitted that "the environmental health or safety risk addressed by this action may have a disproportionate effect on children."

It is EPA's obligation to protect all Americans from harmful pollution like methane. This attempt to dismantle standards that protect us from oil and a gas industry pollution is nothing less than a direct assault on our health and environment. EPA stands for Environmental Protection Agency, not Environmental Pollution Agency. Please fulfill your mission and keep this important methane rule in place.
docketTitle: Oil and Natural Gas Sector -- New Source Performance Standards, National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants, and Control Techniques Guidelines

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Clean Water Action (CWA) (web)
commentText:
On behalf of Clean Water Action, we are submitting comments from more than 1200 Clean Water Action members across the country, opposing this move to delay the implementation of methane pollution standards. Rather than stay these critical protections for any amount of time, we need EPA to strengthen methane pollution safeguards.

Americans depend on EPA to protect us from the harmful pollution that makes it harder to breathe - and the corporate polluters who profit from it. We need EPA to fulfill its mission to "protect human health and the environment" by not letting corporate polluters play fast and loose with our children's health.

It is EPA's obligation to protect all Americans from harmful methane pollution. Any attempt to slow or dismantle standards that cut pollution from the oil and a gas industry is a direct assault on our health and environment - and the Environmental Protection Agency should not be complicit.

Sincerely, 
John Nol
National Oil and Gas Campaigns Coordinator
Clean Water Action

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Earthjustice (web)
commentText:
Attached below are the names of 35,156 individuals who have submitted public comments opposing any delay in the implementation of methane pollution standards. In addition to signing on in support of the following letter, 7,834 individuals of the total number have submitted personalized comments. The personalized comments start on page 2 and end on page 397.

Enforce the methane pollution standards that keep our air clean and our families safe and health (Re: EPA-HQ-OAR-2010-0505-7736)

Dear Administrator Pruitt,

I oppose this move to delay the implementation of methane pollution standards. Rather than stay these critical protections for any amount of time, we need the EPA to strengthen methane pollution safeguards.

Americans depend on the EPA to protect us from the harmful pollution that makes it harder to breathe and the corporate polluters who profit from it. We need the EPA to fulfill its mission to "protect human health and the environment" by not letting corporate polluters play fast and loose with our children's health.

Leaks from shoddy, broken equipment are among the largest sources of methane and other harmful pollutants from oil and gas facilities. But the leak detection and repair standards in this rule will deliver up to 45 percent of target reductions in smog- and soot-forming volatile organic compounds and nearly all target reductions in hazardous air pollutants such as cancer-causing benzene and formaldehyde.

Delaying this rule will irreparably harm millions of Americans who live in close proximity to the more than 18,000 new and modified wells--more than 11,000 of which are located in states that do not impose their own comparable leak detection and repair programs.

It is the EPA's obligation to protect all Americans from harmful methane pollution. Any attempt to slow or dismantle standards that reduce pollution emitted from the oil and gas industry is a direct assault on our health and environment and the Environmental Protection Agency should not be complicit.

Sincerely,

The Undersigned
