title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Moms Clean Air Force (web)
commentText:
Attached are 11,667 signatures from Moms Clean Air Force members, echoing the below message: 

"I am writing today in strong opposition to your proposal to suspend vital air pollution safeguards that will reduce harmful methane, smog-forming volatile organic compounds, and toxic air pollutants like benzene from new and modified sources in the oil and natural gas sector. 

As a parent and a member of Moms Clean Air Force, I am concerned about how pollution from the oil and gas industry affects children's health. Methane leaks make smog worse, contribute to global climate change, and waste money. And where methane is leaking, so are carcinogenic compounds like benzene and other VOCs. I don't want those in the air our kids breathe.
 
The health-protective methane standards were developed through extensive public input and years of agency deliberation. There is no basis for EPA to suspend these safeguards. We need the EPA to fulfill its mission to "protect human health and the environment" by not letting corporate polluters play fast and loose with our children's health.

Please reconsider this dangerous proposal, and ensure these crucial pollution safeguards remain in place."

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by United Methodist Women (UMW) (web)
commentText:
August 7, 2017  

 Administrator E. Scott Pruitt  
Office of the Administrator, Code 1101A 
 Environmental Protection Agency 
1200 Pennsylvania Avenue, N.W. 
 Washington, DC 20460    

Dear Administrator Pruitt,   

EPA Proposed Rule: Oil and Natural Gas Sector; Emission Standards for New, Reconstructed, and Modified Sources: 
Stay of Certain Requirements  Docket # EPA-HQ-OAR-2010-0505 

I am writing on behalf of United Methodist Women (UMW), the largest denominational faith-based organization for women with
approximately 800,000 members, to oppose EPA's proposed two-year stay, and any stay of any duration, of the new source
performance standards for the oil and gas sector, 40 C.F.R. subpart OOOOa.  
 
We appreciate the opportunity to submit public comments, and United Methodist Women nation-wide have expressed their
opposition to the two-year or postponement of the June 2016 rule that requires manufactures of natural gas and oil to adhere 
to strict performance standards on "fugitive emissions" at well sites and compressor stations and emissions from pneumatic
pumps.  Attached are individual letters from United Methodists Women members and friends that were compiled through our
web portal.  

We strongly urge you to adhere to the rule's requirements and not attempt to stay those provisions.  
 
You can contact Elizabeth Lee to further discuss this request. Please see contact information below.     

Respectfully submitted on behalf of United Methodist Women,   

Elizabeth Chun Hye Lee 
Executive for Economic and Environmental Justice 
Christian Social Action 
United Methodist Women United Methodist Office for the United Nations |
Church Center for the UN 777 United Nations Plaza, 11th Floor | 
New York, NY 10017 (T): 212-878-7814 | (F): 212-682-5354
http://www.unitedmethodistwomen.org
Email: elee@unitedmethodistwomen.org

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC) (web)
commentText: Please accept these public comments from 44,895 online members and activists on behalf on the Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC) regarding EPA-HQ-OAR-2010-0505 in support of strong methane pollution protections. These pollution protections are critical safeguards for the health and safety of communities across the country and delaying them gives oil and gas companies a free pass to pollute. You must immediately enforce the lifesaving methane protections that are on the books and protect American's right to clean, healthy air. Thank you.

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Sierra Club (web)
commentText:
December 8, 2017
 
RE: Docket EPA-HQ-OAR-2010-0505-12363
 
To Whom It May Concern:

Please find 15,023 comments attached for inclusion in this docket, EPA-HQ-OAR-2010-0505-12363, "Oil and Natural Gas Sector: Emission Standards for New, Reconstructed, and Modified Sources; Grant of Reconsideration and Partial Stay" regarding the proposed stay of EPA's methane emission standards. 1780 people have taken the time to write a personalized comment and all 15,023 have signed to the following text:

"I oppose any delay in the implementation of EPA's methane pollution standards. Staying these protections will put our environment and public health at risk. If anything, EPA should strengthen the methane pollution safeguards. We depend on EPA to protect us from harmful pollution that makes it harder to breathe, aggravates asthma, warms our climate, and fills our air with toxic compounds. EPA must fulfill its mission to "protect human health and the environment" by maintaining and enforcing these standards and protecting our health. 

Furthermore, the proposed change in the social cost of methane simply doesn't make any sense and disregards basic science and economics. When greenhouse gases like methane are released they don't just stay over the U.S., they warm the entire planet, so we can't create policies that only look at the impacts on the U.S. In addition, EPA's new "interim domestic" social cost wrongly and severely discounts the needs of future generations compared to earlier and more accurate versions of the social cost of methane. 

EPA has an obligation to protect all Americans from harmful methane pollution and other emissions from the oil and gas sector. Any attempt to slow or dismantle standards that cut pollution from the oil and gas industry is a direct assault on our health. EPA must therefore abandon its proposal to stay these standards and continue to enforce them without delay."

We respectfully request the 15,023 comments submitted by the individuals listed in the attached document are reflected in the final comment tally for this docket.

Sincerely,
 
Matthew Gravatt
Associate Director, Federal and Administrative Advocacy
Sierra Club

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Earthjustice (Web)
commentText:
December 4, 2015

Office of Air Quality Planning and Standards 
Environmental Protection Agency 
Research Triangle Park, North Carolina 27711

Appended below are the names of 41,677 individuals who have submitted public comments regarding the Environmental Protection Agency's proposed Emission Standards for New and Modified Sources Rule. In addition to signing on in support of the following letter, 7,300 individuals of the total number have submitted personalized comments. The personalized comments start on page 2 and end on page 513.

Thank you for addressing methane pollution (RE: Docket EPA-HQ-OAR-2010-0505 FRL-9929-75-OAR)

Dear Administrator McCarthy,

For too long, the oil and gas industry has been allowed to leak millions of tons of methane and other toxic chemicals into the air. No one should have to fear that the air they are breathing might be a threat to their health or the health of their loved ones. That's why I support a strong methane pollution standard and want to thank the EPA for its work to meet President Obama's goal of reducing methane pollution from oil and gas operations 40 to 45 percent by 2025.

While this proposal is an important and necessary first step, to meet that goal, the EPA must quickly begin the process of addressing existing sources and requiring all companies--even those that are already doing well--to regularly check for leaks.

Taking steps to cut these emissions makes sense for our health and for our planet, which is already suffering from the impacts of climate change. The Methane Pollution Standard is a sensible, cost-effective proposal to continue addressing the climate crisis and decrease health risks to our children and families.

Sincerely,
The Undersigned

title: Mass comment Campaign sponsored by Earthworks (web)
commentText:
Attached are 6,231 comments in support of strong regulations submitted via TakePart.com in collaboration with Earthworks.

Also attached is an excel spreadsheet with a list of the same commenters without their letters. All letters have the following message: 

To: EPA

I urge the Environmental Protection Agency to issue strong rules to curb methane and other harmful air pollution from oil and gas development (EPA-HQ-OAR-2010-0505 and EPA-HQ-OAR-2013-0685). While no amount of regulation can make fracked gas a clean energy source, I support efforts to capture methane, repair leaks, and aggregate disparate sources of methane and other air pollution along the oil and gas supply chain. These important pollution controls will not only help stave off catastrophic climate change but also protect communities from harm imposed by the oil and gas industry.

I urge you to improve the proposed rules to include

Several key pieces of equipment that were omitted from the proposal that emit methane and harmful VOCs.
Storage vessels that were covered under the VOC standards but are not included in the methane proposal.
Liquids-unloading operations.
Pneumatic controllers that operate on an intermittent or snap-acting basis.
Compressors at well sites.
Mandatory inspections at least quarterly or monthly (rather than a default semiannual requirement), which should remain at a fixed frequency rather than decreasing on low-leak-rate detection.
Shortening the time source operators have to repair leaking equipment if it would be unsafe to make the repair within 15 days of discovery.
Defining "sources" to include functionally interrelated equipment so regulators can aggregate individual emissions sources to prevent significant deterioration of our air quality.
Including communities in the pollution-detection process. A citizen complaint system is needed to allow communities living near fracked gas infrastructure to alert the EPA if they detect odors or air pollution events nearby.
Requiring oil and gas companies to use or bring to market captured gas, rather than flare it, unless extraordinary circumstances make flaring unavoidable.

In addition to these important changes to strengthen the proposals, I urge the EPA to regulate existing sources of methane pollution under section 111(d) of the Clean Air Act. Voluntary standards are insufficient to cut harmful, climate-disrupting methane pollution from oil and gas operations, and they will not adequately protect affected communities. To safeguard communities living with the burden of existing oil and gas infrastructure and to meet President Obama's Climate Action Plan goal of reducing oil and gas sector methane emissions 40 to 45 percent below 2012 levels by 2025, the EPA must move quickly to create rules for existing oil and gas facilities upstream, midstream, and downstream.

I support the EPA's proposals as a means to begin to address the climate crisis exacerbated by the fracking boom and reduce harm to communities living with the burden of the oil and gas industry. I urge the EPA to make the changes needed to ensure that these rules are sufficiently strong to protect public health and tackle climate change. Regulating existing sources of air pollution, coupled with an immediate shift to an economy that depends on clean, renewable energynot fossil fuelsare steps that must be followed to avoid the most devastating effects of catastrophic climate change.
docketTitle: Oil and Natural Gas Sector -- New Source Performance Standards, National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants, and Control Techniques Guidelines

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by National Wildlife Federation (NWF) (web)
commentText:
Please accept the attached 24,794 comments on behalf of supporters of the National Wildlife Federation. 

The bulk of the comments are as follows:

I support the EPA's proposed rules to reduce methane pollution from the oil and gas industry.  

These pollution limits will help to address climate change and its associated impacts to wildlife and people by curtailing methane pollution, which is an especially potent greenhouse gas. The methane limits will also help prevent other dangerous pollutants and habitat degradation caused by industrial oil and gas development. 

Cutting methane pollution is also a vital piece of the President's Climate Action Plan, along with the Clean Power Plan and other important measures to limit carbon pollution.  

Please strengthen the methane rule by expanding its scope to include additional important emissions sources, mandate a higher frequency of repairing methane leaks, ensure that companies capture gas rather than flaring it, and move quickly to expand the EPA methane rule to cover existing oil and gas infrastructure.

Thank you.
docketTitle: Oil and Natural Gas Sector -- New Source Performance Standards, National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants, and Control Techniques Guidelines

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Credo Action (58,678)
commentText:
November 30, 2011

RE: Docket ID Number EPA-HQ-OAR-2010-0505

Dear Administrator Jackson:

Attached you will find 58,678 public comment submissions in support of the Proposed Rule on Oil and Natural Gas Sector: New Source Performance Standards and National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants Reviews. Though the comments vary slightly from person to person, the majority read as follows:

Thank you for proposing new rules to limit toxic air emissions from oil and gas operations. 

The proposed rules are fair, achievable and vitally important given that regulations to protect our air from oil and gas drilling have not kept up with the rapid pace of drilling expansion.

In addition to reducing emissions of volatile organic compounds, your agency should limit emissions of methane, a potent heat-trapping gas that leads to global warming. Your agency also needs to strengthen the limits of hazardous air pollutants and cancer-causing chemicals like benzene to fulfill your legal duty to protect communities from unacceptable health threats like toxic air pollution coming from the oil and gas sector.

These comments have been collected by CREDO Action and submitted to you on behalf of 58,678 members across the country. To see the individual comments and the names of the people who submitted them, please download the attached PDF. This is the first of 11 attachments.

If you have any questions about this petition or the attached comments, please do not hesitate to contact me.


Sincerely,

Elijah Zarlin
Campaign Manager, CREDO Action
415-369-2000
ezarlin@credomobile.com

commentText:
Supplementing our previous comments (including 1jx-89by-nafk, 1jx-87wl-el1j, 1jx-89cl-stci, 80eb92cf, and 1jy-8b5z-87le) attached please find an excel spreadsheet listing 1,070 supporters of the following statement:

"Sally Jewell & President Obama,

"Please maintain critical Endangered Species Protections for wolves in the Pacific Northwest.

"The extermination of wolves in the last century is one of the America's greatest environmental tragedies. Their return represents a chance at redemption. Since wolves were stripped of basic protections in a 2011 budget deal, over 2,000 have been killed for sport.

"In many places, recovery is in its infancy, but won't succeed unless wolves continue to have the basic protections afforded them by the ESA. Americans value native wildlife and the science is clear. I urge you to ensure the story of wolf recovery has a happy ending by maintaining protections for America's wolves!"

There are at least 1,003 individual signatories of which many added additional comments. Some of these comments may be considered substantive and should be treated as such. Additional contact information may be available for some of these commenters.

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
I am writing, along with over 20,000 members of Environmental Action to ask the Fish and Wildlife Service not to strip Endangered Species Act protections from gray wolves or permit increased hunting of this threatened species. 

The re-introduction of wolves into our environment is a cause for celebration, not a reason to re-open hunting. And until the last few years, this iconic species was one of the great triumphs of the Endangered Species Act. Leading scientists have found again and again that wolves and other top predators are an essential part of a healthy ecosystem. And millions of Americans and tourists are drawn to these powerful, inspiring, and too-often misunderstood creatures.

And now, the FWS's own independent review from UC Santa Barbara has unanimously concluded that the proposal is not based on the best available science and that FWS's own research is filled with numerous omissions and errors. 

A few months ago, Sec. Jewell said of the proposed rule that it was "not [her] call," because "you do what the science says." With the release of this study and the thousands of comments attached, science and the pubic have spoken: You must retain federal protections for wolves in the lower 48 states. 

Thank you for your time and consideration,

Drew Hudson
Director, Environmental Action
docketTitle: Removing the Gray Wolf from the List of Endangered and Threatened Wildlife and Maintaining Protections for the Mexican Wolf by Listing It as Endangered

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
March 27, 2014

TO: Interior Secretary Sally Jewell
U.S. Department of the Interior
1849 C Street, N.W.
Washington DC 20240
VIA: http://www.regulations.gov/#!documentDetail;D=FWS-HQ-ES-2013-0073-43030

Subject: Gray Wolf Delisting (proposed rule)  comments
Docket ID: FWS-HQ-ES-2013-0073-43030


Dear Secretary Jewell,

Please accept these comments and those recently submitted from the Endangered Species Coalition (ESC) concerning the proposed rule to remove the gray wolf from the list of threatened & endangered species (but to maintain endangered status for the Mexican wolf). ESC represents over 300 member groups and tens of thousands of supporters who share our mission to protect and restore our nations most imperiled wildlife.  Our members have been deeply involved in wolf recovery efforts across the country. These 18,490 comments are in addition to those submitted in the earlier comment periods. Please also see submitted video comments from young people around the country at http://www.endangered.org/kids-to-secretary-jewell-follow-the-science/ and  http://www.endangered.org/its-about-science/

The Endangered Species Coalition and our members and supporters remain strongly opposed to the proposed rule. We urge FWS to immediately withdraw the rule and continue protections for wolves across the lower-48 states. 

The news that the peer review panel has rejected the science used in writing this proposed rule is the most glaring of what are many reasons to reject this plan. The Service's questionable scientific reasoning and unwarranted political calculus necessitate a complete retraction of this proposal and thorough investigation prior to any similar proposals.

Wolves are still recovering in states around the country and trying desperately to expand into others. Removing Endangered Species Act protections now would threaten this recovery and potentially weaken the Endangered Species Act.

In addition, states are not prepared to take on the responsibility of recovery of a delisted population of wolves.  We urge FWS not to back away from federal recovery and allow scenarios like what is happening in Idaho to occur in other states.  

In Idaho, efforts to kills wolves have ramped up significantly. Year-round hunting and trapping is now allowed in parts of the state, government-paid trappers have been active in Wilderness areas, and a bill continues to move forward that would spend $2 million to kill most of the wolves in the state. Idaho's management plans fail to demonstrate adequate regulatory mechanisms are in place as required by the ESA post-delisting.

In other states; Washingtons wolf recovery trend seems to have stalled in 2014, California has
stubbornly refused to protect wolves, and in Oregon continued poaching, an outbreak of
parvovirus, and a continued campaign of misinformation continue to put wolf recovery
on shaky ground.

In light of these facts and the rejection of this rule by the peer review panel, I urge that the Service immediately withdraw this plan.

Sincerely,


Leda Huta
Executive Director

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
Please find attached 1462 comment letters from Conservation Northwest members and supporters, in 3 PDFs. 

Conservation Northwest has more than 4,800 members and 13,000 activists and supporters throughout the Northwest and US. We work to connect and protect old growth and other wild areas from the Washington coast to the BC Rockies. Our volunteer remote camera monitoring teams discovered the Lookout Pack, Washington's first wolf pack in decades, and we helped Washington build its Gray Wolf Conservation & Management Plan. We continue to work to help Washington learn to live with wolves by funding and supporting non-lethal conflict avoidance measures across the state. Our members are strong supporters of a balanced plan for wolves and people in Washington. www.conservationnw.org

A spreadsheet of contact information is available to FWS staff upon request. Thank you for the opportunity for submitting comments on this important issue.

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
December 13, 2013

Dear US Fish and Wildlife Service,

Care2 members wanted to comment on the Proposed Rule: Removing the Gray Wolf (Canis lupus) from the List of Endangered and Threatened Wildlife and Maintaining Protections for the Mexican Wolf (Canis lupus baileyi) by Listing It as Endangered.

Here is the letter from the Defenders of Wildlife petition on Care2's petition site that our members signed urging you not to delist wolves:

--------------------------------

Dear [decision maker],

I am writing to oppose the move to delist wolves from the Endangered Species Act.

Gray wolf recovery is not complete. This decision could derail wolf recovery efforts in areas around the country where it has barely begun -- in places like the Pacific Northwest and in states that possess some of the nation's best unoccupied wolf habitat, such as northern California, Colorado, and Utah.

Delisting would prematurely turn wolf management over to the states. We've already seen what can happen when rabid anti-wolf politics are allowed to trump science and core wildlife management principles.

Montana, Wyoming and Idaho -- where wolves have already been delisted -- are not managing wolves like other wildlife such as elk, deer, and bears. Instead they're intending to drive the wolves' population numbers back down to the bottom.

Other species, such as the bald eagle, American alligator, and peregrine falcon were declared recovered and delisted when they occupied a much larger portion of their former range. Wolves deserve the same chance at real recovery.

I urge you to continue to protect wolves under the Endangered Species Act.

--------------------------------


Included are 19,461 US comments and signatures, attached in the following 177 pages.
 
Thank you for considering our comments.

Regards,
Sharanya Krishna Prasad
Senior Campaigns Manager, Care2
docketTitle: Removing the Gray Wolf from the List of Endangered and Threatened Wildlife and Maintaining Protections for the Mexican Wolf by Listing It as Endangered

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2013-13708
commentText:
Earthjustice, a public interest law organization, collected 133,074 public comments calling on the Bureau of Land Management to adopt stronger regulations on hydraulic fracturing. Of those, 65,032 were collected through our website; those are contained with their full comment letter in the attached Excel spreadsheet. Some of the personalized comments from that batch are included in the attached PDF letter. The remaining 68,042 were gathered through a petition site and signed on to the exact text below; they are attached in the PDF spreadsheet. Thank you for considering these comments.

-------

I write today in response to the rule proposed by the U.S. Bureau of Land Management governing hydraulic fracturing, or "fracking," on public lands. The current proposal out for public comment is severely inadequate, and in its current form will fail to protect either public health or the environment.

This controversial oil and gas development technique--in which drillers blast millions of gallons of chemically treated water into the earth to force gas from underground deposits--has been linked to air and water pollution and public health problems. In its current form, the proposal fails to stem these problems.

In its latest proposal, the BLM fails to propose adequate well construction and integrity standards. A key test to ensure drinking water sources are properly isolated from the well was dropped. Now a test to ensure proper cementing will be required on only one "type well" and the data from that well used to approve others. Such a procedure invites companies to develop one model well and then to cut corners on the rest. Industry should have to demonstrate the integrity of every well.

The draft requires companies to disclose chemical constituents in fracking fluids, after fracking is complete. Disclosure should occur both before and after fracking, in order to give nearby communities time to establish baseline water quality and then test and monitor water supplies for any fracking-related water pollution. States including Wyoming already require pre-fracking disclosure, so the BLM proposal should go at least this far.

The proposal also signals the use of FracFocus as the tool for disclosure. In its current form, FracFocus is insufficient. It's an industry-funded database that fails to allow users to search across forms or aggregate data from multiple wells. To ensure data is complete, adequate and available, the BLM should have its own website for this information reporting, complete with the ability to search and aggregate data.

The president promised in his State of the Union that this country's gas drilling boom would not come at the expense of public health. As it stands now, the proposed rule fails to meet that promise.
docketTitle: Oil and Gas; Hydraulic Fracturing on Federal and Indian Lands

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2013-13708
commentText:
To be delivered to: Sally Jewell, Secretary of the Interior and President Barack Obama

Please find 7,189 comments attached.

I am calling for a ban on fracking on all federal lands.

Californians deserve to have their public lands managed for the good of the people. These precious wilderness areas belong to us, not the oil and gas industry.

The Bureau of Land Management's proposed rules for regulated hydraulic fracturing on Federal and Native American lands are not only weak, but they do not take into account all the harmful processes required to frack for oil and gas.

Our forests are for hiking, not for fracking.

Born and raised in Los Angeles, I cherish the mountain ranges that surround me. Not only are they a gorgeous backdrop to my city, but they provide a unique way of life. I have fond memories of hiking with my family, cliff jumping into deep pools of icy water with friends, and taking long drives through the Angeles National Forest on the CA-2.

President Obama wants to increase fracking on federal public lands as part of his climate solution, but that plan would only create more problems.

In California, this would open up the Angeles National Forest, the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area, and the Los Padres National Forest to fracking, and could impact Kings Canyon National Park and Sequoia National Park. The fracking industry will destroy our roads and infrastructure, clear our forests and habitats, threaten wildlife and increase air pollution.

Hydraulic fracturing, or "fracking," injects millions of gallons of fracking fluids  a mixture of nearly 600 chemicals, water and sand  into a well to create pressure that cracks open rocks underground, releasing natural gas and oil.

Help protect California's national parks and open spaces from fracking.
docketTitle: Oil and Gas; Hydraulic Fracturing on Federal and Indian Lands

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2013-13708
commentText:
To: Sally Jewell, Secretary of the Interior and President Barack Obama

Attached please find 2185 comments on this proposed rule.

Fracking and unconventional gas and oil extraction is inherently dangerous, and cannot be regulated, and therefore should be banned on federal lands, and everywhere else. Toxic energy policies with catastrophic climate change implications have no place in our energy future!

The Obama Administration recently proposed new, woefully inadequate, rules for oil and gas fracking on federal lands managed by the Bureau of Land Management. By doing so, the BLM will pave the way for drillers to amass corporate profits at the expense of our American treasures and essential resources.

Stand with the people of New York in calling for a National Ban by signing this petition to submit comments under protest for drilling on public lands. No amount of rules will fix the industry's well-documented chronic well casing failures, nor mitigate the gross amount of chemicals, volatile organic compounds, or methane contamination in groundwater.

New Yorkers have long been embroiled in an epic struggle with the oil and gas industry, fighting for basic necessities and resources that are often repeatedly compromised by the drilling and fracking process such as clean water, air, and food, not to mention good health and a sustainable future. New Yorkers know that not only do we need to protect our pristine public lands by banning fracking in those areas, but we also need to protect all Americans from this dubious practice which involves the injecting of millions of gallons of water laced with toxic, cancer causing chemicals in order to shatter bedrock.

Studies show that the process of drilling, fracking, processing and transporting natural gas results in a tremendous amount of methane being released into the air. Methane is 70-100 times more potent than CO2 over a 20- year time frame. Recently published peer-reviewed studies on methane emissions show that, at present, gas extraction and combustion significantly contributes more greenhouse emissions than burning coal.

So not only is fracking dangerous, but the methane emissions from fracking accelerate climate change and spell disaster for our country.

The best way to protect our revered public lands and the rest of our country  including our air, water, food, health and climate - from fracking is to prohibit this inherently dangerous form of fossil fuel extraction entirely. This comment is submitted under protest the question isn't how we should be fracking, but if we should be doing it at all.
docketTitle: Oil and Gas; Hydraulic Fracturing on Federal and Indian Lands

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2013-13708
commentText:
To President Obama:

Please find 152 comments attached.

President Obama and the Bureau of Land Management: We will not stand idly by while private companies are allowed to pump our public lands full of chemicals that harm our health. We demand a complete ban on fracking for oil and gas on all public lands!

The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) is considering new regulations that would expand private companies' ability to drill and frack for oil and gas on public lands from coast to coast. We have until August 23rd, when the comment period ends, to join together and demand a ban on fracking on our public lands.

Fracking on public lands jeopardizes drinking water across the country  from Washington to West Virginia, from Montana to Florida. Each time a new well is fracked, tens of thousands of gallons of toxic chemicals, including known human carcinogens and endocrine disruptors, are pumped deep underground to force oil or natural gas to the surface.

Theres no un-contaminating our water supply. Nows the time for us to act  together.

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2013-13708
commentText:
To President Obama and the BLM:

Please find attached 85,579 comments to this proposed rule.

Here is just one comment, from Mary Russell of Carbondale, Colorado:

I am calling for an immediate ban on oil and gas fracking on all federal lands. The Bureau of Land Management's draft rules for fracking on public lands fail to protect the water we drink, the air we breathe, the climate we depend on, and the land many of us call home. This land is our land and should be managed for the good of the people, not corporate profits for the oil and gas industry. 

I recently sold my house in Glenwood Springs because it sits on the edge of the lower Roaring Fork River, threatened by possible hydraulic fracturing in the Thompson Divide. My property value has plummeted since the doubling of oil and gas development around my home in the past ten years. I've been diagnosed with asthma since moving into my home five years ago.

Since moving to Colorado in 1991, I've seen the public lands I used to swim, bike, hike, and backcountry ski closed to me. No longer can I hike in areas off of Mamm Creek or bike outside of Paonia due to gates erected to keep me out of the public lands my taxes support. I don't swim in the North Fork of the Gunnison for fear of water contamination from hydraulic fracturing in areas whose creeks feed this river. I used to lead my students through the back roads and trails of Grand Mesa, on skis, bikes, and on foot. The views were spectacular as we hiked the Crag Crest Trail or rode our bikes out to Lands End. Now, the fracking trucks along I-70 and the lights of hydraulic fracturing towers obscure our view.

As a DJ on my community public radio station, KDNK, in Carbondale, Colorado, I played Woodie Guthrie's song, "This Land is Your Land" on the 4th of July this year. I dedicated the song to all my listeners, and to all the politicians who have lost sight of what democracy means.

President Obama is about to issue his first major policy on fracking. The Bureau of Land Management has issued draft rules for fracking on 600 million acres of public and Indian lands, like those near me in Colorado. Unfortunately, these rules are straight out of the oil and gas industry's playbook. The provisions on disclosure of the toxic chemicals used in fracking were written by ExxonMobil and taken straight from model bills peddled by ALEC, the right-wing American Legislative Exchange Council. And the draft rules do nothing to protect watersheds that provide drinking water to millions of people.

We have until August 23 to submit our comments to the Bureau of Land Management, and on August 22, anti-fracking leaders will hand-deliver our comments to the BLM in Washington, D.C.
docketTitle: Oil and Gas; Hydraulic Fracturing on Federal and Indian Lands

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2013-13708
commentText:
To President Barack Obama and Secretary Sally Jewell:

Action to address climate change is desperately needed, but any real plan to combat climate change cannot include fracking for natural gas and oil as part of the solution. Drilling, fracking, and transporting gas and oil releases large amounts of methane, a potent greenhouse gas, into the air and contributes to climate change. We are asking you to stop promoting natural gas as a bridge fuel and to take action to ban fracking on all public lands. Natural gas is not clean - we need real renewable energy solutions now.

On June 25, President Obama delivered a major speech on climate change. While there was much to be applauded in the speech, a centerpiece of his plan relies on increased drilling and fracking for natural gas and oil. In fact, the President repeatedly lauded "cleaner" natural gas.

Studies show that the process of drilling, fracking, processing and transporting natural gas results in a tremendous amount of methane being released into the air. Methane is 70-100 times more potent than CO2 over a 20- year time frame. Some recently published studies on methane emissions show that burning natural gas may be even worse, in terms of the overall greenhouse gas footprint, than burning coal for electricity and burning fuel oil to heat homes or run industrial boilers. We need to get off of all fossil fuels now.

This summer, the Interior Department's Bureau of Land Management is accepting comments on a weak set of rules to regulate fracking on federal public lands. We need to tell them to ban fracking on public lands.

Fracking and drilling pollute our water, our air, and our communities but it also drives climate change. Tell President Obama that natural gas is a false solution and that we need to invest in real renewable energy solutions now.
docketTitle: Oil and Gas; Hydraulic Fracturing on Federal and Indian Lands

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2013-13708
commentText:
I am submitting the following comments on behalf of 3269 members of Public Citizen.  The attached document contains the names of said members and additional comments.

Thank you for your consideration,
Allison Fisher
Outreach Director, Public Citizen's Energy Program

Comments: Hydraulic Fracturing on Federal and Indian Lands

We are deeply concerned that Bureau of Land Managements new draft fracking rule is even weaker than the previous version. The regulations seem designed to encourage as much fracking as possible, while doing little to protect the environment or public health.

There are many egregious flaws in the BLMs revised draft fracking regulations:

They expand trade secrets loopholes and allow well operators to avoid disclosing use of dangerous fracking chemicals;

They only require oil and gas companies to report the chemicals used that are not claimed to be trade secrets  and only after fracking has already taken place;

They provide little regulatory protection for air, water and climate. The regulations do nothing to protect people living near fracked wells from air pollutants that increase risks of cancer and respiratory illness;

They do not protect residents from exposure or contamination by the large volume of toxic wastewater fracking produces;
    
There is no requirement to collect and disclose baseline data on air and water quality needed for effective regulation; and
The rules even ignore the advice of the Obama administration's advisory board.

The best way to protect our revered public lands and our air, water, health and climate from fracking is to prohibit this inherently dangerous form of fossil fuel extraction. Please ban fracking on public land.
docketTitle: Oil and Gas; Hydraulic Fracturing on Federal and Indian Lands

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2013-13708
commentText:
Re: Rulemaking/Docket No. BLM-2013-0002-0011

To Whom it May Concern: 

I am writing to deliver the public comments of 123,008 Americans who submitted public comments calling on the Bureau of Land Management to ban fracking on federal lands.

These comments have been collected by CREDO Action. Though the comments vary slightly from person to person, the majority read as follows: 

The Bureau of Land Management's draft fracking regulations are a disgrace. It's clear that the BLM caved to pressure from the fracking industry instead of standing up for Americans' right to drink clean water, breathe clean air, and live on a planet with a stable climate. Fracking is an inherently toxic practice that no amount of regulation can make safe. Moreover, with the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere passing 400 parts per million--well beyond what many scientists say is safe--any policy that allows fracking on federal lands to continue is dangerous and unacceptable. We demand an immediate ban on all shale oil and gas fracking on federal lands.

The comments are attached. This is 1 of 11 attachments. If you have any questions about these signatures, please dont hesitate to contact me through the information provided below.

Sincerely,
Zack Malitz
Campaign Manager, CREDO Action
415-369-2000

docketTitle: Oil and Gas; Hydraulic Fracturing on Federal and Indian Lands

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2013-13708
commentText:
I'm writing to urge you to keep fracking out of our national forests and away from our national parks. America's national parks are very important to me and my loved ones, yet the Bureau of Land Management's (BLM) proposed rules on fracking do very little to protect these important lands and the wildlife that reside in them from dirty drilling.

Across the country, we have already seen fracking contaminate drinking water and turn pristine landscapes into industrial zones. Why would we ever let such dirty drilling anywhere near the cornerstones of America's natural heritage?

Yet the oil and gas industry is already pursuing efforts to frack in areas that provide drinking water to millions of Americans, such as the George Washington National Forest, the Delaware River Basin, the White River National Forest, the Wayne National Forest and the Otero Mesa, home to the biggest untapped aquifier in New Mexico. 

If our national parks are not protected, the visitor experience for the millions of people who enjoy these national parks every year will be ruined. For instance, drillers have been vying to frack in Colorado's White River National Forest, which draws 9.2 million visitors per year who come to enjoy its impressive hiking and camping. 

I urge you to keep fracking away from our national parks and national forests. Let's protect America's natural heritage and the wildlife that call these places home safe for years to come.
docketTitle: Oil and Gas; Hydraulic Fracturing on Federal and Indian Lands

For instance, drillers have been vying to frack in Colorado's White River National Forest, which draws 9.2 million visitors per year who come to enjoy its impressive hiking and camping. 

I urge you to keep fracking away from our national parks and national forests. Let's protect America's natural heritage and the wildlife that call these places home safe for years to come.
docketTitle: Oil and Gas; Hydraulic Fracturing on Federal and Indian Lands

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2013-13708
commentText:
I'm writing to urge you to keep fracking out of our national forests and away from our national parks. America's national parks are very important to me and my loved ones, yet the Bureau of Land Management's (BLM) proposed rules on fracking do very little to protect these important lands and the wildlife that reside in them from dirty drilling.

Across the country, we have already seen fracking contaminate drinking water and turn pristine landscapes into industrial zones. Why would we ever let such dirty drilling anywhere near the cornerstones of America's natural heritage?

Yet the oil and gas industry is already pursuing efforts to frack in areas that provide drinking water to millions of Americans, such as the George Washington National Forest, the Delaware River Basin, the White River National Forest, the Wayne National Forest and the Otero Mesa, home to the biggest untapped aquifier in New Mexico. 

If our national parks are not protected, the visitor experience for the millions of people who enjoy these national parks every year will be ruined. For instance, drillers have been vying to frack in Colorado's White River National Forest, which draws 9.2 million visitors per year who come to enjoy its impressive hiking and camping. 

I urge you to keep fracking away from our national parks and national forests. Let's protect America's natural heritage and the wildlife that call these places home safe for years to come.
docketTitle: Oil and Gas; Hydraulic Fracturing on Federal and Indian Lands

title: Comments on Docket ID - BLM-2013-0002
docketTitle: Oil and Gas; Hydraulic Fracturing on Federal and Indian Lands

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2013-13708
commentText:
President Barack Obama and Secretary Sally Jewell:

Attached please find 59,407 comments to this proposed rule.

I am calling for a ban on fracking on all federal lands.

This land is our land and should be managed for the good of the people, not corporate profits for the oil and gas industry.

The Bureau of Land Management's proposed rules for regulating hydraulic fracturing on Federal and Indian lands are not only weak, but they do not take into account all of the harmful processes required to frack for oil and gas.

The best way to protect our air, water, wildlife, climate and public health is simply to prohibit this inherently dangerous form of fossil fuel extraction on public lands.
Petition Background

One of the things that makes America great is our vast and cherished spaces. Millions of acres across our beautiful country are public, but this land, and many of our favorite iconic landscapes, are under threat from fracking.

The Obama Administration recently proposed new rules for oil and gas fracking on federal lands managed by the Bureau of Land Management (BLM)  including those in the national forest system, and federal lands that are nearby many treasured national parks.

Fracking, defined as the combined process of drilling, fracturing, processing, disposing of waste and transporting oil and gas, has not been proven safe, yet fracking operation continue to be approved putting our public health and environment at risk.

The agency's mission is "to sustain the health, diversity, and productivity of America's public lands for the use and enjoyment of present and future generations." Fracking clearly conflicts with this mission. Sign the petition to ban fracking on public lands.
docketTitle: Oil and Gas; Hydraulic Fracturing on Federal and Indian Lands

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2013-13708
commentText:
I would like to submit these public comments on BLM's Proposed Federal Hydraulic Fracturing Rule on behalf of the National Wildlife Federation.  I have attached an excel spreadsheet with all of the comments that our members submitted on the proposed rule.  

A total of 1,208 people submitted comments on the Hydraulic Fracturing Rule. I have sorted the spread sheet so that the unique comments are at the top, and the form comments are sorted to the bottom. The first 116 rows contain people who submitted unique comments, and the remaining 1,092 people submitted the form comments below:

"I support the Bureau of Land Management's decision to update its regulations governing hydraulic fracturing operations on federal lands. The public lands are a unique trust and the Bureau of Land Management has a special responsibility to ensure conservation of other resources, including fish, wildlife, and water.  To fulfill that responsibility, new fracking regulations must provide full disclosure of chemicals prior to any drilling as well as adequate safety measures to prevent contamination of both ground and surface waters.  I support Bureau of Land Management's decision to improve the underground cement casings to prevent the release of fracking fluids and urge the Bureau of Land Management to require closed-looped containment of fluids above ground to eliminate open waste pits."
 
Thank you for this opportunity to submit public comments on the BLM's Proposed Federal Hydraulic Fracturing Rule. Please contact me with any comments or questions.

Best,

Whitney Coombs

Online Advocacy and Outreach Coordinator
National Wildlife Federation
Rocky Mountain Regional Center
2995 Baseline Rd, Suite 300
Boulder, CO 80303
(303) 441-5162
CoombsW@nwf.org

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
Petition to the US Fish & Wildlife Service
Submitted as public comments on: 80 FR 45154, "Endangered and Threatened Wildlife and Plants; Revision of the Section 4(d) Rule for the African Elephant (Loxodonta africana)," Proposed Rule, 29 July 2015 
(Document ID FWS-HQ-IA-2013-0091)

On behalf of 1,013,942 concerned WWF Supporters 

I commend the US Fish and Wildlife Service and the Obama administration for such a firm commitment to end the devastating slaughter of elephants for their ivory and to ensure that the United States is not helping to drive the illegal wildlife trade.

Along with 80% of the American people, I strongly support ending commercial trade in elephant ivory in the US. I believe we must take all necessary steps to protect these magnificent creatures from extinction.

Fewer than half a million elephants remain in Africa's savannas and jungles--a 95% plunge over the last 50 years. Recently, the killing has surged: Poachers are slaughtering on average one elephant every 15 minutes, and some populations are now on a path to extinction.

Reports from US intelligence agencies and the UN also show that profits from ivory trafficking are fueling crime, corruption and violence in fragile African democracies and financing organizations that threaten both American and African security.

America's role in the consumption and sale of ivory makes us complicit in this crisis and weakens our moral authority to lead internationally. The US is the world's second-largest market for wildlife products, and significant amounts of illegal elephant ivory have been found entering the American market. We must strengthen our laws to prevent this from happening and to encourage other countries to act with similar urgency.

I thank you and others in the administration, including the president himself, for your unprecedented leadership on this issue. Combined with new US efforts to combat wildlife trafficking, the ivory rules proposed by the US Fish and Wildlife Service can help turn the tide for Africa's elephants.

I share the American public's desire to halt the US role in the illegal ivory trade, and I believe that the decision to halt elephant ivory commerce in the US is the right response to the current crisis.

For the sake of the world's elephants, I urge you to keep that promise.
docketTitle: Revision of the Special Rule for the African Elephant

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
September 28, 2015

Public Comments Processing, Attn: FWS-HQ-IA-2013-0091
Division of Policy, Performance, and Management Programs
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
5275 Leesburg Pike, MS: BPHC
Falls Church, VA 22041

Re: Comments on the African Elephant Special Rule Amendment; Docket No. FWS-HQ-IA-2013-0091

Dear Chief Hoover,

Please find attached, 38,395 comments submitted by NRDC online activists regarding the Obama Administrations Proposed Rule revising the Section 4(d) Rule for the African Elephant (Loxodonta africana) contained at 80 Fed. Reg. 45154 (July 29, 2015). 

We deeply appreciate the Services commitment to elephant conservation and urge the Service to move quickly to strengthen and finalize these new protections. With 30,000 elephants being killed every year for their ivory tusks, the Administration must act swiftly to close the final loopholes in federal laws that have allowed ivory trafficking to flourish. 

If you have any questions, please feel free to contact me at (202) 717-8193. 

Thank you. 

Sincerely,
 
Elly Pepper
Wildlife Advocate
Natural Resources Defense Council
docketTitle: Revision of the Special Rule for the African Elephant

title: Comment Submitted by Florida Residents (704 Submissions)
commentText:
704 Flordia residents tell the CFPB

The CFPB must not let debt trap payday lenders continue business as usual. The proposal doesnt go far enough to ensure that someone can repay the loan and have enough money to live on. Also, the proposal requires only that the payday lender not have default rates worse than other payday lenders. These business as usual loopholes allow payday lenders to say that their ability to seize money from a borrowers bank account is the same as the borrowers ability to afford the loan. This is unacceptable. The CFPB must close these loopholes to stop the debt trap. Attention to the comment section.
docketTitle: Payday, Vehicle, Title and Certain High-Cost Installment Loans

title: Comments Submitted by Fiona Cahill, Stop The Debt Trap Coalition (8,960 submissions)
commentText:
8,960 comments on Docket No. CFPB-2016-0025, in support of regulating payday loans. Attached is a file with the 8,960 names in support: 

"People should have enough money to live on after making a payment on loan. This means being able to afford both the loan payment and the light bill, not one or the other. Additionally, everyone should be able to make payments without reborrowing or defaulting on other expenses. 

"The proposed rule doesn't go far enough: it leaves too much room for lenders to game the system and continue to make unaffordable loans. The rule must provide more objective measures for how lenders document expenses so that every loan can be affordably repaid."
docketTitle: Payday, Vehicle, Title and Certain High-Cost Installment Loans

title: Comments Submitted by Fiona Cahill, Stop The Debt Trap Coalition (8,502 submissions)
commentText:
Attached are 8,502 comments from individuals in support of regulating payday loans as outlined in Docket No. CFPB-2016-0025:

"The average borrower takes out 10 loans and pays 391% in interest and fees. 75% of the payday industry's revenues are generated by these repeat borrowers. The debt trap is, in fact, the payday lending business model. I support the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's plan to rein in the worst payday lending abuses."
docketTitle: Payday, Vehicle, Title and Certain High-Cost Installment Loans

title: Multiple Comments Submitted by Murshed Zaheed, CREDO Action (45,342 Signatures)
commentText:
Monica Jackson
Office of the Executive Secretary, CFPB
1700 G Street NW.
Washington, DC 20552

RE: Docket ID:CFPB-2016-0026, Payday Loans

Dear Ms. Jackson,

Attached please find 45,342 individual public comments collected online by CREDO Action for submission to the comment period on the proposed payday lending regulations. Individual comments may differ throughout, although the majority read as follows: 

"The proposed payday lending rule is a major step forward but should be strengthened to better protect American consumers from predatory lenders. The CFPB should apply ability-to-repay requirements to every loan, limit total indebtedness, increase protections against loan flipping, and broaden the rule to cover any loan that enables lenders to coerce repayment from borrowers."

Comments have been separated into 12 separate PDFs to accommodate the delivery. 

Please contact me if you have any questions about the attached comment submissions. Thank you.

Sincerely, 

Murshed Zaheed
Political Director, CREDO Action 
mzaheed@credoaction.com 
415-369-2000
docketTitle: Payday, Vehicle, Title and Certain High-Cost Installment Loans

title: Mass Mail Campaign 16: Comment Submitted by Kayla Gillespie, Total as of 8/23/2017: 68235
commentText: A single unaffordable payday loan is one loan too many. The proposed rule gives a "free pass" to payday lenders to make six bad loans, allowing lenders to sink people into a dangerous debt trap before the rule kicks in. The CFPB was right to base their proposal on the standard that borrowers should be able to repay their loan, but that standard must be on every loan, from the first loan. The CFPB should also enact protections to prevent lenders from stringing people along by ensuring a 60 day break between loans and limiting 'short term' loans to 90 total days of indebtedness per year.
docketTitle: Payday, Vehicle, Title and Certain High-Cost Installment Loans

title: Mass Mail Campaign 27: Comment Submitted by Daryl Worley, Total as of 9/12/2016: 446
commentText: Please do not limit my financial rights.
docketTitle: Payday, Vehicle, Title and Certain High-Cost Installment Loans

title: Mass Mail Campaign 38: Comment Submitted by Michael King, Advance Financial, Total as of 9/4/2016: 232
commentText: I pay all my bills at a loan store. If you close the loan stores I will lose my services too. Our communities need these stores. Banks don't want to help us. Please don't take way these loans.
docketTitle: Payday, Vehicle, Title and Certain High-Cost Installment Loans

title: Mass Mail Campaign 66: Comment Submitted by Tammy Ellis, Total as of 9/4/2016: 257
commentText: These payday loans can make a huge difference in the lives of many of us who sometimes rely on them to cover unexpected costs.  As long as we agree to the terms and have the ability to pay it back, the government should stay out of it.  The consumer should be able to decide for themselves.
docketTitle: Payday, Vehicle, Title and Certain High-Cost Installment Loans

title: Mass Mail Campaign 37:  Comment Submitted by Karem McDonald, Total as of 9/4/2016: 185
commentText: The government should not be making it more difficult for hard working people to get short-term credit.  For some of us, a payday loan may be the only alternative we have.  The consequences of not being able to obtain this money can have long term negative effects to my household finances.
docketTitle: Payday, Vehicle, Title and Certain High-Cost Installment Loans

title: Mass Mail Campaign 188: Comment Submitted by Karen Darnall (Total as of 9/26/2016: 723)
commentText:
I appreciate the opportunity to comment on the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's ("CFPB") proposed rule entitled "Payday, Vehicle Title, and Certain High-Cost Installment Loans", which is Docket No. CFPB-2016-0025.  The proposal takes important steps to curb payday lending and other predatory and abusive lending practices.  That effort should be commended.  

However, I am writing to express my concerns with the anticipated impact this proposal will have on the customers of Louisiana banks and other federally insured depository institutions.

In remarks at a field hearing on the proposed rule in Kansas City, MO on June 2, CFPB Director Richard Cordray was quoted as saying:  "In particular, we are not intending to disrupt existing lending by community banks and credit unions that have found efficient and effective ways to make small-dollar loans to consumers that do not lead to debt traps or high rates of failure.  Indeed, we want to encourage other lenders to follow their model."

My concern is that the current proposal, if unchanged, will do exactly what Director Cordray said the rule is not intended to do:  that is, disrupt small-dollar lending by these federally insured depository institutions.
  
The requirements of this proposed rule are overly complex and prescriptive, and inconsistent with how depository institutions with a relationship with their customer underwrite small-dollar loans.  If finalized in its current form, the additional compliance costs and regulatory risk posed by this proposal could reduce or eliminate many small-dollar loan products offered by depository institutions.  That result would significantly harm consumers by reducing much needed small-dollar credit options.   

Unlike payday lenders and vehicle title lenders, federally insured depository institutions are already heavily regulated at both the state and federal level, and routinely examined for compliance with state and federal lending and consumer protection laws.  I am not aware of deficiencies in the current regulatory framework for federally insured depository institutions that would warrant additional regulation in the small-dollar loan area, nor am I aware of any compelling arguments that the small-dollar loans being offered by such depository institutions are bad options for consumers.  Therefore, subjecting federally insured depository institutions to the additional regulation contained in this proposal is not necessary or appropriate. 

Finally, my understanding is that Section 1022 of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act of 2010 gave CFPB certain authority to exempt from its regulatory requirements any class of covered persons, service providers, or consumer financial products or services.  Director Cordray recently commented on the CFPB's exemption authority in a letter dated August 17 that he sent to 70 U.S. Senators.  In his letter, Director Cordray also gave examples of CFPB's previous use of that authority to tailor its regulations.  His letter was in response to a letter sent by the U.S. Senators on July 18 requesting "that the CFPB carefully tailor its regulations to match the unique nature of community banks and credit unions."  

Based on my above comments, I respectfully urge the CFPB to exercise its exemption authority in order to exempt all federally insured depository institutions from the provisions of this proposed rule.

Thanks for your consideration of my comments.
docketTitle: Payday, Vehicle, Title and Certain High-Cost Installment Loans

organization: Helping Hands Ministry of Belton, Inc.
title: Comments Submitted by Rucker Preston, Helping Hands Ministry of Belton, Inc.
commentText:
Director Cordray,

Thank you for the opportunity to comment on the CFPB's proposed rule that was announced in June. I am the Executive Director of Helping Hands Ministry of Belton, a non-profit, human service organization that serves low-income families with relief, development, and advocacy opportunities. In the first comment letter that is attached, I speak on behalf of Helping Hands Ministry of Belton, Inc. I will share with you why the board of directors and this organization as a whole feels that it is important for the CFPB to enact and enforce strong rules that protect the most financially vulnerable people in our country. 

Additionally, you will find documents with comments from 520 other people our community who feel that the CFPB needs to put forward a strong federal law to protect the most financially vulnerable people in our country.

In particular, please pay attention to the section in the comment letter by Helping Hands Ministry about Henry Montelongo and his comment in a separate comment. He tells his story about how he felt pressured to sign a letter from a short-term lender, stating that any regulations enforced upon the payday & auto title loan industry by the CFPB would be absurd. He says in his comment that this is opposite to his feelings and experience, however, he was scared not to sign the letter. He believed that this vehicle would have been repossessed if he did not sign the letter, which states that the CFPB should not regulate this type of practice.

In these comments, you will hear about how our organization became deeply affected by the short-term, high-cost loan industry, borrower testimonies, and recommendations for the proposed rule. 

As someone who has been deeply invested in payday lending reform for the past two years, I want to thank you for thoughtfully crafting a rule to protect consumers against the predatory practices of payday and auto title businesses. But I'd like to encourage you to add a few extra measures to make the rule even stronger.

In short, my recommendations are:

1.	Ensure that every loan has a realistic ability-to-repay standard applied to it.

2.	Look more closely at long-term loans, and ensure that the terms of these loans are affordable.

3.	Strengthen protections against loan flipping.
   a.	Loans should have a minimum 60 day cooling off period.
   b.	Stronger protections against repeat refinancing of longer-term loans are necessary.

4.	Ensure that the proposed rule apply to both Credit Service Organizations (CSOs) and Credit Access Businesses (CABs).

5.	Ensure that definitions in the rule are clear, and that they encompass state laws as well as local ordinances.
   a.	Specifically, these terms ought to be defined: rollover, refinance, renewal, payment, installment

Director Cordray, thank you again for the extremely hard work you and your staff have done in crafting this rule. Thank you for the opportunity to comment in favor of the proposed rule. I will celebrate the day when effective protections ensure that more vulnerable consumers are protected from unjust lending practices, and I am confident in your ability to bring about that change. I am grateful for your work.

With gratefulness,

Rucker L. Preston
Executive Director
Helping Hands Ministry of Belton, Inc.
docketTitle: Payday, Vehicle, Title and Certain High-Cost Installment Loans

title: Comment Submitted by Jack Shapiro, Organizing for Action
commentText:
Hello,

Please see attached 22,595 comments from Organizing for Action members in support of strong standards for payday lenders. The comment is as follows:

"Payday lending and other short-term high-cost loans can trap people in debt they can't escape. These debt trap loans can be devastating, some charging the equivalent of a 300 percent annual interest rate. That's unacceptable. I support strong standards with no loopholes that will prevent lenders from making loans that borrowers can't repay and from trapping borrowers in long-term cycles of debt."

Thanks,

Jack
docketTitle: Payday, Vehicle, Title and Certain High-Cost Installment Loans

title: Comments Submitted by Fiona Cahill, Stop The Debt Trap Coalition (23,295 submissions)
commentText:
Attached are 23,295 comments from individuals in support of regulating payday loans as outlined in Docket No. CFPB-2016-0025:

"I support the CFPB's effort to stop the debt trap. Payday lenders create a debt trap that locks millions of Americans into a cycle of poverty they can't escape. Unaffordable payday loans cause borrowers to default on other bills and can lead to harms such as overdraft fees and even bankruptcy. Lenders must be required to ensure that every loan, regardless of duration or type, be able to be paid back affordably with enough money left over to cover normal expenses. The CFPB must protect families and ensure that money stays in their hands - not in the pockets of payday loan sharks."
docketTitle: Payday, Vehicle, Title and Certain High-Cost Installment Loans

title: Comments Submitted by Fiona Cahill, Stop The Debt Trap Coalition (53,278 submissions)
commentText:
53,278 comments on Docket No. CFPB-2016-0025, in support of the CFPB's proposed rule to regulate payday lenders. Attached is the file of 53,278 names in support:

"Payday lenders purposefully ensnare people in debt they can't escape. These legalized loan sharks collect 75 percent of their fees from people stuck in more than 10 loans a year by charging 300 percent APR. It's a debt trap. I support the proposed rule to worst payday lending abuses from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau."

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by TakePart.com (web)
commentText:
To: Environmental Protection Agency

I urge you to finalize the Army Corps of Engineers and Environmental Protection Agency's proposed Clean Water Act, Waters of the U.S. rule, as soon as possible, follow the science that shows how water bodies are interconnected, and fully protect all of the waterways that have important connections to one another.

Basic clean water protections for headwater streams and wetlands have been in question for too long. I strongly support protecting the nation's streams, ponds, wetlands, and other waters from pollution. The proposed rule is an important step toward achieving this goal. Preserving our sources of clean drinking water is of the utmost importance. Finalizing a strong rule will secure Clean Water Act protections for countless streams and wetlands, which help supply the drinking water of more than 117 million Americans.

The rule as proposed is a major improvement. I urge you to further strengthen the final rule to fully protect wetlands and other waters found outside the floodplain of covered waterways. Science shows that the health of these waters influences stream flow, water quality, and wildlife in waters downstream.

I urge you to continue to stand up to special interests that oppose these importantand popularclean water protections.

EPA has already received more than 100,000 letters in support of moving forward with this rule to protect streams, wetlands, rivers, and other waters from pollution or destruction. Hunting and angling organizations, public health professionals, and hundreds more local elected officials, farmers, citizens, brewers, and other business leaders have spoken out in support of enhanced protections.As one of the many supporters of this critical initiative to protect our waters from pollution, I thank you and urge you to finalize a strong Waters of the U.S. rule that includes full protection for the nation's waters as soon as possible.

Sincerely,

[10,813 individuals who electronically signed this letter on TakePart.com are listed in the attached document]
docketTitle: Definition of "Waters of the United States" Under the Clean Water Act

title: Mass comment campaign submitted by Rural Coalition et al. (web)
commentText:
For more information contact:  Lorette Picciano, Executive Director of Rural Coalition, (202) 628-7160, lpicciano@ruralco.org or Rudy Arredondo, President of National Latino Farmers and Ranchers Trade Association, (202) 628-1440, hola_5@hotmail.com.

November 14, 2014

Administrator Gina McCarthy
Environmental Protection Agency
1200 Pennsylvania Avenue, N.W.
Washington, DC 20460
 
Re: Revised Definition of Waters of the United States under the Clean Water Act (CWA)
 	
Dear Administrator McCarthy,
 
We, the 106 undersigned organizations, who use and depend on our rivers systems from the headwaters, wetlands and tributaries to floodplains and bays, call on you to put the Clean Water Act (CWA) back to work on all U.S. waters.  We join our diverse voices with the farmers, ranchers, and other rural leaders quoted herein and undersigned, in a joint call to EPA to restore clarity by approving a final Waters of the USA rule. 

We support the rule for the reasons Mr. Alfonzo Abeyta, a fifth generation Colorado ranch-er, highlights in a new video on why restoring CWA  protection is important for agriculture and rural communities:   Farmers know that everything is connected. Snow from the moun-tains feeds the streams. The streams feed the rivers. The rivers feed us. You cant grow food without water without water nothing survives it is our job to protect it.  (http://www.rmfu.org/colorado-farmer-r-e-m-featured-in-waters-of-the-u-s-video/)

We support the Clean Water Act because it has worked in every state improving water quality, stemming the loss of wetlands and safeguarding streams, lakes and wetlands.  That is, it worked until two Supreme Court decisionsSolid Waste Agency of Northern Cook County (SWANCC) v. Army Corps of Engineers (2001) and Rapanos v. United States (2006)created uncertainty regarding what waters are protected, and curtailed CWAs scope. 

Water is the lifeblood for agriculture, small businesses and recreation.  We dont want to go back to the day when two-thirds of our waterways were too polluted for fishing, swimming or drinking.  Therefore those of us in rural communities, agriculture and other small busi-ness need the full protection of the Clean Water Act restored to the countless miles of tribu-tary and seasonal streams, wetlands and rivers that sustain our communities.  
Communities need a strong CWA to address severe and continuing threats like chemicals from mining operations that leaked arsenic into the Alamosa River in Colorado, killing all the fish and compromising the water supply; the arsenic, boron, chromium, and manganese from coal ash, dumped for years into the Dan River by Duke Energy, exceeding the facility's "compliance boundary and polluting rural water supplies; as well as the tides of phospho-rus washed from fertilized farms, cattle feedlots and leaky septic systems upstream that contributed to an algae bloom in Lake Erie which compromised water sources for the cities. We are concerned about the growing contamination in many areas that leaves waterways still too polluted to sustain agriculture, recreation and many other uses.

As producers and others who depend on clean water, we know well that how water is cared for upstream affects river systems downstream. Small streams feed our local sources of drinking water and support traditional irrigation systems and agriculture for tribal, acequia, historic land grant and our diverse farming communities.  Wetlands protect our communities from flooding, and support fish, wildlife, livestock and recreation. The entire river system provides drinking water sources in rural areas and cities alike, and is vital to small businesses  as well. 

We support the rule because we recognize our shared responsibility to protect our entire river systems including the streams and wetlands that nourish the riversfor fishing, boating, recreation, flood control, local water systems and to meet the needs of our com-munities, our farmers, ranches and fishers, our businesses, and protect these bioregions for future generations.  
Many of the undersigned groups have submitted their own comments supporting the com-pletion of the rulemaking process while proposing specific and beneficial improvements.  We believe EPA should take these views into account in issuing the final rule.  

As farmers and small businesses that share the water, we need a regulatory scheme that is clear, predictable, timely, and focused on protecting aquatic resources.  We support the rules exemptions for commonplace farm and ranch operations and incentives for volun-tary conservation practices. We also urge EPA and NRCS to review and retain all of the ex-emptions and exclusions from the Clean Water Act for the farming and agriculture commu-nity including exempting them from the need to obtain a 404 permit when using any of 56 conservation practices  practices that are good for farmers, ranchers, and for clean water.
docketTitle: Definition of "Waters of the United States" Under the Clean Water Act

title: Mass Comment Campaign Sponsored by National Wildlife Federation (NWF) (Web)
commentText:
Please accept the following comments on behalf of the 418 National Wildlife Federation supporters whose names are in the attached sheet. Each person signed comments at local events that are as follows:

Dear Administrator McCarthy:

Thank you for proposing the Clean Water Rule that will restore and clarify the Waters of the United States safeguarded by the Clean Water Act. I support the proposed rules protections for headwater streams and wetlands, and urge you to take additional steps in the final rule to restore protections for prairie potholes and other important waters. 

These protections are vital for the survival of many fish and wildlife species that depend on wetlands and pure, clean streams for their habitat. They are also essential to protecting the drinking water for 117 million Americans.

Thank you again for taking this important first step to protect Americas waters.
docketTitle: Definition of "Waters of the United States" Under the Clean Water Act

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Committee For A Constructive Tomorrow (CFACT) (web)
commentText:
CFACT, Committee For A Constructive Tomorrow

On proposed rule redefining the Waters of the United States pursuant to the Clean Water Act:

"Ditch the rule!"

Statement To President Barack Obama, EPA and the Army Corps of Engineers:

The proposed rule represents an expansion of federal regulatory authority beyond the language and intent adopted by Congress in the Clean Water Act.

The Supreme Court twice rejected attempts by regulators to assert authority over isolated waters ruling that waters must have a a continuous surface connection" or significant nexus to navigable waters. 

Congress repeatedly voted not to adopt policies similar to those in the proposed rule. If the rule is adopted it usurps congressional authority. 

The proposed rule would bring vast amounts of land under federal control adding unnecessary and redundant red tape to areas currently adequately regulated by state and local governments.

EPA's cost-benefit analysis is deeply flawed, employing decades old cost estimates that were not adjusted for inflation, or current economic and market conditions.

We, the undersigned, declare that the proposed rule will place undue regulatory burdens and limitations on people attempting to responsibly use their land, adds new regulatory dead weight to the economy and would produce no meaningful gains for the environment or the nation and should not be promulgated.


See attached file containing the above statement signed by 62,882 concerned individuals.
docketTitle: Definition of "Waters of the United States" Under the Clean Water Act

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Organic Consumers Association (web)
commentText:
To: EPA Administrator, Gina McCarthy

Re: Docket ID: EPA-HQ-OW-2011-0880

I am deeply concerned about protecting our drinking water. I support the Waters of the U.S. rulemaking currently underway by the US EPA and the Corps of Engineers. I believe this rulemaking will clear up confusion surrounding the implementation of clean water programs.

The longstanding confusion has allowed many previously protected waters from having adequate protection, leaving drinking water supplies for one-third of Americans at risk.

The proposed rule addresses the massive growth of expansive factory farms while keeping in place the exemptions for normal farming and ranching activities, such as plowing, seeding, harvesting, construction of stock ponds and irrigation ditches.

Thank you for considering my comments in support of the Waters of the U.S. rulemaking. I urge the US EPA and the Corps of Engineer to move forward as quickly as possible to finalize these rules clarifying the protections offered under the Clean Water Act.

Sincerely,

Please see attached file of 12,294 Organic Consumers Association members who signed this petition, including 1,680 who added their own comments.
docketTitle: Definition of "Waters of the United States" Under the Clean Water Act

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Banning Ranch Conservancy (web)
commentText:
To the EPA and ACOE:

Attached is a letter commenting on the new rules concerning Waters of the United States.  The letter is from the Banning Ranch Conservancy, a non-profit land conservancy working on open space issues at Banning Ranch, in Orange County, California.

Also attached is the same letter with 201 co-signers.  We posted our letter on line and gathered the 200 signatures in a few short days.

Thank you,

Terry Welsh, M.D.
President, Banning Ranch Conservancy.
