title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by VoteVets
commentText:
Hello - 

Please find attached the names of 50,456 veterans, military family members, and VoteVets supporters advocating for a strong Renewable Fuel Standard.

Here is the comment they have added their names to: 

Please preserve a strong Renewable Fuel Standard and increase America's 2017 biofuel targets to the statutory levels called for by Congress. Weaker targets for domestic biofuels threaten the economic, environmental and energy security benefits of America's most successful energy policy.
 
As veterans, military families and VoteVets supporters, we know the cost of America's dependence on foreign oil. We cannot afford to become complacent about shielding our country against the next spike in oil prices or crisis in the Middle East.
 
By protecting America's domestic energy producers from manipulation by foreign cartels, this simple policy has started a revolution that drives billions of dollars of economic activity across the U.S. and supports more than 852,000 American jobs.
 
More than that, investing in cleaner-burning, American-made energy saves consumers money at the pump and reduces emissions.
 
Don't allow special interests to set America down the wrong path. Strengthen the Renewable Fuel Standard, and keep our country on the road to true energy security. .
 
Thank you,
docketTitle: Renewable Fuel Standard Program: Standards for 2017 and Biomass-Based Diesel Volume for 2018

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by National Corn Growers Association (web)
commentText:
I am writing in response to your proposal to reduce the use of ethanol in the Renewable Fuel Standard.  

Biofuels provide a clean, renewable alternative to oil, allowing us to decarbonize transportation fuels, reducing the need for more drilling and fracking that pollutes our water, air and pristine habitats. 

On average, corn ethanol reduces CO2 emissions by 34 percent and advanced biofuels can reduce emissions by 100 percent or more over gasoline.  Globally, ethanol has reduced greenhouse gas emissions by 110 million metric tons - the equivalent of taking more than 20 million vehicles off the road.

Biofuels displace cancer-causing gasoline additives like benzene, the same chemicals found in cigarette smoke. These dangerous additives have also been linked to asthma and drinking water contamination.

I strongly urge you to fully implement the Renewable Fuel Standard as passed by Congress.

Thousands of unique advocates who support this comment are attached with their individual Names, Email Addresses, Addresses, and IPs.
docketTitle: Renewable Fuel Standard Program: Standards for 2017 and Biomass-Based Diesel Volume for 2018

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by National Corn Growers Association (NCGA) (web)
commentText:
I am writing in response to your proposal to reduce the use of ethanol in the Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS).  I believe that a fully realized RFS that a bipartisan congress passed will put money back in the pockets of hard-working Americans. As result of the RFS, ethanol is now blended in 97 percent of our gas supply and has helped to reduce gasoline prices by as much as $.50 to $1.50 a gallon.
 
The RFS drives billions of dollars of economic activity across the U.S., starting with farmers and rural communities. The ethanol industry supports nearly 400,000 jobs and contributes nearly $52 billion to our Gross Domestic Product. The bottom line is that the RFS creates jobs, empowers struggling rural communities and is saving consumers at the pump. I strongly urge you to fully implement the Renewable Fuel Standard as passed by Congress.

Thousands of advocates who agree with these statements are attached with unique email and IP addresses.
docketTitle: Renewable Fuel Standard Program: Standards for 2017 and Biomass-Based Diesel Volume for 2018

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by National Wildlife Federation Action Fund (web)
commentText:
Attached are 22,347 comments from National Wildlife Federation Action Fund supporters urging the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency to defend, not destroy monarch butterfly habitat.

There are 524 unique comments. 21,843 comments request the following:

"To protect vulnerable populations of monarchs and other wildlife that depend on native grasslands, I ask that your agency acknowledge the severe environmental impacts of corn ethanol production and adjust your final Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS) mandate downward.

Native grasslands are disappearing at an alarming rate, along with the monarch butterfly and other wildlife species that depend on them. Studies show the RFS increases demand for corn, contributing to the conversion of millions of acres. Please defend, don't destroy habitat for monarchs and many other species. Reduce the mandate for corn ethanol, don't increase it. 

Additionally, I ask that EPA implement the land conversion protections contained in the law. The RFS includes protections against converting untilled lands for biofuel production. Yet EPA has not implemented this provision as Congress intended. Given the threats to remaining grasslands and the steep declines of monarchs and other wildlife, the land-clearing provision must be enforced to fully protects these critically important habitats.

These two actions together would put us on a better path to meeting our goals for cleaner fuel that does not make it harder to bring monarchs back from the brink. Thank you."


Thank you.
docketTitle: Renewable Fuel Standard Program: Standards for 2017 and Biomass-Based Diesel Volume for 2018

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Greenpeace (4685)
commentText:
Thank you for proposing the long overdue rule that would enforce the
clean air act's modern health standards.  This rule will help to
protect my family and community from the mercury emitted from
coal-fired power plants.  As many as 1 in 6 American women of
childbearing age have enough mercury in their bodies to put their baby
at risk of mercury poisoning, which causes brain damage, learning
disabilities, and birth defects.  Please adopt the strongest possible
protections from mercury and other toxic air pollution emitted from
coal fired power plants.
docketTitle: National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants for Coal- and Oil-fired Electric Utility Steam Generating Units

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Earthjustice (8,704)
commentText:
8,704 individuals (attached) have submitted the following comment:

Every year, power plants release more than 386,000 tons of toxic air pollutants into the air we breathe. These emissions -- which aren't subject to any federal limits to protect our health and safety -- impose a heavy burden on Americans in the form of cancer, heart and lung disease, and thousands of premature deaths every year. The technology to reduce these costly emissions is available and affordable, and I strongly support the EPA's Power Plant Mercury and Air Toxics Standards, which will make our air safer to breathe by requiring that power plants use these proven methods of pollution control to limit their harmful emissions.

In the coming months, I urge you to resist any efforts to weaken or delay your recent proposal to limit power plants' emissions of mercury, lead, arsenic, dioxin, acid gases and other toxic pollutants. The power plant industry has already used its financial and political influence to avoid these important health protections for more than two decades. We cannot wait any longer.

Power plants pump more mercury into our air than all other big industrial polluters combined. Mercury pollution damages aquatic ecosystems and contaminates fish species that many Americans rely on for recreation and nourishment. Pregnant women and young children are most at risk: mercury exposure can lead to birth defects and learning disabilities and can also irreparably impact a young child's ability to talk, think, read, write and learn. It is critically important that we protect these vulnerable members of our society from harm. 

The Power Plant Mercury and Air Toxics Standards will prevent up to 17,000 premature deaths every year and spare many more Americans the physical and financial costs associated with illnesses brought on by breathing dirty air. These benefits to our society should be non-negotiable, considering especially that they outweigh the costs to polluters by as much as 13-to-1.
docketTitle: National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants for Coal- and Oil-fired Electric Utility Steam Generating Units

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Sierra Club (9440)
commentText:
Dear Administrator Jackson:

Please accept the attached 9,440 public comments in support of the long-overdue proposed Mercury and Air Toxics Standard to protect our nations communities from the threats of toxic air pollution produced by power plants. 

Each of the persons listed in the attached file filled out individual postcards with the following message to you: 

ATTN: Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0234

"Dear Administrator Jackson, 

Thank you for proposing long-overdue Clean Air Act standards to protect our nations communities from the threats of toxic air pollution produced by power plants. Power plants are the largest source of toxic air emissions in the United States, and yet no national standards exist to protect communities from the toxic air pollution from these sources.

Power plants emit some of the most hazardous pollutants known to us. In addition to mercury and arsenic, power plants emit lead, other heavy metals, dioxin and acid gases. Even in small amounts these extremely harmful air pollutants are linked to health problems such as cancer, heart disease, brain damage, birth defects, asthma attacks and even premature death.

Without strong protections, thousands of people will continue to suffer. The EPA needs to adopt the strongest air toxics protections possible and stand its ground against industry pressure to weaken the proposed standards. Please continue to defend public health and protect our communities and children from mercury and other toxic air pollution."

Thank you for the opportunity to share these comments with you today.
docketTitle: National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants for Coal- and Oil-fired Electric Utility Steam Generating Units

docketTitle: Waters of the United States  Reinstatement of Preexisting Rules

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Clean Water Action (Web)
commentText:
RE: Docket ID Number EPA-HQ-OW-2017-0203: Comments on Definition of Waters of the United StatesRecodification of Preexisting Rule, Federal Register, Vol. 83, No. 134 (July 12, 2018)

Dear Acting Administrator Wheeler and Assistant Secretary James,

Please find attached 4,595 comments from Clean Water Action members opposed to the reckless plan to repeal the 2015 Clean Water Rule. These are in addition to thousands of other postcards and letters from Clean Water Action members that have been submitted separately. These letters not only urge the Environmental Protection Agency and the Army Corps of Engineers to drop the scheme to wipe out these common sense protections for our water, they also urge the agencies to abandon the scheme to permanently weaken safeguards with a new rulemaking. 

The Administrations latest attempt to justify its proposal to repeal the Clean Water Rule lacks merit. Last year the agencies received 685,000 comments on its original notice of proposed rulemaking to repeal the Clean Water Rule (dated July 27, 2017) and nearly half a million of those comments were in strong opposition to this plan. The new legal theories offered by the Administration in this supplemental notice are weak at best and ignore the overwhelming scientific evidence that protecting small streams and wetlands is essential to ensuring water quality in downstream rivers and larger water bodies. The 2015 Clean Water Rule creates more certainty, not less, regarding which water resources are federally protected, and is legally and scientifically sound.

These thousands of members represent many thousands more opposed to this dangerous plan for our water. Thank you for considering their views.

Sincerely,
Lynn Thorp 
National Campaigns Director
Clean Water Action
docketTitle: Waters of the United States  Reinstatement of Preexisting Rules

Scott Pruitt

Britta Bloomquist

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Nebraska Corn Growers (web)
commentText:
Dear EPA, please construct a WOTUS rule that works for agriculture. 
 
	Farmers support the Clean Water Act and are stewards of the environment. 
	The 2015 rule was overly broad and would put millions of acres under federal jurisdiction.

We strongly support the Administration's decision to rescind the 2015 rule and encourage you create a definition for WOTUS that does not subject upland drainage features to federal jurisdiction, and recognizes that water quality can be protected without it.

Sincerely, 

Nebraska Corn Growers
docketTitle: Waters of the United States  Reinstatement of Preexisting Rules

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by PennEnvironment Research & Policy Center (web)
commentText:
Administrator Pruitt,

In the attached document, 8,050 supporters of PennEnvironment have signed on to the following comment in support of the Waters of the U.S. Rule, opposing efforts to modify or roll back this Rule.

"When it comes to our streams, rivers, lakes and wetlands, the waters we love deserve to be protected. 

But the Trump administration has made clear their intentions to roll back essential protections to our clean water like the Clean Water Rule, which protects the drinking water sources of 117 million Americans. 

I want stronger, not weaker clean water protections. That's why I'm calling on you to defend the waters Americans love, and uphold the Clean Water Rule."
docketTitle: Waters of the United States  Reinstatement of Preexisting Rules

docketTitle: Waters of the United States  Reinstatement of Preexisting Rules

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Clean Water Action (web)
commentText:
RE: Docket ID Number: EPA-HQ-OW-2017-0203: Comments on the Repeal and Replacement of the 2015 Definition of the Waters of the United States, Federal Register, Vol. 82, No. 143 (July 27, 2017)

Dear Administrator Pruitt and Mr. Lamont:

Attached are comments from approximately 9,000 Clean Water Action members and supporters from across the country that all oppose the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) and Army Corps of Engineers' (Corps) proposal to repeal the 2015 Clean Water Rule. An additional 30,000 comments have been submitted on paper.

The Clean Water Rule is needed to better protect critical water resources from harm, including small streams that feed drinking water sources and wetlands that filter pollutants and buffer communities from flooding. Repealing this commonsense, thoroughly vetted rule will needlessly put the communities that depend on these water resources at increased risk of exposure to pollution. 

The job of the EPA and the Corps is to protect people from pollution and to safeguard communities from harm. The agencies should listen to the majority of Americans who want a strong Clean Water Act and immediately withdraw this reckless proposal. Should the agencies propose to revise the 2015 Clean Water Rule, they must engage in a robust stakeholder process and any proposed replacement rule must not further roll back protections for small streams and wetlands. 

Sincerely,
Jennifer Peters
Water Programs Director
Clean Water Action
docketTitle: Waters of the United States  Reinstatement of Preexisting Rules

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by American Rivers (web)
commentText:
September 27, 2017
 
Ms. Donna Downing
Office of Water (4504-T)
Environmental Protection Agency
1200 Pennsylvania Avenue NW
Washington, DC 20460
 
Ms. Stacey Jensen
Regulatory Community of Practice (CECW-CO-R)
U.S. Army Corps of Engineers
441 G Street NW
Washington, DC 20314
 
RE: Comments of American Rivers Opposing Repeal and Replacement of the Clean Water Rule
Definition of "Waters of the United States" - Recodification of Pre-Existing Rules, Docket EPA-HQ-OW-2017- 0203
 
Dear Ms. Downing and Ms. Jensen,
 
Thank you for the opportunity to provide comments on the proposed rule to repeal the Clean Water Rule. American Rivers strongly opposes repeal of the Clean Water Rule. A clear definition of "waters of the United States" in the context of the Clean Water Act is vitally important, and the Clean Water Rule provides that clarity. Repealing the Clean Water Rule and re-codifying the regulations in place before the Rule was finalized is a step backward and a return to regulatory uncertainty among stakeholders. Returning to the status quo ante will further hamper efforts by EPA and the Army Corps of Engineers to enforce the Clean Water Act and protect small streams and wetlands.
 
Attached please find comments on the proposed rule, "Definition of 'Waters of the United States'- Recodification of Pre-Existing Rules," These comments are submitted on behalf of American Rivers.
 
If you have any questions about this submission, please contact Meghan Boian with American Rivers at 202-243-7037. Thank you in advance for considering our views.
docketTitle: Waters of the United States  Reinstatement of Preexisting Rules

title: Comment submitted by John Rumpler, Senior Attorney, Environment America Research & Policy Center - includes Mass Comment Campaign (web)
commentText:
RE: Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OW-2017-0203: Comments on the Repeal and Replacement of the 2015 Definition of Waters of the United States, 82 Fed. Reg. (July 2017)

Dear Administrator Pruitt and Mr. Lamont:
 
On behalf of individuals indicated below, Environment America Research & Policy Center submits the following comments (3 attachments) in strong opposition to the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) and Army Corps of Engineers' (Corps) proposal to repeal the 2015 Clean Water Rule, and any subsequent effort to weaken federal protections for our waterways:

1) a letter signed by 287 individuals from 43 states - including health professionals, business owners, state and local officials, and local conservation leaders deeply concerned with clean water; 

2) separate comments on behalf of 234 business owners, originally filed as an amicus brief in support of the Clean Water Rule, and now submitted here in opposition to the proposed repeal of the Rule; and
 
3) separate comments on behalf of 79 local and state officials, originally filed as an amicus brief in support of the Clean Water Rule, and now submitted here in opposition to the proposed repeal of the Rule.

Sincerely,

John Rumpler, Senior Attorney
Environment America Research & Policy Center
294 Washington Street, Suite 500
Boston, MA 02108
(617) 747-4306 (o)
jrumpler@environmentamerica.org

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Organizing for Action (web)
commentText:
Hello,

Please see attached 11,810 comments from members of Organizing for Action regarding the Waters of the United States rule. The comment is below.

Thanks,

Jack

Jack Shapiro
Director of Policy and Campaigns
Organizing for Action
jshapiro@ofa.us

Comment:

For 45 years, the Clean Water Act has protected our natural resources, and helped keep drinking water safe. In 2015, the Clean Water Rule finally extended protections to streams and wetlands that flow into our larger bodies of water -- helping to ensure that over 117 million Americans have access to clean drinking water. The existing rule incorporates input from 400 stakeholder meetings, one million public comments, and synthesis of more than 1200 peer-reviewed scientific publications, and should not be rescinded. It allows more pollution in our nation's waters, and threatens our public health and the economy.

I oppose the roll-back of the Clean Water Rule.

Signed:

11,810 Members of Organizing for Action
docketTitle: Waters of the United States  Reinstatement of Preexisting Rules

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Earthjustice (web)
commentText:
Attached is the file containing the names of 49,265 individuals who have submitted public comments opposing a repeal and replacement of the 2015 Definition of Waters of the U.S. In addition to signing on in support of the following letter, 12,862 individuals of the total number have submitted personalized comments. The personalized comments start on page 2 and end on page 727 .

RE: Docket ID Number: EPA-HQ-OW-2017-0203: Comments on the Repeal and Replacement of the 2015 Definition of Waters of the U.S.

Dear Environmental Protection Agency:

I am writing in response to your recent request for comments on the repeal of the Clean Water Rule. As someone who supports protections for this nation's waters, I strongly oppose this attack. 

Before finalizing the Clean Water Rule in 2015, EPA held more than 400 meetings with stakeholders across the country, received over 1 million comments--more than 80 percent of which were in support of the rule--and published a synthesis of more than 1,200 peer-reviewed scientific publications, which showed that the small streams and wetlands the rule safeguards are vital to larger, downstream waters.

Repealing the Clean Water Rule would put many of our waters at risk, including waters that are critical for drinking water supplies, recreation, fish and wildlife. It would also affect our economy. Consumers spend $887 billion annually in outdoor recreation and the outdoor recreation economy is responsible for 7.6 million American jobs. Without protections for wetlands and small streams, the outdoor industry will likely suffer. The costs of treating our water also go up when streams and wetlands aren't protected.

Clean water is fundamental to our health and economy, something our nation recognized a long time ago in passing the Clean Water Act. I urge you to reconsider this proposal and leave the Clean Water Rule in place.

The Undersigned
docketTitle: Waters of the United States  Reinstatement of Preexisting Rules

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by United Egg Producers (web)
commentText:
Please see attached a petition signed by approximately 180 US egg producers that says:

"We, the undersigned persons, are part of the US egg industry and submit this petition in support of: 
	The proposed rescission of the 2015 federal rulemaking that defined what are "waters of the United States" 
        (WOTUS) under the Clean Water Act, which is currently the subject of a national stay by order of federal court.
	The recodification of the preceding rulemakings that have been used to define WOTUS during this national stay.
	The subsequent, substantive reevaluation of the definition of WOTUS and the development of a new rulemaking 
         that defines WOTUS consistent with the statute, and the proper role of the states and the federal government in 
        the implementation of the Clean Water Act in support of environmental protection, clean water and the economic 
        health and vitality of our industry and the country."

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by PennEnvironment (web)
commentText:
Dear Administrator Pruitt and Mr. Lamont:
 
We, the 100 undersigned elected officials, business owners, farmers and non-profit leaders listed in the attached document, write in strong opposition to the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) and Army Corps of Engineers' (Corps) proposal to repeal the 2015 Clean Water Rule, and any subsequent effort to weaken federal protections for our waterways.  These rollbacks would recklessly open waterways upon which we all rely to degradation and pollution.
 
We are parents and grandparents, doctors and nurses, business owners, anglers and outfitters, and farmers and ranchers. We are communities at risk from contaminated water and flooding. We are local officials charged with protecting the public's health, safety, and welfare.  Some of us even consider ourselves environmentalists. We all depend upon clean water - whether for drinking, our health, fishing, swimming, paddling, wildlife, or even our jobs.
 
Finalized in 2015, the Clean Water Rule restored federal protections to half the nation's streams, which help provide drinking water to 1 in 3 Americans.  The rule also protects millions of acres of wetlands that provide wildlife habitat and keep pollutants out of 49,000 miles of waterways in Pennsylvania.  No wonder more than 800,000 Americans - including more than 1,000 business owners, local officials, farmers, and health professionals - urged EPA to adopt the the Clean Water Rule.  
 
Repealing the Clean Water Rule turns the mission of the EPA on its head: the agency charged with safeguarding our drinking water is proposing to stop protecting drinking water sources for 8 million Pennsylvanians. It defies common sense, sound science and the will of the American people.
 
Clean water is vital to our ecology, our health, and our quality of life.  We are already seeing drinking water contaminated by algal blooms and toxic chemicals, and a dead zone in the Gulf of Mexico that scientists now estimate will be the size of New Jersey this summer. We should address these threats by strengthening the Clean Water Act and its applicability, not weakening them.
 
We call on EPA and the Corps to reconsider this reckless repeal and stand up for our drinking water.
docketTitle: Waters of the United States  Reinstatement of Preexisting Rules

We write in opposition to the repeal of the Clean Water Rule because we support science-based environmental policy, and current science overwhelmingly supports the existing Clean Water Rule.

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by PennEnvironment (web)
commentText:
On behalf of 3,848 citizens, I would like to submit the following comment: 

Dear EPA Administrator, 

I oppose recent efforts to weaken national fuel efficiency standards for cars. 

If kept intact, these standards would cut carbon pollution nationwide by 6 billion metric tons, protecting the environment and public health. In addition, Pennsylvania has saved $1.2 billion since automakers, federal and state governments and other stakeholders agreed upon the rules on October 15, 2012.

You should be strengthening clean car standards, not putting the nation in reverse.

Sincerely,  
(Names with city, state, and zip code for 3,848 citizens in attached document)

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Defend Our Future (web)
commentText:
To Whom It May Concern: 

Attached, please find the signatures of 1,962 Defend Our Future supporters from across the country who have submitted comments regarding the Environmental Protection Agency and Department of Transportation's proposed rule, The Safer Affordable Fuel-Efficient Vehicles Rule for Model Years 2021-2026 Passenger Cars and Light Trucks. Please consider each a formal comment in the federal docket regarding Docket Number EPA-HQ-OAR-2018-0283-0756. 

The comment they each submitted reads: 

As a young American, I am writing to you today strongly opposed to proposed rollbacks to America's Clean Car Standards. 

Rolling back the clean car standards will make our air more polluted and will force drivers into dirtier, less-efficient vehicles that are more expensive to drive. Tearing down successful and achievable climate change and air pollution protections endangers everyone, and slashing money-saving standards just as gas prices hit a four-year high amounts to a direct attack on families who can't afford to pay more at the pump.

Please stand up for our families and communities who are in danger today and the young people who will inherit the consequences of this reckless action for the rest of their lives.

Please contact me if you have any questions or concerns about this submission. 

Thank you for your consideration,
docketTitle: Rulemaking to Revise Light-Duty Vehicle Greenhouse Gas Emission Standards and Corporate Average Fuel Economy Standards

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Sierra Club (web)
commentText:
October 25, 2018

Re: Docket: EPA-HQ-OAR-2018-0283-0756

Please find 52,825 comments attached for inclusion in the docket, EPA-HQ-OAR-2018-0283-0756, The Safer Affordable Fuel-Efficient Vehicles Rule for Model Years 2021-2026 Passenger Cars and Light Trucks. 10,146 individuals took the time to write the EPA a personal message, and all 52,825 have signed the following text:

Dear Acting Administrator Wheeler,

The clean car standards (the CAFE and greenhouse gas emissions standards) are one of the most important ways we have to reduce climate pollution right now. Flatlining or reducing the improvements from these rules will cost people money and make climate change worse. 

When originally set, these rules would save people thousands of dollars a year and keep billions of barrels of oil in the ground. Barely two years ago, the Department of Transportation and the Environmental Protection Agency did a robust analysis of the impact of these rules. They found the costs have actually dropped over the first few years of implementation. There is no evidence that these standards need to be changed in any way. 

Additionally, Californias authority to set their own emissions standards should be protected, as should the ability for other states to follow Californias standards. Congress explicitly gave California and these states the authority to set these strong environmental protections. These rights should be protected, and this provision should be dropped from any final rule. 

By rolling back these standards, you will be taking money from hard working people and putting it in the pockets of big oil and the car companies. Keep these standards as is and protect our environment and pocketbooks.

We respectfully request that the 52,825 comments submitted by the individuals listed in the document below as well as in the attached spreadsheet be reflected in the final comment tally for this docket.

Sincerely,
Andrew Linhardt
Deputy Advocacy Director
Clean Transportation for All
Sierra Club
docketTitle: Rulemaking to Revise Light-Duty Vehicle Greenhouse Gas Emission Standards and Corporate Average Fuel Economy Standards

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by MN350 (web)
commentText:
We were shocked to read the recent news about the Department of Transportation ignoring Environmental Protection Agency experts and creating its own flawed research in order to freeze automotive fuel efficiency standards. The study conducted by the DOT and EPA claimed that the standards increase highway crashes. But EPA experts know they actually reduce highway crashes-- while cutting pollution, slowing climate change, and saving Americans fuel costs. The Department of Transportation must conduct an honest and scientifically sound analysis and revise this destructive policy change or reverse it altogether. Ordinary Minnesotans cannot afford the increased pollution and climate instability it will bring.

Signed, 
MN350 & 234 ordinary Minnesotans 
(names and addresses attached)

Attached, please find the signatures of 5,926 Moms Clean Air Force supporters from across the country who have submitted comments regarding the Environmental Protection Agency and Department of Transportation's proposed rule, The Safer Affordable Fuel-Efficient Vehicles Rule for Model Years 2021-2026 Passenger Cars and Light Trucks. Please consider each a formal comment in the federal docket regarding Docket Number EPA-HQ-OAR-2018-0283-0756.

The comment they each submitted reads:

I am writing today in opposition to your proposed rollbacks on America's Clean Car Standards. 

The clean car standards are a successful policy that deliver the safe, clean, fuel-efficient cars that our families want and need. They are helping us protect our children's health and future by fighting climate change. Rolling back these standards forces parents into dirtier, less-efficient cars, and is a direct attack on the health of our children. 

As a parent, I expect our leaders to step on the pedal when it comes to pushing for the highest standards possible. Anything less is unacceptable.

Please contact me if you have any questions or concerns about this submission.

Thank you for your consideration,

Kyli Wagner

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Plug In America (web)
commentText:
Dear Acting Administrator Wheeler: 

On behalf of the plug-in electric vehicle (PEV) drivers we represent, Plug In America would like to thank you for this opportunity to provide feedback on the proposed Safer Affordable Fuel-Efficient (SAFE) Vehicles Rule for Model Years 2021-2026 Passenger Cars and Light Trucks. In the attached document, we submit for the official record signatures of Plug In America members who are strongly opposed to the proposed rule, as there are an array of technologies that can meet the standards that are already on the market today, like plug-in electric vehicles. Furthermore, these members strongly oppose the proposal to withdraw the California waiver, as states with extremely poor air quality from tailpipe pollution need to be able to set their own standards and establish programs to mitigate the pollution, like the zero-emission vehicle mandate.

Thank you. 

Best, 
Joel Levin 
Executive Director, Plug In America

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Interfaith Power & Light (Web)
commentText:
Interfaith Power & Light is submitting comments of behalf of 2776 of our members and people of faith from across the country.  
 ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

As a person of faith, I am writing to show my support for the current, strong, and forward-looking clean car standards. I object to any attempt to undermine the standards after they were finalized in a public process with comments from millions of Americans. 
Those bearing the burden of pollution are most often lower-income households and communities of color. It is our moral obligation to protect the most vulnerable among us, the neighbors that our religious traditions call us to care for. Weakening the standards would harm these families and communities first and worst.

Transportation is the largest and fastest growing source of carbon pollution and oil consumption in the U.S. Our vehicles account for almost 50% of oil used in the United States and nearly one third of our climate pollution. The current standards are the most effective policy that we have to address global warming, and we cannot afford to retreat from climate solutions as our communities are being harmed by its impacts here and now.


We are called to be stewards of Creation. Turning our backs on a policy that protects our air and our climate is wrong. Turning the nations back on a policy that protects the most vulnerable is a terrible injustice. 

As a person of faith, I am writing to ask you to support the current clean car standards without compliance loopholes that could erode the benefits of the standards. 

Sincerely,
See attachment for full list of signatures
docketTitle: Rulemaking to Revise Light-Duty Vehicle Greenhouse Gas Emission Standards and Corporate Average Fuel Economy Standards

commentText: Please accept these public comments from 119,984 online members and activists on behalf of the Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC) regarding EPA-HQ-OAR-2018-0283 opposing rollbacks of clean car standards. Strong clean car standards are one of the most crucial things we can do to fight climate change as transportation is the single-largest source of carbon pollution. Keeping strong clean car standards in place would reduce carbon pollution, improve public health and save drivers money at the pump. For these reasons, we urge you to abandon these proposed rollbacks to clean car standards. Thank you for your consideration.

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Environmental Defense Fund (EDF) (web)
commentText:
To Whom It May Concern: 

Attached, please find the signatures of 73,487 Environmental Defense Fund supporters from across the country who have submitted electronic comments opposing EPA and DOT's Rulemaking to Revise Light-Duty Vehicle Greenhouse Gas Emission Standards and Corporate Average Fuel Economy Standards (Docket ID: EPA-HQ-OAR-2018-0283-0756). 

The comment they each submitted reads: 

"I am writing today in strong opposition to this administration's decision to attack America's Clean Car Standards. 

"These pollution control standards are a win-win  they are protecting us from dangerous pollution while saving Americans money at the pump. Rolling back these protections unnecessarily wastes Americans' hard-earned money, and hurts our auto industry's chances at remaining competitive in a global market increasingly dominated by countries investing in cleaner car technology. 

"Last year, EPA concluded an exhaustive technical review of the industry's ability to meet the phase of the standards covering 2022-2025 model years, and found industry can meet those standards at lower costs than initially predicted. 

"It makes no sense to reverse course on this successful policy. Keep these crucial standards intact."

Please feel free to contact me directly if you have any questions or concerns about this submission. 

Thank you for your consideration,

Heather Shelby
Manager, Grassroots Organizing & Activism
Environmental Defense Fund
hshelby@edf.org
(202) 572 3242

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Environmental Action (web)
commentText:
I am writing today on behalf of the national conservation organization Environmental Action and 16,049 people concerned about the administrations proposed rollback of fuel efficiency standards (EPA-HQ-OAR-2018-0283).

Summer 2018 saw saw scorching temperatures, frequent extreme weather events, massive wildfires, and even toxic algae that's littered Florida beaches with the rotting corpses of manatees, sea turtles and other imperiled wildlife.

The United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate change now says that we may have as little as 12 years to avoid even more intense climate-related impacts. 

Unfortunately, the administration's proposed delay would mean that an extra 321 million to 931 million metric tons of carbon dioxide would be emitted -- even as climate change increasingly threatens the lives and livelihoods of people around the world, wildlife, and wild places.

Attached below, please find the signatures of 16,049 people who have signed a petition opposing the administrations proposed delay fuel efficiency standards that help address climate change and reduce harmful air pollution.

Individuals were given the option to customize their comments, but most have signed some version of this text:

"We, the undersigned, strongly oppose the The Safer Affordable Fuel Efficient (SAFE) Vehicles Proposed Rule for Model Years 2021-2026 (EPA-HQ-OAR-2018-0283). The rule is a significant, needless, and potentially dangerous delay in global carbon emission reduction efforts. The United States should be speeding away from fossil fuels that fuel destructive, disruptive and costly climate change -- not encouraging Americans to use more fossil fuels."

Like you, Environmental Action is committed to an accurate public record of the decision making process around this proposed delay. To that end, we ask that these comments be placed in the public record and considered in your planning. 

P.S. Should you wish to review the petition online, it is available at https://environmental-action.webaction.org/p/dia/action4/common/public/?action_KEY=28879
docketTitle: Rulemaking to Revise Light-Duty Vehicle Greenhouse Gas Emission Standards and Corporate Average Fuel Economy Standards

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Environmental Law and Policy Center (web)
commentText:
The Environmental Law and Policy Center submits the attached petition signed by 415 individual signatories in regards to EPA's Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM): Safer Affordable Fuel-Efficient Vehicles Rule for Model Years 2021-2026 Passenger Cars and Light Trucks. 

"We, the undersigned, want cars and trucks that lead the world in quality, get great fuel economy and emit less carbon pollution. The Environmental Protection Agency and Department of Transportation set strong clean car standards in 2012 to ensure that every year through 2025 new cars would use less oil and emit less pollution. These Clean Car Standards should remain in place! 

Smart policies like Clean Car Standards drive automakers to accelerate technological innovation. That innovation supports American manufacturing jobs and helps the Midwest economy thrive. 

Freezing these standards moves America in the wrong direction. Weaker standards will force consumers to pump 500,000 more barrels of oil per day, result in more pollution that harms public health and our climate. Weaker standards will undermine American technological innovation leadership and competitiveness. The auto industry has proven it can make safe, affordable and more efficient vehicles.  

See attached file(s)
docketTitle: Rulemaking to Revise Light-Duty Vehicle Greenhouse Gas Emission Standards and Corporate Average Fuel Economy Standards

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Environmental Entrepreneurs (E2)(web)
commentText:
Monday, August 13, 2018

Secretary Elaine Chao 
US Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Ave, SE
Washington, DC 20590

Mr. Andrew Wheeler
Acting Administrator, EPA
1200 Pennsylvania Ave, NW
Washington, DC 20460

RE: Corporate Average Fuel Economy (CAFE) Standards

Dear Secretary Chao and Acting Administrator Wheeler:

The U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and EPA just issued a joint Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM) on Corporate Average Fuel Economy (CAFE) and the Light-Duty Vehicle Greenhouse Gas Vehicle Emissions standards for model years 2022-2025 that proposes to significantly weaken the existing standards. The current policy was adopted in 2010, after an agreement between the federal government, labor, auto manufacturers and states. The existing strong standards are good for American innovation and business and good for consumers, which is why the business leaders signed below from across the country strongly oppose this NPRM.

Environmental Entrepreneurs (E2) is a national, nonpartisan group of business leaders who advocate for smart policies that are good for our economy and good for our environment. Our members have founded or funded more than 2,500 companies, created more than 600,000 jobs, and manage more than $100 billion in venture and private equity capital.

An ambitious set of vehicle emissions and fuel economy standards benefits consumers and businesses alike and as a nation we prosper when we prioritize innovation and competition while ensuring a stable business policy environment. All of this requires leadership from our elected officials and decision makers at federal agencies, such as EPA and DOT, in partnership with the state officials. 
 
Strong long-term standards have been critical and remain essential to continued recovery of the automotive sector since the economic crash a decade ago. They are key to ongoing innovation and job growth, and to a further strengthening of our manufacturing sector. Since the modern standards went into effect in 2012, we have seen record vehicle sales of vehicles and fuel economy coupled with growing employment in the auto industry. These standardswhen maintainedprovide certainty for the investment that drives innovation.

That innovation makes domestic automakers and their vast network of suppliers competitive in a global market that continues to demand cleaner vehicles. This investment also supports domestic jobs. According to the 2017 edition of the report Supplying Ingenuity, there are 288,000 direct manufacturing and engineering workers in 1,200 facilities across 43 states who are building the technologies that make vehicles cleaner and more fuel efficient.
 
Similarly, the 2018 U.S. Energy Employment Report which E2 recently published along with partners at the National Association of State Energy Officers (NASEO) and the Energy Futures Initiative, found that at least 650,000 jobs in the motor vehicles sector are focused on increasing fuel economy or transitioning to alternative fuels through their daily activities or supply chains.
 
In 1985 more than two-thirds of Detroit Three unit sales were in North America. By 2025, it is projected that only one-third will be sold in North America, while two-thirds of sales will be overseas. In those global markets, consumers demand, and governments often mandate, more fuel efficient and cleaner vehicles compared to the North American market. They also ensure American cars can compete in nations which have far higher gasoline prices than we do in the United States. If we rollback these standards we will cede market share to international competitors already quickly moving to capitalize on our lack of leadership.
 
Lastly, standards protect American families, businesses and institutions against gasoline price volatility. The CAFE standards in 2025 will save drivers between $3,200 and $5,700 over the life of a new car. In fact, improved fuel efficiency is forecast to save Americans a total of about $50 billion by 2030. Instead of going to foreign oil cartels, that is money that can be reinvested in local communities across the country.   
 
E2s members recognize the economic opportunity and necessity of increased fuel economy. We strongly urge both EPA and DOT to do the same, and not rollback these badly needed and highly beneficial standards.
 
Sincerely,  
503 E2 Members
docketTitle: Rulemaking to Revise Light-Duty Vehicle Greenhouse Gas Emission Standards and Corporate Average Fuel Economy Standards

title: Mass Mail Comment Campaign sponsored by Environment America et al. (web)
commentText:
RE: The Safer Affordable Fuel-Efficient Vehicles Rule for Model Years 2021-2026 Passenger Cars and Light Trucks, Docket EPA-HQ-OAR-2018-0283

Dear Acting Administrator Wheeler, 

I write today on behalf of Environment Americas members and supporters across the country who want clean air and a healthy climate. We strongly oppose the administrations attempts to weaken the nations fuel economy and greenhouse gas emission standards.
 
Limiting global warming pollution from transportation--the single largest source of such pollution in the US--is a critical step forward to protect our children from the worst impacts of climate change.  The clean car standards are the single greatest action the US has taken to date to address global warming. We must continue to make progress and cut pollution while curtailing our oil consumption.
 
The clean car standards are the nations most effective program at fighting global warming. Data about pollution and climate-related deaths should be taken into account. Air pollution from transportation is responsible for a staggering 30,000 premature deaths each year, and the changing climate is endangering communities across the country, from more extreme wildfires to more intense storms.
 
By boosting fuel economy, American families save money. Drivers of new vehicles introduced in 2018 will save an average of $2,605 in fuel costs. 
 
These standards are working, and they are saving families money at the pump, while reducing carbon pollution and making the air cleaner and safer for us all to breathe. 
 
There is a reason - many reasons - that 87% of Americans agree automakers should continue to improve fuel efficiency and that hundreds of thousands of comments have already been submitted in support of the current standards. Over the past year, Environment America has defended these standards with over a thousand health professionals, 550 small businesses, and tens of thousands of people joining us in calling for cleaner cars. Environment America previously submitted over 45,000 grassroots comments in support of strong vehicle standards and is submitting an additional 20,852 today. We ask that these names be entered into the official record and considered as separate public comments
 
The existing standards are set to reduce climate pollution by as much as 6 billion metric tons over the lifetimes of the vehicles--the equivalent to carbon pollution from 150 coal-fired power plants for an entire year. 
 
Our families, our health, and our environment are counting on these standards.
 
We strongly urge you not to weaken the clean car standards. Doing so would threaten our health, our environment, and cost American families money.

Sincerely,

Morgan Folger
Environment America
mfolger@environmentamerica.org (202) 461-2443
docketTitle: Rulemaking to Revise Light-Duty Vehicle Greenhouse Gas Emission Standards and Corporate Average Fuel Economy Standards

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
Dear Chief Van Norman and Director Ashe,

My name is Nathan Empsall, and I am a senior organizer for Care2. I am submitting 70,406 comments from Care2 members to Docket ID FWS-R9-ES-2012-0025-3488 in support of listing the African lion as an endangered species.

All 70,406 of these Care2 members have signed their names to the following comment. I am including an Excel spreadsheet containing their names with this letter, as well as additional personal comments that 550 of them appended to their signatures. Here is the text that all of them signed as part of their comments:

"Dear Chief Van Norman and Director Ashe,

"Please move forward with plans to list the African lion as an endangered species.

"The African lion population has decreased nearly 50% and they have disappeared from 75% of their historic range, meeting the criteria to be listed as "endangered" under the Endangered Species Act.

"In just a few decades, the African lion population fell from more than 75,000 to fewer than 40,000. Despite the decline in number, African lions are still being hunted as trophies.

"The U.S. is the world's largest importer of lions and lion parts for commercial and recreational trade - this includes skulls, claws, hides, live lions, and recently, even as food served in restaurants.

"Some people have tried to argue that big game trophy hunters inject money into the local economies, which is then used for conservation. Humane Society International has flatly rejected that notion, saying that none of the money from canned lion hunts is used for wildlife conservation.

"Protect African lions under the U.S. Endangered Species Act. There clearly is no legitimate reason to kill African lions, and their continued slaughter for "sport" is causing their rapid disappearance from the wild.

"Save this iconic species from extinction by listing it as endangered!

"Sincerely,
"The attached 70,406 names"

Thank you for this comment period and for your attention to these 70,406 Care2 members. We look forward to your listing the African lion as an endangered species.

Sincerely,
Nathan Empsall
Care2 Senior Organizing Strategist

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
To: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar and Director Dan Ashe, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service

Dear Secretary Salazar and Director Ashe,
I am writing to urge that the Department of Interior's USFWS list the African lion as "Endangered Throughout its Range" under the Endangered Species Act.

Lions have disappeared from over 80% of their historic range, and their population declined by nearly 50% from just 1980 to 2002. The threats facing African lions today are numerous and reinforcing: habitat destruction and fragmentation, loss of traditional prey species, disease, and inevitable conflict with humans.

The United States can help to stop this marked decline by addressing unsustainable trophy hunting and commercial trade in lion parts.The United States is by far the worlds largest importer of both commercially traded African lion parts and lion trophies. This trend is only increasing.

Protecting African lions under the U.S. Endangered Species Act would begin to curtail this trade and allow lions to recover.

I have attached the signatures of 39,729 individuals who also urge you to list the lion.

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
Leda Huta, Executive Director, Endangered Species Coalition + 39,729 additional signatures

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by InternationalMosaic.com (web)
commentText:
Re:  Proposal to Limit Use of Scientific Evidence in Rulemakings, 83 Fed. Reg. 18,768 (April 30, 2018) - Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OA-2018-0259.  

We are writing, both as editors of InternationalMosaic.com and individually, to provide additional  comments on and objections to the proposal to limit the use of scientific evidence in rulemaking proceedings. Indeed, as was pointed out in, inter alia, our letter dated May 24,  2018, the proposal suffers from multiple fatal flaws that require the proposal's withdrawal.

For example, in the April 23, 2018 letter submitted by 985 scientists and technical experts, the scientists and technical experts say:

"As scientists and technical experts, we urge you to cease any plans to restrict the types of science that the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) can use in regulatory decisionmaking. EPA can only adequately protect our air and water and keep us safe from harmful chemicals if it takes full advantage of the wealth of scientific research that is available to the agency."

For your convenience, an electronic copy of the letter is attached and the letter  can be found at: https://www.eenews.net/assets/2018/04/27/document_gw_01.pdf    

By itself, the attached letter constitutes legally sufficient evidence to compel the conclusion that the proposed rule must be rejected as bad for the environment. In  addition, the letter provides more than sufficient  evidence that adoption of the proposed rule without careful and public consideration of the letter constitutes arbitrary and capricious action violating the Administrative Procedure Act. Finally, the letter adds to the abundant  evidence that the National Environmental Policy Act requires the  preparation of a proper Environmental Impact  Statement before the  regulation can be adopted. 

     		Sincerely,
                     InternationalMosaic.com

     		     Andrew J. Yamamoto, Esq,., Editor
                  
                     Scott D. Pinsky, Esq., Environmental Law Editor
docketTitle: Strengthening Transparency in Regulatory Science

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Defend Our Future (web)
commentText:
To Whom It May Concern: 

Attached, please find the signatures of 5,036 Defend Our Future supporters from across the country who have submitted comments regarding the EPA's Strengthening Transparency in Regulatory Science proposal. Please consider each a formal comment in the federal docket regarding Docket Number EPA-HQ-OA-2018-0259. 

The comment they each submitted reads: 

I'm writing today to strongly express my opposition to your plans to restrict the use of strong, rigorous science at EPA. This proposal undermines scientific research that keeps our communities safe by determining whether chemicals and pollutants cause cancer, heart disease, and more.

Americans deserve the best science, so we have a clear understanding of the risks associated with substances we are exposed to every day. We rely on the EPA to protect us, not to use science as a political bargaining chip. Please abandon this dangerous proposal that puts our science and our safety at risk.

Please contact me if you have any questions or concerns about this submission. 

Thank you for your consideration,

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Moms Clean Air Force (web)
commentText:
To Whom It May Concern: 

Attached, please find the signatures of 11,302 Moms Clean Air force supporters from across the country who have submitted comments regarding the EPA's Strengthening Transparency in Regulatory Science proposal. Please consider each a formal comment in the federal docket regarding Docket Number EPA-HQ-OA-2018-0259. 

The comment they each submitted reads: 

As a parent, I am writing to express my strong opposition to the proposed rule, Strengthening Transparency in Regulatory Science. 

This misleading rule requires that EPA consider only those scientific studies that use publicly available raw data. This would prevent EPA from using studies that are based on personal medical data, thereby eliminating some of the most important long-term epidemiological studies investigating the impacts of pollution on public health. This proposal would significantly limit the research and data that EPA can use to make informed policy decisions under major public health and environmental laws, including the Clean Air Act, Safe Drinking Water Act, and Toxic Substances Control Act. 

American families depend on the EPA and high-quality science to protect us from the impacts of air pollution and toxic chemicals. This proposal puts that protection in jeopardy, placing the health of our children at risk.

Please contact me if you have any questions or concerns about this submission. 

Thank you for your consideration,
docketTitle: Strengthening Transparency in Regulatory Science

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Cornell Alliance for Science (Web)
commentText:
I submit this comment as a concerned citizen to call on the EPA to exclude valid science from regulations on air pollution and other health issues.

The EPA already relies on transparent science to make its decisions. The proposal will not improve this process. Instead, it would allow the agency to ignore critical studies that show the relationship between our health and the environment. We cannot limit the information used to protect our health and environment.

The effects of air pollution and other environmental risks are documented by research that has already undergone a long-established, transparent peer review process. Many of these studies contain confidential patient information that cant and shouldnt be made public. This is no reason to exclude those studies critically important, well-vetted findings. I am deeply concerned that EPAs proposal would allow the agency to ignore these important health studies.

Our communities depend on the EPA to use the best available scientific evidence in making policy decisions. We deserve clean air and water and ask that you adhere to the EPA mandate to protect our health and environment. The EPA must rely on the best available science to protect our future - this proposal makes that impossible.

Please withdraw this proposal and send a message that your time as head of the EPA will bring back science-based policies to protect our planet.
 
Shannon McCleary

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
National Parks Conservation Association
777 6th Street, NW Suite 700
Washington, D.C. 20001
Tel: 800-628-7275

May 10, 2016

Please find attached a Microsoft Excel file (.xlsx format) containing 17,788 comments of National Parks Conservation Association supporters regarding the proposed rule to remove the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem Population of Grizzly Bears from the Federal List of Endangered and Threatened Wildlife.
               
Many people submitted personalized comments, which you will find in the worksheet labeled Customized Message; others signed on to the comments below: 

Thank you for the opportunity to provide comments on the proposed delisting of grizzly bears in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem from the Endangered Species List. I am extremely concerned about your agency's proposed rule and ask that you take the following steps before finalizing it:

* Afford National Park Service managers a formal role in the management of bears on habitat adjacent to park borders, and fully address their concerns. In particular, ensure there are measures in place to protect bears that roam beyond national park boundaries. Hunting inside National Park Service legislative boundaries, on park-adjacent lands, and in key habitat connectivity corridors should be strictly prohibited in the proposed plan and the individual state management plans.

* Include policies and firm commitments to promote Yellowstone bears naturally connecting to populations in Glacier National Park and other areas.

* Clearly articulate how climate change will impact grizzly bears' habitat, food sources and behavior, and how your proposal takes these changes into account.

* Provide the public with a clear and detailed plan for how grizzlies will be managed and protected, and for how their long term conservation will be assured, once management is turned over to state wildlife agencies.

Your proposal to remove endangered species protections from Yellowstone and Grand Teton grizzly bears fails to address these critical concerns and must therefore be revised to ensure the long term health and protection of these amazing animals. 

Thanks again for considering my comments.



If you have any questions about the comments, or prefer to receive them in a different format, please do not hesitate to contact me.

Please accept our gratitude for your agency's collaboration in ensuring that the comments of these concerned individuals are considered. 

Sincerely,

Shane Farnor
Online Advocacy Manager
National Parks Conservation Association

title: Mass comment campaign submitted by Judy Hatcher, Pesticide Action Network, et al. (17,287 signatories)
commentText:
Gina McCarthy, Administrator
Environmental Protection Agency
1200 Pennsylvania Ave. NW
Washington, D.C. 20460 

RE: Docket # EPA-HQ-OPP-2014-0195

Dear Administrator McCarthy, 

We are writing to urge your agency to reject Dow's application for the "new use" of 2,4-D with its Enlist line of genetically engineered seeds. This antiquated, dangerous herbicide is prone to drift off target, damaging neighboring crops and threatening the health of nearby communities. 

As you know, 2,4-D is a reproductive toxicant, suspected endocrine disruptor and possible carcinogen. Children are particularly susceptible to its effects. If EPA approves Dows new 2,4-D formula, use  and therefore exposures  will go up. Agricultural scientists warn that widespread planting of Enlist corn could trigger as much as a 25-fold increase in use of 2,4-D on corn, from an estimated 4.2 million lbs. at present to over 100 million lbs. by 2019.

Recognizing a potential public health disaster looming on the horizon, 70 physicians, nurses and other health professionals have already urged EPA to reject Dows application for new uses of 2,4-D on genetically engineered corn.    

American farmers, too, are deeply concerned that Dows Enlist corn system will threaten their crops and therefore their livelihoods. Drift from 2,4-D is already responsible for more episodes of crop injury than any other herbicide, and its vastly increased use promises still more damage to crops like non-GE soybeans and cotton, vegetables and fruit.  

While Dow says it has developed a new formulation less prone to drifting for miles, the older highly volatile formula is still widely available and its lower cost creates a powerful market incentive to continue its use. And we know from experience that regardless of best practices put forth, pesticide drift is difficult to contain.

We urge you to reject Dow's application and keep 2,4-D from being widely used across America's farmland. 

Sincerely, 

Judy Hatcher, Executive Director, Pesticide Action Network 
On behalf of 17,287 concerned individuals, signatures attached
docketTitle: Evaluation of 2,4-D Choline Salt Herbicide on Enlist Corn and Soybeans

docketTitle: Evaluation of 2,4-D Choline Salt Herbicide on Enlist Corn and Soybeans

title: Mass comment campaign submitted by David Murphy, Founder/Executive Director, Food Democracy Now (17,691 comments)
commentText:
ATTN: Dow Chemicals Enlist Duo 2,4-D and Glyphosate Herbicide Mix, Docket No. EPA-HQ-OPP-2014-0195-0427 
Dear Administrator McCarthy,

On behalf of the non-profit sustainable agriculture organization Food Democracy Now!, I would like to submit the following comments to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency on behalf of more than 17,691 American farmers and citizens to urge that this administration reject the approval of the Enlist Duo 2,4-D and glyphosate herbicide combination developed for application to Dow Chemicals genetically engineered herbicide-tolerant corn and soybeans.
I am writing to urge you to deny approval for Dow Chemicals Enlist Duo 2,4-D and glyphosate herbicide combination, a major component of Agent Orange, the chemical defoliant used by the U.S. military in Vietnam, and glyphosate, the main chemical component in Monsantos best selling herbicide Roundup for the Environmental Protection Agencys Docket No. EPA-HQ-OPP-2014-0195-0427. 

The scientific community has sounded alarms about the dangers of 2,4-D for decades. Numerous studies link 2,4-D exposure to major health problems such as cancer, lowered sperm counts, liver toxicity, Parkinsons disease and birth anomalies in the children of pesticide applicators. Industry and independent scientific tests show that 2,4-D is still contaminated with dioxins. Dioxin contaminants in Agent Orange are thought to be a major cause of many serious medical conditions in both Vietnam veterans and the Vietnamese, including birth defects in the children of exposed parents. EPA has reported that 2,4-D is the seventh largest source of dioxins in the U.S. 

Commercial approval of Dows soy will trigger a large increase in 2,4-D use, but USDA has not conducted a meaningful review of the consequent harm to native ecosystems, crop injury from 2,4-D drifting onto neighboring fields, or the evolution of weeds resistant to 2,4-D. 2,4-D is already the number one culprit in drift-related crop injury complaints, and the huge increase in its use with 2,4-D soy will exacerbate these harms. Even the existing uses of 2,4-D have been found likely to jeopardize protected species such as Pacific salmon, and likely to adversely affect the California red-legged frog and Alameda whipsnake; USDAs approval of 2,4-D soy would worsen these impacts, as well as place many other similar and endangered species at risk. 

Additionally, Dow plans to sell this GE 2-4,D soy stacked with resistance to glyphosatethe active ingredient in Roundup, yet neither Dow nor USDA has analyzed the potential synergistic or cumulative impacts that these planned combinations pose. 

Dow is hyping 2,4-D corn and soy as the supposed solution to glyphosate-resistant weeds, which themselves were fostered by GMO Roundup Ready crop systems. As Dow and other pesticide firms develop new crops resistant to ever more herbicides, weeds will match and exceed them by evolving multiple resistances, and farmers will respond with increasingly toxic herbicidal cocktails. This chemical arms race with weeds means more pesticidal pollution, more disease, higher production costs, and of course increasing profits for firms like Dow that sell both GE seed and pesticides. 

In addition, an increasing number of studies have shown that Roundup is possibly linked to serious human health problems including birth defects, infertility, allergies, liver disease and auto-immune problems.

Already, the over application of Roundup has led to the explosion of superweeds on more than 70 million acres of U.S. farmland, leading to economic hardship for America's farmers and the loss of critical habitat and an alarming decline in Monarch butterfly populations. Rather than double down on this deeply flawed and unsustainable technology, America must invest in more productive methods of food production, like organic and sustainable agriculture.

At a time when farmers, citizens and government have worked hard to limit our use of, and exposure to, toxic chemicals like 2,4-D and dioxins, approving the Enlist Duo herbicidal mix for new GMO crops will take us dramatically backwards, endangering human health and the environment. I urge you to heed the warnings of the scientific and environmental communities and deny approval of Dow Chemicals Enlist Duo herbicidal mix created for 2,4-D and glyphosate resistant genetically engineered corn and soy. At the very least, the EPA must conduct a comprehensive Environmental Impact Statement that carefully examines the human health, environmental and agricultural harms that will be triggered by the increased application of the combination of 2,4-D and glyphosate, including a cumulative assessment that considers the compounded harms from additional deregulation of Dows 2,4-D and glyphosate herbicidal mix.
Sincerely,

David Murphy
Founder | Executive Director
Food Democracy Now!

title: Mass Comment campaign sponsored by Organic Consumers Association (web)24,568 signatures
commentText:
Docket No. EPA-HQ-OPP-2014-0195-0427 

I urge you to reject Dows request to use its Enlist Duo herbicide on its genetically 
engineered herbicide-tolerant corn and soy. 

Rather than expanding the uses of 2,4-D and glyphosate, the EPA should ban these 
dangerous herbicides that have been linked to serious health harms. Both have 
been linked to cancer, birth defects and endocrine disruption. 

The dramatic rise in glyphosate use in conjunction with Roundup Ready crops tells 
us that widespread use of 2,4-D on corn and soy that is genetically engineered to 
tolerate the herbicide will create a surge in its application. The use of 2,4-D has 
already gone up several-fold since bottoming out in the early 2000s. Experts predict 
its use could increase by 50 times if the use of Enlist Duo on Dows herbicide 
tolerant crops is approved. 

Dramatically increasing the use of these herbicides would exacerbate the public 
health crisis that is growing in the U.S. and other countries where 2,4-D and 
glyphosate are widely used. 

Please consider this new evidence that 2,4-D and glyphosate are too dangerous to 
continue to be used in food production: 

Antoniou M, Habib MEM, Howard CV, Jennings RC, Leifert C, et al. Teratogenic Effects 
of Glyphosate-Based Herbicides: Divergence of Regulatory Decisions from Scientific 
Evidence. J Environ Anal Toxicol 2012, S4:006. 

Samsel, A.; Seneff, S. Glyphosates Suppression of Cytochrome P450 Enzymes and 
Amino Acid Biosynthesis by the Gut Microbiome: Pathways to Modern Diseases. 
Entropy 2013, 15, 1416-1463. 

Samsel A, Seneff S. Glyphosate, pathways to modern diseases II: Celiac sprue and 
gluten intolerance. Interdiscip Toxicol. 2013 Dec;6(4):159-184. 

Schinasi, L.; Leon, M.E. Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma and Occupational Exposure to 
Agricultural Pesticide Chemical Groups and Active Ingredients: A Systematic Review 
and Meta-Analysis. Int. J. Environ. Res. Public Health 2014, 11, 4449-4527. 

We urge EPA to reject Dows petition for use of its Enlist Duo on herbicide-tolerant 
corn and soy, and we call on your Agency to instead ban these dangerous 
herbicide. 

Melinda Suelflow
Campaign Coordinator
Organic Consumers Association

6771 South Silver Hill Drive
Finland, MN  55603
(218) 226-4164

 
Campaigning for Health, Justice, Sustainability, Peace  and Democracy

ATTN: Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OAR-2008-0699, National Ambient Air Quality Standards for Ozone
Enclosed are 69,558 individual public comments collected by CREDO Action for submission to the National Ambient Air Quality Standards for Ozone docket. Individual comments may differ throughout, although the majority read as follows: 

The Clean Air Act requires the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to protect public health by setting standards that reflect scientific and medical knowledge. Set the standard to 60 parts per billion in order to adequately protect public health and safety. Anything less will endanger health and does not comply with the law.

The comments have been split into 15 documents in order to facilitate uploading to the Regulations.gov website.
 
Please contact me if you have any questions about the attached comment submissions.

Sincerely, 

Josh Nelson
Campaign Manager, CREDO Action 
jnelson@credoaction.com

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by CREDO Action (4,380 of 50,916)
commentText:
November 8, 2010

ATTN: Administrator Lisa Jackson and EPA staff
Mail code 5305T, 1200 Pennsylvania Ave ., NW
Washington, DC 20460

RE: Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-RCRA-2009-0640

Dear EPA Administrator Lisa Jackson, 

Please find attached the 1st of 13 documents containing 51,396 public comment submissions all recommending the EPA move ahead with the proposed federal regulations for coal ash storage and handling. While the statements vary, the majority of them read as follows: 

" I strongly support EPA moving ahead with proposed federal regulations for coal ash storage and handling. 

Improperly disposed of coal ash threatens our communities and our wildlife. So as you weigh your options for regulating coal ash, I hope you will consider the harm toxic contaminants in coal ash present to our drinking water and our streams.

Every year, 130 million tons of coal ash--containing arsenic, chromium, lead and mercury--is created by coal-fired power plants.  The toxins contained in the coal ash seep into our ecosystems and into our drinking water from unsafe storage in waste ponds and other venues.

States with most of the coal ash also have the weakest regulations--that's why it is critical that we set federally enforceable standards for coal ash disposal.  

Please do not cave to the coal industry by simply putting forth suggested guidelines for states. Safeguard our environment, protect public health and ensure that Dirty Coal properly handles this toxic waste."

If you have any questions about these comment submissions, please dont hesitate to contact me through the info below.

Sincerely,
Matt Lockshin
Campaign Manager, CREDO Action
mlockshin@credomobile.com
415.369.2000
docketTitle: Hazardous and Solid Waste Management System; Identification and Listing of Special Wastes; Disposal of Coal Combustion Residuals from Electric Utilities

States with most of the coal ash also have the weakest regulations--that's why it is critical that we set federally enforceable standards for coal ash disposal.  

Please do not cave to the coal industry by simply putting forth suggested guidelines for states. Safeguard our environment, protect public health and ensure that Dirty Coal properly handles this toxic waste."

If you have any questions about these comment submissions, please dont hesitate to contact me through the info below.

Sincerely,
Matt Lockshin
Campaign Manager, CREDO Action
mlockshin@credomobile.com
415.369.2000
