title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by United Farm Workers (UFW) (Web)
commentText:
These 16,365 people signed the UFW petition at https://takeaction.takepart.com/actions/speak-out-to-protect-farmworkers-from-pesticides-epa-s-aug-18-deadline-is-approaching?cmpid=tp-san w/thefollowing message

To: EPA Administrator Gina McCarthy

We are pleased that your agency has proposed revisions to the Worker Protection Standard, which provides workplace protections to farmworkers. These improvements are long overdue and vital to the health of farmworkers. They include (1) more frequent and improved safety training; (2) stronger requirements for protective equipment; and (3) wider buffer zones between application sites and working crews.

Some very important improvements are missing. We urge you to strengthen the proposed rule to ensure that the new WPS

    Adequately protects young farmworkers: The draft rule allows children as young as 16 to handle hazardous pesticides. This is not adequately protective, as teens bodies are still developing and are more vulnerable to toxic pesticides than adults. No child under the age of 18 should be allowed to handle pesticides.
    Protects farmworkers right to know: Farmworkers must have easy access to vital information about pesticides used in their workplace so they can take precautions to avoid injury. Workers shouldnt have to ask their employers for the name of the pesticide and its health effects, where and when it was applied, and when its safe to reenter a sprayed field. The central posting requirement for all pesticide applications should be reinstated.
    Provides safeguards for pesticide applicators: Workers who handle neurotoxic pesticides deserve the strongest protections medically available. California and Washington state have long-standing programs that monitor applicators exposures to these dangerous pesticides and have helped to reduce illness due to overexposure. All workers who handle these neurotoxins should have the same protections, regardless of the state in which they work.
    Our food system depends on the labor of more than 2 million farmworkers across the country. We hope and expect that you will act to ensure that these workers are provided the safe and healthy workplace they deserve. Thank you for your attention to this important matter.

Sincerely,
docketTitle: Pesticides: Agricultural Worker Protection Standard Revisions

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Earthjustice (Electronic)
commentText:
Thank you for giving the public this opportunity to weigh in on this issue.  

Attached, please find the comments and names of 9,543 total individuals who urge the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency to take the strongest regulatory approach to preclude farmworker exposure to pesticides and adequately address cases of overexposure.

* 214 of these individuals submitted a personalized comment, attached as: EPA-HQ-OPP-2011-0184_Earthjustice-personalized_214comments.pdf

* The names of the remaining 9,329 individuals who submitted the letter below as their public comment, are attached as: EPA-HQ-OPP-2011-0184_Earthjustice-std_9329comments.pdf

These comments are submitted on behalf of these individuals by Earthjustice, a nonprofit environmental law organization.

----------------------------------

Dear Environmental Protection Agency,

I care about the health and safety of our country's 2 million farmworkers and their families who work tirelessly to put food on our table.  While I commend the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) for proposing a stronger Worker Protection Standard (WPS) to safeguard farmworkers from harmful exposures to pesticides, I write to support many aspects of the proposed rule that foster worker health and safety and to underscore areas of the rule in need of strengthening in order to better protect farmworkers. 

Farmworkers are the population most overexposed to pesticides, and for far too long farmworkers have been treated as second class, afforded fewer protections than other workers. At a minimum, farmworkers should to be given the same protections afforded to workers in most other industries. 

Preventing occupational injury and exposure is fundamental to worker protection and it is imperative that we take the strongest regulatory approach to preclude farmworker exposure to pesticides and adequately address cases of overexposure. To that end, I recommend the following: 

* Training Frequency: Workers in other industries receive annual safety training and farmworkers deserve the same protection. To better protect farmworkers and their families from pesticide exposure, I support annual pesticide safety training for workers and pesticide handlers.

* Medical Monitoring: Medical monitoring is common in other industries and pesticide handlers deserve the same protections that are afforded to other workers. I support requiring medical monitoring for farmworkers who mix, load or apply handle the two particularly dangerous classes of neurotoxic pesticides (organophosphate and N-methyl carbamate pesticides) before symptoms or illness occurs. I strongly disagree with EPA's decision not to implement such a program nation-wide. Employers should give workers the option of blood tests to monitor exposure to these neurotoxic chemicals before symptoms or illness occurs. Since California and Washington have implemented a system to monitor workers who handle these types of pesticides, the number of poisonings involving these pesticides has gone down considerably in those states. 

* Hazard Communication: Reinstate the requirement for pesticide hazard information to be posted in a central location where farmworkers will know where to find it, rather than putting the burden on the farmworker to ask the employer for the information as currently proposed. Due to language barriers, legal status and/or fear of retaliation, workers will be reluctant to ask their employer for the information. Such information should also be available in nonemergency situations.

* Emergency Assistance: We support the EPA proposal to require employers to make transportation to a medical facility available to workers and handlers within 30 minutes of learning of an exposure and to require the employer to provide to the worker, handler or the treating medical personnel the Safety Data Sheet and pesticide label (as opposed to waiting for it to be requested). 

* Respirator Training and Fitting: We support requiring employers of pesticide handlers to comply with existing OSHA standards on respirator use, fit-testing of respirators, and medical evaluation requirements whenever a respirator is required by the labeling. 

* Mandatory Posting of Fields: Requiring posting of signs (rather than verbal notice) notifying workers about not reentering fields where pesticides that require a 24-hour period before reentry have been applied (rather than limiting the signage requirement to the two-day or 48-hour waiting period in the proposal). Monterey County, CA requires posting of fields where pesticides that require a 24-hour wait is applied and found that this approach resulted in a significant reduction in pesticide-related illness due to early reentry, which is a major cause of farmworker pesticide exposure and illness ...

[Please read the full comment in the attached documents.]
docketTitle: Pesticides: Agricultural Worker Protection Standard Revisions

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Earthjustice
commentText:
Attached, please find the personalized comments and names of 6,335 individuals.

In addition to their personalized comments, these individuals also signed their support of the following letter. Thank you for giving the public this opportunity to weigh in on this issue.  

These comments are submitted on behalf of these individuals by Earthjustice, a nonprofit environmental law organization.

----------------------------------

Dear Environmental Protection Agency,

Exposure to pesticides is one of the daily realities in the lives of the 2.5 million farmworkers in the U.S. today. Given their persistent exposure to harmful pesticides, it is not surprising that thousands experience acute pesticide illness or injury each year, and countless others suffer chronic health problems as a result of these toxic exposures. 

As a member of Earthjustice, I commend the EPA for moving forward in proposing stronger pesticide safety regulations to protect farmworkers and requiring record-keeping to facilitate enforcement. I respectfully submit the following comment on the proposed changes. Improving the protections, training and information available to workers will reduce human illness and protect wildlife and the environment. Improving farmworker health and safety will protect these vulnerable workers from needless suffering and injury and have far-reaching benefits by reducing healthcare costs and strains on our public health care system.

Farmworkers are the population most overexposed to pesticides, and for far too long farmworkers have been treated as second class, afforded fewer protections than other workers. At a minimum, farmworkers should be given the same protections afforded to workers in most other industries.

Training and related record-keeping should be improved. I applaud the Agency's efforts to improve the frequency and quality of pesticide safety trainings, as well as to institute record-keeping of when these trainings take place. I strongly support annual safety trainings. These are much needed changes.

Training on preventing take-home exposures is particularly important. Pesticide residues on a worker's hair, skin and clothing directly impact the health and well-being of young children in the home. Children are more vulnerable to the impacts of pesticide exposure, particularly during critical windows of development.

I appreciate that the Agency has proposed to reduce the 'grace period' before full WPS training is required, but this revision does not go far enough. EPA has proposed shortening the grace period to 2 days. No 'grace period' of any duration should be permitted. An uninformed farmworker is not equipped to do her or his job without putting themselves, their fellow workers, or their families at undue risk. The risks posed by allowing untrained workers to handle toxic chemicals, even for two days, is not tolerated in any other industry that involves exposure to hazardous chemicals. Workers must be adequately trained before they begin work.  

The current requirement for central posting should not be eliminated but should be enhanced. Farmworkers need ready access to basic information about the pesticides being used at their worksites. Posting information about recent pesticide applications in a central location is one of the most effective ways for workers to protect themselves from pesticide exposures. While there are limitations to this method, it should not be eliminated. Many farmworkers work in greenhouses, nurseries, and ferneries, where a central posting location is common and is viewed by the workers. The expectation that workers can obtain this information from their employers "upon request" is unreasonable and unrealistic. Farmworkers should not be expected to question their bosses in order to obtain information about pesticide applications that may endanger their health. Rather than eliminate this protection, EPA should retain the central posting requirement and in addition require training that provides specific information on the names and effects of the pesticides to which the workers will likely be exposed ...

[Please read the full comment in the attached document.]
docketTitle: Pesticides: Agricultural Worker Protection Standard Revisions

title: Mass Comment  Campaign sponsored by Farmworkers From Pesticides (14,201 signed petitions)
commentText:
To: EPA Administrator Gina McCarthy

Attached please find 14,201 people who signed the UFW petition "Speak Out to Protect Farmworkers From Pesticides by Aug. 18th" located at https://takeaction.takepart.com/actions/speak-out-to-protect-farmworkers-from-pesticides-epa-s-aug-18-deadline-is-approaching?cmpid=tp-san.

They requested we share the following message:

We are pleased that your agency has proposed revisions to the Worker Protection Standard, which provides workplace protections to farmworkers. These improvements are long overdue and vital to the health of farmworkers. They include (1) more frequent and improved safety training; (2) stronger requirements for protective equipment; and (3) wider buffer zones between application sites and working crews.

Some very important improvements are missing. We urge you to strengthen the proposed rule to ensure that the new WPS

Adequately protects young farmworkers: The draft rule allows children as young as 16 to handle hazardous pesticides. This is not adequately protective, as teens bodies are still developing and are more vulnerable to toxic pesticides than adults. No child under the age of 18 should be allowed to handle pesticides. 

Protects farmworkers right to know: Farmworkers must have easy access to vital information about pesticides used in their workplace so they can take precautions to avoid injury. Workers shouldnt have to ask their employers for the name of the pesticide and its health effects, where and when it was applied, and when its safe to reenter a sprayed field. The central posting requirement for all pesticide applications should be reinstated. 

Provides safeguards for pesticide applicators: Workers who handle neurotoxic pesticides deserve the strongest protections medically available. California and Washington state have long-standing programs that monitor applicators exposures to these dangerous pesticides and have helped to reduce illness due to overexposure. All workers who handle these neurotoxins should have the same protections, regardless of the state in which they work. 

Our food system depends on the labor of more than 2 million farmworkers across the country. We hope and expect that you will act to ensure that these workers are provided the safe and healthy workplace they deserve. Thank you for your attention to this important matter.

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by CREDO Action
commentText:
OPP Docket
Environmental Protection Agency Docket Center (EPA/DC) Mail code: 28221T
1200 Pennsylvania Ave. NW.
Washington, DC 20460        
                    
ATTN: Docket EPA-HQ-OPP-2011-0184, Agricultural Worker Protection Standard Revisions: Pesticides
                    
Enclosed are 67,038 individual public comments collected by CREDO Action for submission to the Agricultural Worker Protection Standard Revisions docket. Individual comments may differ throughout, although the majority read as follows: 

More than 1 billion pounds of dangerous pesticides are used in the production of agricultural crops in the U.S. annually, poisoning up to 20,000 farmworkers each year.

More protection for workers means greater access to protective equipment, more frequent safety trainings, mandatory entry restrictions on pesticide-treated fields until they are safe, and a first-ever 16-year-old minimum worker age restriction.

I urge you to enact the EPA's revised Worker Protection Standard to protect agricultural workers from toxic chemical exposure.

The comments have been split into 15 documents in order to facilitate uploading to the Regulations.gov website.
 
Please contact me if you have any questions about the attached comment submissions.

Sincerely, 

Josh Nelson
Campaign Manager, CREDO Action 
jnelson@credoaction.com 
415-369-2000

docketTitle: Greenhouse Gas Emissions Standards and Fuel Efficiency Standards for Medium- and Heavy-Duty Engines and Vehicles (Phase II)

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Sierra Club (web)
commentText:
January 5, 2018
Re: Docket: EPA-HQ-OAR-2014-0827-2368

Please find 10,747 comments attached for inclusion in the docket, EPA-HQ-OAR-2014-0827-2368, "Repeal of Emission Requirements for Glider Vehicles, Glider Engines, and Glider Kits." 1,022   individuals took the time to write the EPA a personal message, and all 10,747 have signed the following text:

"Dear EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt, 
The EPA should not repeal the emission requirements for glider vehicles, glider engines, and glider kits. 

Rolling back standards that limiting pollution from glider kit trucks (freight trucks with a used engine installed in an otherwise new frame), is a waste of taxpayer dollars and endangers the health and safety of American families and our climate. If the glider truck loophole were left open until 2025, EPA estimates indicate that glider vehicles would comprise only 5% of the freight trucks on the road but would account for 33% of all nitrogen oxides and particulate matter emissions from the heavy truck fleet, resulting in as many as 12,800 premature deaths. 

Used engines in gliders can emit as much as 40 times the greenhouse gas and particulate pollution of modern engines. But a repeal would declassify "glider kits" as new vehicles or engines, making them no longer subject to air pollution control requirements. A rollback is a blatant attempt to rig the system for the glider industry at the expense of American families and jobs. Nothing has changed in the last year that warrants a reopening of this lifesaving rule. 

A rollback of the glider kit emission standards would endanger public health and safety, the EPA should keep the rule intact."

We respectfully request that the 10,747 comments submitted by the individuals listed in the two documents below be reflected in the final comment tally for this docket.

Sincerely,
Andrew Linhardt
Deputy Legislative Director for Transportation  
Sierra Club
docketTitle: Greenhouse Gas Emissions Standards and Fuel Efficiency Standards for Medium- and Heavy-Duty Engines and Vehicles (Phase II)

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Moms Clean Air Force (web)
commentText:
Attached are the comments of 1,775 Moms Clean Air Force supporters across the country who have expressed concern about the EPA's proposal to repeal the emission standards and other requirements for heavy-duty glider vehicles, glider engines, and glider kits. The comment they each submitted reads: 

As a mom, I oppose EPA's efforts to reopen the glider trucks loophole. Super-polluting diesel engines should not be exempt from clean air rules. 
 
I am extremely concerned about the public health impacts of glider truck pollution. The pollution from diesel engines has been linked to heart attacks, arrhythmia, stroke, premature death, asthma, respiratory infections, lung cancer, low birth weight, and infant mortality.

Old engines in glider trucks can emit as much as 40 times the air pollution of modern engines. If the glider truck loophole were left open until 2025, EPA estimates indicate that glider vehicles would comprise only 5% of the freight trucks on the road but would account for 33% of all nitrogen oxides and particulate matter emissions from the heavy truck fleet. The resulting cardiovascular and respiratory disease would lead to thousands of premature deaths. 
 
The proposed rollback endangers the public's health and represents a profound disregard for EPA's core mission of protecting public health from pollution. EPA should put our health first. Protect our families from dangerous diesel pollution, and keep super-polluting glider trucks off the road. 


Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns about this submission. 

Thank you.
docketTitle: Greenhouse Gas Emissions Standards and Fuel Efficiency Standards for Medium- and Heavy-Duty Engines and Vehicles (Phase II)

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Environmental Defense Fund (EDF) (web)
commentText:
To Whom It May Concern: 

Attached are the signatures of 50,221 Environmental Defense Fund supporters from across the country who have submitted comments opposing EPA's proposal to repeal emission requirements for glider vehicles, glider engines, and glider kits. The comment they each submitted reads: 

"I'm writing today with great concern over EPA's proposal to reopen the 'glider truck' loophole. Doing so would give an unfair competitive advantage to these super-polluting trucks over trucks that achieve clean air standards. 

Freight truck leaders invested in and now sell cleaner freight trucks and engines. Reopening this loophole could put their prudent investments--and their employees' jobs--at risk, which is why numerous trucking industry leaders have publicly opposed the unfair competition and pollution that would be allowed by a glider kit loophole. 

But this policy wouldn't just unfairly pick winners and losers in the industry. It would put Americans' lives at risk. According to EPA estimates, if the glider truck loophole were left open until 2021, glider vehicles would result in as many as 6,400 premature deaths. These trucks emit as much as 40 times the pollution of modern engines, contributing to a host of respiratory problems that increase our national healthcare costs and put our lives at risk. 

Reopening this loophole takes America in the wrong direction. Please reconsider this dangerous decision."

Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns about this submission. 

Thank you for your consideration,

Heather Shelby
Manager, Grassroots Activism & Engagement
Environmental Defense Fund
hshelby@edf.org
(202) 572 3242

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by World Wildlife Fund (WWF) (6814)
commentText:
I am writing in support of the proposed fuel efficiency standards for new cars and light trucks.

The proposed standards will strengthen fuel efficiency and reduce the
carbon pollution contributing to climate change. By increasing
standards for new passenger cars and light trucks to 54.5 mpg by 2025,
we will show the world that the U.S. is serious about curbing climate
change and reducing our dependence on oil.

I urge both the Environmental Protection Agency and the Department of Transportation to finalize these strong standards.

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsoring organization unknown (22,122)
commentText:
Dear Mr. President:

I support the proposed rule to increase fuel economy for new passenger
vehicles to an average of 54.5 miles per gallon by 2025, which will
allow cars and light trucks to drive farther on a gallon of gas and
reduce U.S. dependence on imported oil.

The price of gas is once again squeezing the budgets of American
families, who already are forced to cut back in other areas just to pay
for basic transportation needs.

This spring, you set a goal of reducing oil imports by one-third this
decade, and in November you proposed fuel efficiency standards that
will effectively double current requirements. I commend your efforts. I
believe it is important to increase U.S. investment in fuel efficient
technologies, save consumers money at the pump, help this country break
its dependence on foreign oil, and protect the environment. Don't let
these standards be watered down -- protect and finalize the new fuel
efficiency rules.

Sincerely,

Jim Georges
docketTitle: EPA/NHTSA Joint Rulemaking to Establish Light-duty Vehicle GHG Emissions Standards and CAFE Standards for Model Year 2017 and Later

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by National Wildlife Federation Action Fund (13,300)
commentText:
I am submitting the following comments in support of strong fuel efficiency standards, along with the names of the 13,300 supporters of the National Wildlife Federation Action Fund who have sent similar comments to the docket via emails to a-and-r-Docket@epa.gov:

I support making our nation's cars and trucks more efficient to cut the carbon pollution from car exhaust that is driving global warming, which threatens the future of American wildlife.

Taken together, the new and proposed fuel economy standards will cut our demand for oil by 3.4 million barrels per day.  That equates to nearly a third of today's transportation fuel use and it cuts carbon pollution by more than 600 million metric tons per year in 2030--that's about 10% of total US carbon pollution today.

These deep oil savings also mean less pressure for risky new drilling projects in the Arctic or to clear cut forest for Canadian tar sands. 

Please move forward with strong fuel efficiency standards that cut oil use and reduce carbon pollution.

Thanks you!

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2016-01865
commentText:
Western Values Project submits the following 26,725 signatures to support the BLM Rule on Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation (Docket #: BLM- 2016-000). 

These signatures were collected during the comment period from petitions on Change.org (https://www.change.org/p/stop-natural-gas-waste-on-our-public-lands-7/) and The Petition Site (http://www.thepetitionsite.com/takeaction/674/794/504/).

Western Values Project

Petition Text

Letter to Bureau of Land Management Thank You for Combating Natural Gas Waste

I'm writing to voice my support for the recent draft rule to limit the waste of natural gas on our public lands. At present, this waste on our federal and tribal lands here in the West undermines energy security and threatens our health - and means taxpayers are losing out on millions of dollars in revenue each year that we could use to improve our schools, build new roads, and repair infrastructure.

Thanks to leadership from the Bureau of Land Management, we now have a draft rule that will take steps to combat this waste, on behalf of all American taxpayers, by reducing flaring, reducing venting, and modernizing the royalty rates charged on wasted gas. Now, I'm writing to ensure that this rule stays strong.

A strong rule to cut natural gas waste on America's public lands would phase out flaring from oil and gas operations, require companies to use a affordable, commonsense technologies that are available now, and require regular (at least quarterly) monitoring to detect leaks.

Thank you for your leadership on this issue. I support a strong rule aimed at ending natural gas waste.
docketTitle: Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2016-01865
docketTitle: Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2016-01865
commentText:
To:Bureau of Land Management Principal Deputy Director Neil Kornze
Thank you for taking action to lower methane waste and pollution from the oil and gas industry on our public lands. To protect our climate from harmful methane pollution, we need to stop venting and flaring, and the Bureau of Land Management's draft rules are an important step forward.
As the administration finalizes these rules, I urge you to make some improvements to ensure that public lands are protected and gas is not wasted:
	Improve leak detection and repair requirements by increasing the frequency of required leak inspections to quarterly for all wells
	Strengthen the control measures and monitoring requirements applicable to pneumatic controllers by requiring the use of zero-bleed pneumatics where feasible and extending standards to intermittent-bleed as well as continuous-bleed natural gas-driven pneumatic controllers
	Improve flaring regulation to more effectively limit the waste of federal and tribal natural gas resources from flaring by making gas-capture plans mandatory and binding, tightening exemption provisions by limiting the scope of current exemptions, their length, and the ability to renew exemptions indefinitely, and requiring operators to report all capture and forgone revenue information in applications; also set a time limit beyond which flaring, even below 1,800 MCF per month per well, is prohibited
	Ensure enforcement of venting, flaring, and leak regulations; enforcement of waste minimization plans is also crucial to ensuring that the plans are carried through during development and production of oil and gas on federal lands
	Improve the rule to provide for improved transparency and accountability by allowing for more public involvement and comment
In addition to strong standards to curb methane pollution and waste, we must work to keep as many fossil fuels in the ground as possible if we are going to stave off the worst effects of climate change. Methane is a highly potent greenhouse gas that we cannot continue to emit if we want to meet the administration's international climate commitments. It's time to end oil and gas leasing on public lands.

 3,253 signatures attached.
docketTitle: Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2016-01865
commentText:
League of Conservation Voters
1920 L St. NW 
Washington, DC 20036

April 22, 2016

Bureau of Land Management 

Dear BLM Director Neil Kornze,

The League of Conservation Voters today, April 22, 2016, is submitting 4,055 comments in favor of strong methane pollution standards for our public lands. For the health and security of our communities and our climate, we ask that you please take these comments into consideration. 

Sincerely, 
Brooke Still
Digital Campaigns Manager
League of Conservation Voters


Petition: 

Subject: Please finalize strong standards for methane pollution

Dear BLM Director Kornze,

Thank you for proposing commonsense safeguards to reduce natural gas waste and methane pollution from oil and gas drilling on America's public and tribal lands. Reducing methane pollution that is vented, flared, and leaked from our public lands is a win for our climate, public health, and taxpayers. These proposed regulations are an important step in the right direction and I urge you to finalize them as quickly as possible. 

As the administration finalizes this rule, I ask that you eliminate several loopholes and strengthen the rule to ensure a fair return to taxpayers and adequate protection for public health and the environment. Please ensure that strong enforcement measures are included, while also strengthening limits on flaring and increasing the frequency of required leak detection and repair inspections. 

Thank you again for taking this critical step to protect our climate and environment.  I urge you to strengthen and finalize the proposed regulations as soon as possible to ensure we leave a safe and healthy planet for generations to come. 

Sincerely, 
The undersigned
docketTitle: Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2016-01865

docketTitle: Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2016-01865
commentText:
Attached are files containing the names of 11,478 individuals who have submitted public comments urging the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) to strengthen the proposed regulations on methane waste and pollution on federal and tribal lands. In addition to signing on in support of the following letter, 2,160 individuals of the total number have submitted personalized comments. The personalized comments start on page 2 and end on page 111 in the .pdf file. Earthjustice has also included the excel files of the individual comments.

Reducing waste and protecting the climate (RE: BLM-2016-0001-0001)

Dear Secretary Jewell and Director Kornze,

Thank you for proposing commonsense regulations that will reduce natural gas waste and pollution on America's public and tribal lands. Reducing natural gas waste is a win for taxpayers, the climate and public health. While the proposed regulations are an important step in the right direction and I urge you to finalize them as quickly as possible, I also ask that you eliminate several loopholes and strengthen the rule to ensure a fair return to taxpayers and adequate protection for public health and the environment.

By requiring oil and gas companies to capture natural gas that would otherwise leak into the air or be vented or burned in a flare, the proposed regulations capture both finite energy resources and millions of tax dollars for federal, state and tribal governments that can be used to fund schools, healthcare and needed road improvements. The BLM is required by law to ensure that these publicly owned resources are not wasted. 

I applaud the BLM for regulating existing oil and gas infrastructure, which is responsible for substantial emissions of the powerful greenhouse gas methane. Regulation of existing sources is necessary to achieve our international climate commitments and avoid the worst impacts of climate change. The BLM's proposal will also protect public health by reducing emissions of ozone-forming pollutants linked to asthma attacks, heart disease and premature death.

The BLM should improve the proposed regulation to better address methane waste and pollution on federal and tribal lands. For example, the BLM should tighten the flaring requirements, increase the frequency with which operators must check for and repair leaky equipment, eliminate loopholes, ensure proper enforcement, and increase transparency through public involvement. 

I am pleased to see the BLM taking steps to modernize its approach to waste on public and tribal lands. A 2016 Colorado College poll found that 80 percent of Westerners support commonsense measures to cut down on waste. The public hearings held across the West confirmed widespread and diverse support for waste reduction measures. Please strengthen and finalize the proposed regulations as soon as possible.

The Undersigned
docketTitle: Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation

title: CA
commentText:
April 8, 2013

Jacob Ackerman
Health Insurance Specialist
CMS, HHS
7500 Security Boulevard
Baltimore, MD 21244

Docket ID: CMS-2012-0031

Dear Mr. Ackerman

I am writing to deliver the public comments of 113,697 Americans who support the methodology outlined in the proposed decision on Rulemaking No. CMS-2012-0031-63161, which would establish alternative ways to fulfill the requirements of the Public Health Service Act and corresponding provisions under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. 

These comments have been collected by CREDO Action. Though the comments vary slightly from person to person, the majority read as follows: 

Thank you for the new the Affordable Care Act rules on contraception, which ensure that women have access to no-cost birth control. Please continue to protect this access, regardless of the right-wing opposition.

The comments are attached. (This is the [5 of 9] attachments.) If you have any questions about these signatures, please dont hesitate to contact me through the information provided below.

Sincerely,
Jordan Krueger
Campaign Manager, CREDO Action
415-369-2000

docketTitle: Rulemaking for the Steam Electric Power Generating Effluent Limitations Guidelines

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Environmental Law & Policy Center (ELPC) (web)
commentText:
July 5, 2017

Submitted electronically at www.regulations.gov 

Attention Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OW-2009-0819

RE: Postponement of Certain Compliance Dates for the Effluent Limitations Guidelines (ELG) and Standards for the Steam Electric Power Generating Point Source Category

The Environmental Law & Policy Center (ELPC) submits 166 comments opposing the postponement of certain compliance dates. 

In 2015, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) revised outdated toxic water pollution discharge standards for power plants. Once implemented, this Toxic Water Rule would eliminate 1.4 billion pounds of toxic metals and chemicals like mercury and lead, and other harmful pollutants from being dumped into our rivers, lakes and streams every year.  ELPC and our members strongly oppose EPA's proposal to delay certain compliance deadlines for the ELG (or Toxic Water Rule), which was published in the Federal Register on November 3, 2015 and became effective on January 4, 2016.
In the five years leading up to the 2015 Toxic Water Rule, many coal plants dumped thousands of pounds of toxic metals and other harmful pollutants into the Midwest's rivers, lakes and streams.

For example:

	In Illinois, the Havana Power Station discharged more than 1,000 pounds of lead into waters that flow into the Illinois River;
	In Ohio,  the Cardinal Power Station discharged 11,500 pounds of arsenic into waters that flow into the Ohio River; and
	In Indiana, the Petersburg Generating Station discharged 5,700 pounds of arsenic and 1,200 pounds of lead into waters that flow into the White River.

We urge that EPA uphold compliance deadlines established as part of the Toxic Water Rule. Coal-fired power plants have had a free pass to pollute our drinking water, aquatic life habitats and recreational water sources for too long. They have put the health of downstream communities and economies at risk. Because of this reckless practice:

	Across the Midwest, health departments have advisories warning against eating locally caught fish that are contaminated with heavy metals.
	45% of waterways that receive coal plant wastewater are contaminated with high levels of heavy metals or other harmful pollutants.
	Toxic chemicals in coal plant wastewater such as mercury, lead, and arsenic can cause cancer and other health problems.
	These chemicals concentrate up the food chain resulting in long-term damage to aquatic ecosystems.

The compliance dates included in the 2015 final Toxic Water Rule are necessary for achieving clean safe drinking water, habitats for aquatic life, and safe and better recreation and tourism throughout the Midwest.

Attached are 166 comments opposing the delay in compliance deadlines, from ELPC members and supporters from across the Midwest and beyond.

We appreciate EPA's consideration of these comments.

Respectfully submitted,
 
 
Ann Mesnikoff
Federal Legislative Director
Environmental Law & Policy Center
docketTitle: Rulemaking for the Steam Electric Power Generating Effluent Limitations Guidelines

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Clean Water Action (web)
commentText:
July 6, 2017

Submitted electronically at www.regulations.gov 
Attention: Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OW-2009-0819

RE: Postponement of Certain Compliance Dates for the Effluent Limitations Guidelines and Standards for the Steam Electric Power Generating Point Source Category

Dear Administrator Pruitt:

Clean Water Action is submitting the more than two thousand attached comments from our members around the country, urging EPA to not delay any of the compliance deadlines for the 2015 Effluent Limitations Guidelines and Standards for the Steam Electric Power Generating Point Source Category nor propose to weaken any of the pollution limits required in these final standards.

Before the 2015 final standards were issued, effluent guidelines and standards for steam electric power plants had not been updated since 1982 and contained no limits on arsenic, lead, mercury, and other harmful pollutants. EPA issued the final ELG rule in 2015 after an extensive rulemaking process, which included numerous technical and scientific studies and hundreds of thousands of public comments, the majority in support of eliminating toxic water pollution from power plants.

Affordable technologies exist today that can eliminate nearly all of this pollution - in fact, many plants are already using it, and the remaining plants must upgrade to these 21st century technologies. The standards finalized in 2015 were already long overdue and any further delay will result in more polluted streams and lakes that are unsafe for fishing and place additional public health risk on communities that rely on drinking water sources downstream of coal fired power plants.

We urge you to not delay any of the compliance deadlines for the final 2015 standards and guidelines for steam electric power plants, nor propose to weaken any of the pollution limits required in these final standards. 

Sincerely, 
Jennifer Peters
Water Programs Director
Clean Water Action
docketTitle: Rulemaking for the Steam Electric Power Generating Effluent Limitations Guidelines

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Sierra Club (web)
commentText:
RE: Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OW-2009-0819
To Whom It May Concern:
Please see attached written comments supported by 32,690 supporters of the Sierra Club.  Their names and contact information are also included below.

Please do not delay any of the compliance deadlines for the 2015 Effluent Limitations Guidelines and Standards for the Steam Electric Power Generating Point Source Category nor propose to weaken any of the pollution limits required in these final standards. 
Before the 2015 final standards were issued, effluent guidelines and standards for coal-fired power plants had not been updated since 1982 and contained no limits on arsenic, lead, mercury, and other harmful pollutants. EPA issued the final ELG rule in 2015 after an extensive rulemaking process, which included numerous technical and scientific studies and hundreds of thousands of public comments, the majority in support of eliminating toxic water pollution from power plants. 
Affordable technologies exist today that can eliminate nearly all of this pollution - in fact, many plants are already using it, and the remaining plants must upgrade to these 21st century technologies. The standards finalized in 2015 were already long overdue and any further delay will result in more polluted streams and lakes that are unsafe for fishing and place additional public health risk on communities that rely on drinking water sources downstream of coal fired power plants. 
I urge you to not delay any of the compliance deadlines for the final 2015 standards and guidelines for coal -fired power plants, nor propose to weaken any of the pollution limits required in these final standards. Thank you for considering my concerns.
docketTitle: Rulemaking for the Steam Electric Power Generating Effluent Limitations Guidelines

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by EarthJustice (web)
commentText:
Attached is a file containing the names of 23,669 individuals who have submitted public comments urging the Environmental Protection Agency to reconsider postponing compliance for the Effluent Limitation Guidelines and Standards for Steam Electric Power Plants. In addition to signing on in support of the following letter, 5,277 individuals of the total number have submitted personalized comments. The personalized comments start on page 2 and end on page 307.

Don't postpone compliance for Effluent Limitation Guidelines and Standards for Steam Electric Power Plants (EPA-HQ-OW-2009-0819)

Dear Administrator Pruitt,

I am writing to share my deep disappointment at your proposal to put an indefinite hold on compliance for the Effluent Limitation Guidelines and Standards for Steam Electric Power Plants. This 2015 rule was a long-overdue update to protect our communities, families, and environment from lead, mercury, arsenic, cadmium and many other dangerous toxic pollutants that coal-fired power plants dump into our waters. Power plants are by far the largest source of toxic pollution in the U.S. and have contaminated over 23,000 miles of rivers. These toxins are linked to cancer and neurological damage, and they bioaccumulate in fish and wildlife, further harming public health.

I urge you to reconsider this damaging proposal. The 2015 Steam Electric Effluent Limitation Guidelines rule for the first time addressed the serious problem of toxic pollution from power plant wastewater. We simply cannot continue to ignore this problem.

Sincerely,

The Undersigned
docketTitle: Rulemaking for the Steam Electric Power Generating Effluent Limitations Guidelines

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Earthjustice (web)
commentText:
Earthjustice, a public interest law organization, has been collecting public comments on the Environmental Protection Agencys effluent limitations guidelines and standards (Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OW-2009-0819). Comments were submitted directly to ow-docket@epa.gov, however, our delivery reports show that many did not make it through. In order to supplement those direct comments, here is a compilation of the individuals who submitted comments. The default comment, which individuals were able to customize and send directly to the EPA, is below. Thank you for your time.
 
-----
 
I urge the EPA to finalize the strongest proposed standards for power plant pollution to protect our waterways. I believe that the power generation industry needs to be accountable for the toxic waste dumped into our rivers and streams.
 
Best available technology should be used to keep the public safe, because the water we rely on can no longer be a dumping ground. By far the best option proposed by EPA is for power plants to install zero liquid discharge technology and convert to safer coal ash handling systems that will eliminate discharges of the most contaminated wastewaters entirely.
 
Too many streams, lakes and rivers have been poisoned by power plant water pollution. The EPA should protect local communities from this pollution by adopting the strongest possible safeguards.
docketTitle: Rulemaking for the Steam Electric Power Generating Effluent Limitations Guidelines

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Sierra Club (web)
commentText:
Dear Administrator Pruitt,

We, the below undersigned over 115,000 Sierra Club members and supporters oppose repeal or weakening of the Clean Power Plan. Please find our names, cities, and zip codes attached along with personalized comments opposing repeal or replacement of the CPP.

All have signed on to the following comment and in many cases provided an individual comment or story, which can be found in the attached spreadsheet:

"I am deeply concerned about the effects of climate change, especially in the wake of extreme weather events that are fueled by a warming world -- stronger hurricanes, unprecedented flooding, and raging wildfires.

The Clean Power Plan is the most significant government action to mitigate climate change. We must not change it. If anything, it should be made stronger to even better protect the health our families and communities. Limiting carbon pollution from coal power plants doesn?t just help us fight climate change, the EPA has previously reported that the Clean Power Plan would prevent 90,000 asthma attacks, 300,000 missed work and school days, and 3,600 premature deaths annually by 2030. 

Dismantling or repealing the Clean Power Plan, will put the health and well-being of our communities, especially communities of color and low-income families that bear the brunt of climate impacts, further at risk. Millions of Americans count on the government to help protect them from crisis and public health disasters. This is one of those moments: Please do not rescind or dismantle the Clean Power Plan."

Sincerely,
115,000 Sierra Club Members and Supporters

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC) (web)

Our supporters oppose any effort to weaken, repeal, or replace the Clean Power Plan, the first national initiative to cut carbon pollution. These comments will also be submitted for the formal comment period on the Clean Power Plan. Thank you.
docketTitle: Greenhouse Gas Emission Guidelines for Existing Stationary Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Clean Water Action (web)
commentText:
February 26, 2018
Docket ID: EPA-HQ-OAR-2017-0545

To Whom It May Concern, 

On behalf of Clean Water Action, I am submitting 1,633 comments from our members opposing any attempt to dismantle the lifesaving Clean Power Plan and replace it with weaker standards that would expose millions of Americans to more pollution. Instead, EPA should strengthen safeguards that address climate change. Any replacement to the Clean Power Plan should reduce carbon pollution even more than the original standards to reflect the market's rapid shift towards clean energy and the falling cost of renewable energy sources like wind and solar. 

EPA has a duty to protect us from climate change, which is exacerbating destructive extreme weather events that threaten our communities, our families, and our way of life. EPA's mission is to "protect human health and the environment" - we need you to live up to that solemn responsibility by reducing the pollution that causes climate change.

Sincerely, 	
Andrew Grinberg 
National Campaigns Special Projects Manager
docketTitle: Greenhouse Gas Emission Guidelines for Existing Stationary Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Climate Reality Project (web)
commentText:
Dear Administrator Pruitt:

The Climate Reality Project believes that any rule to replace America's historic Clean Power Plan must promote clean energy over dirty fossil fuels and protect our health and our environment. Our staff has worked to raise awareness about the Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (ANPR) comment period and encourage our supporters to stand up for strong regulations on the climate change-driving harmful emissions from power plants. The 12,653 comments attached reflect signatures gathered online from our supporters across the country demanding the government prioritize clean energy over fossil fuels, as stated by this language presented to signees:

We strongly oppose repealing the Clean Power Plan.

Poll after poll shows that the overwhelming majority of Americans want the government to confront the climate crisis head-on by shifting from dirty fossil fuels to clean, renewable energy. When EPA proposed the Clean Power Plan, over 4.3 million Americans spoke up to support it. 

The message couldn't be any clearer: We want a clean energy economy. 

The Clean Power Plan is an example of the federal government listening to the American people and taking action. By repealing it, we allow carbon pollution and toxic emissions from the power sector to continue driving climate change and causing health issues for the most vulnerable among us. And we compromise the continued growth of the booming clean energy and efficiency industry that already employs 2.8 million Americans - more than oil, coal, and gas combined.

The Clean Power Plan lays out a legal system designed to be flexible, using legal precedent to offer power plants the option of fulfilling their goals by shifting generation to clean energy off-site. This is the most cost-effective and best way for utilities to reduce emissions by the level necessary to tackle the climate crisis. 

A clean energy economy is good for our planet, our families, and our health. We strongly oppose repealing the Clean Power Plan and call on EPA to act on climate for the sake of all Americans.

The Climate Reality Project and its many supporters demand that the Environmental Protection Agency live up to its mission of protecting our health and environment by cutting carbon pollution from power plants and encouraging clean energy development.

Sincerely,

Ken Berlin
President and CEO, The Climate Reality Project

Re: Defining and Delimiting the Exemptions for Executive, Administrative, Professional, Outside Sales and Computer Employees, Regulatory Information Number (RIN): 1235-AA11

Dear Ms. Ziegler:

Attached please find 183 individual public comments collected by the Economic Policy Institute for submission to the Department of Labor's proposed rulemaking on overtime pay. The comments read as follows: 

"President Obama and the U.S. Department of Labor are proposing to raise the overtime thresholdwhat you can be paid and still qualify for "time-and-a-half" beyond 40 hours per week from $23,600 a year to $50,400. This is a BIG deal. Because of it, about 13 million workers will get a raise.

But if the National Retail Federationwhich includes Walmarthas their way, workers might not ever see a dime of that extra overtime pay.

That's because the National Retail Federation, the National Association of Home Builders, and other corporate lobbyists are trying to run out the clock. Their first step: get the Department of Labor to extend the public comment period by 90 more days. If these corporate lobbyists succeed, they'll stop the new overtime pay rules from taking effect before the holidaysand possibly delay implementation indefinitely.

Join the Economic Policy Institute, Democracy for America, and Robert Reich to tell the Department of Labor: Don't delay overtime pay one day more."

Please contact me if you have any questions about the attached comment submissions.

Sincerely, 

Daniel Essrow

title: Cruickshank, Robert
commentText:
We support the proposed rule that would raise the overtime pay threshold to at least $50,400 per year, and support closing loopholes so that more workers will be eligible to receive overtime pay. This plan is a courageous step in the right direction. It's like a minimum wage hike for the middle class.

Since 1975 we have seen the effective wages of American workers decline. One of the reasons for this is that the overtime threshold has not kept pace with inflation. Workers are not receiving the benefits of their labor and as a result, wages have stagnated or in some cases fallen. The proposed rule would go a long way in addressing this disparity, strengthening our economy by providing more income to households that they can turn around and spend at businesses, creating new jobs and growing our GDP.

On behalf of 33,019 members of Democracy for America, we are submitting their public comments via the attached CSV file in support of the new rules regarding overtime pay.

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2018-03144
commentText: Attached is the second of seventeen files containing  59,610 letters from Friends of the Earth members opposing the roll back the Methane and Waste Prevention rule.
docketTitle: Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation; Rescission or Revision of Certain Requirements

title:
Comment on FR Doc # 2018-03144
10,937 comments
commentText:
Docket ID: BLM-2018-0001

Dear Secretary Zinke,

Please find attached a file containing 10,937 signatories to our advocacy petition encouraging your agency to protect the Bureau of Land Management's Methane Waste Prevention Rule. 

In partnership with The Wilderness Society, members of Care2.com have signed on to some version of the text below:*

====
I oppose the proposal to gut the Bureau of Land Management's Methane Waste Prevention Rule. 

Methane waste and pollution is a serious problem on public lands. Leaking, venting, and flaring from natural gas facilities wastes hundreds of millions of dollars in taxpayer owned natural resources every year. The new proposal eliminates key provisions, which protect against exposure to dangerous pollutants and promotes the waste of 299 billion cubic feet of natural gas, enough energy to heat nearly 500,000 homes each year for the next ten years. In addition, your proposal is a huge step backward on the fight to tackle climate change, resulting in the same amount of short-term climate damage as 8.3 million cars driven over ten years. 

Rolling back the Methane and Waste Prevention Rule results in a free pass to oil and gas companies to waste American energy and pollute on our public lands. Capturing wasted gas would promote responsible energy production and job growth while safeguarding American health and royalty revenue. 

I urge you to halt the effort to gut the rule and instead protect our public lands, health and pocketbooks from methane waste and pollution.
====

* We offered individuals the opportunity to personalize their comments.

Thank you for your agencys collaboration in ensuring that the voices of these concerned activists are heard.

Sincerely,
Ashley Allison 
Director of Client Campaigns, Care2.com

P.S. If you have any questions about the data, please contact me at ashleya@care2team.com
docketTitle: Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation; Rescission or Revision of Certain Requirements

docketTitle: Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation; Rescission or Revision of Certain Requirements

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2018-03144  30,883 comments
commentText:
Please find 30,883 comments attached for inclusion in this docket, BLM-2018-0001-0001, Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation: Rescission or Revision of Certain Requirements regarding the proposed weakening of methane pollution protections. 

Nearly 4,000 people have taken the time to write a personalized comment and all 30,883 have signed to the following text:

Im strongly opposed to the recent proposal to weaken critical methane pollution protections. 

Since 2013, more than $1.7 billion worth of fracked gas has been leaked, vented, or flared on public and tribal lands. Leaked gas contains volatile organic compounds, benzene, and other hazardous air pollutants that are known carcinogens and asthma irritants. 

BLMs current methane rule is a win-win solution that keeps American communities safe from methane and other toxic pollution resulting from oil and gas activity while ensuring that public resources are managed in the public interest. Reducing leaks, venting, and flaring curbs dangerous pollution, and proper management of these public resources ensures the revenue the Bureau of Land Management collects benefits local schools and infrastructure. 

I urge you to stand with the American people and the communities whose health will be harmed by this new proposal. Please leave in place the current standards that effectively protect Americans' health, safety, and ensure responsible management of public resources.

We respectfully request the comments submitted by the individuals listed in the attached document are reflected in the final comment tally for this docket.

Sincerely,
 
Sierra Club
docketTitle: Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation; Rescission or Revision of Certain Requirements

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2018-03144 -- Comments from 6,070 supporters.
commentText:
To Whom It May Concern: 

Attached, please find the signatures of 6,070 Moms Clean Air Force supporters from across the country who have submitted comments regarding the Land Management Bureau's consideration to rescind or revise regulations concerning waste prevention, production subject to royalties, and resource conservation. Please consider each a formal comment in the federal docket regarding Docket Number 18X.LLWO310000.L13100000.PP0000. 

The comment they each submitted reads: 

I am writing today in strong opposition to BLM's recent proposal to weaken crucial methane waste protections.

This proposal gives the oil and gas industry permission to continue to waste a precious resource. It's also a dangerous decision that puts polluters before our families. 

As a parent, I am concerned about the health impacts of methane pollution, which is a dangerous greenhouse gas. By weakening the limits on the amount of methane pollution that the oil and gas industry is allowed to vent, leak and burn, the health and future of American families and our children are being jeopardized. 

Without public hearings, our voices aren't being heard. Please establish public hearings across the West so that the Americans affected by this proposal can give their input.

Children should be protected from the health risks that come from oil and gas infrastructure, including exposure to air pollution linked to heart and lung disease, pregnancy complications, cancer, and more. Now is the time to strengthen, not dismantle, the protections that keep our families and communities safe.

I implore you and the Department of the Interior's Bureau of Land Management to enforce the strong protections against wasteful pollution that American families deserve.

Please contact me if you have any questions or concerns about this submission. 

Thank you for your consideration,
docketTitle: Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation; Rescission or Revision of Certain Requirements

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Illinois Corn Growers Association (web)
commentText:
Corn farmers like me are pleased to see the Environmental Protection Agency's proposed renewable volume obligation (RVO) for 2018. For several years, we have urged the EPA to set the RVO at an effective 15 billion gallons for conventional renewable fuel, as intended by Congress.  We appreciate that EPA has proposed to do so in this rule. EPA's proposal for conventional ethanol is good for farmers who are facing tough economic times and good for consumers who want affordable fuel choices that give us a cleaner environment. 

While I am pleased EPA proposed a conventional fuel volume consistent with the law, I am concerned that EPA proposed to lower the total RVO, as well as the cellulosic and advanced volumes, below the final volumes set for 2017. With many current ethanol producers investing in bolt-on technologies to produce cellulosic ethanol from existing facilities, corn farmers want to ensure that the final 2018 RVO continues to expand the market and draw investment for cellulosic biofuels and other advanced fuels.  Rather than reducing volumes, we ask EPA to take a more forward-looking approach that considers continued growth in the cellulosic and advanced fuels sectors in the final rule. 

I believe the Renewable Fuel Standard has been a resounding success, resulting in cleaner air, greater energy independence, and stronger rural communities. Please keep the RFS moving forward in line with the law.  Doing so will yield greater stability and certainty in the marketplace and spur increased investment in homegrown renewable fuels.  My family farm and my community are counting on that investment. Rural America's economic future depends on it.

Thank you for allowing me the opportunity to comment.
docketTitle: Renewable Fuel Standard Program: Standards for 2018 and Biomass-Based Diesel Volume for 2019

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Sierra Club (web)
commentText:
Corn ethanol has not lived up to its promise of being a safe and environmentally-friendly fuel source. It is having a negative effect on food prices, land use, water quality, and the climate. The EPA must protect our public health and the planet by reducing and eventually eliminating the use of ethanol in our fuels. 

I also request that the EPA conduct the Environmental and Resource Conservation Impact assessment, as well as the anti-backsliding study to determine whether the Programs required renewable fuel volumes adversely impact air quality as soon as possible.

The attached list of 6,445 Sierra Club members and supporters support this statement and 1108 of them have also included their own individual messages as well. Please find them attached as a spreadsheet, pdf, and document.

Thank you for your attention in this matter.

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Mighty Earth (web)
commentText:
Mighty Earth is pleased to provide you with the following list of citizens who are signed a public comment to the EPA in favor of lowering production levels for soy and palm biodiesel and corn ethanol production, in order to protect some of the world's last, great forests and other native ecosystems. 17,951 of these comments are from United States signatories and 21,721 are international.
 
The following is the text of the comment to Administrator Scott Pruitt: 
 
Dear Administrator Pruitt,
 
I am writing to ask you to lower mandated production levels for soy and palm biodiesel and corn ethanol under the Renewable Fuel Standard. Increasing agricultural production for soy and palm biodiesel drives the deforestation of sensitive and valuable forest ecosystems around the world, and corn ethanol threatens native landscapes in the U.S.
 
Forests in Brazil, Bolivia, Indonesia and throughout Latin America and Southeast Asia are known for their beautiful, ecologically important habitats. These places are home to many threatened and endangered species, including the tree kangaroo, orangutan, jaguar and giant anteater.
 
Furthermore, by taking up and storing carbon dioxide, these forests provide an important bulwark against climate change.
 
Unfortunately, to meet growing demand for soy and palm oils, agri-businesses continue to carve out new farms from virgin forest. In the Brazilian Amazon, areas planted with soy have more than tripled in the last 10 years to approximately 3.6 million hectares. Bolivia expects to clear 14 million additional acres for farmland by 2025. In Indonesia, a single company, Korindo, has a target of deforesting 200,000 hectares for oil palm plantations by 2020.
 
When forest clearance is fully considered, biodiesel has no carbon reduction benefits. In fact, a recent analysis based on European Union research found that biodiesel made from soy and palm oil have significantly higher climate emissions than fossil diesel.
 
Growing corn for ethanol has similar problems, and its effects are seen here in the U.S. The dramatic increase in corn production and has contributed to more the conversion of more than 7 million acres of native ecosystems into agricultural land since 2007.
 
Promoting soy and palm biodiesel and corn ethanol threatens critical habitats at and abroad and makes it harder to deliver on our climate benchmarks. Because of this, I encourage your agency to lower biodiesel and corn ethanol production.
docketTitle: Renewable Fuel Standard Program: Standards for 2018 and Biomass-Based Diesel Volume for 2019

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by National Wildlife Federation Action Fund (web)
commentText:
Attached are individual comments from 19,265 National Wildlife Federation Action Fund supporters from across the country, urging the Environmental Protection Agency to acknowledge the severe environmental impacts of corn ethanol production and adjust the final Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS) mandate downward. Specifically:

To protect vulnerable populations of monarchs, bees and other pollinators that depend on native grasslands, I ask that your agency acknowledge the severe environmental impacts of corn ethanol production and adjust your final Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS) mandate downward.

Native grasslands are disappearing at an alarming rate, along with the monarch butterfly and other wildlife species that depend on them. Studies show the RFS increases demand for corn, contributing to the conversion of millions of acres. The agency acknowledged the impact of biodiesel on deforestation abroad -- yet it has not done the same for habitat loss here at home. Please defend, don't destroy habitat for monarchs and many other species. Reduce the mandate for corn ethanol and soy biodiesel. 

Additionally, I ask that EPA implement the land conversion protections contained in the law. The RFS includes protections against converting untilled lands for biofuel production. Yet EPA has not implemented this provision as Congress intended. Given the threats to remaining grasslands and the steep declines of monarchs and other wildlife, the land-clearing provision must be enforced to fully protect these critically important habitats.

These two actions together would put us on a better path to meeting our goals for cleaner fuel that does not make it harder to bring monarchs back from the brink. Thank you.
docketTitle: Renewable Fuel Standard Program: Standards for 2018 and Biomass-Based Diesel Volume for 2019

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Iowa Renewable Fuels Association. Sample attached (paper)
docketTitle: Renewable Fuel Standard Program: Standards for 2018 and Biomass-Based Diesel Volume for 2019

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Waxman Strategies (web)
commentText:
Attached are the names of over 39,000 individuals who signed a comment asking the EPA to reduce biomass-based diesel levels. 

These individuals are concerned about the rapid loss of tropical rainforests and wildlife habitat, and ask that domestic production of biodiesel NOT increase, in order to mitigate feedstock diversion. Diverting domestically-grown oils and fats from food and industrial use to fuel use creates a market opening for imported palm oil. Typically, palm oil is the cheapest replacement and its imports have recently jumped, in tandem with soy oil diversions for biodiesel use. 

Text of citizen comment letter as follows:  

Dear Administrator Pruitt,

I am writing to ask you to lower mandated production levels for biodiesel under the Renewable Fuel Standard, to avoid increasing demand for vegetable oil crops driving massive deforestation in places like Argentina and Indonesia. 

The recent decision to levy tariffs against Argentinian and Indonesian biodiesel was a step in the right direction. However, if the overall biodiesel mandate level is not brought in line with current domestic production, we could face an enormous spike in domestic production. 

And unfortunately, even domestic biodiesel production is tied to the destruction of tropical rainforests in Southeast Asia. The more domestically grown oils are shifted from food products to fuel, the more palm oil is imported to fill the gap. 
Please protect our planet's last, great forests by reducing biodiesel mandate levels.  

Sincerely,
docketTitle: Renewable Fuel Standard Program: Standards for 2018 and Biomass-Based Diesel Volume for 2019

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsoring organization unknown (web)
commentText:
The proposed Particulate Matter standard is yet another example of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) forcing expensive mandates on states, coal-based electricity and the mining community.  EPA is rushing to judgment with this rule, and has entered into a consent decree with environmental groups against the best interests of the public.


Designation as a non-attainment area for PM2.5 has immediate and potentially severe consequences for local jurisdictions in the form of straining already thin local resources while simultaneously driving away manufacturing and investment.  Restrictive regulations such as this one discourage industrial and commercial activity in and around a non-attainment area.  This will stifle job growth in a business's local community.  The resulting reductions in property tax collections will also impair localities' capacity to provide crucial services like public safety and education.


EPA's proposed rule will also impact the mining community through stricter nonattainment standards, the retention of an overly stringent limit for coarse particulates, and the impossibly dense secondary visibly standard.


I urge EPA to withdraw and reconsider the proposed Particulate Matter standard.
docketTitle: Review of the National Ambient Air Quality Standards for Particulate Matter

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by American Lung Association (web)
commentText:
CORRECTION and REPLACEMENT to document ID # 810fe1f5.

Please accept the attached letter from more than 350 health professionals from 41 states around the country (a type on the previous submission stated 450 health professionals).

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Earthjustice. (web)
commentText:
Attached is a file containing the names of 1,357 individuals who have submitted public comments urging the Office of Air Quality Planning and Standards to strengthen protections against toxic pollution from petroleum refineries and resist industry pressure to reduce the effectiveness of important new requirements like fenceline monitoring. In addition to signing on in support of the following letter, 206 individuals of the total number have submitted personalized comments. The personalized comments start on page 3 and end on page 22.

We need clean air every day (RE: EPA ID: EPA-HQ-OAR-2010-0682-0872)

Dear Office of Air Quality Planning and Standards:

Continue to show your commitment for overburdened communities and vulnerable children now, when it most counts--we need national air toxics limits for refineries to apply at all times, not just when it's convenient for oil companies.

I strongly urge the EPA to strengthen protections against toxic pollution from petroleum refineries and resist industry pressure to reduce the effectiveness of important new requirements like fenceline monitoring.

	The EPA must protect refinery communities and remove all of the FREE PASSES TO POLLUTE that would allow oil corporations to poison our air without any consequences. There are widely available and cost-effective ways to reduce toxic air pollution from oil refineries. Many releases are preventable through better maintenance and monitoring, and better control of the equipment. Equipment to prevent pollution while also conserving energy is also widely available. 
	The EPA limits must apply at all times, to hold polluters accountable and give oil refineries the incentive to clean up the air and prevent upsets and malfunctions, instead of allowing uncontrolled pollution releases from smoking flares or pressure-relief devices.
	Health threats from refineries' toxic air pollution are too high. The scientific evidence and the EPA's policies confirm this. I am calling on the EPA to reconsider its refusal to prevent more cancer caused by oil refinery pollution. For communities in the shadow of refineries, every extra human cancer case and every moment a child has difficult breathing due to exposure to refinery pollution is unacceptable--especially on top of all of the other health and safety threats from refineries. 
	The EPA must not allow refineries to reduce or stop air monitoring that communities need, and should not give in to industry pressure to weaken the national standards in the ways industry groups have asked the EPA to do.

I support the EPA's full implementation of important improvements in the standards--including limits on certain sources of toxic pollution at refineries and a first-ever requirement for all refineries to monitor, report and address fugitive emissions of benzene crossing their fencelines into neighboring communities. To be able to breathe freely, communities need the EPA to finish the job now, before it's too late, by exercising strong leadership and fulfilling its obligations under the law to remove all loopholes and prevent refineries from escaping fundamental clean air safeguards for public health. 

We now have a rare opportunity to make our air cleaner and communities safer by finishing the important work the EPA started to control oil refinery pollution. Please seal the EPA's and President Obama's legacy by removing exemptions and showing that you stand with communities that need protection from toxic air pollution and the health and safety problems it causes every single day, not just some days. Please take action now to reduce harm to children living in the shadows of our nation's oil refineries, by preventing all uncontrolled pollution releases and removing this danger to public health.

Sincerely,

The Undersigned

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
On behalf of the Endangered Species Coalition and the more than three thousand supporters that have sent messages as attached, we urge protection of all chimpanzees under the Endangered Species Act.

The use of captive chimpanzees in entertainment, the pet trade and invasive research negatively affects wild populations by leading the public to believe that chimpanzees are not in need of conservation. In addition, captive chimpanzees frequently suffer abuse and neglect in these industries.

Please help all chimpanzees by applying Endangered Species Act protections to captive chimpanzees. The U.S. government must do all it can to help conserve this intelligent and imperiled species, and the best available science supports this change in regulation. 

Thank you for the opportunity to provide input. I look forward to hearing your final decision.

commentText:
August  10, 2016

Environmental Protection Agency
1200 Pennsylvania Avenue, N.W.
Washington, DC 20460

Attached below are the names of 23,375 individuals who have submitted public comments urging the Environmental Protection Agency to finalize the strongest possible revisions to the Regional Haze Rule. In addition to signing on in support of the following letter, 2959 individuals of the total number have submitted personalized comments. The personalized comments start on page 2 and end on page 170.

Finalize strong Regional Haze Rule updates: Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OAR-2015-0531
Dear Administrator McCarthy,

Thank you for proposing important updates to the Regional Haze Rule. As we celebrate the National Park Service's Centennial, we are reminded of just how valuable clean and healthy parks are for the millions of visitors and local economies that depend on the tourism. 

Our national parks are some of our most special and iconic public treasures. Unfortunately, too many of them suffer from poor air quality that not only hinders views and diminishes experiences, but also threatens the health and well-being of visitors and wildlife. 

I urge you to finalize the strongest possible revisions to the Regional Haze Rule. Please reject language that would allow known polluters to avoid or delay cleaning up their harmful emissions. The program must ensure parks are on a clear and certain path to pollution reductions, and states must be held accountable for their contributions to dangerous haze pollution. I also support giving the National Park Service a more meaningful role in the process to ensure that those who know the parks the best are able to help craft the strongest protections. 

I hope you will use every tool at your disposal to ensure polluters are held accountable and that our parks are cleaned up in a prompt and timely fashion. 

Thank you for your work and consideration.
docketTitle: Protection of Visibility: Amendments to Requirements for State Plans

The League of Conservation Voters is submitting the following comment from 16,662 members, all of whom signed on to the following: 

U.S. national parks - often called "America's Best Idea" - are a badge of honor, source of pride for our nation, and an important economic driver. Ensuring our national parks have clean air is central to upholding the environmental values upon which these parks were founded.

Unfortunately, haze pollution currently threatens our national parks. Fossil fuel companies and other Big Polluters have tried to expose loopholes in the Regional Haze Rule for too long.
