title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Conservation Voters of Pennsylvania (web)
commentText:
Administrator Gina McCarthy
Environmental Protection Agency
1200 Pennsylvania Ave., NW
Washington, DC 20460

Re: Regional Haze Rule (Comments on Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OAR-2015- 0531) 

Dear Administrator McCarthy,

Conservation Voters of Pennsylvania, a statewide environmental advocacy organization in Pennsylvania, today submits our comments signed by 1,997 of our members and activists in support of the Clean Air Act's (CAA) Regional Haze Rule. 

We are grateful that you are taking action to protect our national parks and wilderness areas from haze pollution. The proposed amendments to the regional haze rule are a critical step in tackling harmful health pollutants and ensuring that everyone's next trip to a national park will include clear skies and the ability to enjoy the natural beauty our national parks were intended to preserve. 

Thank you for helping to ensure that every state does its fair share to protect our national parks and wilderness areas from haze pollution. Preserving our parks and wilderness areas should come before political posturing and maneuvering, which often lets the biggest and dirtiest polluters off the hook.

However, we are concerned about several provisions in the current proposal, including:
	Extending the deadline for states to submit their next round of haze cleanup plans by three years
	Potentially allowing states nearly a decade to avoid cleaning up sources of air pollution specifically identified by federal land managers as causing impairment of protected national parks and wilderness areas
	Weakening the ability of EPA and the public to force corrective action if states fall behind in achieving their pollution reduction obligations

States can and should meet their current deadlines for preparing plans to clean up haze pollution. We need tighter enforcement, not more leniency.

The Regional Haze Rule has made progress in improving the air quality and visibility, but we must continue to set high standards to restore natural visibility at America's national parks and wilderness areas. The proposed revision of the Regional Haze Rule is a step in the right direction, but it should be strengthened by addressing the shortcomings described above.

Thank you for helping to protect our national parks during their centennial year.

Sincerely,
 
Josh McNeil
Executive Director, Conservation Voters of PA

commentText: Please accept these public comments from 35,218 online members and activists on behalf of the Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC) regarding EPA-HQ-OEM-2015-0725-0890 opposing the proposed roll back of EPA's Risk Management Plan (RMP) rules. These critical rules govern how to prevent, mitigate, and keep surrounding communities safe from disasters at industrial and chemical facilities around the country. Considering that between 2004 and 2013, over 2,200 chemical disasters took place in the US, these rules need to be kept in place and strengthened to protect lives and communities across the country. We urge you to reject any roll back of live saving RMP rules. Thank you for your consideration.
docketTitle: Accidental Release Prevention Requirements:  Risk Management Programs Under the Clean Air Act

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Public Citizen (web)
commentText:
August 23, 2018

The Honorable Andrew Wheeler, Acting Administrator
Environmental Protection Agency
1200 Pennsylvania Avenue NW
Washington, DC 20460

Docket # EPA-HQ-OEM-2015-0725

Dear Acting Administrator Wheeler:

Im writing to oppose the Environmental Protection Agencys rollbacks of the Chemical Disaster Rule.
Each year, an average of 150 fires, leaks, explosions and other incidents occur at chemical plants. The
Chemical Disaster Rule helps protect workers and communities, yet the EPA is proposing to repeal all of
the disaster prevention measures. The EPA should keep and implement the full Chemical Disaster Rule.
Along the Gulf Coast, Hurricane Harvey proved how devastating it can be when natural disasters impact
chemical facilities. The EPA should be working to prevent catastrophic incidents, especially as the risk for
extreme weather events is on the rise.

The EPA claims that the chemical industry will save $88 million/year through these repeals  a tiny
amount for the industry. But when a chemical disaster happens again  and it will  a single event can
cause $220 million in harm. The cost of doing business should include the cost of operating safely.
The EPA must not weaken or delay emergency response requirements, nor should it deny chemical
hazard information to exposed communities. Make companies use safer, less hazardous chemicals and
put into place more robust preparation, planning and incident review.

Sincerely,

Public Citizen and 10,654 signatories (attached)
docketTitle: Accidental Release Prevention Requirements:  Risk Management Programs Under the Clean Air Act

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by BlueGreen Alliance (web)
commentText:
August 23, 2018

RE: Docket EPA-HQ-OEM-2015-0725-0890 

To Whom It May Concern:

Please find 414 comments attached for inclusion in this docket, EPA-HQ-OEM-2015-0725-0890, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs Under the Clean Air Act regarding proposed rescissions of EPAs Chemical Disaster Rule. More than 40 people have taken the time to write a personalized comment and 371 have signed to the following text:

Weakening the Chemical Disaster Rule (EPA-HQ-OEM-2015-0725-0890) will endanger workers, first responders, and the communities surrounding industrial facilities that handle hazardous chemicals. 

Roughly 177 million Americans live close enough to an industrial facility to be affected by a chemical accident, and that risk falls disproportionately on low-income and minority communities. One-in-three schoolchildren currently attend a school in the vulnerability zone for an industrial chemical accident, meaning they are potentially in the path of a lethal industrial chemical release. Workers are greatest risk of injury or death, alongside first responders, who put their lives on the line responding to the industrial fires, explosions, and chemical releases that occur 150 times on average each year across the nation. 

The Chemical Disaster Rule (Amendments to the Accidental Release Prevention Requirements for Risk Management Programs (RMP) under the Clean Air Act), finalized in January 2017, provided critically needed safeguards. The EPAs proposal to weaken the rule will eliminate key provisions that require companies to coordinate with emergency responders; analyze accidents to determine how to prevent them in the future; share information with communities on hazards at the facility and preparedness procedures; conduct independent audits for serious chemical accidents; and, for the most dangerous subset of facilities, evaluate safer technologies and practices so that if an accident occurs (whatever the cause), fewer people will be killed or injured.

EPAs proposal reflects a disregard for the safety of American workers and the millions of Americansincluding school childrenwho work or live in the danger zone of these facilities. I urge you to withdraw EPAs current proposal and implement the Chemical Disaster Rule in its original January 2017 form.

We respectfully request that the 414 comments submitted by the individuals in the attached document be reflected in the final comment tally for this docket.

Sincerely,

Jessica Eckdish
Senior Policy Advisor
BlueGreen Alliance
docketTitle: Accidental Release Prevention Requirements:  Risk Management Programs Under the Clean Air Act

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by the US PIRG (web)
commentText:
The attached signatures represent the 7,356 people who added their name in support of the following message:

Millions of Americans live, attend school, and work within the zone of vulnerability of hazardous chemical facilities, putting them at risk of disaster in the event of a chemical release incident. The Risk Management Program Amendments include rules and regulations invaluable to the safety of families and communities all over the country. I strongly urge you not to rescind and modify the RMP Amendments, to keep Americans safe from chemical catastrophe.

The Risk Management Program Amendments were designed by the EPA in response to significant risk to the safety of American workers and communities. The EPAs own findings defined an urgent need for the common-sense updates and regulations the amendments outline.

When the implementation of the amendments was delayed, devastating chemical disasters continued to occur. Its clear that the EPAs original findings, which informed the construction of the RMP Amendments in the first place, remain relevant -- and the RMP Amendments remain as necessary as ever.

Rescinding the RMP Amendments not only needlessly puts millions of Americans at risk from chemical catastrophe, but also bizarrely disregards the prior work of the EPA on this important subject. In order to prevent future tragedies, the RMP Amendments must be kept in place. 

With millions of American lives at risk every day from facilities covered under the RMP Amendments, this rule is no place to attempt to cut costs or corners.
docketTitle: Accidental Release Prevention Requirements:  Risk Management Programs Under the Clean Air Act

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Beyond Pesticides (web)
docketTitle: Accidental Release Prevention Requirements:  Risk Management Programs Under the Clean Air Act

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by International Union of Operating  Engineers Local 420 (email)
docketTitle: Accidental Release Prevention Requirements:  Risk Management Programs Under the Clean Air Act

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Sierra Club (web)
commentText:
See attached file(s) for 1862 comments.

Eliminating or weakening the Chemical Disaster Rule (EPA-HQ-OEM-2015-0725-0890) would put industrial workers, first responders, and communities living near chemical facilities that use hazardous chemicals at risk. 

The Chemical Disaster Rule (Amendments to the Accidental Release Prevention Requirements for Risk Management Programs (RMP) under the Clean Air Act) provides vital safeguards for over 12,500 facilities that handle hazardous chemicals. This proposal would remove important requirements that help prevent, and appropriately prepare for, deadly chemical accidents. These include important components such as coordination with local emergency responders, investigations of accidents to prevent future disasters, independent third-party audits, and evaluating safer technology and practices that could decrease the number of people injured or killed if a problem occurs at one of these facilities. 

Currently, over 177 million Americans live, work, and go to school close enough to an industrial facility to feel the impacts of a chemical accident. Low-income and minority communities are disproportionately represented in this group. Between 2004 and 2013, there were over 1,500 reported chemical releases or explosions at RMP-covered facilities. Workers at these facilities work in potentially dangerous situations every day, and first responders put their lives on the line without proper information when an accident occurs. 

I urge the EPA to put the lives of children, workers, first responders, and countless communities over the interests of the oil and chemical industry by withdrawing this dangerous proposal to weaken these protections by rescinding amendments and changing compliance dates.

docketTitle: Accidental Release Prevention Requirements:  Risk Management Programs Under the Clean Air Act

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Union of Concerned Scientists(web)
commentText:
To: The Environmental Protection Agency

As Americans who live within a zip code of one of the nation's high-risk chemical facilities, we urge the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to not delay or roll back the improvements made to the Risk Management Program (RMP).

The first revision in more than 20 years to the RMP was shaped by years of rigorous research and public input and was motivated by the legal responsibility of the EPA to mitigate the injuries, lives lost, and property damage of chemical accidents throughout the country. Any attempt to delay or weaken the RMP sacrifices the health and safety of our families, emergency responders, workers, and nearby communities, who are often low-income communities and communities of color already bearing the burden of environmental hazard.

We ask the EPA to take its mission and legally-mandated responsibility seriously and to embrace the amendments to the RMP rule that will reduce risks associated with and improve emergency response to catastrophic chemical facility incidents.
 
Sincerely, 

The undersigned
(attached: signatories of 5,630 residents near high-risk chemical facilities)

title: Mass Mail Campaign Sponsored by EarthJustice (Web)
commentText:
Attached is a file containing the names of 13,698 individuals who have submitted public comments urging the Environmental Protection Agency's  to set strong chemical safety standards. In addition to signing on in support of the following letter, 1,535 individuals of the total number have submitted personalized comments. The personalized comments start on page 3 and end on page 112.

Protect communities from chemical disasters (Docket ID: EPA-HQ-OEM-2015-0725)

Dear Administrator McCarthy,

Thank you for recognizing the need to set stronger chemical safety standards. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) must use its full legal authority and commonsense measures to protect workers and communities from chemical disasters.

The EPA must immediately use its authority under the 1990 amendments to the Clean Air Act to prevent future chemical disasters. Any commonsense strategy for reducing chemical disasters should include an EPA requirement that chemical facilities both assess safer measures and also put them in place. Voluntary guidelines are not getting the job done to protect workers and communities. It's not fair for the burden of hazardous releases to fall only on workers, vulnerable communities and first responders who have little or no ability to protect themselves and their families once a chemical disaster is in progress. That's why the EPA must exercise its authority and fulfill its responsibility to act under the Clean Air Act's "Bhopal" provisions in section 112(r)(1) and 112 (r)(7) to require refineries and chemical facilities to use the safest cost-effective chemical process available to eliminate the potential for catastrophic chemical releases.

A report by the Environmental Justice and Health Alliance for Chemical Policy Reform (cosponsored by Coming Clean and the Center for Effective Government) highlighted that more than 134 million Americans live in the danger zones around 3,433 facilities that store or use highly hazardous chemicals. Most in danger are the 3.8 million people living at the fence line of these facilities. How many more news headlines and how much more preventable suffering must our country endure before the EPA uses its power to hold chemical facilities accountable for safe operations? 

The threat posed by chemical disasters is more acutely felt by residents of communities of color. Specifically, the EJHA report found that Blacks are 75 percent more likely than the greater U.S. population as a whole to live in fenceline zones near chemical facilities. Latinos are 60 percent more likely to live in fenceline communities.

The final rule should:

	Finalize the EPA's proposed requirement for a safer alternatives assessment by certain oil refineries, chemical manufacturers and paper plants to determine the availability of safer available chemical processes and/or inherently safer technologies (IST); require this assessment to be reported to EPA, and strengthen transparency for the affected public; require this assessment to occur expeditiously, not wait another five years; and apply the assessment requirement to all hazardous-release industries covered by Clean Air Act section 112(r).
	Prioritize protection of the most vulnerable populations, including workers, nearby communities and first responders. 
	Require all refineries and chemical facilities to reduce the use of the most toxic substances where alternatives are available, and implement other safer practices, like backup power, to prevent catastrophic accidents.|
	Engage workers in the alternatives and feasibility assessment process and ensure they have whistleblower protections and anonymous reporting.
	Require and strengthen hazardous leak detection and require fenceline monitoring at all hazardous facilities to ensure prompt action is taken when a release occurs and to give communities and first responders near hazardous facilities real-time information on hazards as they begin to happen, instead of just after the fact.

Preventing chemical disasters could be part of the Obama administration's legacy if you strengthen and finalize this rule to address the safety threat that refineries and other chemical facilities pose to both workers and communities.

The Undersigned
docketTitle: Accidental Release Prevention Requirements:  Risk Management Programs Under the Clean Air Act

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Greenpeace USA (USB)
docketTitle: Accidental Release Prevention Requirements:  Risk Management Programs Under the Clean Air Act

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Public Citizen Texas (Web)
commentText:
Re: Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs under the Clean Air Act, EPA Docket No. EPA-HQ-OEM-2015-0725

Dear Director McCarthy:

Attached, please find the name of 450 members and supporters of Public Citizen Texas who signed onto the following statement: 

The EPA must increase protections against catastrophic releases of hazardous chemicals by requiring facilities using those chemicals to study the use of safer technologies. The EPA should go further than its proposed rule by requiring all facilities that are possible sources of such disasters to study safer technologies, not just facilities in a handful of industries.

And the EPA should actually require companies to use feasible safer technologies that they identify in the required studies. Studying safer technologies will only benefit the public if companies have to use those technologies when they can.

The EPA should also make sure that the public knows about the hazards posed by facilities near them and about the efforts those facilities have made, or not made, to reduce the risk. And companies should be required to conduct disaster drills on a frequent basis, and should be required to implement any new rules the EPA issues as soon as possible, not years in the future.

Your proposed rule needs to be tougher and better!

------
Thank you very much in advance for your consideration of these citizens' comments. Please contact me if you have any questions regarding this submission.

All the best,

Susan E. Harley, JD
Deputy Director-- Congress Watch
Public Citizen
sharley@citizen.org
(202) 454-5150

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Sierra Club (Web)
commentText:
5,012 Sierra Club supporters from across the states with the highest incidence of chemical facility accidents have submitted comments urgently asking the EPA to create strong protections for their communities by improving upon the proposed rule. The existing rule does not go far enough to protect the people who live in the danger zones of our nation's chemical facilities. 

Please find two spreadsheets attached of all 5,012 comments including customized letters from 124 of the most passionate citizens.

Protect workers and communities; finalize strong chemical plant safety protections - Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OEM-2015-0725

I urge the EPA to finalize strong chemical safety protections that prioritize worker safety and community and environmental health. A report by the Environmental Justice and Health Alliance (EJHA) for Chemical Policy Reform highlighted that more than 134 million Americans live in the danger zones around 3,433 facilities that store or use highly hazardous chemicals. Specifically, I urge you to finalize safeguards that:

-Require implementation of "inherently safer technologies" (IST) where feasible.
-Require a "safer technology and alternatives analysis" (STAA) to be submitted to EPA and make the results publicly available.
-Expand the scope of the STAAs to include other facilities, such as water treatment plants.
-To make information on facility hazards and safer alternatives more publicly available. 

Thank you.

See attached file(s)
docketTitle: Accidental Release Prevention Requirements:  Risk Management Programs Under the Clean Air Act

docketTitle: Methylene Chloride and N-Methylpyrrolidone (NMP); Rulemaking under TSCA Section 6(a)

title:
Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Environmental Defense Fund (EDF)
(web)
commentText:
To Whom It May Concern: 

Attached is a document containing the signatures of 33,363 Environmental Defense Fund supporters from across the country who have submitted electronic comments regarding EPA's Regulation of Certain Uses under Toxic Substances Control Act: Methylene Chloride and N-Methylpyrrolidone. The comment they each submitted reads: 

"I'm writing today to strongly urge EPA to finalize its rules to ban high-risk uses of trichloroethylene (TCE), methylene chloride (DCM), and N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP) under the new Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA).  

These chemicals are extremely toxic. TCE is carcinogenic and can cause heart defects in the developing fetus.  DCM is a very lethal chemical  over the past few decades, dozens of workers have died from using DCM-based paint stripping products.  NMP is often used as a substitute for DCM in paint stripping products, yet it also presents major health risks  ranging from developmental and reproductive toxicity to neurotoxicity to liver and kidney damage. 

EPA had not successfully banned a chemical under the original TSCA in nearly three decades.  Now, with its greater authority under the new TSCA as amended by the Lautenberg Act, EPA can score an early public health victory by banning these toxic chemicals for these high-risk uses.  

But the chemical industry is complaining and pressuring EPA to back off, delay, or weaken these much needed rules.  Some in industry are suggesting that measures like putting a simple label on these deadly products or requiring workers to wear protective gear would suffice.  But labels, personal protective equipment, and concentration limits are not enough to protect my family and community.

I strongly urge the Agency to stay on track and promptly ban TCE used as a spot cleaning agent in dry cleaning, as an aerosol spray degreaser in commercial and consumer settings, and as a vapor degreaser in commercial settings, and both DCM and NMP used for commercial and consumer paint stripping. Safer alternatives are already widely available. 

There is simply no excuse to continue putting my family's and my community's health at risk by delaying or weakening these rules."

Please let me know if you have any additional questions or concerns about this submission. 

Thank you for your consideration, 

Heather Shelby
Manager, Grassroots Organizing & Activism
Environmental Defense Fund
hshelby@edf.org
docketTitle: Methylene Chloride and N-Methylpyrrolidone (NMP); Rulemaking under TSCA Section 6(a)

docketTitle: Methylene Chloride and N-Methylpyrrolidone (NMP); Rulemaking under TSCA Section 6(a)

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by League of Conservation Voters (LCV) (web)
commentText:
I urge the EPA to ban commercial and consumer uses of the toxic chemicals methylene chloride (DCM) and N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP) in paint and coating removal. Chemicals linked to cancer, developmental toxicity, harm to fetuses, and other harmful health impacts don't belong on store shelves. 

Safer alternatives are readily available-- but we need EPA to ban both of these chemicals from the products available on store shelves and in the workplace. While EPA has proposed two options for regulating NMP, the best option for public health is a ban on NMP and DCM. 

Action on these toxic chemicals is long overdue. Please move to ban these toxic chemicals now!

These comments are submitted on behalf of 17,134 LCV members. Please see attached file.
docketTitle: Methylene Chloride and N-Methylpyrrolidone (NMP); Rulemaking under TSCA Section 6(a)

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Earthjustice (web)
commentText:
Attached is a file containing the names of 24,111 individuals who have submitted public comments regarding the Environmental Protection Agency's proposed rule concerning the uses of Methylene Chloride and N-Methylpyrrolidone under the Toxic Substances Control Act.  In addition to signing on in support of the following letter, 3,901 individuals of the total number have submitted personalized comments. The personalized comments start on page 2 and end on page 267.

Ban commercial and consumer uses of the toxic chemicals methylene chloride (DCM) and N-methylpyrrol (EPA-HQ-OPPT-2016-0231-0001)

Dear Environmental Protection Agency:

I urge the EPA to finalize the proposed ban on commercial and consumer uses of the toxic chemicals methylene chloride (DCM) and N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP) in paint and coating removal. Chemicals linked to cancer, developmental toxicity and other health impacts don't belong on store shelves.

Safer alternatives are readily available--but we need EPA to ban both of these chemicals from the products available on store shelves and in the workplace. While EPA has proposed two options for regulating NMP, the best option for public health is a ban on NMP and DCM. 

Action on these toxic chemicals is long overdue. Please move quickly to ban these toxic chemicals now!

Sincerely,

The Undersigned

title: Shea, Devan
commentText:
This rule would overturn decades of federal and state law and precedent safeguarding tips as the property of workers, by allowing employers to take control of their employees' tips. The Fair Labor Standards Act was amended in 1974 to clarify that tips are to be retained by the employee except when a valid tip pooling arrangement is in place. In 2011, the DOL reiterated the FLSA and over 40 years of custom and practice by the DOL and state agencies, affirming that tips are always the property of the employee (Regulation 29 C.F.R.  531.52).

If adopted, this regulation would force a vulnerable workforce further into poverty, economic instability, and vulnerability to harassment and assault. Tipped restaurant workers already have the lowest federal minimum wage in the country at just $2.13. As a result, they experience disproportionate rates of poverty, discrimination, and sexual harassment. The subminimum wage of $2.13 is generally not enough to cover an employee's tax liability, requiring workers to depend on tips for the entirety of their take home wage. In states with a tipped subminimum wage, workers receive their wage directly from the customer.

Attached are comments gathered in opposition to "Tip Regulations Under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA)" regulation (RIN: 1235-AA21)
docketTitle: Tip Regulations under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA)

This rule would overturn decades of federal and state law and precedent safeguarding tips as the property of workers, by allowing employers to take control of their employees' tips. The Fair Labor Standards Act was amended in 1974 to clarify that tips are to be retained by the employee except when a valid tip pooling arrangement is in place. In 2011, the DOL reiterated the FLSA and over 40 years of custom and practice by the DOL and state agencies, affirming that tips are always the property of the employee (Regulation 29 C.F.R.  531.52).

If adopted, this regulation would force a vulnerable workforce further into poverty, economic instability, and vulnerability to harassment and assault. Tipped restaurant workers already have the lowest federal minimum wage in the country at just $2.13. As a result, they experience disproportionate rates of poverty, discrimination, and sexual harassment. The subminimum wage of $2.13 is generally not enough to cover an employee's tax liability, requiring workers to depend on tips for the entirety of their take home wage. In states with a tipped subminimum wage, workers receive their wage directly from the customer.

Attached are comments gathered in opposition to "Tip Regulations Under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA)" regulation (RIN: 1235-AA21)
docketTitle: Tip Regulations under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA)

title: Mass Comment Campaign submittted by Alexander Rony, Earthjustice (73,302 comments and signatures)  )
commentText:
Thank you for giving the public this opportunity to weigh in on this issue. Attached you will find the public comments of 73,302 individuals who are opposed to Dow AgroSciences application to expand the use of the pesticide known as sulfoxaflor. All of these individuals signed on to the letter below, and 8,910 added their own comments. The people who included additional comments have been compiled in a separate PDF.

**********************************************

Sample Comment: 

Deny Dow AgroScience's application to expand the registration of sulfoxaflor (Docket ID:
EPA-HQ-OPP-2014-0156).

Thank you for considering my input.

As a citizen concerned about our nation's health and food security, I urge you to deny Dow AgroScience's application to expand the registration of the bee-killing pesticide sulfoxaflor so that it can be sprayed on corn, alfalfa, oats, and several significant and widely grown crops.

Honeybees are dying at rates unprecedented in history, prompting the U.S. Department of Agriculture to warn that it is no longer confident in our ability to "meet the pollination demands of U.S. agricultural crops." Rather than expand the number of crops that can be sprayed with highly toxic and systemic insecticides like sulfoxaflor, the EPA must take immediate steps to help bees recover. I join with other members of Earthjustice in calling for you to suspend the use of sulfoxaflor on all crops pending a thorough analysis of the impacts to bees and the many crops that depend on bees for pollination.
docketTitle: Sulfoxaflor   Pesticide Petition (PP# 4F8237) and Registration Requests for use on Corn, Sorghum, Pineapple, Alfalfa, Clover, and Cacao

title: NPCA Cover Letter (12.02.14)
docketTitle: National Park Service, Alaska Region, Hunting and Trapping in National Preserves

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2014-20881
commentText:
The following comments are submitted on behalf of 16,885 members and supporters of the International Fund for Animal Welfare (IFAW). A PDF file including their names and contact information is attached. We applaud the Service's efforts to protect Alaska's wildlife, and thank you for your consideration. 


LETTER FROM MEMBERS: 


Dear Dr. Frost, 

I am writing in support of the National Park Services (NPS) proposed rule concerning hunting and trapping in national preserves in Alaska (RIN 1024-AE21; Fed. Reg. Doc. No. 2014-20881; NPS-2014-0004-0001). 

By prohibiting the artificial manipulation of predator-prey dynamics, as well as unsporting and inhumane practices such as denning, baiting and hounding, NPS will take an important step toward maintaining the ecological integrity of national preserves across Alaska. 

In particular, I strongly encourage the Service to implement and enforce proposed prohibitions against:
	Killing predators to artificially boost game populations, which is both inhumane and ecologically destructive; 
	Spotlighting to take black bear cubs and sows at den sites, when they are particularly vulnerable;
	Baiting brown and black bears, which is known to lead to habituation to human food and corresponding conflicts; 
	Taking wolves and coyotes during the denning season, when their pelts have little value and there is an enhanced risk of orphaning pups; and
	Using dogs to hunt black bears, which can cause prolonged suffering to the bears, as well as serious injuries to the dogs. 

Each of these practices disrupts ecosystems, threatens target and non-target animals with inhumane capture and killing, and runs counter to traditional fair chase principles. It is NPSs responsibility to manage national preserves for the benefit of all Americans, and implementing the proposed rule will advance that important mission. 

Sincerely,
(Please see attachment for names)
docketTitle: National Park Service, Alaska Region, Hunting and Trapping in National Preserves

docketTitle: Proposed rule; Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation; Delay and Suspension of Certain Requirements

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2017-21294
commentText:
On behalf of 200 fellow citizens, please accept our comments regarding the delay and suspension of the Bureau of Land Management's methane rule.

Each year, $330 million of natural gas is wasted on our public lands through the harmful practices of venting and flaring. Fortunately, the BLM made great strides towards curbing this waste and reducing the burden on both taxpayers and the environment, by finalizing the Methane and Waste Prevention Rule last year. The BLM rule takes a cost-effective and common sense approach to reining in methane waste and modernizing how energy is developed and used across our landscapes.

Without the BLM methane waste rule, the oil and gas industry would be free to recklessly leak millions of tons of methane pollution and toxic chemicals into the air without limits, harming our health and accelerating climate change. Furthermore, children who suffer from asthma are threatened by toxic air pollution that is released alongside natural gas waste, and if DOI delays or completely repeals the rule, that will harm children's health.

Strong protections on methane and toxic pollution from oil and gas production are a win-win, keeping us safer and providing needed revenue that benefits our local schools and infrastructure like roads and bridges. Suspending the BLM methane waste rule means the waste of more American energy and is unacceptable.

Sincerely,
Neal Ullman
Program Director
Montana Conservation Voters Education Fund
Helena, MT
docketTitle: Proposed rule; Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation; Delay and Suspension of Certain Requirements

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2017-21294
commentText:
November 6, 2017

Secretary Zinke, 
The U.S. has taken important strides to address dangerous methane pollution, and we can't afford to go backward. Leaking, venting, and flaring from natural gas facilities wastes hundreds of millions of dollars in taxpayer owned natural resources and puts our families at considerable health risk. 

Strong protections on methane and toxic pollution from oil and gas production are a win-win, keeping us safer and providing needed revenue that benefits our local schools and infrastructure like roads and bridges. Suspending the BLM methane waste rule means wasting American energy and is unacceptable. If you care about families like mine, I urge you not to suspend natural gas waste limits. 

Thank you,

Signed by 8242 Green America members.  Please see the attached comments on BLM-2017-0002
docketTitle: Proposed rule; Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation; Delay and Suspension of Certain Requirements

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2017-21294
commentText:
To whom it may concern, 

Attached is a file containing the signatures of 4,966 Moms Clean Air Force supporters from across the country who have submitted comments regarding The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) Proposed Rule: Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation; Delay and Suspension of Certain Requirements. The comment they each submitted reads: 

As a parent, I am concerned about the venting, flaring, and leaking from natural gas operations, and how these wasteful practices make climate change and air pollution worse. Any delay or suspension of the Natural Gas Waste Prevention Rule is a threat to the health and future of our children. 

The U.S. has taken important strides to address dangerous methane pollution, and we can't afford to go backward. Leaking, venting, and flaring from natural gas facilities puts our families at risk and wastes hundreds of millions in taxpayer-owned natural resources. Suspending the BLM methane rule allows the oil and gas industry to recklessly leak methane and toxic chemicals into the air -- putting our children at greater risk for asthma attacks and cancer. The two year delay also makes climate change worse and wastes taxpayer dollars. 

If you care about families like mine, I urge you not to suspend natural gas waste limits.

Please contact me if you have any questions or concerns about this submission, Anneka Wisker at awisker@momscleanairforce.org.

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2017-21294
commentText:
On behalf of Environmental Action, an education and advocacy organization dedicated to the conservation of America's treasures, I formally submit more than 18,266 signatures in favor of strong protections against methane and toxic pollution from oil and gas production.

We need to keep environmental protections intact that help protect our lands and water from overuse and pollution. These regulations are important first steps to help protect health and safety of public lands and nearby communities. Delaying on environmental regulations is a dangerous step backward from guidelines that would help end wasteful natural gas leaks and dangerous flares.

Every year, the oil and gas industry leaks millions of tons of methane pollution. Methane is extremely potent -- about 30 times more potent than CO2 -- and it's a huge contributor to climate change. That's why the Interior Department's Bureau of Land Management stepped in and issued the methane emissions rule last year.

I ask that these signatures be entered into the official record and considered as individual comments. Each of the people listed in the attached spreadsheet signed this comment:

The U.S. has taken important strides to address dangerous methane pollution and we can't afford to go backward. Methane leaks from natural gas facilities and operations puts our families' health at risk.

Any attempts to delay or dismantle standards limiting dangerous methane pollution, a key contributor to climate change are unacceptable. Strong protections against methane and toxic pollution from oil and gas production keeps us safe.

Delaying critical safeguards against methane pollution puts all of us at risk. I urge you to immediately implement these lifesaving standards.

For your convenience, the petition remains available online at: http://bit.ly/2haczYK
. 

Should you have any questions about the petition or signature file, please contact me at 202-461-2449 x349 or by email at Sally@environmental-action.org.

Sincerely,

Sally King
Environmental Action
docketTitle: Proposed rule; Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation; Delay and Suspension of Certain Requirements

organization: Mass Comment Campaign of the Sierra Club
title: Comment on FR Doc # 2017-21294
commentText:
November 6, 2017
 
Mass Comment Campaign of the Sierra Club
RE: Docket BLM-2017-0002-0001
 
To Whom It May Concern:

Please find 36,559 comments attached for inclusion in this docket, BLM-2017-0002-0001, "Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation; Delay and Suspension of Certain Requirements" regarding the proposed stay of BLM's methane rule. Many commenters have written a personal statement and all 36,559 have signed to the following text:

"The United States has taken important strides to address dangerous methane pollution and we cannot afford to go backward. Leaking, venting, and flaring from gas facilities puts our families at considerable health risk. BLM's methane rule is a win-win, keeping us safe from methane and other toxic pollution resulting from oil and gas activity and ensuring public resources are managed in the public interest. 

Reducing leaks, venting, and flaring curbs dangerous pollution, and proper management of these public resources ensures the revenue the BLM collects on our behalf benefits our local schools and infrastructure like roads and bridges. Suspending the BLM methane rule would end these benefits and is unacceptable. If you care about families like mine, I urge you not to suspend the BLM's Waste Prevention Rule."

We respectfully request the 36,559 comments submitted by the individuals listed in the attached document are reflected in the final comment tally for this docket.

Sincerely,
 
Matthew Gravatt
Associate Director, Federal and Administrative Advocacy
Sierra Club
docketTitle: Proposed rule; Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation; Delay and Suspension of Certain Requirements

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2017-21294
commentText:
To Whom It May Concern: 

Attached please find 2 files containing the signatures of a total of 47,783 EDF supporters who submitted comments regarding the BLM Proposed Rule: Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation; Delay and Suspension of Certain Requirements (Docket ID RIN 1004-AE54).

The comment they each submitted reads: 

"I am writing today in strong opposition to any attempts to delay, weaken, or revoke the Bureau of Land Management's crucial methane waste protections. 

Doing so defends the worst actors of the oil & gas industry, and puts their interests above the health and safety of American families and their communities, all while wasting taxpayer dollars. Since 2013, more than $1.7 billion worth of natural gas has been squandered on public and tribal lands. 

The best in the business have made it clear that this problem can be fixed using available, low-cost technologies. We don't need to look any further than states like Colorado and Wyoming to see that protections that leverage these commonsense technologies can be extremely successful. 

I stand with the more than two-thirds of American voters who want to keep these protections strong and in place."

Please feel free to reach out to me directly if you have any questions or concerns about these submissions. 

Thank you for your consideration,

Heather Shelby

Manager, Grassroots Organizing & Activism
Environmental Defense Fund
hshelby@edf.org

title: Mass Comment Campaign Petition submitted by Zarah Patriana, Earthjustice (32,176 signatures)
commentText:
Attached is the file containing the names of 32,176 individuals who have submitted public comments urging the Environmental Protection Agency to ban all uses of the neurotoxic pesticide chlorpyrifos. In addition to signing on in support of the following letter, 2,889 individuals of the total number have submitted personalized comments. The personalized comments start on page 2 and end on page 231.

Ban chlorpyrifos now (RE: EPA-HQ-OPP-2015-0653-0402)

Dear Environmental Protection Agency:

I urge the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency to ban all uses of the neurotoxic pesticide chlorpyrifos immediately. Whenever this chemical is sprayed in the air, it can cause both immediate and long-term health harms to farmworkers, kids and others who are exposed. Every year, chlorpyrifos spraying in agricultural fields poisons farmworkers and other people exposed to pesticide drift in the air. This chemical is also linked to reduced IQ and attention deficit disorders in children. Just last year the EPA released an updated assessment of chlorpyrifos and concluded that current safety standards are not enough to protect public health. 

The EPA should take immediate steps to ban this brain-damaging pesticide to: 

	Protect children from learning and memory impairments
	Protect communities from poisoning when the pesticides drift off crops and into nearby neighborhoods and schools
	Prevent contamination of our food 
	Prevent contamination of our drinking water
	Prevent worker poisonings and harm to their children

Action on this toxic chemical is long overdue. I urge you to ensure that your agency moves quickly to ban chlorpyrifos now.

Thank you for your consideration of this important issue.

Sincerely,

The Undersigned
docketTitle: Chlorpyrifos Tolerance Rulemaking

title: Mass Mail sponsored by Natural Resources Defense Council (Web)
commentText:
The attached files contain letters from 919 individuals who submitted the comment below. 

Jan 3, 2016

EPA Administrator Gina McCarthy

Subject: Ban all use of the toxic pesticide chlorpyrifos

Dear Administrator McCarthy: EPA Administrator Gina McCarthy,

EPA's recent proposal to ban use of the neurotoxic pesticide
chlorpyrifos on food crops was a big step in the right direction. I
urge you now to follow through with this proposal -- and to do even
more to protect our health by banning all uses of this dangerous,
outdated chemical.

After years of delay, EPA has finally acknowledged the extensive
evidence that exposure to chlorpyrifos damages the development of
children's brains. Immediate action to ban chlorpyrifos is needed to:

* Protect children from reduced IQ, developmental delay, and other
harms to the brain and nervous system;
* Protect communities from health harms of chlorpyrifos when it drifts
off crops and into nearby neighborhoods and schools;
* Protect infants from contaminated drinking water and other unsafe
exposures; and
* Protect workers from being poisoned at unconscionable rates

A complete ban on this toxic chemical is long overdue. I urge you to
ensure that your agency moves quickly to ban chlorpyrifos now.

Thank you for your consideration of this important issue.
docketTitle: Chlorpyrifos Tolerance Rulemaking

title: Mass Mail sponsored by Earthjustice (Web)
commentText:
RE: Docket ID # EPA-HQ-OPP-2015-0653-0001

OPP Docket
Environmental Protection Agency Docket Center (EPA/DC)
(28221T) 1200 Pennsylvania Ave. NW.
Washington, DC 20460-0001

Appended in the attached .pdf are the names of 56,515 individuals who have submitted public comments with Earthjustice regarding the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) petition to revoke all tolerances for the insecticide chlorpyrifos. In addition to signing on in support of the following letter, 10,063 individuals of the total number have submitted personalized comments. The personalized comments start on page 2 and end on page 706.

Protect ALL communities from the toxic risks of chlorpyrifos (RE: Docket ID # EPA-HQ-OPP-2015-0653-0001)

Dear Administrator McCarthy,

I urge the EPA to ban all uses of the neurotoxic insecticide chlorpyrifos, based on extensive evidence that it causes neurodevelopmental harm to children and poisons workers and their families when it's sprayed in the fields. The EPA banned household uses of chlorpyrifos in 2000 and now has proposed a ban for use on food crops. That doesn't go far enough: All workers and communities deserve protection.

After years of delay, the EPA has finally acknowledged the extensive evidence that exposure to chlorpyrifos damages the development of children's brains. It's time to act to protect children from reduced IQ, delayed development and attention disorders associated with this dangerous pesticide. 

Despite acknowledging the brain impairments to children at low levels of exposure, the EPA is considering allowing continued use of this pesticide on some crops and in nurseries, based on scientifically flawed studies conducted by Dow Agrosciences, the company that manufactures chlorpyrifos.

The EPA should take immediate steps to ban all uses of chlorpyrifos in order to:

* Protect children from learning and memory impairments
* Protect communities from pesticide poisonings when chlorpyrifos drifts off crops and into nearby neighborhoods and schools
* Prevent contamination of drinking water with chlorpyrifos
* Prevent worker poisonings

Action on this toxic chemical is long overdue. I urge you to ensure that your agency moves quickly to ban chlorpyrifos now.

Thank you for your consideration of this important issue,
The Undersigned
docketTitle: Chlorpyrifos Tolerance Rulemaking

title: CREDO_Coal_Bonding_comments_part1
docketTitle: WEG Petition for Rulemaking - Self-Bonding

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2016-14525
docketTitle: WEG Petition for Rulemaking - Self-Bonding

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2016-14525
commentText:
Thank you for accepting comments on the self-bond program. I am submitting this comment on behalf of NextGen Climate America, a non-partisan, non-profit organization dedicated to creating a level playing field so that low-carbon advanced energy solutions can fairly compete with entrenched fossil fuel interests. Launched in 2014, we develop and advance policies to prevent climate disaster and promote prosperity for every American. 

NextGen Climate America is concerned about potential liability for governments and taxpayers from companies that have financially collapsed but are still self-bonded. With billions of dollars in reclamation costs covered by only self-bonds, it is time to act to mitigate the risk. We support OSMRE issuing guidance to the states and improving its regulations to close loopholes and better protect taxpayers, in addition to vigorously pursuing enforcement of reclamation laws in bankruptcy court and through other available enforcement channels. Ultimately, the practice of self-bonding must be discontinued, and until it is, OSMRE should take steps to limit its availability to only those cases where the company is truly solvent in the long term, and has maintained a strong record of performing reclamation and obtaining full bond release. This necessarily excludes any company currently or recently in bankruptcy.

NextGen Climate America has written on this topic at https://nextgenamerica.org/blog/too-big-to-fail-coal-edition/, the contents of which are incorporated herein by reference.

NextGen Climate America has also received signatures from members of the public, who have endorsed the following statement on this topic:

"PETITION TO SECRETARY JEWELL:
Secretary Jewell, the coal companies made a promise to the American people to clean up their own pollution  and now we must hold them to it. Please take action to close the self-bonding loophole and make sure states enforce the law requiring coal companies to clean up their pollution. Taxpayers shouldn't have to foot the bill for their mess."

The 229 signatures received are attached to this comment.

David Weiskopf
Attorney and Policy Development Manager
NextGen Climate America
docketTitle: WEG Petition for Rulemaking - Self-Bonding

NextGen Climate has also received signatures from members of the public, who have endorsed the following statement on this topic:

title: Mass Comment Campaign submitted by Kristin Schafer, Policy & Program Director, Pesticide Action Network (PANNA) (10,898 signatures)
commentText:
Administrator Gina McCarthy
Environmental Protection Agency
1200 Pennsylvania Avenue, N.W.
Washington, DC 20460


October 6, 2014


Re: Docket # EPA-HQ-OPP-2013-0758


Dear Administrator McCarthy,

We urge you to reject the request from Syngenta Crop Protection for increased tolerance levels of thiamethoxam, a neonicotinoid pesticide known to harm bees and other pollinators.

Increased tolerance levels on the requested crops  including corn, soybeans, wheat, and alfalfa  would pave the way for foliar spray, resulting in drift to neighboring crops and flowering plants where bees forage. It will also increase surface water contamination.

The crops named in Syngentas request account for more than 250 million acres of land, much of it in the Midwest where pollinator populations are already particularly vulnerable.

Across the country, bees are dying off at unprecedented rates. Instead of allowing more bee-toxic pesticides in the field, we urge you to take immediate action to protect bees from neonicotinoids already in widespread use.


Sincerely,

Kristin Schafer, Policy & Program Director 
Pesticide Action Network 
Oakland, CA 

On behalf of the 10,898 signatories below, concerned citizens from all 50 states, Washington, DC and several Canadian provinces.
docketTitle: Thiamethoxam: Amended Tolerances

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Friends of the Earth (Web) Part 3 of 4 (11,005 comments)
commentText: Friends of the Earth submits the following 10,500 comments, many of the comments unique, regarding Syngenta's petition to increase existing tolerances and create new tolerances for thiamethoxam on food crops.
docketTitle: Thiamethoxam: Amended Tolerances

title: Mass Comment campaign submitted by Katie Reilly, Online Organizer, Exclamation Point Campaigns, Sierra Club (71,969)
commentText:
Please accept the attached documents containing 71,969 comments as part of the docket for Residues of Pesticide Chemicals in or on Various Commodities. Thank you. 

Food is more important than profit -- suspend neonics! (EPA Docket  EPA-HQ-OPP-2014-0008-0005)

U.S. beekeepers lost an average of 45 percent of their colonies between the end of 2012 and the end of 2013 -- and thanks to pesticides called neonicotinoids, hives are producing 85 percent fewer queens. 

Neonicotinoids aren't just terrifying for the beekeepers or our agricultural economy -- they're terrifying for my family. This enormous threat to our food supply is why I request that the EPA deny Syngenta's request to expand and increase the use of thiamethoxam, and instead immediately suspend all registration of neonicotinoids.

The massive decline in the bee population threatens the very survival of the fruits and vegetables grown on our soil. In the past several months, at least five separate studies have added substantial weight to the growing body of evidence showing that widespread use of neonicotinoids -- like thiamethoxam -- is linked to this Colony Collapse Disorder. Our food supply is more important than expanding corporate profits, so Americans need you to deny Syngenta's request and suspend neonic registration now!

organization: The Pew Charitable Trusts - 11,125 members of public
title: Comment on BSEE-2013-0011-0031
commentText: Thank you for the opportunity to provide comment on DOI's proposed Requirements for Exploratory Drilling on the Arctic Outer Continental Shelf.  The Pew Charitable Trusts submits the attached comments on behalf of 11,125 members of the public.
docketTitle: Requirements for Exploratory Drilling on the Arctic OCS

title: Comment on BSEE-2013-0011-0031
commentText:
Dear Director Hopper and Director Salerno,

This message has been signed by 13,788 people in the Ocean Conservancy community. There names as well as cities and states of residence are attached to this message.

The offshore Arctic Ocean is home to an amazing array of wildlife, including walruses, polar bears, ice-dependent seals, and bowhead and beluga whales. It is also a remote and challenging environment, which makes offshore oil and gas operations in Arctic waters especially risky. When there is a major spill in the Arctic Ocean, clean-up will be all be impossible, and the damage could be catastrophic.
 
The Department of the Interior should not allow oil companies to drill in the Arctic at this time. But if drilling does go forward, it is essential that oil and gas operators are held to the highest possible standards for safety and oil spill prevention and response. The Department of the Interior's proposed Arctic standards are an important first step. These proposed rules include critical requirements for oil spill prevention and control that should not be weakened, including:
 
+ A capping stack and containment system must be located nearby to quickly capture oil spilling from an out-of-control well;
+ A second rig must be located in the region and available to respond to an out-of-control well before ice moves in; and
+ Drilling and oil spill response plans must take into account Arctic conditions such as ice, dangerous sea states, and dense fog.
 
In addition, the Department of the Interior should strengthen the proposed rules to allow the public to review and comment on oil companies' proposed spill response plans. These plans are an important window on a company's preparedness for operating in a dangerous and unique environment, and they deserve public scrutiny.
 
If oil companies want to operate in Arctic waters, they should be required to meet the strongest standards possible for safety, oil spill prevention, and response. I support the improvements proposed in the Arctic standards, and I urge you to strengthen the rules even more by providing for public review and comment on oil spill response plans.

Sincerely,
docketTitle: Requirements for Exploratory Drilling on the Arctic OCS

commentText: CEA generated 87,491 signatures in the 8 attached documents in response to the request for comments on proposed Arctic offshore exploration drilling regulations (BSEE-2013-0011) to be reviewed by the Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement and the Bureau of Ocean Energy Management.

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
December 23, 2014

Division of Policy and Directives Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service Headquarters
MS: BPHC, 5275 Leesburg Pike
Falls Church, VA 22041-3803

Attached are the names of 43,790 individuals who have submitted public comments urging the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Services to protect the Mexican gray wolf. In addition to signing on in support of the following letter, 3,621 individuals of the total number have submitted personalized comments. The personalized comments start on page 2 and end on page 223.

RE: Please strengthen rules to protect the Mexican Gray Wolf  (RE: Docket No. FWS-R2-ES-2013-0056)

Dear U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service,

I am writing to urge you to protect the Mexican gray wolf.

Wolves are a keystone species--their presence is critical to maintaining the structure and integrity of our native ecosystems. 

The Mexican gray wolf subspecies is genetically distinct from other wolves, and is one of the most endangered mammals in North America.

Before finalizing regulations to protect wild Mexican gray wolves, please address the following flaws of your recent proposal:

* Putting a population cap on wolves that is not scientifically based
* Failing to adequately address illegal wolf killings
* Excessively restricting where wolves can roam
* Allowing members of the general public to kill wolves with a permit, which could easily result in the deaths of the individuals most critical to the survival of this already struggling species

For years, these wolves have struggled to survive in the wild. We need regulations to protect them that are scientifically based.

Thank you for your consideration,

The Undersigned
docketTitle: Proposed Revision to the Nonessential Experimental Population of the Mexican Wolf

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
docketTitle: Threatened Status for the Distinct Population Segment of the North American Wolverine Occurring in the Continguous United States

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
In addition to our formal organizational comments and those of other conservation organizations, attached please find pdf documents containing 1,031 comments from members and supporters of Oregon Wild in Oregon and around the country. Though all represent the individual views of the submitters, please note there are over 90 distinct messages.

Oregon is currently home to only three known wolverines in the state. However, given the effort required to confirm those three and anecdotal evidence there are likely others. The state is home to a considerable amount of suitable habitat. However the species and their habitat face severe threats that are both direct and indirect including climate change, development, habitat fragmentation, mismanagement of habitat, inadequate regulations, trapping, some public hostility towards wildlife, and the effects from small isolated populations.

Given the small number of wolverines in Oregon and the lower-48 United States and the threats they face, wolverines are deserving of the full protections of the Endangered Species Act. They require significant critical habitat designations and a complete recovery plan to recover in Oregon and neighboring states. 

Recent trapping in Oregon and the states response coupled with a lack of a management plan and weak trapping regulations demonstrated how woefully unprepared Oregon is to manage and recover wolverines without the full protections of the federal Endangered Species Act.

We urge you to give wolverines the full protections of the Endangered Species Act, designate critical habitat in Oregon and elsewhere, and complete a recovery plan that will allow them to recover where they already exist and disperse to and thrive where good habitat remains. 

Respectfully Submitted,

Robert Klavins
Wildlife Advocate
Oregon Wild
5825 N. Greeley Avenue
Portland, OR 97217
rk@oregonwild.org
503.283.6343
docketTitle: Threatened Status for the Distinct Population Segment of the North American Wolverine Occurring in the Continguous United States

organization: Center for Biological Diversity and 117 other organizations
title: Comment on FR Doc # 2017-15696
docketTitle: Oil and Gas; Hydraulic Fracturing on Federal and Indian Lands; Rescission of a 2015 Rule

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2017-15696
commentText:
Please find 30,821 comments attached. More than 2,400 people have taken the time to write a personalized comment and 28,414 have signed to the following text:

I write to urge you to protect the Bureau of Land Management's safeguards for hydraulic fracturing (fracking) on public lands. Fracking is a dangerous practice that can contaminate our air and water, while contributing to the release of greenhouse gases. There is no amount of regulation that can make fracking safe, but rescinding or weaken the recently updated rules only puts our shared resources at greater risk. 

The updated fracking rules are long overdue and simply lay out basic standards for states to follow. They were enacted after years of review and process and should not be weakened or repealed. Please do not put our federal lands at risk by repealing our first line of defense against groundwater contamination.

Sincerely,

28,414 from across the country
docketTitle: Oil and Gas; Hydraulic Fracturing on Federal and Indian Lands; Rescission of a 2015 Rule

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2017-15696
commentText:
September 25, 2017

U.S. Department of the Interior
Bureau of Land Management 20 M Street SE, Room 2134 LM
1849 C Street NW.
Washington, DC 20240

On behalf of Environmental Action, an education and advocacy organization dedicated to the conservation of America's treasures, I formally submit more than 16,000 signatures in strong opposition to rescinding Bureau of Land Management's 2015 final rule "Oil and Gas, Hydraulic Fracturing on Federal and Indian Lands.

We need to keep environmental protections intact that help protect public lands and water from overuse and pollution. These regulations are important first steps to help protect health and safety of public lands and nearby communities. Removing environmental regulations is a dangerous step backward.

Please don't let our federal lands be put at risk by weakening or repealing our first line of defense against groundwater contamination

I ask that these signatures (attached) be entered into the official record and considered as individual comments. Each of the people listed in the attached spreadsheet signed this comment:

"I write to urge you to protect the Bureau of Land Management's protections from hydraulic fracturing on public lands.
The best way to protect our air, water and communities is to prohibit this harmful form of fossil fuel extraction. America's public lands, rightfully known as national treasures, are at risk from fracking for oil and gas.

There is no amount of regulation that can make fracking safe, but rescinding or weaken the recently updated rules only puts our shared resources and nearby communities at greater risk to drilling accidents, leaks and spills that pollute air and contaminate drinking water.

The updated fracking rules are long overdue after years of review and process. They simply lay out basic standards for states to follow. Please do not put our federal lands at risk by weakening or repealing our first line of defense against groundwater contamination."

For your convenience, the petition remains available online at: http://bit.ly/2fvlxCu.

Should you have any questions about the petition or signature file, please contact me at 202-461-2449 x349 or by email at Sally@environmental-action.org.

Sincerely,

Sally King
Environmental Action
docketTitle: Oil and Gas; Hydraulic Fracturing on Federal and Indian Lands; Rescission of a 2015 Rule

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2017-15696
commentText:
Dear Secretary Zinke, 
 
Please find attached over 5,000 comments from Earthworks members urging the Bureau of Land Management not to rescind your 2015 rule addressing hydraulic fracturing on federal and Indian lands, 82 Fed. Reg. 34,464 (July 25, 2017). If BLM chooses to revisit the 2015 Rule, the agency should consider strengthening its requirementsnot repealing them. 
 
Thank you.
docketTitle: Oil and Gas; Hydraulic Fracturing on Federal and Indian Lands; Rescission of a 2015 Rule

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2017-15696
commentText:
Attention: 1004-AE52,
U.S. Department of the Interior, 
Director (630), Bureau of Land Management, 
Mail Stop 2134LM,
 1849 C St. NW., 
Washington, DC 20240

Appended below are the names of 56,432 individuals who have submitted public comments calling for the protection of existing fracking rules. In addition to signing on in support of the following letter, 10,433 individuals of the total number have submitted personalized comments. The personalized comments start on page 2 and end on page 569.

Re: Proposed rescission of Bureau of Land Management Hydraulic Fracturing Rule, 82 Fed. Reg. 34464 (July 25, 2017)
Dear Secretary Zinke,

Please do not rescind the Bureau of Land Management's 2015 rule addressing hydraulic fracturing on federal and Indian lands. The rule is the product of nearly five years of agency work, expert input, public comments and hearings, and it provides much-needed updates to the Bureau's existing regulations, which were last overhauled in the 1980s. The 2015 rule requires companies to store fracturing wastes in tanks rather than pits, and for the first time will require prior review and approval of fracturing operations on public and tribal lands. The rule also modernizes the agency's well construction and testing standards and mandates disclosure of the chemicals that companies use in fracking fluid. All of these are reasonable, cost-effective measures that will better protect our public lands, drinking water, wildlife and public health and safety. They should not be abandoned.

Thank you for your consideration of these comments. 

The Undersigned
docketTitle: Oil and Gas; Hydraulic Fracturing on Federal and Indian Lands; Rescission of a 2015 Rule

organization: Americans for Financial Reform & Public Citizen
title: Comment on CFPB-2016-0020-0001 (281)
commentText:
Full comment from 281 organizations that advocate on behalf of consumers, students, civil rights, labor, small business, and more in the attached. The undersigned organizations strongly support the proposed rule.

--

August 22, 2016
 
Monica Jackson
Office of the Executive Secretary
Consumer Financial Protection Bureau
1700 G Street, NW
Washington DC 20552
	
Re: Docket No. CFPB-2016-0020 or RIN 3170-AA51

The undersigned consumer, civil rights, labor, community, and non-profit organizations strongly support the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB)'s proposed rule to limit pre-dispute binding mandatory (or forced) arbitration clauses in consumer finance contracts. The CFPB rule, which will restore consumers' ability to band together in court to pursue claims, is a significant step forward in the ongoing fight to curb predatory practices in consumer financial products and services and to make these markets fairer and safer.  

Lenders and other financial services companies use forced arbitration to push consumers out of court and into a private arbitration system that is tilted against them. Forced arbitration eliminates the right to a civil jury trial, limits discovery, restricts or prohibits public disclosure of proceedings and outcomes, and makes meaningful appeals virtually impossible. It also often prohibits consumers from banding together in a class action to hold the company responsible. 

The CFPB's thorough arbitration study  clearly documents how forced arbitration blocks consumer access to courts, shielding banks and lenders from meaningful accountability for their unlawful behavior. Finalizing the proposed rule will restore crucial class action rights that deter systemic abuses and bring much-needed transparency to consumer financial arbitration...

title: [Spreadsheet] Comment Submitted by Caitlin Alesio Maloney, Courage Campaign (28,003)
commentText:
August 22, 2016

Monica Jackson
Office of the Executive Secretary
Consumer Financial Protection Bureau
1700 G Street, NW
Washington DC 20552

Re: Docket No. CFPB-2016- 0020 or RIN 3170-AA51

Dear Ms. Jackson:

The attached comments are submitted by Courage Campaign on behalf of our members regarding the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's ("CFPB") proposed rules to restrict the use of forced arbitration clauses in consumer financial contracts and restore consumers' ability to band together in class actions.

We are submitting 28,003 comments from individuals around the country urging the Bureau to strengthen the proposals in its Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (Docket ID CFPB-2016- 0020). Specifically, we call on the Bureau to use its full authority to restore consumers' right to choose how to resolve disputes with financial institutions in the final rule. 

The petition language signed onto by these individuals is as follows:

To: Consumer Financial Protection Bureau 

Consumers already face a stacked deck when they try to hold large corporations accountable for harms - but forced arbitration clauses in consumer financial contracts make it nearly impossible to beat the odds. I support the CFPB's proposed rule to restore consumers' right to join together and take companies to court when they break the law.

Barring consumers from joining class actions directly opposes the public interest. I urge the CFPB to act on its congressional mandate by restricting the abusive practice of forced arbitration in the final rule.

Some signers chose to make additional comments, which are present in column F of the attached spreadsheet. 

If you require any additional information, please let us know.

Sincerely,

Caitlin Alesio Maloney
Courage Campaign
caitlin@couragecampagin.org
