title: Mass Mail Comment Campaign sponsored by Greenpeace USA (Web)
commentText:
Dear EPA Administrator McCarthy,

It's been over a year since President Obama introduced the executive order (#13650) to improve chemical safety and security, which directs federal agencies to modernize chemical plant safety and security policies. I'm concerned that since the disaster in West, Texas that took the lives of fifteen people and injured over 200, very little has been done to modernize policies to require facilities to adopt inherently safer systems.
				
The Agency must use its authority under the 1990 Clean Air Act to prevent a future chemical disaster as soon as possible. Common sense solutions exist and the best way to prevent a future disaster is to require chemical facilities to use safer chemical processes. The only way to ensure they are used is to activate the Clean Air Act's "Bhopal" provision in sections 112 (r)(1) and 112 (r)(7)(A). By activating this authority the EPA can require chemical facilities to use the safest cost-effective chemical process available to eliminate the potential for catastrophic chemical releases.
			
We've seen the news headlines from West, Texas; Charleston, West Virginia; Richmond, California and these disasters illustrate the need for new safety requirements that will truly prevent tragedies. The EPA's current timeline for a decision on new safety rules is scheduled for 2016 and that could be too late for those who live in the shadow of dangerous facilities.
				
The EPA must finalize regulations before President Obama leaves office.
				
Enforceable disaster prevention requirements are long overdue and should be prioritized immediately because hazards are unacceptable and the threat to people's lives are preventable.
			
Actions the Agency should take under the "Bhopal" amendment to the 1990 Clean Air Act include:
					
- Make prevention a requirement that chemical facilities use safer chemicals or processes wherever feasible.

- Prioritize protection of the most vulnerable populations, including workers, nearby communities and first responders.

- Require chemical facilities to reduce the use of the most toxic substances where alternatives are available.

Signed,
31,624 concerned members of the public (see attached spreadsheet)
Delivered by Greenpeace USA
docketTitle: Accidental Release Prevention Requirements:  Risk Management Programs Under the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r)(7); Rule Modernization Under Executive Order 13650; Request for Information

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Center for Science and Democracy at the Union of Concerned Scientists (Web)
commentText:
Dear Administrator McCarthy,

Citizens and scientists alike are asking the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to act now and modernize chemical plant safety and security policies. When the Center for Science and Democracy at the Union of Concerned Scientists informed supporters of the opportunity to comment on the EPAs Request for Information on potential revisions to the Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations and related programs, 16,494 people responded enthusiastically with comments. 

In the attached documents, you will find each of these comments from concerned citizens who want the EPA to use its authority to act and especially consider the following three standards while it reviews the RMP: 

* The EPA must require the use of safer chemical processes wherever
possible to reduce risk to the public and workers. In the absence of
regulation requiring this, many companies lack the incentive to switch
to safer alternatives, even though they exist.

* The EPA must improve access to scientific information, especially
during emergency situations. Lack of information can be detrimental to
the environment and human health, as recently demonstrated by the
chemical spill in West Virginia's Elk River in January 2014.

* The EPA must require better chemical disclosure. Currently, chemical
facilities can abdicate responsibility for emergency response
preparedness to local authorities without providing them with all the
information and capacity they need. This is unacceptable and needs to
be fixed immediately.

It has been more than a year since President Obama signed an executive order directing federal agencies to modernize chemical plant safety and security policies. With limited federal action to date, the need for improvement remains evident, as illustrated by the recent disasters in Charleston, West Virginia; West, Texas; and Richmond, California. 

Disaster prevention, transparency, disclosure, and access to information must be central to any revisions of the RMP. As echoed by the 16,494 comments here, the EPA must take appropriate steps to protect communities from risks posed by chemical facilities and ensure that the Agency can respond effectively when accidents occur. 

Center for Science and Democracy at the Union of Concerned Scientists, on behalf of 16,494 members of the public
docketTitle: Accidental Release Prevention Requirements:  Risk Management Programs Under the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r)(7); Rule Modernization Under Executive Order 13650; Request for Information

title: Mass Comment Campaign Sponsored by Earthjustice (Web)
commentText:
Appended in the attached document from Earthjustice are 35,608 individuals who have submitted public comments urging the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency to use its authority under the 1990 Amendments to the Clean Air Act to prevent future chemical disasters. In addition to signing on in support of the following letter, 2,345 individuals personalized their comments. The personalized comments start on page 3 and end on page 141. The 33,263 standard form letter comments begin on page 142.

Environmental Protection Agency
1200 Pennsylvania Ave. NW.
Washington, D.C. 20460

RE: Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs Under the Clean Air Act - Request for Information and Comments (Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OEM-2014-0328)

Dear Environmental Protection Agency,

The EPA has taken an important step by requesting information on how to improve chemical safety oversight. Now the agency must use its full legal authority and commonsense measures to protect workers and communities from chemical disasters.

Over a year ago, President Obama introduced Executive Order #13650, directing federal agencies to modernize chemical plant safety and security policies. In 2013, an explosion in West, TX , took the lives of 15 people--including firefighters--and injured more than 200. In 2012, the Chevron oil refinery exploded in Richmond, CA, causing more than 15,000 people to seek medical treatment. Despite these disasters and many other close calls, very little has been done to modernize policies to require facilities to adopt inherently safer systems.

The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) must immediately use its authority under the 1990 Amendments to the Clean Air Act to prevent future chemical disasters. Any common sense strategy for reducing chemical disasters should include an EPA requirement that chemical facilities use safer processes. Voluntary guidelines are not getting the job done to protect workers and communities. That is why the EPA must activate authority under the Clean Air Act's "Bhopal" provisions in sections 112 (r)(1) and 112 (r)(7)(A) to require chemical facilities to use the safest cost-effective chemical process available to eliminate the potential for catastrophic chemical releases.

A recent report by the Environmental Justice and Health Alliance (EJHA) for Chemical Policy Reform (cosponsored by Coming Clean and the Center for Effective Government) highlighted that more than 134 million Americans live in the danger zones around the 3,433 facilities that store or use highly hazardous chemicals. Most in danger are the 3.8 million people living at the fence line of these facilities. How many more news headlines and preventable suffering must our country endure before the EPA uses its power to hold chemical facilities accountable for safe operations? The threat burden posed by chemical disasters is more acutely felt by residents of communities of color and those with limited economic and political influence. Specifically, the EJHA report found that Blacks RE: Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-OEM-2014-0328 are 75 percent more likely than the greater U.S. population as a whole to live in fenceline zones near chemical facilities. Latinos are 60 percent more likely to live in fenceline communities. The current EPA timeline for updating chemical safety standards asks the public to wait until 2016, when there are steps that can be taken immediately to prevent chemical disasters. Vulnerable communities and workers cannot afford to wait for a safer industrial neighbor.

We also call on the Obama EPA to adopt standards during this administration to enforce disaster prevention standards under the "Bhopal" amendment to the 1990 Clean Air Act, including:
* Requiring chemical facilities to use safer chemicals or processes wherever feasible
* Prioritizing protection of the most vulnerable populations, including workers, nearby communities, and first responders
* Requiring chemical facilities to reduce the use of the most toxic substances where alternatives are available
* Requiring the use of backup power and the adoption of inherently safer systems before these emergencies occur
* Phasing out the use of hydrogen fluoride
* Providing for anonymous worker reporting of safety and maintenance issues
* Providing support for those impacted by the inaction of the EPA and industrial bad actors for a just and safe relocation. This is not a first resort.

There is no better time than the present to address the safety threat that refineries and other chemical facilities pose to both workers and communities.

Sincerely,
The Undersigned
docketTitle: Accidental Release Prevention Requirements:  Risk Management Programs Under the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r)(7); Rule Modernization Under Executive Order 13650; Request for Information

title: Mass Mail Campaign sponsored by Public Citizen (Web)
commentText:
October 29, 2014

Public Citizen Activists Petition EPA: More Than 8,000 Support Plan to Update Safety Requirements for Facilities That Store Hazardous Chemicals

The 8,067 members and supporters of Public Citizen whose names are gathered in the attached petition signed onto the following statement regarding EPA-HQ-OEM-2014-0328:

I am deeply concerned about the safety of hazardous chemical facilities in this country.

More than 110 million people live in high-risk zones near these facilities, but basic safety standards are not required in the manufacturing and storing of dangerous chemicals. We should not risk more tragedies at facilities that store flammable chemicals, like the fertilizer plant in West, Texas that exploded in 2013.

I urge you to act swiftly to implement the disaster prevention requirements included in executive order #13650 which directs federal agencies modernize chemical plant safety policies. Safer processing methods, reduced use of the most toxic substances and commonsense safety measures should be a requirement for all hazardous chemical facilities.

The online petition can be found on Public Citizens website at the following URL:

http://pubc.it/1FTsXCJ

###

Public Citizen is a national non-profit organization with more than 350,000 members and supporters. We represent consumer interests through lobbying, litigation, administrative advocacy, research and public education on a broad range of issues including consumer rights in the marketplace, product safety, financial regulation, safe and affordable health care, campaign finance reform and government ethics, fair trade, climate change and corporate and government accountability. Learn more at citizen.org

title: Mass Mail Comment Campaign sponsored by Greenpeace USA (Web)
commentText:
Dear EPA Administrator McCarthy,

It's been over a year since President Obama introduced the executive order (#13650) to improve chemical safety and security, which directs federal agencies to modernize chemical plant safety and security policies. I'm concerned that since the disaster in West, Texas that took the lives of fifteen people and injured over 200, very little has been done to modernize policies to require facilities to adopt inherently safer systems.
				
The Agency must use its authority under the 1990 Clean Air Act to prevent a future chemical disaster as soon as possible. Common sense solutions exist and the best way to prevent a future disaster is to require chemical facilities to use safer chemical processes. The only way to ensure they are used is to activate the Clean Air Act's "Bhopal" provision in sections 112 (r)(1) and 112 (r)(7)(A). By activating this authority the EPA can require chemical facilities to use the safest cost-effective chemical process available to eliminate the potential for catastrophic chemical releases.
			
We've seen the news headlines from West, Texas; Charleston, West Virginia; Richmond, California and these disasters illustrate the need for new safety requirements that will truly prevent tragedies. The EPA's current timeline for a decision on new safety rules is scheduled for 2016 and that could be too late for those who live in the shadow of dangerous facilities.
				
The EPA must finalize regulations before President Obama leaves office.
				
Enforceable disaster prevention requirements are long overdue and should be prioritized immediately because hazards are unacceptable and the threat to people's lives are preventable.
			
Actions the Agency should take under the "Bhopal" amendment to the 1990 Clean Air Act include:
					
- Make prevention a requirement that chemical facilities use safer chemicals or processes wherever feasible.

- Prioritize protection of the most vulnerable populations, including workers, nearby communities and first responders.

- Require chemical facilities to reduce the use of the most toxic substances where alternatives are available.

Sincerely,
273 concerned members of the public (see attached)
Delivered by Greenpeace

title: Mass Mailing - Sierra Club - Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
SierraRise, a project of the Sierra Club, has collected 29,885 public comments from supporters about endangered species protections for the rusty patched bumble bee (Docket ID FWS-R3-ES-2015-0112-0028). These individuals, who are included in the attached document, signed on to the following statement:

"The number of rusty patched bumble bee (Bombus affinis) populations has declined by an estimated 91 percent in just two decades, and the remaining populations do not appear to be stable. Given the economic value of pollinators and the rusty patched bumble bee's impact on wildflowers, cranberries, plums, apples, and other important crops, it is imperative that your agency protect the species as endangered and designate critical habitat in each relevant ecoregion."

Thank you for considering this public input as you weigh how to best preserve the rusty patched bumble bee's future.

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
Appended below are the names of 40,703 individuals who have submitted public comments calling for a revised recovery plan for Mexican gray wolves. In addition to signing on in support of the following letter, 4,662 individuals of the total number have submitted personalized comments. The personalized comments start on page 2 and end on page 435.

RE: Endangered and Threatened Wildlife and Plants; Mexican Wolf Draft Recovery Plan, First Revision (FWS-R2-ES-2017-0036-0001)

Dear Fish and Wildlife Service,

Thank you for releasing a draft recovery plan for the Mexican gray wolf, an iconic species of the American Southwest.  Unfortunately, scientific shortcomings in the draft plan will prevent the lobo's recovery.  I urge you to revise the recovery plan so that it is based on the best available science.

Specifically, I urge you to fix the following flaws:

	The draft recovery plan calls for too few wolves over too small an area.  The peer-reviewed, best available science says that additional Mexican wolf populations must be established in the United Statesspecifically in the Grand Canyon and southern Rockiesfor the species to survive.  Mexican wolves should number at least 700 in the United Statesnot the 320-380 FWS calls for in the draft plan.
	The draft recovery plan relies too heavily on recovery in Mexicodespite the fact that habitat there is inadequate. Further, prey numbers used in FWS's modeling exercises are unreliable and likely biased high.
	The draft recovery plan does not sufficiently address the genetic threats facing the Mexican wolf.  For example, FWS allows for continued erosion of the genetic diversity of the captive Mexican gray wolf populationdespite the fact that the genetic diversity of the captive population has already substantially deteriorated and retains only 83% of the founders' genetic diversity.  In addition, the draft plan states that natural reproduction, rather than releases of captive wolves, will drive growth of the wild Mexican wolf populations.  This will prevent necessary infusion of new genes into the wild populations and lead to further inbreeding problems.
	FWS hands control of releases of captive wolves over to the states of Arizona and New Mexico.  This is problematic when the states have been actively hostile to Mexican wolf recovery, with New Mexico even filing a lawsuit to prevent such releases.

For years, Mexican gray wolves have struggled to survive in the wild.  With this recovery plan, FWS is charting the course for the future of this species: will it once again flourish on the Southwestern landscape, or will it go extinct?  The current recovery plan overlooks the best available science and threatens the future of the Mexican wolf.  Please address the shortcomings identified in this letter and craft a science-based recovery plan that will prevent extinction of this magnificent and critically endangered species.
docketTitle: Endangered and Threatened Wildlife and Plants; Mexican Wolf Draft Recovery Plan, First Revision

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2015-17308
commentText:
Please find attached a 53 .rtf files containing 26,064 comments from Sierra Club members and supporters who are asking that OSM move forward with the strongest possible Stream Protection Rule.

A typical comment from these individuals follows: 


Along with all 2.4 million Sierra Club members and supporters, I am asking that the Department of Interior and Office of Surface Mining finalize a strong Stream Protection Rule to protect our waterways and communities from mining pollution. 
 
Thank you for proposing this long awaited rule. Many of the communities living near mining sites cannot rely on their elected or local officials to stand up against Big Coal. They have looked to you and the rest of this Administration to help their communities where their state officials fail them. 

While the proposed Stream Protection Rule does make some strides in holding Big Coal accountable for their pollution, I think the rule could be strengthened to ensure citizens across the nation do not have to suffer from living in the shadows of mining sites.
 
Since citizens are not able to rely on their local and state officials to stand up for them against Big Coal, they must have the tools to do it themselves. While this proposed rule takes a step in holding mining companies accountable, it also must clarify in its final rule that the law allows citizens to enforce water quality standards.
 
The proposed Stream Protection Rule has a lot of potential to help communities around the country fight for the health and safety of their water. Please strengthen and finalize this rule before the end of the Administration.



Please enter these 20,064 comments into the record for this comment docket.


See attached file(s)
docketTitle: Stream Protection Rule

title: Comment on the Stream Protection Rule

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2015-17308
commentText:
Dear OSM,

Attached please find following petition and 1,177 petition signers, all calling on OSM to finalize a strong Stream Protection Rule to ensurer a cleaner, healthier future for our communities.

Sincerely,
Kristin Brown
League of Conservation Voters

Petition Text:

Thank you for proposing the long-awaited Stream Protection Rule to protect our waterways and communities from hazardous coal mining pollution. I urge you to stand up to the Big Polluters who have been allowed to poison our waters and families for too long by quickly finalizing a strong rule. 

The draft Stream Protection Rule includes some very important steps forward, including enhanced water quality monitoring and stream restoration requirements. However, the rule needs to be stronger, ensuring that citizens will still be able to enforce water quality standards and hold polluters accountable in the courts for damage they cause. In addition, reinstating the 100 foot "buffer zone" would help prevent streams from being destroyed in the first place and reduce the need for restoration.

For too long, coal mining pollution has jeopardized the health and environment of mining communities. Please finalize a strong Stream Protection Rule soon to ensure a cleaner, healthier future for all our communities.
docketTitle: Stream Protection Rule

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2015-17308
commentText:
Office of Surface Mining Reclamation and Enforcement
c/o Joseph Pizarchik, Director
1951 Constitution Avenue NW
Washington, DC 20240

Appended below are the names of 18,306 individuals who have submitted public comments regarding the Office of Surface Mining Reclamation and Enforcement's (OSM) proposed Stream Protection Rule. In addition to signing on in support of the following letter, 3,276 individuals of the total number have submitted personalized comments. The personalized comments start on page 2 and end on page 235.


Strengthen the Stream Protection Rule (RE: Docket ID # OSM-2010-0018-0001)

Dear Secretary Jewell, Director Pizarchik, and Administrator McCarthy,

Mountaintop removal coal mining is a national disgrace. It has already flattened 500 mountains, obliterated 2000 miles of streams, and erased 2.5 million acres of Appalachia's ancient forests. This destruction won't stop unless you act.

To make sure your Stream Protection Rule actually protects community water sources from the extreme and irreversible damage of mountaintop removal mining, you need to strengthen the proposed rule. Most important, you need to make clear that mining operations will never be allowed to violate water quality standards, and you must ensure that citizens can enforce water quality standards when state regulators fail. You also need to restore the ban on harmful mining activities within 100 feet of streams. Your legacy should be ending the destruction of waters by mountaintop removal mining, not a weakening of existing protections. 

I stand with all the people of Appalachia whose health, culture and access to clean water are threatened by mountaintop removal mining. I hope the Obama administration will stand with us, too, by strengthening this rule before it is finalized.

Thank you for your consideration,
The Undersigned

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsoring unknown (web)
commentText:
On Behalf of 6305 (attached) Public Citizen members we submit the following comments on the EPA's proposed rule: National Oil and Hazardous Substances Pollution Contingency Plan. 

The EPAs new rule must be as strong as possible to ensure protection of public health and the environment. At a very minimum, the rule must require:

Sufficient testing to understand the effectiveness and toxicity of dispersants prior to listing them as approved for use.
    
Criteria that ensure that dispersants approved for use do not pose any danger to public health and the environment.
    
Public identification of dispersant ingredients to allow the agency and the public to ensure that the chemicals used to respond to an oil spill are not as toxic  or more toxic  than the oil being spilled.

Monitoring of the dispersants impacts on public health and the environment after they are applied.

We owe it to current and future generations to require companies and the government to protect public health and the environment. I urge you to finalize a dispersant rule that includes the strongest protections possible. We must ensure that dispersants are never again used without adequate information.

Thank you for your consideration
docketTitle: Revisions to the National Oil and Hazardous Substances Pollution Contingency Plan; Subpart J Product Schedule Listing Requirements

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Earthjustice (web)
commentText:
The attached document includes the names of 46,274 individuals who have submitted public comments regarding the National Oil and Hazardous Substances Pollution Contingency Plan urging the Environmental Protection Agency to pass strong new regulations on oil dispersants. In addition to signing on in support of the following letter, 4,376 individuals of the total number have submitted personalized comments. The personalized comments start on page 2 and end on page 266.

RE: National Oil and Hazardous Substances Pollution Contingency Plan EPA-HQ-OPA-2006-0090-0010

Dear Environmental Protection Agency,

Twenty-six years after the Exxon Valdez grounded in Prince William Sound and five years after the Deepwater Horizon blowout in the Gulf of Mexico, it's high time for the EPA to finalize a strong rule to ensure that responses to oil spills are not more hazardous to public health and the environment than the release of oil itself. In both Alaska and the Gulf, too little was known about chemical dispersants that were released in unprecedented volumes to disperse oil. We now know that these chemicals don't get rid of the oil--and that the effects of oil mixed with dispersants can be more harmful than oil alone.

We need a strong rule to make sure we sufficiently test and understand the effectiveness and toxicity of the chemicals used in response to oil spills, and the EPA should never again allow the use of dispersants that add to the toxic brew in our nation's waters. In addition, information about the chemicals in dispersants--including the chemical ingredients and health and safety information--shouldn't be secret. The public, including workers exposed to dispersants, fisherman who rely on clean waters for their livelihood, and nearby residents, have the right to know what they're being exposed to.

The long-overdue rule must ensure protection of public health and the environment so our coastal communities don't face the threat of another chaotic and uninformed response when the next oil disaster hits. Please finalize a strong rule before dispersants are used again without adequate protection or information.

Thank you for your consideration,
The Undersigned
docketTitle: Revisions to the National Oil and Hazardous Substances Pollution Contingency Plan; Subpart J Product Schedule Listing Requirements

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2017-27898
commentText:
See attached file(s) for submission of signers for the following comment:

Ban Gunman's Accessories That Enabled Vegas Killing Spree
This summer, a gunman killed 58 people and injured 546 more in an instant in Las Vegas. Using an accessory called a bump stock, the gunman was able to turn his semi-automatic weapon into one that was nearly automatic, giving him the ability to turn a concert into a massacre in mere seconds. Automatic weapons are tightly regulated in the U.S., but bump stocks, the tool that lets semi-automatic weapons become nearly automatic, are not. Its a loophole. And so far, Congress hasnt done anything about it.

Instead of implementing comprehensive legislative changes that would take bump stocks off the national market immediately, Congress is letting the process drag out for years in a federal rulemaking process. We cant wait that long. Cities like Columbia, South Carolina and states like New Jersey, led by Gov. Chris Christie, have already banned bump stocks in the months since the Las Vegas massacre. But a patchwork of city and state laws isnt enough. We need to ban bump stocks nationwide, now, so tragedies like Las Vegas can never happen again. Tell Congress and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms: If Columbia, South Carolina can do it, so can the countrywe need more than a patchwork of local and state laws, we need a national ban on bump stocks.
docketTitle: ANPRM on "Bumpfire" Stocks and Other Similar Devices. To comment on the NPRM, search ATF-2018-0002

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2017-27898
commentText:
Hello,

Please see attached 1,911 comments from members of Organizing for Action regarding the review of the Application of the Definition of Machinegun to Bump Fire Stocks and Other Similar Devices. The comment is below.

Thanks,
Dana

Dana Mayber
Deputy Campaigns Director
Organizing for Action
dmayber@ofa.us



Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives (ATF)- Docket number 2017R-22				

Comment: To fully protect American communities from another mass shooting on the devastating scale of Las Vegas, Congress must act to ban bump stocks and other similar firearm devices or accessories designed to dramatically accelerate the rate of gunfire. In the absence of congressional action, ATF should issue a new rule clarifying that the definition of "machine gun" in the National Firearms Act of 1934 includes conversion devices like bump fire stocks that convert a semi-automatic rifle into the functional equivalent of a fully automatic rifle. These devices are intended to circumvent the restrictions on possession of fully automatic firearms, and both Congress and ATF must take action quickly to address this threat to public safety.

Signed: 1,911 Members of Organizing for Action

title: Comment from Alexander Rony
commentText:
Earthjustice, a nonprofit law organization, collected 11,039 public comments regarding the proposed rule for Northeast Multispecies Fishery Framework Adjustment 48, particularly as it relates to the opening of protected waters for industrial fishing. These comments have been attached.

Users were able to customize their public comment, and several of these are attached in a separate document. Below is the standard, unedited comment. Thank you for considering these points.

Default Comment:

I strongly oppose NOAA Fisheries' proposal to potentially open nearly 5,000 square miles of protected New England waters to commercial fishing. These areas have been protecting habitat and contributing to the recovery of fish and other wildlife for nearly two decades. With several groundfish species still severely depleted, now is not the time to eliminate protections and risk pushing these groundfish beyond their ability to recover. 

Recent scientific assessments indicate that many of New England's groundfish populations are at precariously low levels and half are being fished at unsustainable rates. For example, Gulf of Maine cod is at approximately 16 percent of what is considered a healthy population, while Georges Bank cod is at just 7 percent. Removing protections for juvenile and spawning fish will result in even greater damage to these populations, their habitat, and the fishing communities that depend on them. 

These proposed changes to protected areas represent a fundamental change in the way marine resources are managed for the public good and will have significant impacts to the region's ocean habitat. I urge NOAA Fisheries to complete a full analysis of the potential biological and economic impacts prior to reopening any currently protected areas to additional fishing. In short, an environmental impact statement is needed.
docketTitle: Framework Adjustment 48 to the Northeast Multispecies FMP

title: Comment from Greg Wells
commentText: Please find the attached comments from 63,769 individuals urging NOAA Fisheries to complete a full analysis of impacts (i.e., an Environmental Impact Statement) prior to opening any of the year-round closed areas to commercial groundfishing. A sample of letters are provided, as well as a spreadsheet with all the names, cities, states and countries of individual signers. Please note that many of these letters have been personalized and include additional comments.

title: Comment on BSEE-2018-0002-0001
commentText:
Defenders of Wildlife is submitting this message on behalf of the attached list of 14,763 individual commenters.

These 14,763 commenters have stated that they care deeply for our natural world, and are writing to express their strong opposition to the proposed revisions to the Well Control Rule. Weakening this lifesaving necessary rule increases our risk of catastrophic oil spills that threaten human life and wildlife alike. As we witnessed with Deepwater Horizon, the increased risks of the loss of human life and devastating impacts to our marine wildlife, oceans and coasts are not worth weakening this rule.

The American people strongly oppose weakening key parts of a rule that were put in place to protect the marine environment, marine wildlife and people whose livelihoods depend on fishing and coastal tourism as well as those working in the offshore drilling industry. 

Several federal government investigative bodies that examined the Deepwater Horizon catastrophe recommended these detailed technical upgrades to enhance safety and environmental protection. President Trump issued Executive Order 13795 on April 28, 2017 instructing the Department of the Interior to reconsider these rules to promote energy exploration and production. The oil industry strongly supported weakening these rules. 

The upgraded rules have been working. In fiscal year 2017, there were zero blowouts, down from several blowouts in previous years.

Key parts of the rule that would be weakened by Interior include: real-time monitoring of drilling operations offshore and onshore, a standardized safe drilling margin (i.e., the amount of drilling muds needed to prevent upward pressure that results in blowouts), and several important procedures for equipment failure investigations and reporting.  

Americans want clean, safe coasts and oceans and want their coastal regions to be free from oil and other toxins so they can enjoy marine wildlife and can fish and recreate safely.

Each of the 14,763 commenters listed in the attached document strongly oppose this irresponsible rollback of safety standards for offshore drilling and urge you to keep these vital regulations in place.

Win Without War supporters oppose the proposed rule regarding demonstrations and special events in the National Capital Region, 83 Fed. Reg. 40460 (Aug. 15, 2018). The American public has the right to peacefully demonstrate at the White House and National Mall, and these proposed regulations will curb our ability to exercise our First Amendment rights.

Please find attached 8,600 signatures. This is in addition to the approximately 23,000 signatures we delivered in person to the National Park Service office today. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter and for your work preserving America's best idea.

Amy Frame,
Digital Director
Win Without War
docketTitle: Special Regulations, Areas of the National Park System, National Capital Region, Special Events and Demonstrations

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2018-17386
commentText:
October 15, 2018

National Park Service
National Mall and Memorial Parks
900 Ohio Drive SW, Washington, DC 20024
Attn: Brian Joyner

Attached please find 19,499 comments collected online by CREDO Action in regards to regulations governing the management of permitted demonstrations and special events on the National Mall and Memorial Parks (RIN 1024-AE45).

Individual comments may differ throughout, although the majority read as follows: 

"I am writing to express my opposition to the National Park Service's proposed regulations that will negatively affect the rights of the people to demonstrate in the nation's capital. These regulations would impede the ability of people to assemble and to speak out on matters of importance, which is crucial to participatory democracy.

I oppose any effort by the government to charge demonstrators for engaging in First Amendment activities. Demonstrations, including musical performances or other elements that are part of them, are different than special events that are commercial or corporate sponsored and should remain fully distinct in their treatment.

The White House sidewalk should not be restricted or closed to protest assemblies. From Suffragists, to anti-lynching pickets, to anti-war demonstrations, to calls to save our environment, this is a critical and iconic location for the expression of views to the government, to the press and to the world.

I also oppose other restrictions and burdens on protests in the proposed regulations including the proposal to eliminate the rule, ordered previously by the courts, that permit applicants know within 24 hours whether their permit is granted or denied so that they can immediately begin organizing and let people know about a demonstration and make plans to come. This is important to my ability to participate in free speech activities in Washington, D.C."


Sincerely, 

Brandy Doyle
Campaign Manager, CREDO Action 
bdoyle@credoaction.com

title: Form Letter from MomsRising [Multiple Signatures=1001] Part 8 of 8
commentText:
Dear Commissioner Gottlieb:

Please find comments from 1001 parents attached, asking for immediate implementation of the menu labeling guidelines that were scheduled to take effect in May 2017. (Document is Part 8 of 8)

Guessing games are fun, but not when it comes to knowing what's in the food we give our kids. Menu labeling helps parents and kids make informed choices about what they eat and drink.

Eighty percent of Americans support menu labeling in chain restaurants, and 81% support having restaurants provide information about prepared foods. [1] Families eat out almost twice as often as they did in the 1970s, and kids consume about 1/4 of their daily calories at fast-food and other restaurants. [4] And let's be real: many of the options on the menu aren't healthy. At one popular establishment, a side order of corn bread has over TWICE the calories as a side order of fries. [1]

Menu labeling works! New York City has already implemented menu labeling, and 82% of consumers reported that it has had an impact on what they've ordered. [3]

Labeling will make a big difference when it comes to the health of our families, too. Studies show that providing nutrition information at restaurants can help people make lower calorie choices, and encourage restaurants to introduce lower-calorie items or change recipes to cut calories on current items. [5] It just makes sense all around.

Any delays to implementing menu labeling as proposed is bad news for families.

Menu labeling gives parents the information they need to make healthy choices for their families. Eating out shouldn't be a guessing game.

Sincerely,

Karen Showalter, Senior Campaign Director, Momsrising.org
Kristin Rowe-Finkbeiner, Executive Director, MomsRising.org

1. https://cspinet.org/resource/nutrition-labeling-restaurants-supermarkets-other-food-service-establishments-0
2. https://cspinet.org/protecting-our-health/menu-labeling
3. https://cspinet.org/resource/new-york-city-rave-reviews-menu-labeling
4. http://www.ers.usda.gov/topics/food-choices-health/food-consumption-demand/food-away-from-home.aspx#.UuATMRAo7ct
5. http://www.rwjf.org/en/library/articles-and-news/2017/07/comments-from-richard-besser-on-nutrition-labeling-of-menu-items-in-restaurants-and-retail-food- establishments.html
docketTitle: Nutrition Labeling of Standard Menu Items in Restaurants and Similar Retail Food Establishments

title: Form Letter from MomsRising [Multiple Signatures=2500] Part 4 of 8
commentText:
Dear Commissioner Gottlieb:

Please find comments from over 2500 parents attached, asking for immediate implementation of the menu labeling guidelines that were scheduled to take effect in May 2017. (Document is Part 4 of 8)

Guessing games are fun, but not when it comes to knowing what's in the food we give our kids. Menu labeling helps parents and kids make informed choices about what they eat and drink.

Eighty percent of Americans support menu labeling in chain restaurants, and 81% support having restaurants provide information about prepared foods. [1] Families eat out almost twice as often as they did in the 1970s, and kids consume about 1/4 of their daily calories at fast-food and other restaurants. [4] And let's be real: many of the options on the menu aren't healthy. At one popular establishment, a side order of corn bread has over TWICE the calories as a side order of fries. [1]

Menu labeling works! New York City has already implemented menu labeling, and 82% of consumers reported that it has had an impact on what they've ordered. [3]

Labeling will make a big difference when it comes to the health of our families, too. Studies show that providing nutrition information at restaurants can help people make lower calorie choices, and encourage restaurants to introduce lower-calorie items or change recipes to cut calories on current items. [5] It just makes sense all around.

Any delays to implementing menu labeling as proposed is bad news for families.

Menu labeling gives parents the information they need to make healthy choices for their families. Eating out shouldn't be a guessing game.

Sincerely,

Karen Showalter, Senior Campaign Director, Momsrising.org
Kristin Rowe-Finkbeiner, Executive Director, MomsRising.org

1. https://cspinet.org/resource/nutrition-labeling-restaurants-supermarkets-other-food-service-establishments-0

title: Mass Comment Campaign entitled "Clean Up Cement Kilns Now!" sponsored by Earthjustice (13,343 signees)
commentText:
Clean Up Cement Kilns Now! 

WHEREAS: Mercury pollution is a dangerous neurotoxin that causes serious 
health effects, including impairing the ability of children to read, write, walk, talk 
and learn;

WHEREAS: Mercury pollution has contaminated hundreds of lakes, streams, 
rivers, creeks and ponds, and poisoned certain fish populations to the point where 
they are no longer safe to eat;

WHEREAS: The cement industry is a major industrial polluter of mercury and 
other toxic air pollutants;

WHEREAS: Cement kilns have severely underestimated the amount of mercury 
pollution they are emitting into the environment;

WHEREAS: the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency has the responsibility and 
duty under the Clean Air Act to regulate mercury and other toxic air pollution from 
major industrial polluters;

WHEREAS: For nearly a decade, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency has 
ignored the law, the courts, and the will of the people requiring it to clean up 
mercury pollution from the cement industry;

WE THE UNDERSIGNED URGE the Administrator of the U.S. Environmental 
Protection Agency, the agency charged with regulating mercury and other toxic air 
pollutants from major industrial sources including the cement industry, to adopt the 
strongest limits on mercury pollution for all existing cement kilns in the United 
States. We also urge the EPA to immediately require cement kilns to test their 
actual mercury emissions and make this information readily available to the public. 
The cement industry has received a free pass to pollute mercury for far too long; it 
is time the EPA does its job and puts an end to this dangerous threat to our health 
and the environment.
docketTitle: National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants From the Portland Cement Manufacturing Industry

title: Mass Comment Campaign entitled "Thank You for Cutting Cement Kilns' Mercury" sponsored by Earthjustice (4963 signees)
commentText:
Docket ID: No. EPA-HQ-OAR-2002-0051
Thank You for Cutting Cement Kilns' Mercury

Dear Administrator Jackson,

We, the undersigned, applaud you for taking the first significant step towards 
cleaning up mercury, hydrochloric acid, particulate matter and other toxic air 
pollution from our nation's cement kilns.

This is an important decision that will affect the lives of millions of Americans who 
are forced to breathe the toxic pollution that cement kilns emit. Controlling cement 
kilns' mercury emissions will also go a long way toward cleaning up our water 
bodies and making our fish safe to eat again. Eating fish is a healthy part of any 
diet, and it is important that we make sure the fish we eat is free of mercury.

We sincerely hope that you and the EPA will stand strong behind these standards 
which, at long last, bring cement kilns' toxic pollution under control. We also hope 
you will continue the important work of cleaning up toxic air pollution by setting 
strong rules for other sources, such as power plants, chemical refineries and 
incinerators. Thank you for your leadership on this important issue, and keep up 
the good work!
docketTitle: National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants From the Portland Cement Manufacturing Industry

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Environmental Defense Fund (EDF) (web)
commentText:
To Whom It May Concern: 

Attached is a document containing the signatures of 33,363 Environmental Defense Fund supporters from across the country who have submitted electronic comments regarding EPA's Regulation of Certain Uses under Toxic Substances Control Act: Trichloroethylene; Vapor Degreasing. The comment they each submitted reads: 

"I'm writing today to strongly urge EPA to finalize its rules to ban high-risk uses of trichloroethylene (TCE), methylene chloride (DCM), and N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP) under the new Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA).  

These chemicals are extremely toxic. TCE is carcinogenic and can cause heart defects in the developing fetus.  DCM is a very lethal chemical  over the past few decades, dozens of workers have died from using DCM-based paint stripping products.  NMP is often used as a substitute for DCM in paint stripping products, yet it also presents major health risks  ranging from developmental and reproductive toxicity to neurotoxicity to liver and kidney damage. 

EPA had not successfully banned a chemical under the original TSCA in nearly three decades.  Now, with its greater authority under the new TSCA as amended by the Lautenberg Act, EPA can score an early public health victory by banning these toxic chemicals for these high-risk uses.  

But the chemical industry is complaining and pressuring EPA to back off, delay, or weaken these much needed rules.  Some in industry are suggesting that measures like putting a simple label on these deadly products or requiring workers to wear protective gear would suffice.  But labels, personal protective equipment, and concentration limits are not enough to protect my family and community.

I strongly urge the Agency to stay on track and promptly ban TCE used as a spot cleaning agent in dry cleaning, as an aerosol spray degreaser in commercial and consumer settings, and as a vapor degreaser in commercial settings, and both DCM and NMP used for commercial and consumer paint stripping. Safer alternatives are already widely available. 

There is simply no excuse to continue putting my family's and my community's health at risk by delaying or weakening these rules."

Please let me know if you have any additional questions or concerns about this submission. 

Thank you for your consideration, 

Heather Shelby
Manager, Grassroots Organizing & Activism
Environmental Defense Fund
hshelby@edf.org
docketTitle: Trichloroethylene (TCE); Regulation of Use in Vapor Degreasing under TSCA 6(a)

commentText:
Please find 12,479 individual comments attached in 13 documents. These comments are urging the EPA to adopt a strong rule to protect Americas waterways from the harmful impacts of power plants. 

Specifically, the EPA's new rule must adopt stringent regulations that require the equivalent of the protection achieved by closed-cycle cooling or better, effectively phasing out once-through cooling.

Please review each comment individually.

title: Comment from National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition (Multiple Signatures=15,265 Total)
commentText:
To Whom It May Concern:

Please accept the attached 15,265 signatures as stakeholder comments on the Food and Drug Administrations (FDA) proposed rule for Standards for the Growing, Harvesting, Packing, and Holding of Produce for Human Consumption (the Produce Rule) and proposed rule for Current Good Manufacturing Practice and Hazard Analysis and Risk-Based Preventive Controls for Human Food (the Preventive Controls Rule).  This submission is in addition to and complements our formal organizational comments, and a copy has been submitted to both rule dockets.

These signatures were jointly collected by the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition, Farm Aid, and Pesticide Action Network of North America and reflect a cross-section of concerned farmers, consumers, and advocates from across the country.  All of these individuals have signed on to the attached statement; many have also submitted additional personal statements, which are also included below. 

Consumers, farmers, and food entrepreneurs are invested in the continued growth and success of sustainable farming systems and believe it is critical that these rules be substantially revised to reflect the issues described herein. 

Thank you for your consideration of these citizen comments.

Sincerely,

National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition
Farm Aid
Pesticide Action Network of North America


Attached:
Full citizen petition text
List of signatures with additional comments
docketTitle: Current Good Manufacturing Practice and Hazard Analysis and Risk-Based Preventive Controls For Human Food

title: Comment from Food Democracy Now! (Multiple Comments and Signatures=Over 45,549
commentText:
On behalf of the family farm and sustainable agriculture organization Food Democracy Now!, I would like to submit the following comments and signatures of more than 45,549 American farmers and citizens to suggest urgent corrections be made to new food safety rules being promulgated by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in accordance to the Food Safety Modernization Act (FSMA) of 2010 in order to protect the economic viability of Americas family farmers and local food producers.

I am writing because at Food Democracy Now! we are concerned about the impact that FDAs proposed FSMA rules will have on the farms that millions of Americans buy food from, the impact it will have on business, and American familys ability to find local food. I ask you to ensure that new regulations do not put family farms out of business, harm farmers soil, water, and wildlife conservation efforts, or shut down the growth of local and regional healthy food systems in the name of false food safety measures.

Growing food and agricultural products is an inherently risky business. There are a lot of steps where things can go wrong. Disease, rot, bacteria and contamination are manageable risks of growing, harvesting, processing, packaging, shipping and handling food. Unfortunately, the massive industrialization of our food supply in the past 40 years has resulted in the growth of previously unimaginable food safety outbreaks that have been massive in scale. The rise of antibiotic resistance in factory farms, E. coli tainted meat and outrageous outbreaks of salmonella in peanut butter and half a billion eggs prove that Americas industrial food supply increases food safety risks and that economies of scale do not necessarily lead to economies of safety.

Rather than focus on these very real problems, the new rules written for the FSMA attempt to place a one-size-fits-all approach that will force many small and mid-sized family farmers out of business. As currently written, the new food safety rules being promulgated by the FDA threaten to put more than 30,000 farms out of business; reduce the supply of fresh, local produce in schools and hospitals; push farmers to tear out wildlife habitat and increase the use of chemicals rather than natural fertilizer.

The U.S. needs federal policies that support, not hinder existing and beginning farmers in their continued efforts to grow more fruits and vegetables for local markets.

Currently, local food and agricultural production is one of the fastest growing segments of agriculture and the new FSMA rules unfairly threaten this vibrant industry, which includes 8,144 farmers markets.

Its common knowledge that different production systems and supply chains pose inherently different risks to the safety of our food supply and the FDA must focus our limited government resources to address the highest risks, those posed by the massive factory farms and industrial food processors.

Regulations must be scale- and supply-chain appropriate to be effective; a one-size fits-all approach will put small and mid-sized farms and processors out of business, undermine public health goals, such as increased production of, availability of, and access to healthy foods, as well as economic opportunity, equity and job-creation goals.

I urge you to modify the rules so that they:

    Allow farmers to use sustainable farming practices, including those already allowed and encouraged by existing federal organic standards and conservation programs. Specifically, FDA must not exceed the strict standards for the use of manure and compost used in certified organic production and regulated by the National Organic Program.

    Ensure that diversified and innovative farms, particularly those pioneering models for increased access to healthy, local foods, continue to grow and thrive without being stifled. Specifically, FDA needs to clarify two key definitions: first, as Congress required, FDA must affirm that farmers markets, CSAs, roadside stands, and other direct-to-consumer vendors fall under the definition of a retail food establishment and are therefore not facilities subject to additional regulation. Second, FDA should adopt at least the $1,000,000 threshold for a very small business and base it on the value of regulated product, not all food, to ensure smaller farms and businesses (like food hubs) fall under the scale-appropriate requirements and arent subject to high cost, industrial-scale regulation.

    Provide options that treat family farms fairly, with due process and without excessive costs. Specifically, FDA must clearly define the material conditions that lead to a withdrawal of a farmers protected status in scientifically measurable terms. FDA must also outline a clear, fair, process for justifying the withdrawal of a farmers protected status and for how a farmer can regain that status.

Thank you for your consideration,

David Murphy
Founder / Executive Directory
Food Democracy Now!
docketTitle: Current Good Manufacturing Practice and Hazard Analysis and Risk-Based Preventive Controls For Human Food

title: Comment on BSEE-2017-0008-0001
commentText:
Please accept the attached comments from over 40,000 members and activists of Friends of the Earth, who are opposed to any reduction in the safety requirements and regulations associated with offshore drilling operations.

Substantive comments from Friends of the Earth in opposition to this proposed action can be found in the coalition letter submitted by Center for Biological Diversity and other partner organizations. BSEE should not implement the proposed revisions to the PSSR, particularly the elimination of third-party inspections of SPPE and the broad incorporation industry-generated standards. If offshore drilling is to increase, as this Administration has stated, so must the corresponding level of safety and prudence. OCSLA specifically requires BSEE to ensure that offshore energy development is balanced with the
protection of the human, marine, and coastal environments; and that adequate environmental safeguards are in place. Rolling back critical safety measures implemented after the Deepwater Horizon disaster would do just the opposite, and further increase the inherently dangerous risks of offshore oil and gas drilling.
docketTitle: 1014-AA37  Proposed Rule: Oil and Gas and Sulphur Operations on the OCS-Oil and Gas Production Safety Systems-Revisions

title: Comment on BSEE-2017-0008-0001
commentText:
January 29, 2018

Department of the Interior
Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement
Attention: Regulations Development Branch
45600 Woodland Road, VAE-ORP
Sterling VA 20166

Dear BSEE Director Scott Angelle,

On behalf of Environmental Action, an education and advocacy organization dedicated to the conservation of America's treasures, I formally submit more than 18,390 signatures in strong opposition to Oil and Gas Production Safety Systems; Revisions: Oil and Gas and Sulphur Operations on the Outer Continental Shelf (Docket ID: BSEE-2017-0008-0001). 

Offshore drilling is extremely dangerous, and the safety regulations under consideration were created to prevent another disaster like Deepwater Horizon in 2010. Rolling back basic safety regulations is a huge step in the wrong direction. Our ocean waters support diverse marine life. We can't put our coastal communities at risk of catastrophic damage from an oil spill. Oil spills are deadly, and the damage they cause lasts for generations. 

I ask that these signatures (attached) be entered into the official record and considered as individual comments. Each of the people listed in the attached spreadsheet signed this comment:

Offshore drilling is inherently dangerous, and the safety regulations under consideration were created to prevent another disaster like Deepwater Horizon in 2010.

Getting rid of these rules risks another major spill, which puts the animals that live in our oceans at risk -- everything from hypothermia in seals, to damaging the internal organs of sea otters, to causing reproductive harm in orcas.

Do not overhaul these important safety regulations for offshore drilling.

For your convenience, the petition remains available online at: https://environmental-action.webaction.org/p/dia/action4/common/public/?action_KEY=24334

Should you have any questions about the petition or signature file, please contact me at 202-461-2449 x349 or by email at Sally@environmental-action.org.

Sincerely,

Sally King
Communications Director
Environmental Action
docketTitle: 1014-AA37  Proposed Rule: Oil and Gas and Sulphur Operations on the OCS-Oil and Gas Production Safety Systems-Revisions

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2013-19222
commentText: As a pro-Life taxpayer I am concerned the Office of Personnel Management's (OPM) proposed rule to allow funds authorized by the Federal Employee Health Benefits Program (FEHBP) to subsidize Congressional staff and Members of Congress' healthcare plans offered on the Affordable Care Act's (ACA) state exchanges may contribute federal funding towards plans that include elective abortion. The ACA allows health plans offered on the exchanges to include elective abortion and nothing in the proposed rule would prohibit Members or their staff from receiving federal contributions if they select a benefits package that includes abortion. This is serious departure from the Smith Amendment that prevents Financial Services appropriations from paying for "abortion, or the administrative expenses in connection with any health plan under the Federal employee health benefits program which provides any benefits or coverage for abortions." The proposed rule should comport with federal law and prohibit any OPM contribution to health plans that include abortion coverage.
docketTitle: Federal Employees Health Benefits Program: Members of Congress and Congressional Staff

title: Mass Comment Campaign submitted by Earthjustice (48,998 web)
commentText:
Attached is the file containing the names of 48,998 individuals who have submitted public comments urging the Environmental Protection Agency to withdraw the proposed decision to re-register the insecticide sulfoxaflor. In addition to signing on in support of the following letter, 11,632 individuals of the total number have submitted personalized comments. The personalized comments start on page 2 and end on page 614.

Withdraw your proposed decision to re-register the insecticide sulfoxaflor (Docket ID: EPA-HQ-OPP-2010-0889-0407)

Dear Administrator McCarthy,

I am writing to urge the EPA to withdraw its proposed decision to re-register sulfoxaflor for use on a variety of different crops. 

Bees are facing many challenges, and pesticide exposure is at the top of the list. A mounting body of scientific evidence points to widespread use of systemic insecticides--including sulfoxaflor and similar neonicotinoids--as a key factor in bee declines. 
A meta-analysis of 800 peer-reviewed studies, released by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature's Task Force on Systemic Pesticides--an international group of independent scientists--is calling for action to restrict the use of systemic insecticides, finding no doubt that they are contributing to colony collapse.

Systemic insecticides like sulfoxaflor can easily kill bees outright, but even at sublethal doses they can impair bees' brain functions and suppress their immune systems--making them more susceptible to diseases, pests and other stressors.

This problem is urgent. Beekeepers report continuing unsustainable losses, and many have gone out of business. This winter we saw a record 44 percent loss in beehives.

I urge the EPA to listen to the growing body of science that tells us we need to restrict this class of pesticides. Neonicotinoids like sulfoxaflor are a key part of the problem and need to be tackled head-on. EPA should not re-register sulfoxaflor in the absence of scientific evidence that there will be no impacts to bees.

The Undersigned
docketTitle: Sulfoxaflor; New Active Ingredient

title: Mass Comment  Campaigns submitted by Andy Kelley, California League of Conservation Voters (10,274  web)
commentText:
Dear EPA Administrator Gina McCarthy,

I'm writing today on behalf of 9,927 members of the California League of Conservation Voters who urge you to withdraw your proposed decision to re-register the insecticide sulfoxaflor (Docket ID: EPA-HQ-OPP-2010-0889-0407).

For your review I have included letters from 2,304 of our members who wrote you with their individual comments, as well as a listing of our members who have co-signed our public comment below.

We urge you to take action to protect the bees by keeping sulfoxaflor and other bee killing pesticides off the market.

Sincerely,

Andy Kelley on behalf of the California League of Conservation Voters

----

Dear EPA Administrator Gina McCarthy

In order to protect bee populations and our nation's food supply, urge the EPA to withdraw its proposed decision to re-register the insecticide "sulfoxaflor" for use on a variety of different crops.

Bee populations are declining throughout the country. Increasingly, scientific evidence points to use of insecticides--including sulfoxaflor and other neonicotinoids--as a major factor in colony collapse. This problem becomes more urgent every day.

Beekeepers report unsustainable losses, and many have gone out of business. Last year, for instance, California beekeepers lost nearly 40 percent of their hives, a rate that was twice the national average.

Systemic insecticides like sulfoxaflor can easily kill bees outright, but even at sublethal doses they can impair bees' brain functions and suppress their immune systems--making them more susceptible to diseases, pests and other stressors.

I urge the EPA to listen to the growing body of scientific evidence that we must restrict this class of pesticides. Neonicotinoids like sulfoxaflor pose a major threat to our bees, and to California's agricultural ecosystem and economy. EPA should not re-register sulfoxaflor in the absence of scientific evidence that there will be no impacts to bees.

Sincerely,

9,927 members of the California League of Conservation Voters

Complete listing of names, addresses, and individual comments are attached to this message.
docketTitle: Sulfoxaflor; New Active Ingredient

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2014-04100
commentText:
Attached please find 4,420 individual comments from Food & Water Watch Supporters encouraging the following for the "Local School Wellness Policy Implementation" proposed rule:

Because children spend many hours at school, it is critical that
schools adopt policies that support healthy eating and physical
activity. I strongly support the following in the rule:

- All local school wellness policies should address nutrition
guidelines for all foods and beverages available during the school day,
and should only permit marketing of foods and beverages that meet
USDA's "Smart Snacks" standards.

- There should be at least one school official who serves as the
designated contact for the wellness policy and who has authority and
responsibility to ensure that each school complies with the policy.

- A diverse team of stakeholders, including parents, school officials,
students, community members, etc., should be involved in developing and
implementing the local wellness policy. In addition, the policy and
assessment of implementation should be made publicly available.

- Regular assessments of the local wellness policy, as well as annual
reports to demonstrate schools' progress toward meeting wellness policy
goals, are essential for ensuring that each school complies with the
policy.

Thank you for proposing these much-needed updates to strengthen
nutrition and physical activity in schools. I urge you to quickly
finalize the rule, and work with schools to ensure full implementation.
docketTitle: Local School Wellness Policy Implementation under the Healthy, Hunger-Free Kids Act of 2010

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2016-21359
commentText:
Susan B. Moskosky
Office of Population Affairs
Department of Health and Human Services 
200 Independence Avenue SW., Suite 716G 
Washington, DC 20201
                        
RE: (RIN) 937-AA04, Compliance with Title X Requirements

Dear Ms. Jackson,

Attached please find 52,424 individual public comments collected online by CREDO Action for submission to the comment period on Title X Requirements. Individual comments may differ throughout, although the majority read as follows: 

"I support President Obama's new rule that would prevent states from withholding Title X federal family-planning money for reasons other than a provider's ability to deliver services effectively. Adopting the new rule would stop Republican extremists from using politics to deny trusted health care providers like Planned Parenthood Title X funding. Please bring an end to state-level attacks on women's health. Ensure that all women and all families have unfettered access to high-quality comprehensive reproductive health care."

Comments have been separated into 14 separate PDFs to accommodate the delivery. 

Please contact me if you have any questions about the attached comment submissions. Thank you.

Sincerely, 

Nicole Regalado
Campaign Manager, CREDO Action 
nregalado@credoaction.com 
415-369-2000

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
Pangolins are the most-trafficked mammal, possibly the most-trafficked animal, on the planet. An estimated 100,000 pangolins are killed every year, an unsustainable number that warrants an "endangered" status for each species. Pangolins are clearly threatened by Factors A, B, D, and E as set forth by section 4(a) of the Endangered Species Act. Illicit trade and habitat destruction have spread globally and now impact every species of pangolin. Unfortunately, current measures have not been enough to stem the tide of pangolin deaths. 

The attached document includes public comments from 21,295 individuals who are calling on the United States to issue the strongest protections possible for Chinese pangolins under the Endangered Species Act, the Lacey Act, and the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species.
docketTitle: Two Petitions to List the Chinese Pangolin under the Endangered Species Act

title: Form Letter Comment from Friends of the Earth [multiple signatures=32192]
commentText:
The undersigned 32,192 people urge the Food and Drug Administration to reject Oxitec's application to release genetically engineered mosquitoes in the U.S. This experiment would risk our environment, our health and Florida's local economy, which depends on tourism. 

While limiting mosquito populations and the spread of dengue fever and Zika virus is important, this experiment is risky for our environment and public health and is fraught with many unanswered questions. The "new animal drug" law is inappropriate for the review of novel risks and impacts of GMO mosquitoes and other new applications of genetic engineering. 

We request that the FDA reject Oxitec's application for genetically engineered mosquitoes and: 
 Complete a full environmental impact statement on Oxitec's GMO mosquito release proposal. 
 Have a committee of independent ecologists and entomologists, public health experts (including dengue fever and Zika virus specialists), and other key experts and public stakeholders review the proposal from Oxitec.
 Convene a public meeting in the Florida Keys, advertised in the Federal Register, for the review of the company's proposal with the above committee present.

Our government agencies must not rely only on data from the companies that would profit from genetically engineered organisms to decide what information the public and regulators should know. Until the above requests have been met, the application for the field release of genetically engineered mosquitoes must not be allowed to move forward.
docketTitle: Draft Environmental Assessment and Preliminary Finding of No Significant Impact Concerning Investigational Use of Oxitec OX513A Mosquitoes; Availability

title: Form Letter Comment from Food & Water Watch [multiple signatures=17358]
commentText:
Please find attached a petition, signed by 17,358 Food & Water Watch supporters, urging the FDA to reject Oxitec's
application to release genetically engineered mosquitoes in the U.S.

The petition states:

Dear Commissioner Califf,

I urge the Food and Drug Administration to reject Oxitec's application to release genetically engineered mosquitoes in the U.S. (FDA-2014-N-2235).

This experiment is being proposed without the consent of the local community, and potential risks to the environment, public health and Florida's tourism-dependent economy have not been fully assessed. While limiting mosquito populations and the spread of dengue fever is important, this proposal is riddled with too many unanswered questions to proceed. The federal government does not have an appropriate policy to evaluate this new technology. By relying on the animal drug process, the FDA's assessment of possible novel risks from this experimental release is full of holes. I urge the FDA to:

--Complete a full environmental impact statement on Oxitec's  GMO mosquito proposal.

--Convene a committee of independent ecologists and entomologists, public health experts (including dengue fever specialists), and other key experts and stakeholders to review the proposal.

--Convene a public meeting in the community where the field trial is proposed. 

Until the above requests have been met, the application for the field release of genetically engineered mosquitoes must not be allowed to move forward.
docketTitle: Draft Environmental Assessment and Preliminary Finding of No Significant Impact Concerning Investigational Use of Oxitec OX513A Mosquitoes; Availability

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC) (web)
commentText: Please accept these public comments from 43,698 online members and activists on behalf on the Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC) regarding EPA-HQ-OAR-2012-0788 in support of a strong uranium mining rule. A strong rule would protect groundwater in scarce western aquifers from contamination caused by in-situ leach uranium mining. It is vital to protect the lives and health of communities across the West and for these reasons we urge you to strengthen and finalize this the "re-purposed" uranium mining rule. Thank you.
docketTitle: Health and Environmental Protection Standards for Uranium and Thorium Mill Tailings (40 CFR Part 192)

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
The attached file contains the names of 20,290 individuals who have submitted public comments urging the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to list the Pacific fisher as threatened under the Endangered Species Act. In addition to signing on in support of the following letter, 506 individuals of the total number have submitted personalized comments. The personalized comments start on page 2 and end on page 46.

Please list the Distinct Population Segment of fisher under the Endangered Species Act 
(RE: Docket ID FWS-R8-ES-2014-0041)

Dear Fish and Wildlife Service,

I urge you to list the Pacific fisher West Coast population as threatened under the Endangered Species Act.

As you know, fishers have declined dramatically in recent decades due to trapping, logging, and fire. Climate change is amplifying these risks.

Recently, super-toxic rat poisons have shown up as a new threat to fishers. Eighty-five percent of fishers studied from 2012 to 2014 had rodent poisons in their blood. Thirteen fishers were found poisoned to death in California during that time.

U.S. Forest Service researchers have concluded that the southern Sierra fisher population, which is critical to the survival of the entire species, "may face imminent extinction" in the absence of increased protection.

The fact is that there are probably fewer than 150 adult female fishers left in the entire Sierra Nevada. If ever an animal was in desperate need of protection, the fisher is it.

Listing the species as threatened will help preserve the habitat needed for the fisher to make a comeback.

Thank you for your consideration,
The Undersigned
docketTitle: Threatened Species Status for West Coast Distinct Population Segment of Fisher

docketTitle: Listing  the Big Sandy and Guyandotte River crayfishes as Threatened or Endangered

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
To Whom It May Concern:

We are submitting 19,572 public comments regarding the proposed rule on behalf of citizens across the country who are deeply concerned about the risks posed by mine waste and pollution on the habitats of the Big Sandy and Guyandotte River Crayfish.

On behalf of Americans who are concerned about public safety and the environment, I urge you to include each of the enclosed public comments in the official record.

See comments in the attached 40 files.
docketTitle: Listing  the Big Sandy and Guyandotte River crayfishes as Threatened or Endangered

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
Please find the attached 13,567 comments in support of protecting the Big Sandy Crayfish and the Guyandotte River Crayfish under the Endangered Species Act and the designation of critical habitat to ensure that these species survive for future generations. 
These two crayfishes need immediate protection to have a chance at long term survival. They face big threats and have long been in need of protection. The Big Sandy crayfish was first identified as being in need of federal protection in 1991. The Guyandotte River crayfish was just discovered and is already in danger of extinction. In addition to pollution from coal mining, the crayfish are threatened by interstate highway construction, oil and gas development, logging and sprawl. 
Please immediately protect both species under the Endangered Species Act with critical habitat. Protecting the clean water the crayfish need to survive will also benefit human communities in Appalachia where public health is threatened by coal mining pollution.
docketTitle: Listing  the Big Sandy and Guyandotte River crayfishes as Threatened or Endangered

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Clean Water Action (web)
commentText:
Dear Administrator Pruitt,

I am submitting 1807 comment from Clean Water Action members opposed to any attempts by EPA to repeal or weaken the federal coal ash protections adopted in 2015. This is in addition to more than 1700 comments that have submitted directly to the docket. 

For decades too many communities across the country have been exposed to this toxic pollution, and it is unacceptable for your agency to again put them at risk.

EPA must continue to require monitoring of groundwater near coal ash sites, closure of leaking ponds and unstable landfills, clean-up of contaminated sites, public posting of utility monitoring and inspection results, and all of the minimum safeguards required by the 2015 rule. 

EPAs job is to protect public health and the environment, not to give coal utilities a free pass to poison people with their toxic waste. Please withdraw this reckless proposal.

Sincerely, 

Jennifer Peters
National Water Programs Director
Clean Water Action
docketTitle: Hazardous and Solid Waste Management System: Disposal of Coal Combustion Residues From Electric Utilities; Remand Rule
