docketTitle: National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants for Utility Air Toxics; Clean Air Mercury Rule (CAMR)

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsoring organization unknown (1,226)
commentText:
Melissa Drapeau <no-reply@democracyinaction.org> 
12/15/2004 08:54 AM
Please respond to
Eldandmsd@hotmail.com
	To
Group A-AND-R-DOCKET@EPA
cc

bcc

Subject
Attention Docket ID No. OAR-2002-0056
	




Dear Administrator Leavitt:

EPA is long overdue in controlling toxic air pollution from coal- and 
oil-fired power plants.  In 2003, forty-five states had issued advisories 
to warn against eating mercury-contaminated fish from local waters.  
Mercury and other air toxics from power plants put fetuses and children at 
risk for serious and permanent health impacts.  In healthy adults, mercury 
and other air toxics can adversely affect fertility and blood pressure 
regulation and contribute to heart-rate variability and heart disease.  
Coal-fired power plants are the largest uncontrolled source of mercury, 
acid gases, arsenic, and chromium air pollution; and they are the second 
largest source of lead and dioxin air pollution.

Your agency is promoting a weak plan that addresses only mercury.  This 
plan would delay and weaken reductions of mercury required in the Clean 
Air Act, and completely ignores more than 60 other power plant air toxics 
that threaten our health. We need a rule finalized as quickly as possible 
that requires maximum reductions in all air toxics from every applicable 
power plant unit within the shortest possible timeframe.

The EPA's docket of over 680,000 public comments from earlier this year 
proves that Americans want the highest standard of protection from toxic 
power plant emissions as soon as possible. Your agency promised to do the 
necessary analysis to "get it right" on mercury - analysis that would show 
how fast and how quickly mercury reductions could be made with new 
technology and stricter controls.  Instead, the Agency has reneged on its 
promises to analyze more stringent regulations and continues to promote an 
illegal pollution trading program for emissions of mercury.

I urge you not to ignore the law, which requires a stronger plan for 
faster reductions - in order to protect the health of the American people 
and future generations of children

Sincerely,
Melissa Drapeau
2881 Sw 147 st

Ocala, FL 34473

title: Comment from Lora Snyder
commentText:
On behalf of Oceana and 33,807 Oceana members, please see the attached petition regarding the proposed shrimp trawling requirements for sea turtle conservation to reduce the incidental bycatch and mortality of sea turtles in the Southeastern U.S. shrimp fisheries.  We are in favor of the proposed narrow-spaced TED requirement for skimmer, pusher-head, and wing net trawls as it will yield benefits for the environment, commercial shrimp fishermen, the local tourism industry, and commercial and recreational fishermen targeting other species.

Thank you!
docketTitle: Proposed Rule to Require Mandatory Use of Turtle Excluder Devices (TEDs) in Skimmer Trawls, Pusher-Head Trawls, and Wing Nets (Butterfly Trawls)

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
Dear Daniel Ashe,

18,842 supporters of SierraRise, a Sierra Club community, have signed a petition opposing the proposed reclassification of the West Indian Manatee.

You can find the names of the 18,842 petition signatures in the attached document. The petition text that all signed is as follows:

I'm calling on the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to continue protecting the West Indian Manatee.

The great work we have done in protecting these lumbering gentle giants is clear, as the population has rebounded since the early '90s. But over the last five years more than 3,000 manatees have died in the state of Florida. It's clear the population is still vulnerable. Therefore, we need to take every possible step to ensure the continued survival of these animals.

That's why I'm requesting that you reconsider your plans to reclassify the West Indian Manatee from "endangered" to "threatened." Do not undo the great work we have done so far in protecting these beloved marine mammals.
Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,

The undersigned
docketTitle: Petition to Downlist the West Indian Manatee, and Proposed Rule to Reclassify the West Indian Manatee as Threatened

title: Inversions and Related Transactions (REG-135734-14)
commentText:
To whom it may concern:

Attached, please find comments submitted by 29,845 members and supporters of Americans for Tax Fairness and Daily Kos urging adoption of the proposed rule on Inversions and Related Transactions, also known as the "serial inverter" rule. We are very pleased that the Treasury Department took this action to protect the loss of critical tax dollars by U.S. corporations seeking to shift their legal address offshore, typically to a tax haven. This rulemaking is necessary because the U.S. Congress has failed to act to stem the tide of inversions.

Inversions are one of the more egregious forms of tax dodging. They occur when U.S. multinational corporations purchase a foreign company in order to shift their corporate headquarters on paper to a low-tax (or no-tax) jurisdiction to avoid paying U.S. corporate income taxes. These inversions do not change anything about how the business is conducted or where it is managed - they are simply a way for a corporation to avoid paying its fair share of taxes. Clearly, corporations that desert America should not be rewarded with a tax break.  
 
The serial inverter rule was critical in Pfizer's decision to end its proposed merger with Allergan, a serial inverter. This saved the loss of as much as $35 billion in taxes Pfizer owes on its offshore profits. But the Treasury Department's rule could be even stronger by applying it to all corporations that invert with a foreign firm. That would take away the ability of corporations that invert from doing a "hopscotch loan," which lets them dodge paying U.S. taxes on the billions in offshore profits they have stashed in tax havens.
Respectfully submitted,

Frank Clemente
Executive Director
Americans for Tax Fairness
fclemente@americansfortaxfairness.org

Chris Bowers
Executive Campaign Director
Daily Kos
chris@dailykos.com
docketTitle: Inversions and Related Transactions (REG-135734-14)

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Earthjustice (web)
commentText:
Attached is a file containing the names of 25,751 individuals who have submitted public comments regarding the Environmental Protection Agency's proposed rule concerning the use of Lead Free Pipes, Fittings, Solder and Flux for Drinking Water. In addition to signing on in support of the following letter, 5,212 individuals of the total number have submitted personalized comments. The personalized comments start on page 2 and end on page 365.

Get lead out of our drinking water (RE: EPA-HQ-OW-2015-0680-0001)

Dear Environmental Protection Agency:

We don't want lead in our drinking water pipes, fittings, fixtures, solder and flux. Requiring third-party certification is important to ensure that products meet national leaching standards for lead. The EPA must not remove this requirement from its regulations.

	For years, EPA policy has been to require third-party certification that pipes and fixtures do not leach unsafe amounts of lead.
	Lowering the amount of overall average lead allowed in a pipe or fixture is important, but it cannot replace the leaching standard.
	Even small leaded components can leach considerable amounts of dangerous lead. 
	Different alloys or manufacturing processes can also affect the amount of lead that leaches.
	If you want to keep people safe from lead, the only way to do it is to lower the amount of average lead allowed, as Congress did, and continue to require a third-party leaching test.

When Congress passed the Reduction of Lead in Drinking Water Act, it was trying to protect our health. It defies reason to use this Act as an excuse to weaken lead protections for families in this country. Please continue to require third-party certification that proves products do not leach lead.

Sincerely,

The Undersigned
docketTitle: Use of Lead Free Pipes, Fittings, Fixtures, Solder and Flux for Drinking Water

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
To Whom It May Concern:

Please find attached a Microsoft Excel file (.xlsx format) containing 5,772 comments of Audubon California supporters about the proposed rule to list the western population of Yellow-billed Cuckoo (Coccyzus americanus occidentalis) as threatened under the Endangered Species Act of 1973.
docketTitle: Threatened Status for the Western Distinct Population Segment of the Yellow-billed Cuckoo

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
docketTitle: Threatened Status for the Western Distinct Population Segment of the Yellow-billed Cuckoo

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
Please find attached a Microsoft Excel file (.xlsx format) containing and additional 10,313 comments from National Audubon Society supporters about the proposed rule to list the western population of Yellow-billed Cuckoo (Coccyzus americanus occidentalis) as threatened under the Endangered Species Act of 1973. These comments are in addition to the 5,772 previously submitted.
	
Many people submitted personalized comments, which you will find in a separate tab; others signed on to the comments below: 

====================
I am writing to support the listing of the Western population of Yellow-billed Cuckoo (Coccyzus americanus occidentalis) as "Threatened" under the Endangered Species Act. As the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service analysis shows, this species has suffered a dramatic decline in the West as a result of the loss of its breeding habitat. 

Human interventions and impacts, including dams, water diversions, ground-water pumping, and other development are jeopardizing the continued existence of this species in the Western United States. In the arid West, where these birds were once common, documented breeding habitat loss is over ninety percent in comparison with a half-century ago. 

Extended drought and predicted climate change further jeopardize this species and add to the need for it to be listed as Threatened. 

The remaining strongholds for western Yellow-billed Cuckoo are the iconic wild rivers: the Colorado, Dolores, San Pedro, Gila, Sacramento, Rio Grande and Kern Rivers. Listing will help ensure that these rivers will be protected to conserve and restore this species and the habitats upon which it depends.
====================

If you have any questions about the comments, or prefer to receive them in a different format, please do not hesitate to contact me. I can be reached via e-mail at lpomper@audubon.org or by telephone at (202) 600-7960.

Please accept our thanks for your agency's collaboration in ensuring that the comments of these concerned individuals are considered.
docketTitle: Threatened Status for the Western Distinct Population Segment of the Yellow-billed Cuckoo

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
Please find attached a Microsoft Excel files (.xlsx format) containing 24,698 comments of National Audubon Society supporters about the 90-Day Finding on Petition - Southwestern Willow Flycatcher.
	
Many people submitted personalized comments, which you will find in the first worksheet; others signed on to the comments below: 

========================
I am writing to express my strong opposition to a deeply flawed proposal to remove the Southwestern Willow Flycatcher from protections under the Endangered Species Act. The Southwestern Willow Flycatcher is struggling to survive and should retain its Endangered status.

At the time the bird was listed as endangered in 1995, an expert panel convened by the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service confirmed that the Southwestern Willow Flycatcher is a distinct subspecies worthy of protection, and there is nothing in this latest petition that casts doubt on that determination. One study, put forth by a researcher with financial ties to developers, should not be enough to overturn decades of objective research to the contrary.

The study that the petitioners rely upon has substantial limitations. While it purports to be the final word on DNA evidence, it is far from conclusive on the subject of the Southwestern Willow Flycatcher's status as a subspecies. A peer-reviewed journal article contends that the developers' research misinterprets its own genetic data and downplays significant differences in physical attributes and geological range between different subspecies.

The Southwestern Willow Flycatcher is an essential part of the ecology of California, Nevada, Utah, Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico, and Texas. Please support efforts to protect this bird from extinction and continue to coordinate with all federal agencies to protect vital water resources and rivers providing habitat these birds depend on.

Thank you for your strong history of standing up to these types of efforts to use questionable science to remove species from the protections afforded by the Endangered Species Act. Please stay strong and reject the current petition to remove the Southwestern Willow Flycatcher's Endangered status.
========================

If you have any questions about the comments, or prefer to receive them in a different format, please do not hesitate to contact me.

Please accept our thanks for your agency's collaboration in ensuring that the comments of these concerned individuals are considered.
docketTitle: Petition to Delist Southwestern willow flycatcher

title: Form Letter Comment from American Association for Justice (AAJ) [multiple signatures=23485]
commentText:
The attached document contains the petition signatures of 23,485 individuals who support the finalization of FDA's rule. The petition these individuals have signed reads as follows:

LETTER TO: U.S. Food and Drug Administration

We believe it is critically important that all prescription medicines, including generic drugs, carry current and accurate safety warnings. Both brand name and generic manufacturers should be accountable for the safety of their products.

We applaud the FDA for your proposal to fix the generic drug safety loophole, but we are concerned that the rule has been delayed. We urge you to finalize the generic drug labeling proposal as promptly as possible. Safety is an issue that cannot wait.
docketTitle: Supplemental Applications Proposing Labeling Changes for Approved Drugs and Biological Products

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
Subject: Establish Loggerhead Critical Habitat - Docket No. FWS-R4-ES- 2012-0103 

Dear U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, 

I'm writing to share my support for the immediate designation of critical habitat on U.S. nesting beaches that are important to threatened loggerhead sea turtles as required under the Endangered Species Act. I support permanent the critical habitat protections proposed for 739 miles of coastline that cover 84 percent of nesting areas from North Carolina to Florida to Mississippi. 

In addition, I urge you to extend the critical habitat designation to all key Florida nesting beaches. Please do not exclude the three Florida counties covered by voluntary Habitat Conservation Plans (HCPs) as proposed by USFWS. These plans expire over time and are vulnerable to cut-backs and political agendas. Loggerheads live for decades so they need permanent habitat protections over hundreds of years. Critical Habitat under the ESA is long term and essentially permanent. I support the detailed comments by Turtle Island Restoration Network and its ocean partners on this topic. 

Lastly, I urge the USFWS to consider adding more nesting beaches, upland areas and unoccupied habitat to the proposed designation to provide loggerheads access to alternative nesting areas as populations increase and climate change triggers the rise of sea levels and sand temperatures that reduce current habitat. 

Thank you for your consideration and action as you finalize this important critical habitat proposal for the Northwest Atlantic population of loggerhead sea turtles. 

Signed, PLEASE SEE ATTACHED SIGNATURES
docketTitle: Designation of Critical Habitat for the Northwest Atlantic Ocean Distinct Population Segment of the Loggerhead Sea Turtle

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
Dear U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service,

Thank you for the opportunity to share the individual comment letters from thousands of individuals in support of immediate designation of critical habitat on U.S. nesting beaches that are important to threatened loggerhead sea turtles as required under the Endangered Species Act. I support permanent the critical habitat protections proposed for 739 miles of coastline that cover 84 percent of nesting areas from North Carolina to Florida to Mississippi.

In addition, I urge you to extend the critical habitat designation to all key Florida nesting beaches. Please do  not exclude the three Florida counties covered by voluntary Habitat Conservation Plans (HCPs) as proposed by USFWS. These plans expire over time and are vulnerable to cut-backs and political agendas. Loggerheads live for decades so they need permanent habitat protections over hundreds of years. Critical Habitat under the ESA is long term and essentially permanent. I support the detailed comments by Turtle Island Restoration Network and its ocean partners on this topic.

Lastly, I urge the USFWS to consider adding more nesting beaches, upland areas and unoccupied habitat to the proposed designation to provide loggerheads access to alternative nesting areas as populations increase and climate change triggers the rise of sea levels and sand temperatures that reduce current habitat.

Thank you for your consideration and action as you finalize this important critical habitat proposal for the Northwest Atlantic population of loggerhead sea turtles.

Sincerely

Chris Pincetich
docketTitle: Designation of Critical Habitat for the Northwest Atlantic Ocean Distinct Population Segment of the Loggerhead Sea Turtle

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Earthworks (web)
commentText:
Attached are 6,231 comments in support of strong regulations submitted via TakePart.com in collaboration with Earthworks.

Also attached is an excel spreadsheet with a list of the same commenters without their letters. All letters have the following message: 

To: EPA

I urge the Environmental Protection Agency to issue strong rules to curb methane and other harmful air pollution from oil and gas development (EPA-HQ-OAR-2010-0505 and EPA-HQ-OAR-2013-0685). While no amount of regulation can make fracked gas a clean energy source, I support efforts to capture methane, repair leaks, and aggregate disparate sources of methane and other air pollution along the oil and gas supply chain. These important pollution controls will not only help stave off catastrophic climate change but also protect communities from harm imposed by the oil and gas industry.

I urge you to improve the proposed rules to include

Several key pieces of equipment that were omitted from the proposal that emit methane and harmful VOCs.
Storage vessels that were covered under the VOC standards but are not included in the methane proposal.
Liquids-unloading operations.
Pneumatic controllers that operate on an intermittent or snap-acting basis.
Compressors at well sites.
Mandatory inspections at least quarterly or monthly (rather than a default semiannual requirement), which should remain at a fixed frequency rather than decreasing on low-leak-rate detection.
Shortening the time source operators have to repair leaking equipment if it would be unsafe to make the repair within 15 days of discovery.
Defining "sources" to include functionally interrelated equipment so regulators can aggregate individual emissions sources to prevent significant deterioration of our air quality.
Including communities in the pollution-detection process. A citizen complaint system is needed to allow communities living near fracked gas infrastructure to alert the EPA if they detect odors or air pollution events nearby.
Requiring oil and gas companies to use or bring to market captured gas, rather than flare it, unless extraordinary circumstances make flaring unavoidable.

In addition to these important changes to strengthen the proposals, I urge the EPA to regulate existing sources of methane pollution under section 111(d) of the Clean Air Act. Voluntary standards are insufficient to cut harmful, climate-disrupting methane pollution from oil and gas operations, and they will not adequately protect affected communities. To safeguard communities living with the burden of existing oil and gas infrastructure and to meet President Obama's Climate Action Plan goal of reducing oil and gas sector methane emissions 40 to 45 percent below 2012 levels by 2025, the EPA must move quickly to create rules for existing oil and gas facilities upstream, midstream, and downstream.

I support the EPA's proposals as a means to begin to address the climate crisis exacerbated by the fracking boom and reduce harm to communities living with the burden of the oil and gas industry. I urge the EPA to make the changes needed to ensure that these rules are sufficiently strong to protect public health and tackle climate change. Regulating existing sources of air pollution, coupled with an immediate shift to an economy that depends on clean, renewable energynot fossil fuelsare steps that must be followed to avoid the most devastating effects of catastrophic climate change.
docketTitle: PSD and NSR  Major Source Determination for Oil and Gas Extraction Facilities

title: write-in campaign
commentText:
The Sierra Club initiated a write-in campaign in support of the Sanctuary Nomination 
Process that generated comments from 17,746 individuals.  Of that total, approximately 
7,300 were identical to one base comment, and another approximately 10,400 comments 
were identical to a second base comment.  

In addition to the base comments, NOAA analyzed the data set to extract the following 
512 unique comments that were submitted as part of the two general comments, and 
about 40 comments that were entirely unique and not based on the write in form letter.  

These will be considered for the final rule.

---------------------------------------

General Comment #1 Received  Approximately 7,300 duplicates or identical to the 
following:
I strongly support the re-establishment of the nomination process for new National 
Marine Sanctuaries. This process is an important first step toward filling a gap in 
protection for California's coastal waters.  As a Californian, I value clean beaches, clean 
water, and healthy fish and wildlife. We need to take steps now to protect our ocean for 
future generations. Drilling and fracking do not belong in our coastal waters.  After 13 
years with no new National Marine Sanctuary designations, it is clear that we must re-
establish the public process for nominating new sanctuaries. I am confident that the 
proposed grassroots process will lead to expanded protections for marine habitat and 
wildlife off the coast of California. 

General Comment #2 Received  Approximately 10,400 duplicates or identical to the 
following:
I strongly support the re-establishment of the nomination process for new National 
Marine Sanctuaries. This process is an important first step toward filling a gap in 
protection for many of our coastal waters.  I value clean beaches, clean water, and 
healthy fish and wildlife. We need to take steps now to protect our ocean for future 
generations.  After 13 years with no new National Marine Sanctuary designations, it is 
clear that we must re-establish the public process for nominating new sanctuaries. I 
support the overall criteria proposed by NOAA for evaluation potential nominations.  
However, I am concerned about how restrictions on oil and gas drilling will be considered 
within criteria 8 of the proposed regulation. Offshore oil and gas drilling is incompatible 
with the National Marine Sanctuary Program's mission to protect our most precious 
marine ecosystems. Protecting natural resources must be prioritized over potential future 
oil and gas drilling.
docketTitle: Re-establishing the Sanctuary Nomination Process

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
Please find attached a Microsoft Excel file (.xlsx format) containing 16,524 comments of National Audubon Society supporters about the proposed rule to list the rufa Red Knot (Calidris canutus rufa) as threatened under the Endangered Species Act of 1973. These comments are in addition to the 17,066 that were submitted during the Fall 2013 comment period. We ask that you withhold the personal addresses of our supporters from the public record. 

Many people submitted personalized comments, which you will find in a separate tab; others signed on to the comments below: 

------------------------------------------------------------
I am writing in support of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's proposed listing of the rufa Red Knot as threatened under the Endangered Species Act. Rufa Red Knots, which migrate over 9,000 miles along the Atlantic coast from the Canadian Arctic to southern Argentina, have declined by about 75 percent since the 1980s from over 100,000 to about 25,000 today. These declines, and the broad threats that it faces across its range, make it vulnerable to extinction in the foreseeable future and an appropriate candidate for listing under the ESA.

Overfishing of horseshoe crab eggs in Delaware Bay has been the primary cause of the knot's decline, as birds that cannot fatten up for the last leg of their journey to their Arctic breeding grounds don't survive the trip or arrive in such poor condition that they cannot nest successfully. However, coastal development and engineering projects, as well as chronic disturbance, at migratory stopover sites throughout the U.S. have also depleted feeding and resting habitat for migrating Red Knots. In addition, climate change has been identified as affecting conditions in the Arctic and elsewhere, mismatching the timing of food availability for migrating and breeding knots.

The threats to the rufa Red Knot and its incredible journey are so large and systemic that state and local action, such as New Jersey's moratorium on horseshoe crab fishing in its portion of Delaware Bay, are insufficient to meet the challenges of conserving Red Knots for future generations. Federal listing will provide additional protections, research, and management needed to halt current precipitous declines and recover Red Knot populations. That is why I support the proposed listing of the rufa Red Knot.
------------------------------------------------------------

If you have any questions about the comments, or prefer to receive them in a different format, please do not hesitate to contact me. I can be reached via e-mail at lpomper@audubon.org or by telephone at (202) 600-7960.

Please accept our thanks for your agency's collaboration in ensuring that the comments of these concerned individuals are considered.
docketTitle: Threatened Status for the Rufa Red Knot

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
Dear U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, 


An additional 1,940 supporters of the Sierra Club have signed a petition urgently asking the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to take action to protect the Kentucky arrow darter and it's diminishing habitat. 
 
You can find the names of the 1,940 petition signatures attached. The petition text that all 15,389 supports signed (see previous submission) is as follows:

Attn: FWS-R4-ES-2015-0132-0001 Kentucky Arrow Darter listing

I am writing in support of Endangered Species Act protection for the Kentucky arrow darter. This unique species, found nowhere else on earth, has already disappeared from nearly half of its historical range -- 36 of 74 streams -- and surviving populations are at high risk. 44 percent of this loss has occurred only since the mid-1990s. 

The darter is threatened by habitat loss from many activities including coal mining, logging, land development, and oil and gas development. It is also vulnerable to global climate change. The best available information clearly shows that the darter warrants federal protection. 

Protecting the streams that the darter needs to survive will also protect other species and people in its watersheds. Please promptly finalize protection for the Kentucky arrow darter and for its critical habitat. 

The darter makes up a special part of the natural heritage of eastern Kentucky, and I urge you to safeguard it for future generations.

Sincerely, 

The  undersigned 
See attached file(s)
docketTitle: Threatened Species Status for Kentucky Arrow Darter

title: Submitted Electronically via eRulemaking Portal
commentText:
Dear U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, 

13,448 supporters of the Sierra Club have signed a petition urgently asking the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to take action to protect the Kentucky arrow darter and it's diminishing habitat. 
 
The arrow darter was once found in 74 streams, but today it's only in 38. Nearly half of that loss happened in the last twenty years -- since mountaintop removal mining picked up and polluted the water with metals and other contaminants. 

It's clear that urgent action is needed to protect the Kentucky arrow darter, you have a chance to make a dramatic difference in the continuation of this species while protecting other nearby animals and communities. 
 
You can find the names of the 13,448  petition signatures attached as well a second spreadsheet containing the edited petition text that 453 of the most passionate supporters submitted. The petition text that all 13,448 signed is as follows:

Attn: FWS-R4-ES-2015-0132-0001 Kentucky Arrow Darter listing

I am writing in support of Endangered Species Act protection for the Kentucky arrow darter. This unique species, found nowhere else on earth, has already disappeared from nearly half of its historical range -- 36 of 74 streams -- and surviving populations are at high risk. 44 percent of this loss has occurred only since the mid-1990s. 

The darter is threatened by habitat loss from many activities including coal mining, logging, land development, and oil and gas development. It is also vulnerable to global climate change. The best available information clearly shows that the darter warrants federal protection. 

Protecting the streams that the darter needs to survive will also protect other species and people in its watersheds. Please promptly finalize protection for the Kentucky arrow darter and for its critical habitat. 

The darter makes up a special part of the natural heritage of eastern Kentucky, and I urge you to safeguard it for future generations.

Sincerely, 

The 13,448 undersigned 
(attached)

title: Mass mail campaign entitled, "The Environmental Protection Agency should stop its misguided and illegal effort to exempt factory farms from reporting their toxic air releases." sponsored by the Sierra Club (2,040)
commentText:
Linda Judd <juddjl@yahoo.com> 
Sent by: Sierra Club Membership Services 
<membership.services@sierraclub.org>
02/11/2008 07:27 PM
Please respond to
Linda Judd <juddjl@yahoo.com>	To
	Docket Superfund@EPA
	cc
	
	bcc
	
	Subject
	EPA Docket ID No. EPA-HQ-SFUND-2007-0469
	
	



Feb 11, 2008

Mr. Stephen Johnson

Dear Mr. Johnson,

The Environmental Protection Agency should stop its misguided and
illegal effort to exempt factory farms from reporting their toxic air
releases. Some large factory farms release millions of pounds of toxic
chemicals, such as ammonia and hydrogen sulfide, which are formed as
animal manure degrades.  Why should the EPA create a special-interest
exemption for factory farms when they release the exact same chemicals
as manufacturing facilities that are required to report releases?
Congress intended for the public to have the right to know about large
releases of toxic chemicals, and this proposed regulation directly
contradicts the intent of Congress.  I urge you not to exempt factory
farms from the requirement to report toxic air releases.
Collecting information on toxic chemical releases from factory farms
is critical.  A number of studies, including one by Iowa State

University and the University of Iowa in 2002, have found a variety of

health problems among factory farm workers and residents who live near
these operations, including bronchitis, asthma and

antibiotic-resistant bacterial infections.  People who live near these

facilities should have the right to know what hazardous chemicals they
are being exposed to. The EPA should not exempt factory farms from
these important laws.

Sincerely,

Ms Linda Judd
156 Sylvan Rd
Walnut Creek, CA 94596-6036



This is a mass email campaign. The comments received under this campaign are similar in content and format. A sample PDF has been provided for review. To date, a total of 2,040 idential comments have been received.

docketTitle: CERCLA 108(b) Financial Responsibility Requirements for Facilities in the Hard Rock Mining Industry; Proposed Rule

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Earthworks (web)
commentText:
Earthworks members are submitting 9,349 comments with the following message or similar (attached):

Dear EPA Administrator, 

I am writing today to urge the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to complete rigorous financial assurance regulations as required under CERCLA 108(b) to protect taxpayers from the clean-up costs associated with metal mines and to ensure timely clean-up to protect communities from the hazardous materials associated with these mines. 

Strong financial assurance regulations are needed to protect the American taxpayer from the burden of clean-up costs associated with mining industry - the nation's leading source of toxic pollution.  With an estimated backlog of $20-54 billion for clean-up of hardrock mines, American taxpayers are already unfairly faced with an enormous financial burden. For example:

	In Montana, taxpayers have already spent roughly $26 million to treat toxic acid mine drainage at the Zortman Landusky Mine.
	In South Dakota, $100 million has been spent at the Gilt Edge Mine and another $89 million is needed. 
	In Nevada, the Yerington Mine will cost taxpayers more than $30 million just to address the most immediate public health and safety threats. 
	In Oregon, acid mine drainage at the Formosa Mine has caused extensive, unfunded,  damage to water resources.
	In Colorado, the Summitville mine left taxpayers to fund more than $100 million in cleanup costs. 

The EPA estimates that based on current funding levels, ($100-150 million per year), no more than 8-20% of all cleanup work could be completed within 30 years. These rules are necessary to shift the financial responsibility for remediation to the industry, not the taxpayer, and to ensure timely clean-up. 

I strongly support the EPA's preferred option (Option 1) that precludes the use of corporate guarantees, or mere promises, as an instrument for financial assurance.  Corporate or "self" guarantees are no guarantee at all because they are not backed by real assets, cash or cash equivalents.  It conflicts with the purpose of the rule-making because it places the financial risk primarily on the American taxpayer, rather than the polluter. 

These rules are essential because the hazardous releases covered by the CERCLA 108(b) program, such as hazardous spills, natural resource damages and public health assessment, are not covered by other state and federal state land management regulatory programs. 

Any reductions to the financial assurance calculations must only be applied for engineering controls that are installed and demonstrated to be working to reduce the scope and severity of hazardous releases; not mere plans. 

Program deferrals should not be authorized because the risks and liabilities under CERCLA 108(b) differ from those of state and other federal land management agencies. The EPA cannot ensure compliance with the statute if the program is deferred.  

These rules follow a simple and fair principle: If you make a mess; you clean it up.
docketTitle: CERCLA 108(b) Financial Responsibility Requirements for Facilities in the Hard Rock Mining Industry; Proposed Rule

title: Mass comment  Campaign Sponsored by Center for Food Safety  (10,718 Signatures)
commentText:
Please find attached comments signed by 10,718 Center for Food Safety members and supporters opposing the approval of dicamba use on genetically engineered, dicamba-resistant cotton and soybeans (Docket No. EPA-HQ-OPP-2016-0187). 

Monsanto's genetically engineered Roundup Ready crops are planted on over 150 million acres nationwide. They have triggered a huge increase in the use of glyphosate (Roundup) herbicide, and an epidemic of glyphosate-resistant "superweeds." Now, in a misguided effort to fix the weed resistance problem created by its Roundup Ready crops, Monsanto has genetically engineered soybeans and cotton to be resistant to more toxic herbicides like dicamba. 

If EPA approves this new use, millions more pounds of dicamba will be sprayed together with continuing heavy use of glyphosate. EPA's proposed approval would significantly increase use of dicamba, creating the risk of weed resistance.
Dicamba is an older herbicide that studies have linked to higher risk of cancers like non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, as well as developmental toxicity; other tests indicate the potential for neurological impacts. Dicamba is soluble in water and moderately persistent, and so carries a large surface water and groundwater contamination risk. Dicamba is also volatile and can drift for miles. Dicamba drift has caused millions of dollars in damages to growers who have suffered crop losses due to herbicide drift onto their farms. The proposed approval would also damage and harm other crops and species, including threatened and endangered species, because dicamba is drift-prone and volatile.

Inevitably, increased use of dicamba will generate new "superweeds" resistant to multiple herbicides, and the chemical arms race with weeds will continue. This means more pesticide pollution, more disease and environmental damage, and of course, increasing profits for firms like Monsanto that sell both dicamba-resistant seeds and the herbicides used with them. 

At a time when farmers, citizens, and government have worked hard to limit our use of, and exposure to, hazardous pesticides like dicamba, approving new use of dicamba for Monsanto's dicamba resistant cotton and soybeans would take us backwards, seriously endangering human health and the environment.
docketTitle: Dicamba: New Use on Herbicide-Tolerant Cotton and Soybean

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by CREDO Action from Working Assets (7,926)
commentText:
To Whom it May Concern:

I'm writing regarding docket number EPA-HQ-OAR-2011-0081. On behalf of 7,926 Pennsylvania and New Jersey residents, we urge you to significantly reduce sulfur dioxide emissions from the Portland Generating Station.

The submissions were collected by CREDO Action, and though they vary throughout, the messages within can be summed up as follows: 

"Thank you for proposing a plan to reduce Sulfur Dioxide emissions from the Portland Generating Station.

The Sulfur Dioxide emissions from burning coal have for too long damaged the health and air of both New Jersey and Pennsylvania residents.

New Jersey has implemented strong reductions in Sulfur Dioxide, yet the EPA's plan for the Portland Generating Station falls short of these targets.

Please meet the emissions reductions targets requested by the State of New Jersey, and implement the strongest possible plan to make GenOn clean up its dangerous Sulfur Dioxide pollution that puts the health of both New Jersey and Pennsylvania residents at risk."

If you have any questions about these comments, please dont hesitate to contact me at jnelson@credomobile.com.

Thank you for your time.

Josh Nelson, Campaign Manager
CREDO Action from Working Assets

title: Comment on FR Doc # E8-14911
commentText:
The Center for Food Safety
660 Pennsylvania Ave, SE, #302 
Washington DC 20003
P: (202)547-9359 
F: (202)547-9429 
office@centerforfoodsafety.org

Docket No. MMS-2008-OMM-0012
AD30 - Alternative Energy and Alternate Uses of Existing Facilities on the OCS.

September 8, 2008

Please find attached a ocver letter and 3,648 public comments on Docket No. 
MMS-2008-OMM-0012 from Center for Food Safety members opposing rules in 
the AEAU on the OCS that would allow existing and new energy facilitiessuch 
as oil rigs and fish farmsto be used as parent sites for the development of 
polluting, industrial scale open ocean aquaculture facilities. 

The Center for Food Safety (CFS) is a national, non-profit, membership 
organization founded in 1997 to protect human health and the environment by 
curbing the use of harmful food production technologies and by promoting organic 
and other forms of sustainable agriculture. CFS represents approximately 67,000 
members.

Marine aquaculture could significantly harm the environment, human health, and 
the economies of local fishing communities. Offshore aquaculture in the United 
States could pose many of the same documented problems as large-scale net 
pen and cage aquaculture have created around the world, including, but not limited 
to pollution, escapement, and heavy use of wild fish in feed. In terms of pollution 
from aquaculture, fish feces and uneaten feed flow freely out of cages and into the 
environment. The escapement of salmon, halibut, and cod from ocean fish farms 
is another chronic problem. Furthermore, the species proposed for aquaculture in 
U.S. federal waters rely on high quantities of fishmeal and fish oil to meet their 
dietary needs. Finally, offshore aquaculture in the U.S. could cause negative 
socioeconomic impacts through environmental impacts and by competing with the 
existing seafood industry and communities.

Oil, gas or other energy facilities, whether currently in use or not, are not the 
appropriate location for offshore aquaculture operations. Had aquaculture facilities 
existed on oil rigs in the Gulf of Mexico during violent storms in recent years, 
there could have been massive releases of captive fish, feed, and other pollutants 
directly into ocean waters. Oil and gas rigs, or other energy facilities, active or 
decommissioned, should not be substituted for best available technology in open 
water aquaculture. MMS is not equipped to comprehensively manage a new 
industry, especially one Congress has thus far found to be a dubious endeavor. 

There are currently two bills pending in Congress that would set up a permitting 
regime for offshore aquaculture. Congress has thus far rejected these federal bills, 
in part because they did not have strong environmental and socioeconomic 
standards to guide the NOAA's decision-making. Without a bill with strong 
environmental and socioeconomic protections, there should be no offshore 
aquaculture facilities in U.S. federal waters. MMS should not use this rulemaking 
to bypass Congress.

MMS should not finalize a program such as this one, which fails to have strong 
standards limiting aquaculture facilities' impacts from fish waste and fish feed 
effluent, use of fishmeal and fish oil, escapes, and disease, all of which can harm 
the marine environment and the fishing communities that rely on them.

Thank you for taking our concerns under consideration,

Joseph Mendelson, III
Legal Director
Center for Food Safety
docketTitle: AD30 - Alternative Energy and Alternate Uses of Existing Facilities on the OCS.

title: Comment on FR Doc # E8-14911
commentText:
Addition to previous comment: 3 additional attachments of public comments from 
CFS members.

The Center for Food Safety
660 Pennsylvania Ave, SE, #302 
Washington DC 20003
P: (202)547-9359 
F: (202)547-9429 
office@centerforfoodsafety.org


Docket No. MMS-2008-OMM-0012
AD30 - Alternative Energy and Alternate Uses of Existing Facilities on the OCS.

September 8, 2008

Please find attached 3,648 public comments on Docket No. MMS-2008-OMM-
0012 from Center for Food Safety members opposing rules in the AEAU on the 
OCS that would allow existing and new energy facilitiessuch as oil rigs and fish 
farmsto be used as parent sites for the development of polluting, industrial scale 
open ocean aquaculture facilities. 

The Center for Food Safety (CFS) is a national, non-profit, membership 
organization founded in 1997 to protect human health and the environment by 
curbing the use of harmful food production technologies and by promoting organic 
and other forms of sustainable agriculture. CFS represents approximately 67,000 
members.

Marine aquaculture could significantly harm the environment, human health, and 
the economies of local fishing communities. Offshore aquaculture in the United 
States could pose many of the same documented problems as large-scale net 
pen and cage aquaculture have created around the world, including, but not limited 
to pollution, escapement, and heavy use of wild fish in feed. In terms of pollution 
from aquaculture, fish feces and uneaten feed flow freely out of cages and into the 
environment. The escapement of salmon, halibut, and cod from ocean fish farms 
is another chronic problem. Furthermore, the species proposed for aquaculture in 
U.S. federal waters rely on high quantities of fishmeal and fish oil to meet their 
dietary needs. Finally, offshore aquaculture in the U.S. could cause negative 
socioeconomic impacts through environmental impacts and by competing with the 
existing seafood industry and communities.

Oil, gas or other energy facilities, whether currently in use or not, are not the 
appropriate location for offshore aquaculture operations. Had aquaculture facilities 
existed on oil rigs in the Gulf of Mexico during violent storms in recent years, 
there could have been massive releases of captive fish, feed, and other pollutants 
directly into ocean waters. Oil and gas rigs, or other energy facilities, active or 
decommissioned, should not be substituted for best available technology in open 
water aquaculture. MMS is not equipped to comprehensively manage a new 
industry, especially one Congress has thus far found to be a dubious endeavor. 

There are currently two bills pending in Congress that would set up a permitting 
regime for offshore aquaculture. Congress has thus far rejected these federal bills, 
in part because they did not have strong environmental and socioeconomic 
standards to guide the NOAA's decision-making. Without a bill with strong 
environmental and socioeconomic protections, there should be no offshore 
aquaculture facilities in U.S. federal waters. MMS should not use this rulemaking 
to bypass Congress.

MMS should not finalize a program such as this one, which fails to have strong 
standards limiting aquaculture facilities' impacts from fish waste and fish feed 
effluent, use of fishmeal and fish oil, escapes, and disease, all of which can harm 
the marine environment and the fishing communities that rely on them.

Thank you for taking our concerns under consideration,

Joseph Mendelson, III
Legal Director
Center for Food Safety

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2018-15823
commentText:
The 6,208 members and supporters of Public Citizen whose names are gathered in the attached comment signed onto the following statement regarding the Department of Educations proposed rule ED-2018-OPE-0027: 
 
Dear Secretary DeVos: 
 
I oppose the U.S. Department of Educations attempt to allow for-profit colleges to receive federal student aid while forcing students to give up their right to take schools to court if they are cheated or wronged by the school. Forced arbitration provisions, together with class-action bans and gag clauses that prevent students from discussing arbitration proceedings with other students, have stopped students from accessing the court system to bring claims of wrongdoing against for-profit schools, including claims against the now-shuttered Corinthian Colleges and ITT Technical Institute. 
 
The vast majority of nonprofit and public institutions already refuse to include these shameful provisions in their contracts, but we need protections against unethical for-profit colleges. The department should not abandon a fair and strong rule that would protect students. 
 
We urge you to uphold students right to their day in court by prohibiting predatory, for-profit colleges from receiving federal funds if they force their students into biased arbitration rather than allowing them to bring claims in a neutral, open court. 
 
### 
See attached file(s)
docketTitle: Institutional Accountability

title: Mass comment campaign sponsoring by Earthworks (web)
commentText:
The attached 4,825 signatures are in favor of placing the Anaconda Copper Mine on the National Priorities List and have signed the following petition:

I support the placement of the Anaconda Copper Mine on the National Priorities List. 

The problems at the mine have been public since approximately 2003 and [supporters of NPL listing have] attended numerous meetings regarding the situation, both technical and community meetings. 

Though the EPA and Atlantic Richfield have completed several cleanup actions since that time under emergency regulations, it is clear that the most consequential remaining problem, contaminated groundwater from the mine proceeding towards a major aquifer, can only be addressed by placing the entire site on the National Priorities List. 

Some community members and elected officials from Yerington and Lyon County have proposed other alternatives for dealing with the issues and none were viable; in the meantime those living north of the mine, the most affected, have radionuclides at illegal levels in their well water and the contaminated groundwater plume continues north. 

Therefore I believe it is past time to "list" the mine. Please place the Anaconda Mine on the NPL list at the earliest opportunity, so remediation finally can be completed. 

Thank you for your work and dedication.
docketTitle: National Priorities List, Notice of Proposed Rulemaking - Anaconda Copper Mine

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Clean Water Action (web)
commentText:
Prevent Chemical Spills Into Water and Protect Drinking Water Sources  

Please find 4,756 comments from Clean Water Action members urging EPA to reconsider its decision not to develop safeguards to prevent spills of hazardous substances into rivers, lakes, streams, and other water bodies. The Clean Water Act directs EPA to set up this program. Existing laws and regulations do not ensure that drinking water sources and all of our water are protected. 

Facilities handling hazardous substances should develop comprehensive plans to prevent discharges into water. Our drinking water sources, rivers, lakes, and streams need protection from leaking storage tanks and other chemical spills that threaten our health, our water, and wildlife.

Thank you for your consideration.

Michael Kelly, Clean Water Action
docketTitle: Clean Water Act Hazardous Substances Discharge Prevention Rulemaking

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Clean Water Action (web)
commentText:
Dear Administrator Pruitt and Acting Assistant Secretary Fisher: 

Attached are more than 2,000 letters from Clean Water Action members across the country who strongly oppose your proposal to delay the implementation deadlines for the 2015 Clean Water Rule, which became effective on August 28, 2015 after being adopted with overwhelming public support. Instead the Clean Water Rule should be implemented as soon as EPA is authorized to do so.

Our nation has already lost over half our wetlands and continues to lose more at an alarming rate. For too long small and headwater streams, which make up the majority of stream miles in the U.S., have been at increased risk of pollution. The Clean Water Rule is needed to help protect these vital water resources that buffer communities from flood waters, filter pollutants, and feed the drinking water sources for over 1 and 3 people.

We urge EPA and the Army Corps of Engineers to immediately withdraw this reckless proposal to delay critical clean water protections and instead move swiftly to implement the 2015 Clean Water Rule as soon as they are authorized to do so.

Thank you for considering our concerns.
Bob Wendelgass
President & CEO
Clean Water Action
docketTitle: Definition of Waters of the United States  Addition of an Applicability Date to 2015 Clean Water Rule

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Sierra Club (web)
commentText:
Dear EPA Administrator Gina McCarthy and Assistant Administrator for the Office of Air and Radiation Janet McCabe: 

Recently, over 1300 Sierra Club members and supporters in Texas submitted personal comments to Administrator McCarty in support of EPA's proposed SO2 non-attainment designations near the three Luminant plants (Big Brown, Monticello, and Martin Lake). These comments are attached and incorporated herein for deposit into the regulations.gov docket and for consideration by you and your staff as part of this administrative record. 

It is imperative for the health of the communities near these plants that EPA finalize these non-attainment designations and take another important step toward cleaner air for all Texans. 

Thank you,

Chrissy Mann
Senior Campaign Representative
Sierra Club Beyond Coal Campaign
chrissy.mann@sierraclub.org
docketTitle: Air Quality Designations for the 2010 Sulfur Dioxide (SO2) Primary National Ambient Air Quality Standard (NAAQS) - Second Round

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by San Juan Citizens Alliance (SJCA) (Web)
commentText:
Name: Bonita Peak Mining District
Docket #: EPA-HQ-OLEM-2016-0152

San Juan Citizens Alliance (SJCA) has been working in Southwest Colorado since 1986. During that time we have established a record of success in building and implementing effective and collaborative campaigns to protect the health of our region's air, land and water. Our dedication to community-based advocacy and organizing has earned the organization respect and support in local communities. 

Today, we represent our nearly 700 dues-paying members and 4,000 supporters, as well as the 418 supporters who signed the petition included below, in urging you to officially add the Bonita Peak Mining District to the National Priorities List.

The names of all signatories, including their city and state of residence, are attached. This list represents the overwhelming desire of locals and non-locals alike to finally clean up the massive and destructive legacy hard rock mining has left in our watershed. 

Over the years, SJCA has participated in efforts to clean up the headwaters of the Animas River. It has become increasingly clear, however, that grassroots efforts are insufficient to solve this massive and complicated threat. The Gold King Mine blowout of August 2015 demonstrated the striking vulnerability of downstream communities. It made the stakes of inaction frighteningly clear. 

The Gold King Mine disaster and continued existence of un-remediated inactive and interconnected mines in the region continue to threaten the livelihoods, businesses and health of communities spanning multiple municipalities, counties, states and sovereign nations. Elected officials and communities have overwhelmingly spoken out in favor of adding the region to the National Priorities List. We join them. Clean water is a right, one that is currently threatened. Please help our community access the needed technical and financial resources to ensure our children know a cleaner watershed.



PETITION

Dear Administrator McCarthy, 

Following the Gold King Mine disaster of August, 2015, communities up and down the Animas River watershed banded together to address the longstanding pollution caused by acid mine drainage. After considerable deliberation, it has been nearly universally determined that listing the region on the Superfund National Priorities List (NPL) is a critical and necessary mechanism for finally realizing the clean up of more than a century of mining waste. 

In recent months, the towns of Silverton and Durango, Colorado, along with their respective counties, San Juan County and La Plata County, have found common ground in their support of a NPL listing. This shared commitment to securing a place on the NPL is further strengthened by the support of the Navajo Nation, Senator Bennet of Colorado, Senators Udall and Heinrich of New Mexico and Representative Lujn of New Mexico. 

As community members, we whole-heartedly support the Environmental Protection Agency listing the Bonita Peak Mining District on the National Priorities List, making the area eligible for long-term clean up through the Superfund program. With your assistance, we will finally begin to reclaim the health of our beloved Animas and San Juan Rivers
docketTitle: National Priorities List, Notice of Proposed Rulemaking: Bonita Peak Mining District

title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Conservation Colorado (Web)
commentText:
Concerning the Bonita Peak Mining District, San Juan County, CO	EPA-HQ-OLEM-2016-0152:

We encourage the Environmental Protection Agency to add the Bonita Peak Mining District to the Superfund National Priorities List. This area includes the Gold King mine, which spilled over 3 million gallons of toxic sludge into the Animas River in August of 2015. Ten months after this disastrous mine spill, leakage continues to contaminate the Animas River downstream. Residents of nearby communities in Southwest Colorado will continue to be at risk without the superfund designation and following cleanup so I urge the EPA to take action.

Thank you.
docketTitle: National Priorities List, Notice of Proposed Rulemaking: Bonita Peak Mining District

title: MN Haze SIP: National Parks Conservation Association letter campaign (894 similar/duplicate comments)
commentText:
I'm writing to urge you to work with Minnesota and Federal Land Managers to adopt an 
adequate haze plan for Minnesota that includes specific requirements to reduce air pollution 
at the coal plants and taconite facilities that are polluting the region's treasured landscapes.

As a national park visitor and advocate for the parks, I value the beauty of Voyageurs and Isle 
Royale National Parks. An adequate haze plan would clean up the air in these parks and 
other wilderness areas, which are affected by pollution from power plants and taconite 
facilities.

As currently written, the Minnesota haze plan fails to require some of the most egregious air 
polluters in the state--coal and taconite plants--to use the most effective emissions control 
technologies to protect and restore air quality to our region's wild lands. The Minnesota plan 
lets polluters rely on alternative measures that will not clean up enough pollution to protect 
our national parks. Instead of exempting Minnesota polluters from the most effective 
emissions control technologies, EPA must require appropriate emission reduction from 
Minnesota polluters.

Pollution from coal-fired power plants and taconite facilities have hurt our national parks and 
wilderness areas for too long. EPA cannot let Minnesota polluters escape pollution controls; 
it must require that the air in our parks, and throughout the region, be cleaned up for present 
and future generations.

Thank you for considering my comments.
docketTitle: Minnesota Regional Haze SIP

title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Rogue Riverkeeper
commentText:
Dear EPA,

Please find the two attached PDF comments for Docket ID: EPA-HQ-OW-2012-0195 (Notice of Intent to revise stormwater regulations for logging roads).

The simple message is this:

"We value clean water and wild fish. Industrial logging roads are a leading cause of sediment pollution and we believe it is time for the logging industry to do its fair share to protect water quality. We oppose efforts to exempt the timber industry and logging roads from the Clean Water Act. Please ensure that industrial logging road pollution remains regulated under the Clean Water Acts permit program."

To excerpt one of the personalized comments:

"The vast majority of the drainage ditches for logging roads clearly meet the definition of a "point source" that has been in the CWA since its creation in 1972. For decades, EPA has ignored this fact, and the result is continued degredation of thousands of miles of streams and lakes nationwide. The forest industry has had a 40 year reprieve from being held accountable under the CWA, during which they could have proven that voluntary measures (self-policing) would work. The facts prove otherwise." - Bill Painter, Mint Spring, Virginia

Please confirm receipt. Thank you.

For a future with wild salmon in Pacific Northwest streams,

Lesley Adams.

--
Lesley Adams, Program Director
Rogue Riverkeeper
PO Box 102
Ashland, Oregon 97520
541.488.9831
www.rogueriverkeeper.org
docketTitle: Stormwater Discharges from Forest Roads

title: Mass Comment Campaign, Sponsor Unknown entitled " I am concerned about the sweeping changes that EPA has proposed in its Certification of Pesticide Applicators Rule" (251 comments)
commentText:
As a farmer, rancher, and certified pesticide applicator in Texas, I am concerned about the sweeping changes that EPA has proposed in its Certification of Pesticide Applicators Rule.
Why are these changes needed?  The rulemaking cites a number of reports and studies; however, none link pesticide-related illnesses to certified applicator competency.  Why does EPA believe that more ridged federal standards are needed to reduce the number of pesticide-related illnesses when there is no established connection between the two?

Texas, like many other states, has had an effective program in place for many years.  It does not need to be changed.

The 3-year certification length proposed in the rule is arbitrary.  There is no reason to limit the length of certification particularly if a state requires applicators to complete periodic CEUs trainings to maintain the certification.  In Texas, private applicators renew their license every 5 years and commercial applicators renew their licenses annually.  This system works well.

The amount of training proposed solely for Core Competency (6 CEUs per 3 years) is excessive.  Repeated training on the same core subject matter would quickly become repetitive and redundant.  

The method-specific competency standards proposed are overly burdensome.  EPA should consider removing all method-specific categories for private applicators. Re-certification requirements for commercial applicators should be reduced as well. Many commercial applicators would need certification in 6 to 8 separate method-specific categories.  Under the proposed rule, that would mean 42 to 54 CEUs every 3 years when Core Competency requirements are included.  This is excessive.

Proposed changes to the minimum age requirement is also a concern.  To be consistent with the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), EPA should adopt a minimum age of 16 (rather than 18) for both certified and non-certified pesticide applicators working on farms or in the agricultural sector.  EPA should observe similar exemptions offered to family members under the FLSA.

Despite perceived shortcomings with the current pesticide applicators rule, existing state programs are working well and do not need to be changed.

I appreciate the opportunity to comment on this proposed rule.
docketTitle: Certification of Pesticide Applicators Rule Revision (40 CFR 171)

title: Form Letter Comment from Cornucopia Institute [multiple signatures=215]
commentText:
215 signatures for the following petititon:

To the FDA:

Please do not approve genetically engineered salmon. The health risks of consuming salmon that has been genetically altered to produce growth hormones at all times are unknown. Your claim that genetically engineered salmon is safe to eat is based on an assumption, not on rigorous scientific investigation.

The accidental release of transgenic salmon could be devastating to marine ecosystems and wild salmon populations. It is nave to assume that no transgenic fish will escape into the wild. The National Academy of Sciences wrote that release of transgenic fish is of immediate concern and might pose environmental hazards. These impacts would likely be irreversible.

I urge you to put human health, the environment, and the economic well-being of coastal fishing communities first. The FDA should rely on independent and credible science, not on science supplied by the corporation that stands to profit from your approval.

Please delay approval of genetically engineered salmon until the results of independent scientific studies show that genetically engineered fish is safe to eat and harmless to the environment.

Please also require the labeling of GE foods, to allow consumers to make an informed choice.

Sincerely,
docketTitle: Draft Environmental Assessment and Preliminary Finding of No Significant Impact For a Genetically Engineered Atlantic Salmon; Availability

title: This is a mass letter campaign.  The comments received under this campaign are identical or nearly identical in content and format. A sample PDF has been provided for review.  A total of 762 comments have been received to date.
commentText:
The Honorable David Michaels, Ph.D., MPH 
Assistant Secretary 
Occupational Safety and Health Administration 
U.S. Department of Labor 
200 Constitution Avenue, N.W. 
Washington, D.C. 20210

Re: Docket ID OSHA- 2010-0034, Occupational Exposure to Respirable Crystalline Silica  

Dear Assistant Secretary Michaels:  

As an employer in the construction industry, I am writing in response to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) above-referenced notice of proposed rulemaking on occupational exposure to respirable crystalline silica, which was published in the Federal Register on September 12, 2013, at 78 Fed. Reg. 56274. The proposed rule drastically lowers the Permissible Exposure Limit (PEL) for crystalline silica and requires contractors to implement engineering controls and follow several "ancillary" provisions, such as exposure monitoring, medical surveillance and the establishment of regulated areas.  

As a construction employer, I believe exceptional jobsite safety and health practices are inherently good for business. However, the proposed rule is potentially the most far-reaching regulatory initiative proposed by OSHA for the construction industry.  Silica is found in numerous building materials and can easily be disturbed by a number of job tasks found on the worksite. The proposed rule uses an overly complicated structure to control crystalline silica in a construction environment. OSHA must understand that this material cannot be separated out of daily tasks or avoided on the worksite. 

The proposed rule drastically lowers the PEL to 50 ?g/m3, with an action level of 25 ?g/m3. It is important to note that construction previously had a PEL of 250 ?g/m3, versus the general industry PEL of 100 ?g/m3. OSHA states the reason for lowering the PELs is the current levels result in significant risk of material health impairment among exposed workers. However, recent studies show there is a significant downward trend of incidences of silicosis under the current PEL levels.  The proposed PEL and action level are simply not feasible for the construction industry to attain in most operations most of the time. The control measures that OSHA relies on under its own analysis do not reliably reduce silica exposures in construction to those levels and OSHA does not account for the variety of construction environments that exist throughout the United States.

OSHA proposed Table 1 as a means of compliance with the exposure monitoring and methods of compliance provisions for the construction industry. While I appreciate that OSHA attempted to recognize the unique nature of construction through its proposed Table 1, it ultimately falls short and would be unworkable for me to implement as an employer. One of the main reasons Table 1 is ineffective can be found in the "Engineering and work practice control methods" section of the table, which states that there be "no visible dust" emitted from a process after the introduction of the engineering control methods. Even through the use of wet methods or engineering controls, rarely-if ever-will there be no visible dust emitted from silica generated activities. Therefore, Table 1 as written would not be a viable path for reaching compliance. 

OSHA has not shown that the proposed rule is technologically or economically feasible for the construction industry. Many of the provisions in the rule making simply will not work in the "real world" of construction. OSHA should withdraw its burdensome proposal until it can demonstrate a rule making of this kind is necessary and workable. The unintended consequences of this sort of extreme regulation, is that it can lead to greater unemployment in an industry that has already suffered considerably in the past few years. Therefore, I encourage OSHA to work with the construction industry to ensure that the actions taken are sober, reasonable and can achieve positive results without jeopardizing the employment opportunities for a large section of the American workforce.

Thank you for the opportunity to submit comments on this matter.
docketTitle: Occupational Exposure to Crystalline Silica
